webTitle: Homes alone won't make us world beaters

fields.headline: Homes alone won't make us world beaters
fields.trailText: Swish, sleek and crazily exorbitant new stadiums are coming out of our ears. Why and what for?
fields.body:
The latest spin-docs' wheeze, apparently, is that Mr Tony's Dome, obsolete at this year's end, should be the glistening catalyst and centrepiece for the British bid for the Olympics of 2008, 2012, whenever. Have we gone completely potty?

Swish, sleek and crazily exorbitant new stadiums are coming out of our ears. Why and what for?

Ignoring all the Justice Taylor-inspired post-Hillsborough rebuilding - in the five years from 1990 an astonishing 164 new Football League all-seat grandstands were erected - consider these even more grandiose actual or planned sporting amphitheatres:

Cardiff's overpowering millennium precipice; the still raged-over Himalayan new Wembley; Manchester's mecca for the Commonwealth Games; soaring Twickenham; monumental Murrayfield; Huddersfield's McAlpine; Sheffield's millstone; a gleaming, still unpaid-for, Hampden Park to go with Glasgow's two other vast arenas; Leicester's on-off new World Cup stadium; the proposed privately developed 80,000-seater for Heathrow...

And a few more as well, not forgetting the Fulham pharaoh Fayed's pledge to transform his villagey Cottage into a towering Thameside mansion.

Such a plethora of peoples' palaces is becoming utterly absurd. What are we going to do with them all? (Are there really that many pop concerts to go round?) The direst of warnings was sounded a couple of months ago when the Scottish Rugby Union, unable to fill its monstrous Murrayfield white-elephant for a Scotland World Cup match against the world champions South Africa last autumn, had to pipe-up at full volume an ersatz tape of canned applause so as to provide an "atmosphere" of a cheering full house.

Then there is David Hemery, the former Olympic athlete, demanding - once his sport had been ditched from Wembley's modified proposals - that athletics should have built for itself and its sole use a bespoke new Olympic arena.

What, taxpayers' millions for his discredited pastime? Sorry, Dave, we'll have to think about that one. Anyway, even if in the next 20 years Britain were to win the bids to stage all three of the Olympics, the World Championships and European Championships, that would be just the three times in 20 years that athletics in this country could remotely fill even a reasonably sized stadium.

What is more, the two Mr Tonys' World Cup bid for soccer seems already to be decaying before our very eyes. Like his Domist obsession, a World Cup was Blair's beloved bright-eyed baby in the first place. Watch him soon distance himself from it and angle all the poisoned arrows of blame towards poor old Banks.

How all Britain's bidding rivals must have gloated with glee as they read transcripts of the Westminster select committee debates of Tuesday - shambles upon shaming shambles, hatreds upon personal hatreds, with an even more gloriously bitter and bitchy sequel promised for next Thursday. Meanwhile Fifa is all ears.

And that little soap opera is already being smokescreened by worrying government refusals to publish in full the financial accounts so far of the £10m handed over by the likes of the national lottery to fund the 2006 World Cup bid. What exactly has been spent on the worldwide lobbying and what precise form has the persuading taken?

Simple questions. Simple answers. So why the coyness? The International Olympic Committee, meanwhile, has become embroiled in controversy over such worldwide lobbying, in particular, for the 2002 Winter Games.

Yesterday Juan Antonio Samaranach, the IOC president, said he will return to the United States in two weeks to answer questions from federal authorities investigating the Salt Lake City bid scandal.

The IOC announced last month that Samaranch had agreed to submit to a voluntary interview with Justice Department and FBI investigators probing the more than £1m in improper payments, gifts and other inducements offered to IOC members during Salt Lake's winning bid for the 2002 Games.

Samaranch has not been served with a subpoena and the IOC says he is not a target of the investigation but the whole scandal has further undermined the credibility of the organisation and the perils of lobbying.

In Britain, in the mean-time, we remain stadium bonkers. When the Empire Exhibition closed in 1925, Wembley was auctioned.

Not a bid was offered and these very pages described "a vast white elephant, a rotting sepulchre of hopes and the grave of fortunes".

Those few words might yet have been a 75-year long prophecy.

fields.headline: Wembley crackdown on pirate hospitality
fields.trailText: Wembley is cracking down on pirate hospitality after discovering that 3,500 tickets for last November's Euro 2000 play-off between England and Scotland were illegally sold off by rogue operators in package deals for around £1.5m.
fields.body:
Wembley is cracking down on pirate hospitality after discovering that 3,500 tickets for last November's Euro 2000 play-off between England and Scotland were illegally sold off by rogue operators in package deals for around £1.5m.

The deals often included illicit parking and off-site food and drink prepared in anything from hotels to car parks. "What we found was extraordinary," said Wembley's safety officer Noel Jeffs.

"Venues without safety licences for commercial activities; unlicensed venues selling alcohol; false promises made about hospitality quality and ticket [seat] locality; meals cooked in transit vans in car parks and prices ranging from £299 per head up to £1,015 for virtually the same thing."

Undercover purchases by stadium officials and evidence gathered on match-day revealed the extent of the abuse. Deals were readily available by mail-order, on the internet and in newspapers and magazines.

Similar deals are already on offer for England's game against Argentina on February 23. Officials have warned that spot-checks will be carried out and fans with illegally transferred tickets may be refused entry.

They also insist that anyone advertising or promoting unauthorised packages could be effectively closed down and have ticket stocks confiscated. Thirty three pirate operations were discovered in November.

"Unsuspecting hospitality purchasers could have found themselves in lowest price seats, some obscured by pillars," Jeffs added. "Especially alarming was the fact that apparently no attempt had been made to segregate nationalities."

The Keith Prowse company offered the only official packages; although general ticket sales were limited to four per person, and group bookings were accepted only from schools, thousands got into the wrong hands.

Wembley is working with the Football Association, the Metropolitan police and trading standards officers to try to solve the problem. It is also talking with the FA about expanding the official hospitality market, which at present offers around 1,750 tickets as part of package deals.

fields.headline: Keegan calls for pay curb
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan has told Premiership players that, if they do not like playing so many games each season, they should accept less money.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan has told Premiership players that, if they do not like playing so many games each season, they should accept less money.

Concern about the number of matches top players face has been growing. But the England coach said that in his final season as a Liverpool player some team-mates played up to 70 games "and the only time we got a rest was when we broke our legs".

He added: "Players nowadays earn more in a season than I did in my entire career. Many may complain about their workload but there is a simple answer. If they want to play fewer matches, pay them less money. If you play 10% fewer games, you will get 10% less."

Keegan was also critical of the growing number of foreigners in the Premiership, which cuts down his own choice. "When I watch club games I'll sometimes see only four or five Englishmen on the pitch," he said. "There needs to be a compromise. Also I'm not convinced that English fans want to see 11 foreigners playing for Chelsea or Arsenal."

As for this summer's European Championship, Keegan claimed that his team can prosper. "I am convinced that England can win Euro 2000," he said. "Forget the way in which we got through. You don't get given a one-goal start simply because you qualified well."

As for the games with Germany - in Euro 2000 and the qualifiers for the 2002 World Cup - he added: "If we have an advantage over Germany, it is that we have a good number of talented youngsters. The Germans have been disappointed with their Under-21 side, which has failed to qualify for Euro 2000 and the Olympics."

Keegan will be in Frankfurt today with a Football Association delegation seeking to agree dates for the World Cup qualifying matches against the Germans, Finland, Greece and Albania. Once the schedule is drawn up, the coach and the FA will have to decide where to play the home matches as Wembley will be unavailable due to rebuilding work.

"I think the four options for us, bearing in mind the fact that we have been to Sunderland, are Newcastle, Liverpool, Manchester United and Aston Villa, although Leeds would also come into it," he added.

 Barcelona have hinted that they may listen to offers for Rivaldo, their £37m-rated European player of the year.

The club president Josep Luis Nunez, referring to a pre-Christmas spat between the Brazilian and the coach Louis van Gaal, said: "What Barcelona can't do is have players who are unhappy. When a player says he isn't happy at the club, the best thing is to help him find another one."

fields.headline: Backing for Saint Jones
fields.trailText: For Middlesbrough earlier this week, read Southampton yesterday. Following Bryan Robson's lead, Dave Jones has brushed aside calls for his resignation and received a vote of confidence from his chairman.
fields.body:
For Middlesbrough earlier this week, read Southampton yesterday. Following Bryan Robson's lead, Dave Jones has brushed aside calls for his resignation and received a vote of confidence from his chairman.

The pressure on Jones to quit was intensified by Sunday's 5-0 defeat at Newcastle which left Southampton with two wins from 16 league matches. Ninth in September, they have plummeted to fourth from bottom and are out of both cups.

Jones, though, remains defiant. "I've never rolled over and given up in my life and I'm not about to start now," he said. "Everyone is low at the moment after what happened to us last weekend and the team coach was very quiet on the way back from Newcastle.

"But we are spending this week regrouping, making sure heads don't drop."

Southampton supporters have been broadly supportive of Jones, who is awaiting a date for trial on child abuse charges relating to his days as a social worker on Merseyside. But some fans have been angered by a perceived lack of cover for injuries at centre-back and fear the club are in free fall.

"People are now talking about it being a crisis and relegation looming," Jones said. "The only people not talking about those things are us.

"We will prove everyone wrong, as we did last year and this club has done many times before." A year ago Southampton were second from bottom.

Jones can at least count on the moral and financial support of his chairman Rupert Lowe as he prepares for critical games at home to Everton and West Ham and away to Sheffield Wednesday.

"I'm sure Dave can turn things around," Lowe said. "We have always said, if the manager asks for money for a player he feels will strengthen the team, we will do all we can.

"We've been busy finalising the plans for a new stadium which is my priority at the moment and, if Dave asked me to sign a cheque for £25m, there's obviously no way I could do it. But we have provided cash this season for transfers and we will continue to do so where necessary."

fields.headline: Leboeuf rises to Bates
fields.standfirst: Vialli's players suffer the chairman's tongue lashing
fields.trailText: Last night's two managers, old friends from their days at Juventus, went out to a restaurant together after this tie. However, Gianluca Vialli will not need David Platt to tell him that Chelsea made a right meal of beating First Division Nottingham Forest.
fields.body:
Last night's two managers, old friends from their days at Juventus, went out to a restaurant together after this tie. However, Gianluca Vialli will not need David Platt to tell him that Chelsea made a right meal of beating First Division Nottingham Forest.

A second goal five minutes from time, scored by Dennis Wise's head, could not mask the reality of another unconvincing exhibition from the Premiership side.

Chelsea had gone into the game with much to prove, not least to their chairman. In his programme notes Ken Bates, with typical forthrightness, described the team's latest disappointing Premiership performance at home to Leicester on Saturday as "'the worst display I have seen from a Chelsea team for many a year".

He didn't blame Vialli but the team - "It doesn't matter how much talent a player has if he doesn't use it."

In that context, this match offered a timely test of the application and commitment of Chelsea's highly paid squad.

Forest have fallen on hard times since they contested a Uefa Cup quarter-final just four years ago, with the club's status eroded by financial problems and a revolving door in the manager's office.

The club that Brian Clough built are currently fighting against relegation from the First Division and came into this tie with the worst away record of the 92 clubs. At Grimsby on Saturday, a game which saw two Forest players sent off and the assistant manager Dennis Booth escorted from the ground for insulting a policeman, the team notched up their seventh away defeat in a row.

But although David Platt is finding life hard in his first stint as an English club manager, he knew that a good performance against a team of Chelsea's calibre would do wonders for his players' brittle confidence.

And in fact Forest began promisingly. On 17 minutes they made a four-on-two break from their own area which would have threatened more but for an awful pass from the captain Riccardo Scimeca on which the move broke down.

Slowly, however, the home side's class began to tell. Dave Beasant saved well from Gianfranco Zola's free-kick, then smothered bravely at the feet of Tore Andre Flo, both strikers playing in the absence of the ineligible George Weah.

But then the former Chelsea goal keeper's goal lived a charmed life. On 29 minutes the forest defender Matthieu Louis-Jean acrobatically hooked the ball of the line after Dan Petrescu's one-two with Gustavo Poyet had allowed the Romanian to chip the keeper.

Seconds later Frank Lambourde cut the ball back from the by-line but Zola directed an inviting shot wide from 12 yards. Two minutes after that scare, Beasant could only watch as Jon Harley's 20-yard volley thundered off the bar.

Despite those close shaves, Chelsea went in at half-time reflecting on another lacklustre domestic performance lacking cohesion and conviction as so many have this season.

It was not long into the new half, however, before Forest were again living on their nerves. Zola fired just wide and Didier Deschamps then set up Poyet on the left of the area for a goal-bound shot which was deflected just past the post.

But eventually Forest had to buckle and on 57 minutes Chelsea took the lead after the 18-year-old David Prutton hand-balled about 20 yards out on the left. Zola fired in a curving free-kick to the near post where Frank Leboeuf, escaping any marker, rose high and, using the pace of the ball, headed it backwards past Beasant.

Forest immediately sent on a second striker, Marlon Harewood, and within seconds of ar riving he nearly scored an unlikely equaliser. Holding off John Terry, he unleashed a close-range shot which Ed de Goey did well to block. It was just a little reminder that Chelsea were not home and dry.

fields.headline: Wasim loses way after milestone
fields.trailText: Wasim Akram became the first bowler to take 400 wickets in one-day internationals in Sydney yesterday but he could not stop his Pakistan side going down heavily to Australia.
fields.body:
Wasim Akram became the first bowler to take 400 wickets in one-day internationals in Sydney yesterday but he could not stop his Pakistan side going down heavily to Australia.

Chasing Australia's 286 in the day-night match, Pakistan made a flying start to reach 100 in 12.1 overs for the loss of only two wickets. But they subsided to 205 all out in the 46th over after Stuart MacGill engineered a middle-order slump on his way to taking four for 19 in 10 overs.

"We had a perfect start for a one-day cricket chase of 287 but again, if you lose wickets, it doesn't matter how good a start you have," Wasim said, adding that Pakistan had not bowled well and their fielding was pathetic.

Wasim, the Pakistan captain, reached the 400-wicket landmark with his third wicket of the Australian innings. He ended with three for 40 off nine overs.

"I am quite honoured that I have got 400 wickets for Pakistan but it would have been much better if we had won today," he said.

Chasing the big Australian total - the third highest in one-day cricket at the Sydney Cricket Ground - Pakistan attacked from the outset, smashing 33 runs off Glenn McGrath's first two overs and reaching 50 in the sixth over.

Ijaz Ahmed fell for 23, off only 11 balls, but Saeed Anwar and Abdur Razzaq continued to plunder the Australian attack. Razzaq smashed five consecutive fours off McGrath's fifth over, forcing Australia's premier paceman out of the attack.

McGrath had no wicket for 62 after his first spell - in stark contrast to last Friday against India on the same ground when he bowled 10 overs for eight runs and four wickets.

fields.headline: Swann asked to hang around
fields.trailText: Graeme Swann, one of the Test selectors' more imaginative picks last autumn, was due to arrive back in England today but instead will be staying out here in the South African sun.
fields.body:
Graeme Swann, one of the Test selectors' more imaginative picks last autumn, was due to arrive back in England today but instead will be staying out here in the South African sun.

Swann has been placed on standby for the one-day series against South Africa and Zimbabwe, as there is a fitness worry about Ashley Giles, and will remain with the squad until the game against Zimbabwe on January 30, when a final decision will be made.

"Swann will stay on until Kimberley," said England's coach Duncan Fletcher. "We need some back-up and it will give us a chance to have a look at him again."

Giles has been suffering back spasms and missed Tuesday's one-day warm-up in Bloemfontein. Yesterday he was ordered to rest and swim but it was a pained and stiff cricketer who eased himself into the hotel pool yesterday afternoon.

The talented Northamptonshire all-rounder has somehow maintained his smiling disposition, despite not getting into the Test team who lost 2-1 to South Africa. He played only two first-class games which produced five wickets for 367 and 45 runs. He also played in three meaningless one-day fixtures.

As the fifth Test drew to its dramatic close on Tuesday, there was only anticlimax for Swann. He had been overlooked for the one-day squad and was fined £250 for missing the team bus to Centurion on Friday, when he was on 12th-man duty. He was in despair.

The 20-year-old, an off spinner who gives the ball a fair rip, was unlucky not to be drafted into the one-day party when Andy Flintoff was injured, even though it would not have represented replacing like with like.

All-rounders and spinners were at the forefront of Fletcher's mind yesterday, as he reflected on his first series in charge.

"We have got to develop some more good all-rounders. In Flintoff, to a degree, we have done that. With him, Michael Vaughan and Chris Silverwood we have seen three good young cricketers come through. But we really need a good wrist-spinner. It gives you another option."

Today England play their final one-day warm-up match against North West at Potchesfstrom. It is understood that the selectors have discussed keeping wicket with Mark Alleyne for greater balance.

webTitle: Rousing finale to an old refrain

fields.headline: Rousing finale to an old refrain
fields.standfirst: England's promise is hampered by a lack of Test quality bowlers
fields.trailText: "Positive reinforcement," said the under-performing England batsman Chris Adams on the eve of the final Test, "is infinitely preferable to negative enforcement." So, at the end of yet another lost series, against a side with no huge superiority in individual talent but with immense depth, it is the positive aspects that Nasser Hussain and Duncan Fletcher will want to carry home once the one-day hoopla is done.
fields.body:
"Positive reinforcement," said the under-performing England batsman Chris Adams on the eve of the final Test, "is infinitely preferable to negative enforcement." So, at the end of yet another lost series, against a side with no huge superiority in individual talent but with immense depth, it is the positive aspects that Nasser Hussain and Duncan Fletcher will want to carry home once the one-day hoopla is done.

The unusual but eminently praiseworthy events of Tuesday's final day provided a rousing finale to the series and, if Hansie Cronje is a Calvinist at heart, then he was the court jester here and deserves much credit for his initiative. It was a day no less hard fought than any other in the series, with both sides committed to win. At no time did it smack of one-day cricket and it was a creditable victory for England. They will be under no illusions that this in any way compensates for the earlier deficiencies but, if the win itself has little meaning, then the manner in which England went about the task was terrific.

In fact, they competed for most of the series until finally in Cape Town they cracked as suddenly and emphatically as a yacht's mast in an Atlantic gale. After the first Test at the Wanderers, which remains an aberration in which the first few overs pretty much settled the series before it was out of nappies, England suffered in Port Elizabeth, from duff umpiring and Lance Klusener, and still came up smiling, ruled the roost in Durban until Gary Kirsten got his head down, and did so for the first two sessions at Newlands as well. It was as if two cars had been racing neck and neck, however, but the English one had the foot to the boards while the South African model had another gear yet unused.

On balance South Africa deserved their win and 2-1 was probably the right result: 3-0, as might have been the case, would have been a travesty, so perhaps Cronje, subconsciously, might have been redressing the balance when he suggested the collusion.

England, as Hussain keeps stressing, came to South Africa to win the series but also to find out about players, to begin yet again the exacting process of spotting talent, identifying temperament and providing as easy an induction into Test cricket as the flabby, pampered county circuit will allow.

There was a new administration in Hussain and Fletcher, who had never met before the end of last season, and a world away from the dedicated, passionate, patriotic but often frenetic regime of David Lloyd and the captains with whom he worked. Hussain has shown himself to be masterly already, a clever fellow, highly respected even by those within and without the team who had doubts about his capacity to handle not success but failure, particularly on a personal level.

His response has been to bat with a dedication that may have surprised even him - more than 1,000 minutes at the crease, spanning three innings, before he was dismissed has never been surpassed in Test cricket - to captain sensibly, to goad, cajole and to conduct realistic, honest, articulate and interesting press conferences.

It has to be a further indictment of the county system that it failed to single out his management skills sufficiently at an earlier stage.

Fletcher has been understated. He is wary of the limelight, without shying away. When he speaks, it is generally with purpose, although his criticism of the dreadful England bowling on the first day at Centurion was so dilute it almost amounted to a defence. He is keen to be seen as back- up to the captain, who has seized the role with relish.

But the "new faces" policy was only a partial success. We are unlikely to see Adams in a Test again, for example, nor Gavin Hamilton nor even Darren Maddy. Mark Butcher has been a consistent failure since his hundred in Brisbane more than a year ago with a top score since then of 48 (even Andy Caddick can match that) and a career average of below 25 over 26 Tests is not acceptable. Mark Ramprakash could well be Mike Atherton's partner there next summer.

But against that Michael Vaughan has shown temperament, technique and, on Tuesday, attacking skills as well; Andy Flintoff, provided he remains fit and dedicated to his career, looks the closest yet to a proper all-rounder, and Chris Silverwood is quick at times which on flat pitches can make up to some extent for modest skills.

Overall, though, the bowling has been variable and on the flat pitches they missed Dean Headley. The development of bowlers is expected to form a key part of the central contracts issue but there will be some hard thinking to be done to find the right ones.

fields.headline: Lords back trial by jury
fields.trailText: The government suffered its first defeat at the hands of the partially-reformed House of Lords tonight, as peers wrecked home secretary Jack Straw's controversial plans to restrict the right to trial by jury.
fields.body:
The government suffered its first defeat at the hands of the partially-reformed House of Lords tonight, as peers wrecked home secretary Jack Straw's controversial plans to restrict the right to trial by jury.

Tory and Liberal Democrat peers, supported by retired law lords and Labour rebels, voted by 222 to 126, a majority of 96, to pass amendments to the criminal justice (mode of trial) bill and restore the right of the accused to choose jury trial

Lords Leader Baroness Jay said passing the amendment had "effectively killed the bill".

"As amended it no longer represents government policy," she said

"We will not proceed with this bill and will be introducing a no 2 bill in the Commons in the present session."

Despite the eviction of most of the hereditaries in November, the political balance of the house is still weighted against the present government - 232 Tories and 54 Liberal Democrats against 181 Labour peers, with 161 crossbenchers and seven non-aligned peers - so the success of the committee stage amendment is not unexpected.

Nevertheless the margin of defeat represents an embarrassment for the government, as the bill's opponents included a large number of Labour peers .

The bill proposed to restrict the right to jury trial in so-called "either-way" cases - such as theft, burglary and handling - but with the right to appeal against a magistrates' court's decision to try the case.

The government argues that this will save an estimated £105 million a year, partly in reduced prison sentences, and lessen the trauma for victims who have to wait longer for crown court jury trials than for JP hearings.

The bill's critics argue that the change would fail to make the predicted savings, would be perceived as disadvantaging people from ethnic minorities, and would erode a judicial tradition dating from Magna Carta.

In a heated Lords debate, Liberal Democrat Lord Dholakia said a "crucial" argument against the proposals was the effect on black and Asian defendants, particularly when Government research on the issue was so "inadequate".

"At a time when the criminal justice system needs to take every step it can to repair the confidence of racial minorities abolishing the right to elect jury trial is a step in precisely the opposite direction.

Labour peer Baroness Kennedy said the bill's aims - to increase court efficiency and crack down on abusers - were laudable but admitted that she could not support it.

"The reason I oppose this bill and the reason I have supported this amendment, which I did with some pain in my heart, is because I think it is an issue of principle.

"I believe that the impact of this bill will be socially divisive and discriminatory ... and I think it does remove an important citizen's right."

At the opening of the debate, Tory home affairs spokesman Lord Cope of Berkeley, asserted the peer's right to table an amendment.

"Some people seem to think that we, the House of Lords, should not pass this amendment because it is 'too important a matter'," he said

"We are told we should stand back, hold our noses, and leave the decision to the House of Commons, that the elected house with its large government majority, fiercely controlled, should alone decide.

"But no one in the Commons was elected on the basis of the position in this bill. It formed no part of the Labour manifest. Indeed the Labour party were at that stage very strongly against the whole idea.

"If it came into any elector's consideration at the last election, Labour were elected to oppose this bill."

He argued that the partly reformed House of Lords, comprising appointed peers and elected hereditaries, had the authority to vote down the bill.

Lord Cope, a life peer and former MP, added: "Perhaps in due course there will be a different second chamber in the United Kingdom. Meanwhile we must do our duty for which we were selected, and each of us must decide the issue and vote accordingly."

fields.headline: Hollywood star Hedy Lamarr dies
fields.trailText: Hedy Lamarr, the movie star who blended her billing as the most beautiful woman in the world with disastrous career choices and an unlikely talent as an inventor, died last night at the age of 86.
fields.body:
Hedy Lamarr, the movie star who blended her billing as the most beautiful woman in the world with disastrous career choices and an unlikely talent as an inventor, died last night at the age of 86.

In a poignant postscript to a life that helped to introduce nudity to the movies, police said they were treating the case of the actress who was married and divorced six times as an unattended death.

Lamarr was born Hedwig Eva Maria Kiesler in Vienna, the daughter of a banker. She appeared in a series of Austro-German films from 1930 but it was not until three years later that the world started to pay attention with the release of Gustav Machaty's erotic drama Ecstasy, in which she was naked for a 10-minute sequence.

Her first Hollywood movie, Algiers, directed by John Cromwell, was a success. But, usually typecast as a woman of mystery, her career faltered more often than it soared. She did not help her case by turning down the role of Ilsa in 1943's Casablanca, a part that went to Ingrid Bergman.

When she did have a hit, such as Samson and Delilah in 1949, there were problems with her poor English and inability to show emotion.

But it is safe to suppose she is the only screen siren to receive a patent for her part in developing a technique allowing control of torpedoes over long distances without detection.

fields.headline: Lords reform
fields.standfirst: The government's reform of the Lords heralds the end of constitutionally-enshrined aristocratic government in Britain. But how far will Tony Blair go? As Lord Wakeham's commission publishes its reform proposals, Patrick Barkham examines the key issues
fields.trailText: The issue explained
fields.body:
What is the House of Lords?

The House of Lords is one part of the ancient triumvirate in the British constitution, which also includes the monarchy and the Commons. Representing the interests of the aristocracy, the lords historically combined with the "commoners" to challenge and check the power of kings.

These days, the Lords is the second legislative chamber in parliament, responsible for amending and scrutinising the activities of the government-dominated Commons. Other democratic countries have a similar institution, often known as an upper chamber or senate.

Who are the members of the House of Lords?

Where the Lords differs from other upper chambers is the presence of hereditary peers - lords who inherit their title from their fathers (or, less frequently, their mothers). The 1958 Life Peerages Act enabled the prime minister to appoint life peers, who hold their position for their lifetime but cannot hand it down to their heirs. These are known as "day boys" by the hereditaries; "Tony's cronies" by today's Tories. Also seated in the chamber are 26 bishops, reflecting the Church of England's role as the official state religion, and 12 law lords.

What does the House of Lords do?

Like other upper chambers, the Lords is part of the legislative process, scrutinising the work of the Commons and the government. Most major legislative bills are designed by the government and are debated in the Commons before coming to the Lords, which can propose amendments or delay non-financial legislation. The 12 law lords also act as the UK's final court of appeal.

Why is Labour reforming the Lords?

The House of Lords is widely condemned as undemocratic: "one of the most curious of the curious anomalies in British public life, defying all logic of democratic and secular politics", in the words of political scientist John Kingdom.

The presence of an unelected upper chamber mocks the principle of a representative democracy, in which all people are equally entitled to participate in politics. The law lords can both make and judge the law: this runs counter to the democratic ideal of a "separation of powers", which holds that the judiciary (courts), legislature (parliament) and executive (government) should remain independent of each other, checking and balancing each other's power.

Self-interest also plays a part in Labour's decision to reform the Lords. Dismantling the chamber enhances Labour's reformist credentials. More importantly, abolishing the hereditary peers removes a key source of Conservative opposition to the government. Predominantly Tory, the hereditary peers have fuelled a number of revolts against Labour's legislation, including major opposition to Labour's welfare plans last autumn.

What can be done with the Lords?

There are two main options. The first is to create an upper chamber which is subservient to the government, sustaining the British tradition of a dominant executive. A House of Lords wholly nominated by the prime minister would be the most extreme example of this. Opponents argue that this would perpetuate the undemocratic imbalance of power in British politics, which makes government an "elective dictatorship".

The second option is to create a second chamber similar to those in other western democracies: a directly elected, independent body, designed to check and scrutinise the power of the government, with no overlapping of judicial or legislative functions. Tony Blair is among those who believe this would undermine the Commons and introduce gridlock into politics, threatening the speed and efficiency with which the government can act.

What has Labour done so far?

Labour's House of Lords Act 1999 removed all but 92 hereditary peers last year. A further 10 were immediately granted life peerages by the prime minister, allowing them to stay in the Lords. Initially seeking the removal of all hereditary peers, Mr Blair was forced to approve this compromise before the Lords would approve his legislation. The new house first assembled for the Queen's speech on 17 November 1999.

The 92 hereditary peers who remained were elected by their peers, after all published 75-word manifestos justifying their retention. Lord Onslow's manifesto read: "It would be as vainglorious to proclaim a personal manifesto as it would be arrogant to list any permanent achievements." He was elected.

What is the royal commission?

The government has said reform will not stop here. But it has not decided what further changes to make to the Lords, which, by other countries' standards, is still absurdly undemocratic.

A royal commission, chaired by Conservative peer Lord Wakeham, was established in 1999 to consider and make recommendations on the role and functions of a second chamber. It was supposed to report by the end of 1999, but disagreements among the academics and politicians who make up the body delayed its publication until now.

Cynics observe that royal commissions are often used as tools of procrastination by governments wanting to be seen to be making reformist noises but unwilling to take legislative action. The highly respected Jenkins commission on electoral reform reported in November 1998, but the government has subsequently placed electoral reform at the bottom of its priorities. It is highly unlikely that Jenkins' recommendations will ever be adopted.

What does the Wakeham commission recommend?

Lord Wakeham's recommendations represent a compromise between government supporters, who wanted a fully-nominated chamber, and more radical reformists, who wanted a directly-elected second chamber.

The commission recommends:
 a significant minority of "regional members" chosen on a basis which reflects the views of the regional electorates;
 a totally independent appointments system with a remit to bring in representatives from all sectors of society (rather than the present system of prime ministerial patronage);
 a statutory minimum proportion (30%) of women;
 fair representation for ethnic minority groups;
 a broader range of religious representation.

What the commission does not recommend is also significant. It fails to argue for a second chamber consisting wholly, or largely, of directly elected peers.

What will happen next?

Probably very little, although Lord Wakeham insists "there is no sign" that the government will abandon the reforms it started.

The commission has offered a compromise but no clear lead. Guardian columnist Hugo Young believes that "Labour leaders had given no thought to what should happen next. They were agents of gesture, not reform." That gesture - removing all but 92 hereditary peers - may be as revolutionary as parliamentary reform gets under the Blair government.

fields.bodyText: What is the House of Lords? The House of Lords is one part of the ancient triumvirate in the British constitution, which also includes the monarchy and the Commons. Representing the interests of the aristocracy, the lords historically combined with the "commoners" to challenge and check the power of kings. These days, the Lords is the second legislative chamber in parliament, responsible for amending and scrutinising the activities of the government-dominated Commons. Other democratic countries have a similar institution, often known as an upper chamber or senate. Who are the members of the House of Lords? Where the Lords differs from other upper chambers is the presence of hereditary peers - lords who inherit their title from their fathers (or, less frequently, their mothers). The 1958 Life Peerages Act enabled the prime minister to appoint life peers, who hold their position for their lifetime but cannot hand it down to their heirs. These are known as "day boys" by the hereditaries; "Tony's cronies" by today's Tories. Also seated in the chamber are 26 bishops, reflecting the Church of England's role as the official state religion, and 12 law lords. What does the House of Lords do? Like other upper chambers, the Lords is part of the legislative process, scrutinising the work of the Commons and the government. Most major legislative bills are designed by the government and are debated in the Commons before coming to the Lords, which can propose amendments or delay non-financial legislation. The 12 law lords also act as the UK's final court of appeal. Why is Labour reforming the Lords? The House of Lords is widely condemned as undemocratic: "one of the most curious of the curious anomalies in British public life, defying all logic of democratic and secular politics", in the words of political scientist John Kingdom. The presence of an unelected upper chamber mocks the principle of a representative democracy, in which all people are equally entitled to participate in politics. The law lords can both make and judge the law: this runs counter to the democratic ideal of a "separation of powers", which holds that the judiciary (courts), legislature (parliament) and executive (government) should remain independent of each other, checking and balancing each other's power. Self-interest also plays a part in Labour's decision to reform the Lords. Dismantling the chamber enhances Labour's reformist credentials. More importantly, abolishing the hereditary peers removes a key source of Conservative opposition to the government. Predominantly Tory, the hereditary peers have fuelled a number of revolts against Labour's legislation, including major opposition to Labour's welfare plans last autumn. What can be done with the Lords? There are two main options. The first is to create an upper chamber which is subservient to the government, sustaining the British tradition of a dominant executive. A House of Lords wholly nominated by the prime minister would be the most extreme example of this. Opponents argue that this would perpetuate the undemocratic imbalance of power in British politics, which makes government an "elective dictatorship". The second option is to create a second chamber similar to those in other western democracies: a directly elected, independent body, designed to check and scrutinise the power of the government, with no overlapping of judicial or legislative functions. Tony Blair is among those who believe this would undermine the Commons and introduce gridlock into politics, threatening the speed and efficiency with which the government can act. What has Labour done so far? Labour's House of Lords Act 1999 removed all but 92 hereditary peers last year. A further 10 were immediately granted life peerages by the prime minister, allowing them to stay in the Lords. Initially seeking the removal of all hereditary peers, Mr Blair was forced to approve this compromise before the Lords would approve his legislation. The new house first assembled for the Queen's speech on 17 November 1999. The 92 hereditary peers who remained were elected by their peers, after all published 75-word manifestos justifying their retention. Lord Onslow's manifesto read: "It would be as vainglorious to proclaim a personal manifesto as it would be arrogant to list any permanent achievements." He was elected. What is the royal commission? The government has said reform will not stop here. But it has not decided what further changes to make to the Lords, which, by other countries' standards, is still absurdly undemocratic. A royal commission, chaired by Conservative peer Lord Wakeham, was established in 1999 to consider and make recommendations on the role and functions of a second chamber. It was supposed to report by the end of 1999, but disagreements among the academics and politicians who make up the body delayed its publication until now. Cynics observe that royal commissions are often used as tools of procrastination by governments wanting to be seen to be making reformist noises but unwilling to take legislative action. The highly respected Jenkins commission on electoral reform reported in November 1998, but the government has subsequently placed electoral reform at the bottom of its priorities. It is highly unlikely that Jenkins' recommendations will ever be adopted. What does the Wakeham commission recommend? Lord Wakeham's recommendations represent a compromise between government supporters, who wanted a fully-nominated chamber, and more radical reformists, who wanted a directly-elected second chamber. The commission recommends:  a significant minority of "regional members" chosen on a basis which reflects the views of the regional electorates;  a totally independent appointments system with a remit to bring in representatives from all sectors of society (rather than the present system of prime ministerial patronage);  a statutory minimum proportion (30%) of women;  fair representation for ethnic minority groups;  a broader range of religious representation. What the commission does not recommend is also significant. It fails to argue for a second chamber consisting wholly, or largely, of directly elected peers. What will happen next? Probably very little, although Lord Wakeham insists "there is no sign" that the government will abandon the reforms it started. The commission has offered a compromise but no clear lead. Guardian columnist Hugo Young believes that "Labour leaders had given no thought to what should happen next. They were agents of gesture, not reform." That gesture - removing all but 92 hereditary peers - may be as revolutionary as parliamentary reform gets under the Blair government. webTitle: Britain's ethical foreign policy: keeping the Hawk jets in action

fields.headline: Britain's ethical foreign policy: keeping the Hawk jets in action
fields.standfirst: Exclusive :  Blair tells FO Zimbabwe must have spares for Congo war
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has overuled the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, by giving the go-ahead for the sale of spare parts to Zimbabwe for British Hawk fighter jets being used in an African civil war that has cost tens of thousands of lives.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has overuled the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, by giving the go-ahead for the sale of spare parts to Zimbabwe for British Hawk fighter jets being used in an African civil war that has cost tens of thousands of lives.

The Downing Street decision drives the biggest hole yet through Mr Cook's ethical foreign policy, which was supposed to deny arms to countries engaged in external aggression or internal repression. Zimbabwe, which is deeply involved in the Congo war, fails on both counts. The background to British involvement with the Zimbabwean military is laid out in a restricted foreign office document from the British high commissioner in Harare which has been leaked to the Guardian.

The document discloses "burning resentment" on the part of the Zimbabwean military over an unofficial embargo by Britain last year on the supply of spares for Hawks.

The Congolese civil war is bloodier than the conflicts involving either Indonesia or Pakistan, both of which have been embroiled in British arms sales rows in the last fortnight. Thousands of civilians have been killed or have starved to death, and large swathes of the country have been devastated.

Zimbabwe, which admits to having 11,000 troops in the Congo, has 10 Hawks, sold by Lady Thatcher in the early 1980s, of which five or six are in action at any one time. One was shot down a few months ago. Zimbabwe became involved in the conflict on the side of Congolese government in its battle against local rebels backed by Rwanda and Uganda.

Mr Blair's decision, reached last week and circulated internally in government circles at the weekend, ends a protracted debate between the ministry of defence and the department of trade and industry battling for the defence industry on the one side and the foreign office on the other. Mr Blair, who has tended in the past to side with the MoD-DTI axis, did not go into detail about the reason for his decision but he was under pressure from arms dealers who claimed that failure to deliver meant Britain risked gaining a reputation for unreliability among arms-buying nations.

A Whitehall source, furious over the Downing Street decision, said: "This is crazy at a time when there is the prospect of a peace settlement. It sends the wrong signal." The source said the ethical foreign policy was undermined: "They are completely muddled."

The source added that Zimbabwe, which has an inflation rate of 57% and record unemployment and which has had to renege on its debt repayments, was among the countries that should be least encouraged to spent much-needed finance on weapons. The conflict is costing Zimbabwe £1m a day.

As the conflict in the Congo deteriorated last year, Whitehall departments discussed whether a new policy towards arms sales to Zimbabwe was needed. An unofficial arms embargo was imposed, though never made public.

Applications from British arms companies for export licences began to pile up.

After much Whitehall wrangling, a meeting of all the relevant departments was held at the cabinet office, which acted as chairman. An apparent compromise was thrashed out in which Britain would agree to provide spares but no new arms. The distinction was academic anyway, as Zimbabwe does not have the finances for new arms.

Mr Cook initially agreed to the compromise, though with reservations. But he later came back strongly opposed to the resumption of any military sales, including spare parts.

With the departments unable to agree a compromise, Downing Street intervened and Mr Blair chose to ignore Mr Cook's protests. The government is due to announce within the next few weeks in a written parliamentary answer that sales will resume.

Mr Cook's opposition could be linked to an attempt to negotiate a peace settlement by Richard Holbrooke, the US ambassador to the United Nations, who is the present chair of the security council.

The timing of the disclosure of resumed UK arms sales is likely cause embarrassment between Britain and the US as Mr Holbrooke is to open discussions on Monday in New York with representatives from the Congo and neighbouring countries.

The extent to which the Zimbabwean military was desperate for spare parts is confirmed in a four-page diplomatic telegram from the British high commissioner in Harare, Peter Longworth, which was circulated in Whitehall. His telegram, dated this month and marked "restricted", said the Zimbabwean military did not understand the British government's position in relation to the Congo and "bear a burning resentment as a result of the decision not to continue with supplies of Hawk spares."

In an assessment of the chances of a military coup, he said Britain had influence with the Zimbabwean military, inculcating values that made a coup less likely.

Zimbabwe has the Hawk MK60 and 60a, which can carry bombs, rockets and cannon.

The civil war, which began in August 1998 in the aftermath of the Rwandan genocide, pits Zimbabwe, Namibia, Angola and the president of the Congo, Laurent Kabila, against Rwanda, Uganda and Congolese rebels.

fields.headline: The £5bn conflict of interest
fields.standfirst: When ethical clashes with political and profitable
fields.trailText: As soon as Robin Cook announced shortly after New Labour came to power that he would introduce an "ethical dimension" to foreign policy, Whitehall warned that his pledge would be a hostage to fortune.
fields.body:
As soon as Robin Cook announced shortly after New Labour came to power that he would introduce an "ethical dimension" to foreign policy, Whitehall warned that his pledge would be a hostage to fortune.

How could the world's second biggest arms exporter, with an industry officially estimated to sell more than £5bn a year in weapons overseas, up to a quarter of the global market and employing 400,000, pursue a foreign policy where ethics played a part?

And even less so when the most lucrative arms markets are countries with the most repressive regimes or engaged in conflicts.

The government's election manifesto stated: "We support a strong UK defence industry which is a strategic part of our industrial base as well as our defence effort".

Defence analysts said yesterday that the industry has such a strong lobbying power, it has managed to persuade Downing Street that Mr Cook's "ethical dimension" could be deleterious to an industry that helps UK manufacturing occupy a leading world position.

The industry is dominated by BAE Systems, the giant formed from the £8bn merger last year with GEC's Marconi defence arm and successful exporter of Hawk training aircraft to 12 countries, Harriers, Tornados and the like.

But it comprises a host of smaller players such as Cobham, Hunting and GKN and is so attractive as a bridge between the US and Europe that it is now heavily courted by the Americans, French and Germans.

BAE, through mammoth deals such as the Al Yamamah programme with Saudi Arabia actively endorsed by governments, carries enormous political clout, capable of relying on MPs of all parties, including Labour MPs in Lancashire, to pursue its interests.

It is, says one analyst, exceptionally good at lobbying and senior executives spend as much time, if not more, in Whitehall as in the boardroom.

Arms sales do not just help the balance of trade. They are seen as a boost for other exports, to help Britain "punch above its weight" - a favoured foreign office phrase - and keep the intelligence agencies in business.

If Britain did not sell weapons, then its rivals would, argue the arms companies, the ministry of defence and the department of trade and industry.

Now the government contends that if Britain did not continue to supply weapons to its traditional markets its customers would consider Britain unreliable - and turn to other countries.

According to the International Institute for Strategic Studies, Britain sold $9bn worth of arms in 1998, with the government approving export licences for a wide range of military equipment to Indonesia, Turkey, China, Bahrain, and Algeria, as well as Saudi Arabia, Britain's main arms customer.

Sales included 38 armoured combat vehicles to Indonesia, 18 Tornado aircraft, 100 air-to-ground missiles to Saudi Arabia, and more than 400 air-launched missiles to the United Arab Emirates.

The MoD and the arms industry argue that exports - which account for 40% of British weapons production - make unit costs for supplies to the British armed forces cheaper.

Independent analysts say that government help in promoting arms exports - through the MoD's arms salesmen, hidden subsidies provided by export credit guarantees and publicly funded research and development - skews the manufacturing sector of the economy.

fields.headline: Is postgraduate study for you?
fields.trailText: Are you fed up with someone else always beating you to that dream job? Are you desperate for a major career change but haven't got the right skills? Did you love your first degree so much you're ready for more? If any of these questions strike a chord, then you may well find the answers at The Postgraduate Study and Training Fair 2000.
fields.body:
Are you fed up with someone else always beating you to that dream job? Are you desperate for a major career change but haven't got the right skills? Did you love your first degree so much you're ready for more? If any of these questions strike a chord, then you may well find the answers at The Postgraduate Study and Training Fair 2000.

The 21st century is an exciting time to be job hunting, but with more people armed with a degree than ever before, the chances are you'll need something extra to stand out from the crowd. Don't underestimate the value that a postgraduate qualification can add to your CV.

At The Postgraduate Study and Training Fair 2000 you can chat to 70 of the foremost HE and Training providers in the UK and Europe. Language, IT and business courses, masters degrees, design and printing qualifications, teacher training - the choices are seemingly endless and you'll need to plan the next step very carefully indeed.

In addition, the university of London will provide impartial careers and CV advice, a cyber cafe, and computer aided careers guidance, as well as facilitating a comprehensive seminar programme devoted to helping you make the right decision about your future. Come and participate in seminars on Funding your Postgraduate Course, Postgraduate Study in the USA or Ireland, Getting into PR and Advertising, Teaching English Abroad and Returning to Study as a Mature Graduate, among others.

Whatever the future holds for you, the next move could be vital and you must make an informed decision. Increased international mobility means that UK graduates are now competing with candidates from abroad, many of whom have studied for longer than the UK average. Never before has the need to improve and add to your skills been greater and the Postgraduate Study and Training Fair 2000 is the best place for you to start.

The Postgraduate Study and Training Fair 2000 is at the Business Design Centre on Wednesday 26 January (12.30 - 8.30pm) & Thursday 27 January (12 noon - 7.00pm). Entrance is free. Need to know more? Phone free on 0800 252 183 or visit the website.

fields.headline: Should you be investing in your future?
fields.trailText: The MBA (Master of Business Administration) is one of the most widely recognised and respected professional postgraduate qualifications in the world. Studying for an MBA could be your opportunity to move out of 'middle-management' and gain the confidence, experience and knowledge to progress within the business world.
fields.body:
The MBA (Master of Business Administration) is one of the most widely recognised and respected professional postgraduate qualifications in the world. Studying for an MBA could be your opportunity to move out of 'middle-management' and gain the confidence, experience and knowledge to progress within the business world.

So, where do you start? The MBA Fair 2000 will give you the opportunity to find out more about the range of programmes being offered by both British and International Schools, with almost sixty top Business Schools exhibiting.

You may be looking to focus your career direction by studying for a specialist MBA such as the MBA in Financial Studies run by the University of Nottingham Business School, alternatively a more general MBA covering a broad range of subjects may be more appropriate. In recent years, there has been a rapid increase in the number of students studying through part-time or distance learning programmes, these offer the flexibility to study for an MBA while still working.

A comprehensive seminar programme will be running throughout the Fair covering a range of topics to help you decide whether you are ready to take an MBA and how to select the most appropriate course for you. There will be a presentation on 'What is an MBA?' by Mike Jones, Director General of The Association of MBAs, and Sam Crooks, International Director of GMAC (Graduate Management Admissions Council) will talk on the content and format of the GMAT test and its use in the MBA selection procedures.

Finally, maybe you want to take this opportunity to study overseas, to experience a new culture and a different way of life. There are Schools from four continents present at the Fair promoting their MBA programmes. So, to get the facts right and make an informed decision visit the MBA Fair 2000 - your future might be worth it.

fields.trailText: Zimbabwe is a country ripe for revolution and Robert Mugabe is its lord of misrule. A collapsing health service, an Aids crisis, record unemployment and interest rates, inflation at 57%, and an annual 10% budget deficit are but aspects of a bigger, unstable picture. Zimbabwe's foreign exchange reserves are all but exhausted. Its fuel supply is down to six days. Its total external debt is $4.5bn. The IMF and World Bank have withdrawn support because of economic mismanagement and the disastrous Congo war, to which Mr Mugabe committed 11,000 troops. Last week, Zimbabwe defaulted on UK export guarantee repayments; South African banks cut off further credit; and it was forced to plead for the IMF to return to the rescue.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe is a country ripe for revolution and Robert Mugabe is its lord of misrule. A collapsing health service, an Aids crisis, record unemployment and interest rates, inflation at 57%, and an annual 10% budget deficit are but aspects of a bigger, unstable picture. Zimbabwe's foreign exchange reserves are all but exhausted. Its fuel supply is down to six days. Its total external debt is $4.5bn. The IMF and World Bank have withdrawn support because of economic mismanagement and the disastrous Congo war, to which Mr Mugabe committed 11,000 troops. Last week, Zimbabwe defaulted on UK export guarantee repayments; South African banks cut off further credit; and it was forced to plead for the IMF to return to the rescue.

Mr Mugabe, trying to sweeten voters ahead of promised parliamentary elections in March, has raised public sector salaries without the cash to pay for it. Further, the president keeps his generals and Zanu-PF partymen in line with patronage and promises of land which he threatens to expropriate (without compensation) from white farmers. He distracts attention with homophobic rants, with attacks on opposition politicians and journalists, and with abuse of Britain, his favourite scapegoat. He pretends to reform the constitution but makes a mockery of the process by retaining sweeping powers for himself. It was only after Joshua Nkomo's death last year that he finally offered restitution for the mass killings in Matabeleland which occurred after independence in 1980. Human rights organisations estimate that as many as 30,000 people may have died. At 75, besieged by the evidence of his own failures and with no obvious successor, Mr Mugabe is more foundering than founding father. Little wonder that Britain's man in Harare has been busy assessing the likelihood of rising civil unrest and a military coup.

Whether a revolution, if it comes, is peaceful or violent, Zimbabwe is simply not a place where Britain should be selling arms. As with Pakistan recently, Robin Cook was right to oppose the export of Hawk aircraft spares. Tony Blair's overruling of him says much about the prime minister's inexperience in international affairs. The US, trying to broker a Congo and Burundi peace, will not thank him. Impoverished Zimbabweans will not. And nor will Britain's military suppliers, once they realise that they are extremely unlikely ever to get paid.

He distracts attention with homophobic rants, with attacks on opposition politicians and journalists, and with abuse of Britain, his favourite scapegoat. He pretends to reform the constitution but makes a mockery of the process by retaining sweeping powers for himself. It was only after Joshua Nkomo's death last year that he finally offered restitution for the mass killings in Matabeleland which occurred after independence in 1980. Human rights organisations estimate that as many as 30,000 people may have died. At 75, besieged by the evidence of his own failures and with no obvious successor, Mr Mugabe is more foundering than founding father. Little wonder that Britain's man in Harare has been busy assessing the likelihood of rising civil unrest and a military coup. Whether a revolution, if it comes, is peaceful or violent, Zimbabwe is simply not a place where Britain should be selling arms. As with Pakistan recently, Robin Cook was right to oppose the export of Hawk aircraft spares. Tony Blair's overruling of him says much about the prime minister's inexperience in international affairs. The US, trying to broker a Congo and Burundi peace, will not thank him. Impoverished Zimbabweans will not. And nor will Britain's military suppliers, once they realise that they are extremely unlikely ever to get paid.

webTitle: The generals profit as the people pay with their lives

fields.headline: The generals profit as the people pay with their lives
fields.standfirst: British-made Hawks bomb Congo as Zimbabwe fights a war which is making a select few rich
fields.trailText: British-made Hawks bomb Congo as Zimbabwe fights a war which is making a select few rich
fields.body:
The long suffering people of the Democratic Republic of Congo have little inclination to dwell on how the bombs that kill their families and destroy their homes are delivered. The hundreds who died last year in Makanza, Goma or Kisangani might have fallen victim to aircraft from an array of countries. After all, Congo's war has become a multinational free for all.

But somewhere in the mix is a handful of British Hawks flown by the Zimbabwe airforce. They deliver bombs and unguided rockets. When they miss, civilians pay. The aircraft take the killing far beyond the front line, tormenting the Congolese people who, for the most part, feel no great loyalty to either side in the 17-month civil war.

The 11,000 Zimbabwean troops in Congo represent the largest contingent of foreign soldiers fighting to prop up President Laurent Kabila's regime against Rwandan and Ugandan-backed rebels who occupy more than half the country.

Other countries also came to Mr Kabila's aid, most notably Angola. But Angola had its own civil war and so Zimbabwe has done much of the work to keep the rebels at bay.

Tens of thousands of Congolese civilians have died. Some were caught in the fighting, others were murdered by the rebels or pro-Kabila forces in wholesale massacres of those considered disloyal or just of the wrong ethnic group. Many more died of hunger and exhaustion as they hid in the jungle.

Cities and towns are wrecked. Villages are flattened. Large parts of a fertile country twice the size of France and Germany combined are having trouble finding food for the first time in living memory. Even the capital, Kinshasa, is grappling to feed itself or find enough fuel to cook.

Congo's 50m people thought they had escaped such horrors when a relatively bloodless rebellion overthrew despot Mobutu Sese Seko three years ago. Mobutu watched his country wither through neglect but now parts of it are being ground into the dust by a profit-driven war.

President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe says he sent his troops to Congo to prevent the overthrow of a legitimate government, albeit a regime that came to power by force with the backing of the very people now trying to overthrow it.

But there is another motive behind Zimbabwe's interest in propping up Mr Kabila. Zimbabwe's generals, political allies and relatives have made small fortunes in Congo's diamond and cobalt mining industries, and trading in timber and transport.

The army has created companies to do business in Congo because, it says, Zimbabwe's private sector is not taking advantage of the opportunities. This week, one of the military's firms said it had a multi-million dollar diamond mining deal in Mbuji-Mayi. The state-owned Zimbabwean Defence Industries won a £35m contract to supply the Congolese army. Profits go to generals and politicians.

Zimbabwe's Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals has even accused the army of smuggling hundreds of African grey parrots worth as much as a £1,000 each. The political and military elite are not the only ones to profit. Many on the rebel side are getting rich too but no one doubts that the men from Zimbabwe have organised it best. But the war is bleeding the coffers of Mr Mugabe's government of more than £1m a day.

He staved off the worst consequences for over a year with some judicious financial juggling. But now hard currency reserves have run dry, the Zimbabwe dollar is collapsing and inflation is surging. The country is in recession for the first time since independence in 1980.

As a result, Zimbabwe has defaulted on loans, including those guaranteeing British exports. The cash crunch has created a fuel crisis because oil companies refuse to extend credit to Zimbabwe. Motorists queue for hours to buy petrol. Electricity is supplied only because South Africa's Eskom power company continues to cater for almost half Zimbabwe's needs - even though it has not been paid in months.

Last year the head of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, described Zimbabwe's economic crisis as "very dangerous" and blamed it on the war in Congo. Britain's minister for Africa, Peter Hain, was "very concerned".

The widespread unpopularity of the war and the economic crisis have helped to galvanise the strongest political challenge to Mr Mugabe in his two decades in power. Trade unionists have led the way with strikes and the launch of a new political party. Some newspapers openly taunt him. Even old allies, such as the soldiers and civil servants, have made their discontent known.

Mr Mugabe's government has tried to win them back by doubling their pay (even though that adds to the country's financial woes). It has turned on longtime foes, with sometimes brutal treatment of journalists who expose the truth of the war in Congo and dissent in the army. Political and trade union opponents have been beaten up.

The government could be made to pay the price of its adventure in Congo in two critical ballots over the coming weeks. A referendum on a revised constitution which strengthens Mr Mugabe's powers is promised soon.

Parliamentary elections are scheduled for March. The opposition believes that the war, economic crisis and general desperation at Mr Mugabe's rule offers it the best chance ever of overturning his parliamentary majority.

Britain and the US have pressed Mr Mugabe to get his troops out of Congo. He would now like to do that. The government says it will bring half the soldiers home in time for the election in March.

Zimbabwe hoped a peace accord signed in August would offer a face-saving way to bring the soldiers home and protect its investments, but the fighting continues.

There is, perhaps, too much bitterness and suspicion, and a belief among some of Mr Kabila's enemies that Zimbabwe cannot keep up the fight for much longer.

fields.headline: The Wakeham commission recommendations
fields.standfirst: Key points for a new second chamber
fields.trailText: What should the second chamber do?
fields.body:
What should the second chamber do?

Three fundamental tenets guide the report. The second chamber should be 'broadly representative' of Britain in the 21st century, provide an 'effective check' on the House of Commons, and give the regions, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland a 'formally constituted voice' at Westminster.

Characteristics

While authoritative, the second chamber should not challenge the democratic authority of the Commons. It should include people who are not professional politicians - some should be able to shed a philosophical, moral or spiritual light on issues, or be experts in a particular field - and who may attend on a part-time basis. There should be no minimum attendance requirement.

No one political party should be able to dominate, and the chamber should continue to be 'relatively non-polemical'.

How should they be chosen?

Not principally by election, either direct or indirect; nor by random selection; nor by co-option.

A 'proactive' independent appointments commission of eight people should be responsible for choosing the new members. A 'significant minority' of them should represent the regions and nations; at least a fifth should not be affiliated to a political party; at least 30% should be women and at least 30% men; and minority ethnic groups should be represented. Twenty-six should be members of Christian denominations, and five from other faiths.

Members should all have equal rights; there should be no two-tier system of privileges. All should serve for 15 years, except regional members, who should serve for three parliamentary terms. They may be reappointed or expelled, and there should be no minimum age.

What about the existing life peers?

They should be appointed to the new chamber for life, if they wish.

What will the new members, and their chamber be called?

They should no longer be peers. Their title, and the name of the chamber, is a question that should be 'left to evolve'.

Scrutinising secondary legislation

The chamber should 'sift' secondary legislation, but any vote against a draft instrument can be overturned by the Commons after three months. Similarly, if the second chamber votes to annul an instrument, the Commons can override the vote after the same period.

Law-making

The Commons should still have the final say in public policy, but the second chamber should be able to force them to reconsider proposed new law.

There should be a new joint committee to help the two chambers agree on Bills without excessive delays.

Some private Bills should be considered first by the second chamber, rather than the Commons.

The constitution

The second chamber should not be given any extra powers in constitutional or human rights issues. However, there should be two new committees to discuss their interests in, and concern for, these issues.

The chamber should be able to investigate whether government bills comply with decisions of the European Court of Human Rights.

Beyond the south-east

A proportion of the members of the second chamber should represent the regions and nations of the UK. But the chamber should not become a 'federal legislature', and it should not become a forum for liaison between the nations.

No member should be automatically entitled to sit in, or nominate anyone else for, the devolved assemblies.

A new committee on devolution issues should be created, which might sometimes meet outside London.

Holding the government to account

Members of the second chamber can be ministers. Ministers themselves should be able to speak to, and be questioned by, the chamber.

An EU committee should be established to encourage better liaison between the EU and the second chamber.

Justice and the second chamber

The role of the Lords of Appeal should not change. However, they should publish a statement of the principles they mean to observe when they vote in the second chamber and sit on related cases.

webTitle: Vanessa Feltz returns to daytime television

fields.headline: Vanessa Feltz returns to daytime television
fields.trailText: After nearly a year in the wilderness, Vanessa Feltz will return to BBC daytime television in March with a new series to justify her £2m contract.
fields.body:
After nearly a year in the wilderness, Vanessa Feltz will return to BBC daytime television in March with a new series to justify her £2m contract.

Feltz, whose daily morning series The Vanessa Show was axed by the BBC last June after it was found to have featured faked guests, will host a 10-part series about the workings of television.

The presenter, who signed a £2m two-year contract with the BBC in August 1998 after her ITV contract ended in a dispute about money, has been at the centre of a row over the amount of money the corporation pays to stars. Her contract on joining the BBC was reported to cover three series aside from The Vanessa Show.

The BBC announced yesterday that Talking Television will launch in March. The half-hour show will include interviews, reviews and previews of programmes. Originally it was planned as a debate show, but the format has been remodelled.
