webTitle: Tesco leads the world online growth and profit

fields.headline: Tesco leads the world online growth and profit
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: It is a rarity in the world of e-commerce: an internet business that is profitable. But yesterday Tesco announced that its online grocery shopping business was now the biggest in the world, with annualised sales of £125m.
fields.body:
It is a rarity in the world of e-commerce: an internet business that is profitable. But yesterday Tesco announced that its online grocery shopping business was now the biggest in the world, with annualised sales of £125m. It is poised for further expansion which should create 7,000 jobs - and is making money.

Two thousand new shoppers are signing on with Tesco Direct every week and it now has 250,000 registered users. By the end of this year, 90% of the population will have access to the service.

The implications could be enormous. If shoppers mostly stay at home, there are question marks over the future of the vast out-of-town superstores into which the supermarket chains have ploughed millions.

Equally, there is the potential for further erosion of high street retailing. A survey by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors Research Foundation, to be published tomorrow, will warn that computer access and time pressures mean "the days of high street shopping could be numbered".

But there are alternative suggestions that e-shopping could mean a new role for traditional retailers, as shoppers order only commodities - tinned food and toilet rolls - for delivery, and revert to small shops for pro duce which they traditionally like to see before buying, like cheeses, charcuterie, fresh meat, fruit and vegetables.

Supermarket group Iceland, which started nationwide internet shopping last October and was overwhelmed with the response, has observed this trend. Malcolm Walke, its chairman, said its shoppers ordered mainly low-margin, bulk commodity goods - taking their custom for the more profitable purchases elsewhere.

Tesco now offers web shopping to anyone who lives within a 25-minute drive of a selected 100 stores. But by the end of this year, the online service will be available from 300 of Tesco's 640 stores and expanded to offer non-food items like books clothing, gifts, furnishings and banking services.

"We are now the biggest on-line grocery business in the world, and that is fact", said a Tesco spokesman. Its nearest rival is Peapods, a US grocery business which has 100,000 e-customers.

Tesco's approach is radically different from that of its main competitors. Its online business is based on its traditional stores. The staff manning the keyboards, trolleys and delivery vans for the stay-at-home shoppers are all store workers, although they work solely on the online service.

The system is highly automated. Orders coming in are fed through a computer which provides the least time-consuming route around the store for the pickers. The computer also calculates the best delivery route for the driver.

But Asda and Sainsbury believe that Tesco has got it wrong. They are ploughing millions into constructing huge warehouses, or picking centres, which will service net shoppers only.

Asda currently operates two, in Croydon and Watford, which can offer internet shopping to a potential one million shoppers. It will open two more depots inside the M25 by the end of this year and has plans for eleven more, nationwide, within the next three to five years.

By the summer, Asda@ Home is also going on Open, the television shopping channel available to Sky Digital subscribers, although the service will only be available to Londoners.

Sainsbury, which is investing £30m in e-commerce, is equally London-oriented, and a net laggard. Its first picking centres have yet to open, and it has no plans to open any outside the capital.

But that may be about to change. The Sainsbury strategy was devised by Dino Adriano, who was ousted last week and replaced by Sir Peter Davis, the e-wise boss of the Prudential insurance group, which revolutionised personal banking with Egg.

Mr Adriano was insistent that his was the right plan, supported by evidence from the US that store-based e-shopping was not cost-effective. He reckoned stores should not be cluttered up with internet pickers and packers.

Tesco, unsurprisingly, begs to differ. "There is no business model anywhere that proves picking centres can be profitable," said a spokesman. "By using our stores what we are doing is making the assets we already have work harder.

"We can increase our e-business three times before we start to reach capacity. The store-based model works well and we are a long way off changing it."

webTitle: Cybersurfing: window shopping on the web

fields.headline: Cybersurfing: window shopping on the web
fields.trailText: In the good old days, when people took lunchbreaks, and offices were round the corner from the high street instead of in an industrial wasteland, window shopping was a daily pleasure. We're having to learn a new way of doing it these days.
fields.body:
In the good old days, when people took lunchbreaks, and offices were round the corner from the high street instead of in an industrial wasteland, window shopping was a daily pleasure. We're having to learn a new way of doing it these days. Too rainy to go out? Too cold to stare through fogged-up shop fronts? Window shopping on the internet involves less wear and tear on shoe leather, can whizz you through London, Paris and New York before you've finished getting the spinach out of your teeth and, just like the real thing, usually ends up with you buying something you can't afford.

You have to think time-killing: it's that swinging-your-shoe, what-shall-I-do-now feeling, when you know that anything, anything at all, is better than going back to work. Here's a guide to web-window licking for novices.

At www.audiostreet.com you can fiddle around for hours. The site sells thousands of albums (at some good discounts) and lets you play 30-second outtakes from most of them: I go through The Pixies, a bit of Abba and a couple of sweethearts by Van Morrison before being told to shut up by the rest of the office.

Forced to move on, I next find my way to www.margherita2000.com which is run by Ariston. The company has come up with a washing machine to which you can send emails from work, once you've bought it and had it plumbed in - must be one of the greatest time-wasters ever. The cartoons are very sweet too. But you still have to get your flatmate or partner or dog to actually load the machine.

A bit peckish, I meander to www.simplyfood.co.uk/chocolate, where, by pressing my thumb to the computer screen and clicking on Go, a bar of chocolate tells me what my chocolate levels are like. I am a disgrace to chocoholics, apparently, but don't know if that means I eat too much or too little.

The site tries to tempt me to buy the chocolate tasting box (for £14.95): 10 different kinds of chocolate so you can persuade yourself that instead of stuffing your face,you're educating your palate. Or get stuck into the comparison reviews (what is it about these things that is so interesting?): they've tried out organic tomato sauce, sushi boxes and smoked salmon.

Feeling I should really elevate my mind from my stomach (where it usually is) I next visit www.ottakars.co.uk, a classy book site full of predictions, gossip and news, and a very tasteful selection of books. A bit too tasteful for me, in fact, and I scarper to www.dogdoo.com, a site I've heard of, but hadn't quite believed existed. For a few dollars, the site promises to send, anonymously of course, a box of dog turds to your worst enemy. It's worth visiting just to read the thank-you letters and recommendations.

There should be a link between the dog poo site and www.gentlehints.com , a site which will anonymously notify colleagues, or friends, of personal hygiene problems, on your behalf, with a letter that starts: "From someone who cares." Yuh! Right! Now feeling a little queasy, I drop into www.lucozade.com for an instant boost: click on the designated spot, and a compliment flashes up. It tells me I'm looking great today. We like this site. (Or, for unreconstructed men, and there are plenty of you around, just leaf through the Lucozade gallery of Lara Croft pictures - schwing!) We're having to learn a new way of doing it these days. Too rainy to go out? Too cold to stare through fogged-up shop fronts? Window shopping on the internet involves less wear and tear on shoe leather, can whizz you through London, Paris and New York before you've finished getting the spinach out of your teeth and, just like the real thing, usually ends up with you buying something you can't afford. You have to think time-killing: it's that swinging-your-shoe, what-shall-I-do-now feeling, when you know that anything, anything at all, is better than going back to work. Here's a guide to web-window licking for novices. At www.audiostreet.com you can fiddle around for hours. The site sells thousands of albums (at some good discounts) and lets you play 30-second outtakes from most of them: I go through The Pixies, a bit of Abba and a couple of sweethearts by Van Morrison before being told to shut up by the rest of the office. Forced to move on, I next find my way to www.margherita2000.com which is run by Ariston. The company has come up with a washing machine to which you can send emails from work, once you've bought it and had it plumbed in - must be one of the greatest time-wasters ever. The cartoons are very sweet too. But you still have to get your flatmate or partner or dog to actually load the machine. A bit peckish, I meander to www.simplyfood.co.uk/chocolate, where, by pressing my thumb to the computer screen and clicking on Go, a bar of chocolate tells me what my chocolate levels are like. I am a disgrace to chocoholics, apparently, but don't know if that means I eat too much or too little. The site tries to tempt me to buy the chocolate tasting box (for £14.95): 10 different kinds of chocolate so you can persuade yourself that instead of stuffing your face,you're educating your palate. webTitle: Bargain hunting:  how to compare prices

fields.headline: Bargain hunting:  how to compare prices
fields.trailText: There are a handful of internet sites which can make your life considerably easier, both online and offline. These are not shopping portals (though they may offer that facility as well), but price or product comparison sites. Here are the best.
fields.body:
There are a handful of internet sites which can make your life considerably easier, both online and offline. These are not shopping portals (though they may offer that facility as well), but price or product comparison sites. Among the best is www.buy.co.uk . Comparing utility prices has become so complicated, even the likes of Which? and telecoms watchdog Oftel admit it's beyond the reach of mere mortals: you need special computer software to do it.

If you type in your annual gas (water, or electritcy) bill into buy.co.uk's search engine, plus your current provider and your preferred method of payment, it will come back with the best deal. It also has a mobile phone tariff calculator, and will shortly add a dual fuel calculator.

For comparative financial information, www.moneyextra.com/main.asp is hard to beat. Without asking you to register, it will go off and find you a new mortgage, the best deal on credit cards, deposit and current accounts, ISAs, insurance, and personal loans.

Moneyextra doesn't compare pensions. If you want to see how yours is doing, go to www.micropal.com, an acknowledged leader in the provision of fund information. The site takes getting used to, but if you put in your pension details, it will tell you its Mircopal rating, which is the sort of thing financial advisers use.

If it's more general shopping you are after, visit www.shopsmart.com. According to managing director, Daniel Gestetner, it's the biggest shopping portal in the UK, and has already gobbled up some good directories such as www.shopguide.co.uk and www.enterprisecity.co.uk .

The site has a price comparison calculator, which is a model of how these things should be set up. It includes the cost of postage, packing and delivery, is fast and efficient, and lists price, product and shop. (Sounds like commonsense, but so many websites don't deliver the basics). On the downside, the price comparison covers only music, movies, video, PC games and books. This leaves 75 percent of Shopsmart's shopping categories with no way of comparing prices. The site also checks only the shops on its site, not the whole web, but it does have a strict criteria of the types of shops it includes.

"They have to use a secure system," says the MD, Daniel Gestetner. "They have to give a telephone number, they have to a have a UK presence, as a lot of the horror stories you hear are from people buying abroad, and they have to take credit cards."

A site called www.priceoffers.co.uk is a curious beast: it's an online guide to offline bargains. Still if you want to know there's 50% off Simpson videos at Asda, this is the place to come.

fields.headline: Cybershopping's 50 favourite sites
fields.standfirst: We've all heard of amazon and lastminute.com, and there's no better way to get net shopping than with safe and reliable sites like these. But if that's as far as online buying has taken you, it's time to visit some of the web's more tempting addresses and discover just how fast you can blow your money in cyberspace
fields.trailText: We've all heard of amazon and lastminute.com, and there's no better way to get net shopping than with safe and reliable sites like these. But if that's as far as online buying has taken you, it's time to visit some of the web's more tempting addresses and discover just how fast you can blow your money in cyberspace
fields.byline: Felicity Lawrence and Sally Kinnes. Additional research by Helen Brooks
fields.body:
1 Are you sitting comfortably? Start by getting the right seat at www.thechair.co.uk, where you can zoom around and try out modern or classic designs. It has its own very good take on the much-imitated Arne Jacobsen chair Christine Keeler once famously perched on - it's called the Kite, and costs £69.

2 Put on your slippers. www.agentprovocateur.com can supply satin mules with maribou trim (£55), as well as all sorts of expensive underwear. Practical they ain't - but then the company is run by Vivienne Westwood's son, and all you have to do with this kind of shopping is relax, sit back and enjoy it.

3 Fix yourself a drink, courtesy of www.berry-bros.co.uk, one of Britain's oldest and most traditional wine merchants, yet also one of the quickest off the mark to set up a comprehensive website. Scan its bestsellers list for a quaffable merlot Domaine d'Antugnac at £4.95.

4 If you're feeling flush, you'll enjoy www.amivin.com's interpretation of everyday wines "all under £11.75". This site gives a guarantee that its prices won't be beaten, and the Errazuriz Sauvignon Blanc at £5.49 goes down a treat.

5 Get yourself a personal organiser so that you can store these web addresses and browse and shop on the bus on the way to work. The Psion Series 7 is about as clever as personal organisers get. As well as standard PC-type applications (word processor, spreadsheet), it has a web browser, email and is the first Psion to have a colour screen. It's available from www.insight.com/uk/ at £657.99.

6 Rather cheaper is the Psion Revo, selling for £214.99 at the good computer and electronics site www.microwarehouse.co.uk. The Revo doesn't come with a colour screen, but it will send and receive email if you connect it up to a mobile phone with an infrared port.

7 Book your entertainment for later. www.odeon.com has listings for many of its cinemas and you can order your tickets online. Why not check out Angela's Ashes?

8 Staying in? www.blackstar.co.uk is one of the best sites for videos and DVDs. In case you missed what everyone's been talking about, the video of Ali G Innit is £14.39, and has the best bits from his TV interviews and some footage never broadcast.

9 Line up some food, in case you get carried away by your cybershopping and find it's closing time when you resurface. Sign up for a weekly order of organic fruit and vegetables at www.organicsdirect.co.uk. Don't be put off by the whole-foody nutloaf design on this site, just enjoy knowing you will be supporting small local producers. A standard vegetable box is £14.95. The bread is good too - no arguments about whether fresh means fresh or reheated or half-baked here.

10 www.iceland.co.uk has won the race to be the first major retailer offering online shopping nationwide. It was also the first to take a stand against GM foods. Get it to bring a chicken tikka or a week's supply of fish fingers to your door. (If you are on a Mac, you have to use Netscape Navigator.)

11 If you live in the right postcode, take advantage of Tesco's efforts to fight back against Asda by cutting its prices. www.tescodirect.com can provide you with a van of food and wine fit for the Queen, (or was it the Queen's servants?), and will probably be cheaper than your local supermarket, despite the £5 delivery charge.

12 For a treat, sample some Lakeland organic trout from Hawkshead, at www.edirectory.co.uk/organicfish. It will arrive the next day fresher than the average fish counter offerings. It's just £2.00 for a 392g fish, but with a hefty £8.50 delivery charge, you'll need to order in bulk to make it worthwhile.

13 For meat, www.richardwoodall.co.uk is hard to beat. This company's ham has been served not only to the Queen but also to travellers on Concorde and, less encouragingly, to passengers on the Titanic. Smoked home-cured bacon is a great last meal at £3.34 for a 500g pack.

14 www.realmeat.co.uk is also excellent and has a wider range.

15 Wonderful olive oils are among the range of delicatessen produce available at www.morel.co.uk. The French everyday olive oil comes in a beautiful 1 litre tin costing £6.90.

16 More delicatessen goodies - as well as delicious bread - can be found at www.villagebakery.com .

17 Once the provisioning has been done, you can settle down for some serious spending. Nervous about the phone bill? Go to www.bt.com to change your friends and family discounted numbers. Your chosen "best friend" number (which receives a 15% discount) will, of course, be your internet dial-up number.

18 Some things are meant to be expensive. www.ifexonline.co.uk will do you a nice Le Corbusier sofa for £1,200. This site is a vast catalogue of everything from beds to broom cupboards, all top of the range, utterly desirable and liable to break the bank. Tiny pictures prevent excessive salivation.

19 For cheaper cupboards, filing boxes, shoe racks, and all the accessories that would help you organise your life if only you were that kind of person, go to www.theholdingcompany.co.uk. A zinc doctor's cupboard (£220) could restore you. The owner of the site, being American, is light years ahead of most when it comes to efficient online ordering services.

20 Plain, sensible and affordable is www.mccord.uk.com, where a white shag-pile carpet starts at £19.99. Just remember it's called a Flokati rug now.

21 For an affordable yet collectible piece of modern design, look at Ella Doran's table mats, £29.50 for six on www.bluedeco.com.

22 Bag a bit of design history by visiting the second-hand designer furniture shop www.eatmyhandbagbitch.co.uk for a System 1-2-3 Armchair by Verner Panton, great condition, a snip at £750 (that Panton exhibition at the Design Museum last year did wonders for prices, wouldn't you know), or an Eero Saarinen tulip chair at £225. (Online browsing, email ordering.)

23 The self-respecting kitchen is supposed to have a Dualit toaster these days. The assembler's individual mark is on the base plate, and they are even made from the same heat-proof material as used in the space shuttle (nothing being too good to launch your day). You can read all about them at www.dualit.com, then buy one cheap at www.ogormans.co.uk (from £100 for a two-slicer, to £250 for a four-slice sandwich).

24 "We won't be beaten on price" is the kind of reassurance canny shoppers like to hear, especially if they have an extravagance in mind such as a stylish Smeg fridge. www.electric-shop.co.uk makes such a promise and of the three Smegs listed, prices start at £659 for the FC 36RX stainless steel model.

25 The site above doesn't list Smeg's retro Fab 32 but you can find one at www.fhm.co.uk/shop/, the online outpost of the magazine. The FHM lads seem an unlikely target for such a fridge but the price is good (£1,130). Must be its curves, and its lager-holding capacity.

26 www.value-direct.co.uk is another site confident about its pricing. It offers refunds of 110% if you can find the same product cheaper elsewhere, including delivery. This, then, is the place to buy that Dyson vacuum cleaner you've always promised yourself. The stylish no-bag, no-loss-of-suction De Stijl DC04 machine costs £238.95 (UK delivery is free).

27 After all this bargain hunting, time for a splurge. The Cross in Notting Hill is one of the fashion crowd's favourite shops. Set up by Sam Robinson and Sarah Keen, whose friends have handy names like Jemima Khan and Jade Jagger, it sells an eclectic mix of clothes, and things for children and the home. Be tempted by Megan Park's hand-embroidered silk sarong skirt (£325) at www.www.thecrosscatalogue.com, or settle for flower flip-flops at £30. Assuage your guilt by buying something for someone else, a teddy bear with heart, say (£22).

28 Stella McCartney, with her Chloe label, is next season's guest designer at La Redoute, a French mail-order catalogue that has gone online at www.redoute.co.uk . It is one of the best for affordable but stylish interpretations of designer fashion. Already on the site is a range by Joseph: long flared skirt, £44.99; trousers, £44.99. McCartney's bosses are threatening to make you get a catalogue before you can order the Chloe dress, though (try emailing a request).

29 For more designer gear, there's www.ghost.co.uk, whose site sells a limited range of its classics (including the straight pant in viscose, £81, and the cowl camisole, £72).

30 www.diesel.co.uk has a funky site with the latest streetwear. Its Luster jean (£60) promises to "give delightful female calf muscles just the respect they deserve". Men can buy the Diesel logo on their workwear pants for a mere £70.

31 www.boo.com also has a great range of urban wear, and the latest in website design. It is especially hot on trainers, with labels such as DKNY, Acupuncture and Jil Sander, but unforgiveably hasn't been set up for Mac users.

32 For reliable everyday clothes for adults and children, www.boden.co.uk has a good online catalogue and seems to have recovered from its Christmas blips.

33 If the funds are falling a little low, time to have a flutter at the online bookmakers www.bluesq.com.

34 Plan to make some serious savings on your next car by visiting www.oneswoop.com . Selling starts on March 1, but you can register now. It is dedicated to using the net to overcome the rip-off dealer network that has forced UK drivers to pay over the odds for their cars. It has a deal with M&S financial services to arrange finance, and delivers direct to your door. So far it can offer Ford, Audi/Volkswagen, Peugeot, Rover and Vauxhall/Opel, but eventually it hopes to sell all models and promises mouthwatering discounts.

35 Carphone Ware- house's website, www.carphonewarehouse.com may not be the easiest to navigate, but the company does promise to refund 110% if you find a phone cheaper elsewhere, and will even monitor prices (and refund the difference with a voucher) three months after your purchase. Order online and its 48-hour delivery service is free, making it the best place to buy Ericsson's dinky and highly desirable new T28 phone (£249.99), the teenagers' must-have, an Ericsson Chatboard (£19.99) or Nokia's 7110 phone (£129.99). The Nokia is, so far, the only WAP (wireless application protocol) on the market, allowing you to access a simplified, no-picture version of the internet and send and receive emails. Stock can be a problem on the Nokia.

36 The term "MP3" is the most searched on the internet, even more than "sex", which is saying something. But then MP3 is the technology that is threatening to put the music industry out of business. MP3 players allow you to download music absolutely free from the internet (via a cable attached to your PC) and then play it. You can buy them at the good discount site www.unbeatable.co.uk (Samsung YPE32 for £129.99).

37 www.dixons.co.uk still has an MP3 player, the Diamond-Rio 300, in the sale at £99.99.

38 For a list, by music category, of sites where you can download free music, go to www.mp3.com.

39 How about saying it with flowers? www.0800-blossoms.com knocks the spots off most Interflora bouquets and, though not cheap, provides a fast and reliable service. The "French country hand-tied posy" is £35.50 including delivery.

40 Feeling lost? The Garmin eMap is a global positioning system receiver which allows you to find out exactly where you're going. It costs £208.99 for a hand-held one. Or there's the world's first wristwatch designed to receive and process GPS information (£299). A version for the car costs £499. Already spotted on smart school runs in London. All from www.21store.com, a good place for anything electronic.

41 Babies can travel in luxury in a Trekker all-terrain buggy, about £300 from www.urchin.co.uk, for "kids with brattitude". If they haven't got it already, they will have when you've spent this kind of money on them. This site has an imaginative range of products: the cardboard house is £46, the sheep lamp, £29.99.

42 Older kids will start demanding a bike. www.wiggle.co.uk is an all-singing, all-dancing cycle specialist. Refuse requests for the stumpjumper, £999; settle for the children's Hotrock bike at £169.99. You can order Durex here too (too late, too late).

43 Even cheaper still, tell them to make do with finger bikes - the latest playground craze. A model bike that can perform stunts - heel flips, 50/50 grinds, don't worry, parents aren't meant to understand any of these terms - is available at the excellent toy site, www.etoys.co.uk, for £6.99.

44 Retreat to the garden. Connect to a full list of all the nurseries selling plants in the country through the Royal Horticultural Society's Plant Finder at www.rhs.org.uk . It has links to those that have online sites. Sadly, the RHS site itself is suffering from a touch of blight and is much harder to find your way round than it used to be.

45 One of the country's best growers for a wide range of plants is Burncoose. Go to www.eclipse.co.uk/burncoose for a Camellia "E.G Waterhouse" at £7.

46 www.oxalis.co.uk is a portal for 29 nurseries, and though the quality is variable, it has some worthwhile places to visit, particularly for tools.

47 Flagging? www.ukyes.com will sell you Viagra pills in different strengths. You have to fill out a medical checklist for Dr Richard Brye Franklin to review, and the site's security certificate seems to have expired. It also seemed keen to double our order when checked yesterday, but hell . . .

48 Beginning to think you need to upgrade your computer? For a full range of manufacturers, check out www.dabs.co.uk . The name's daft but the site is highly recommended.

49 Overwhelmed? Get away from it all with a train ticket - Paris, Bognor, anywhere - ordered from www.thetrainline.com .

50 But don't forget, if you take that mobile or personal organiser with you on the high street, the Guardian's www.shoppingunlimited.co.uk is only a click away.

This site is a vast catalogue of everything from beds to broom cupboards, all top of the range, utterly desirable and liable to break the bank. Tiny pictures prevent excessive salivation. 19 For cheaper cupboards, filing boxes, shoe racks, and all the accessories that would help you organise your life if only you were that kind of person, go to www.theholdingcompany.co.uk. A zinc doctor's cupboard (£220) could restore you. The owner of the site, being American, is light years ahead of most when it comes to efficient online ordering services. 20 Plain, sensible and affordable is www.mccord.uk.com, where a white shag-pile carpet starts at £19.99. Just remember it's called a Flokati rug now. 21 For an affordable yet collectible piece of modern design, look at Ella Doran's table mats, £29.50 for six on www.bluedeco.com. 22 Bag a bit of design history by visiting the second-hand designer furniture shop www.eatmyhandbagbitch.co.uk for a System 1-2-3 Armchair by Verner Panton, great condition, a snip at £750 (that Panton exhibition at the Design Museum last year did wonders for prices, wouldn't you know), or an Eero Saarinen tulip chair at £225. (Online browsing, email ordering.) 23 The self-respecting kitchen is supposed to have a Dualit toaster these days. The assembler's individual mark is on the base plate, and they are even made from the same heat-proof material as used in the space shuttle (nothing being too good to launch your day). You can read all about them at www.dualit.com, then buy one cheap at www.ogormans.co.uk (from £100 for a two-slicer, to £250 for a four-slice sandwich). 24 "We won't be beaten on price" is the kind of reassurance canny shoppers like to hear, especially if they have an extravagance in mind such as a stylish Smeg fridge. www.electric-shop.co.uk makes such a promise and of the three Smegs listed, prices start at £659 for the FC 36RX stainless steel model. 25 The site above doesn't list Smeg's retro Fab 32 but you can find one at www.fhm.co.uk/shop/, the online outpost of the magazine. The FHM lads seem an unlikely target for such a fridge but the price is good (£1,130). Must be its curves, and its lager-holding capacity. 26 www.value-direct.co.uk is another site confident about its pricing. It offers refunds of 110% if you can find the same product cheaper elsewhere, including delivery. This, then, is the place to buy that Dyson vacuum cleaner you've always promised yourself. The stylish no-bag, no-loss-of-suction De Stijl DC04 machine costs £238.95 (UK delivery is free). 27 After all this bargain hunting, time for a splurge. The Cross in Notting Hill is one of the fashion crowd's favourite shops. Set up by Sam Robinson and Sarah Keen, whose friends have handy names like Jemima Khan and Jade Jagger, it sells an eclectic mix of clothes, and things for children and the home. Be tempted by Megan Park's hand-embroidered silk sarong skirt (£325) at www.www.thecrosscatalogue.com, or settle for flower flip-flops at £30. Assuage your guilt by buying something for someone else, a teddy bear with heart, say (£22). 28 Stella McCartney, with her Chloe label, is next season's guest designer at La Redoute, a French mail-order catalogue that has gone online at www.redoute.co.uk . It is one of the best for affordable but stylish interpretations of designer fashion. Already on the site is a range by Joseph: long flared skirt, £44.99; trousers, £44.99. McCartney's bosses are threatening to make you get a catalogue before you can order the Chloe dress, though (try emailing a request). 29 For more designer gear, there's www.ghost.co.uk, whose site sells a limited range of its classics (including the straight pant in viscose, £81, and the cowl camisole, £72). 30 www.diesel.co.uk has a funky site with the latest streetwear. Its Luster jean (£60) promises to "give delightful female calf muscles just the respect they deserve". Men can buy the Diesel logo on their workwear pants for a mere £70. 31 www.boo.com also has a great range of urban wear, and the latest in website design. It is especially hot on trainers, with labels such as DKNY, Acupuncture and Jil Sander, but unforgiveably hasn't been set up for Mac users. 32 For reliable everyday clothes for adults and children, www.boden.co.uk has a good online catalogue and seems to have recovered from its Christmas blips. 33 If the funds are falling a little low, time to have a flutter at the online bookmakers www.bluesq.com. 34 Plan to make some serious savings on your next car by visiting www.oneswoop.com . Selling starts on March 1, but you can register now. It is dedicated to using the net to overcome the rip-off dealer network that has forced UK drivers to pay over the odds for their cars. It has a deal with M&S financial services to arrange finance, and delivers direct to your door. So far it can offer Ford, Audi/Volkswagen, Peugeot, Rover and Vauxhall/Opel, but eventually it hopes to sell all models and promises mouthwatering discounts. 35 Carphone Ware- house's website, www.carphonewarehouse.com may not be the easiest to navigate, but the company does promise to refund 110% if you find a phone cheaper elsewhere, and will even monitor prices (and refund the difference with a voucher) three months after your purchase. Order online and its 48-hour delivery service is free, making it the best place to buy Ericsson's dinky and highly desirable new T28 phone (£249.99), the teenagers' must-have, an Ericsson Chatboard (£19.99) or Nokia's 7110 phone (£129.99). The Nokia is, so far, the only WAP (wireless application protocol) on the market, allowing you to access a simplified, no-picture version of the internet and send and receive emails. Stock can be a problem on the Nokia. 36 The term "MP3" is the most searched on the internet, even more than "sex", which is saying something. But then MP3 is the technology that is threatening to put the music industry out of business. MP3 players allow you to download music absolutely free from the internet (via a cable attached to your PC) and then play it. You can buy them at the good discount site www.unbeatable.co.uk (Samsung YPE32 for £129.99). 37 www.dixons.co.uk still has an MP3 player, the Diamond-Rio 300, in the sale at £99.99. 38 For a list, by music category, of sites where you can download free music, go to www.mp3.com. 39 How about saying it with flowers? www.0800-blossoms.com knocks the spots off most Interflora bouquets and, though not cheap, provides a fast and reliable service. The "French country hand-tied posy" is £35.50 including delivery. 40 Feeling lost? The Garmin eMap is a global positioning system receiver which allows you to find out exactly where you're going. It costs £208.99 for a hand-held one. Or there's the world's first wristwatch designed to receive and process GPS information (£299). A version for the car costs £499. Already spotted on smart school runs in London. All from www.21store.com, a good place for anything electronic. 41 Babies can travel in luxury in a Trekker all-terrain buggy, about £300 from www.urchin.co.uk, for "kids with brattitude". If they haven't got it already, they will have when you've spent this kind of money on them. This site has an imaginative range of products: the cardboard house is £46, the sheep lamp, £29.99. 42 Older kids will start demanding a bike. www.wiggle.co.uk is an all-singing, all-dancing cycle specialist. Refuse requests for the stumpjumper, £999; settle for the children's Hotrock bike at £169.99. You can order Durex here too (too late, too late). 43 Even cheaper still, tell them to make do with finger bikes - the latest playground craze. A model bike that can perform stunts - heel flips, 50/50 grinds, don't worry, parents aren't meant to understand any of these terms - is available at the excellent toy site, www.etoys.co.uk, for £6.99. 44 Retreat to the garden. Connect to a full list of all the nurseries selling plants in the country through the Royal Horticultural Society's Plant Finder at www.rhs.org.uk . It has links to those that have online sites. Sadly, the RHS site itself is suffering from a touch of blight and is much harder to find your way round than it used to be. 45 One of the country's best growers for a wide range of plants is Burncoose. Go to www.eclipse.co.uk/burncoose for a Camellia "E.G Waterhouse" at £7. 46 www.oxalis.co.uk is a portal for 29 nurseries, and though the quality is variable, it has some worthwhile places to visit, particularly for tools. 47 Flagging? www.ukyes.com will sell you Viagra pills in different strengths. You have to fill out a medical checklist for Dr Richard Brye Franklin to review, and the site's security certificate seems to have expired. It also seemed keen to double our order when checked yesterday, but hell . . . 48 Beginning to think you need to upgrade your computer? For a full range of manufacturers, check out www.dabs.co.uk . The name's daft but the site is highly recommended. 49 Overwhelmed? Get away from it all with a train ticket - Paris, Bognor, anywhere - ordered from www.thetrainline.com . 50 But don't forget, if you take that mobile or personal organiser with you on the high street, the Guardian's www.shoppingunlimited.co.uk is only a click away.

webTitle: Falling for Vertigo by WG Sebald

fields.headline: Falling for Vertigo by WG Sebald
fields.standfirst: Stephen Moss assesses the critical verdict on Sebald's curious mix of travelogue,  literary essay, philosophical reflection and fictive exploration
fields.trailText: WG "Max" Sebald is sometimes compared with Kafka. His fictions - if they are fictions - are unpindownable - but, if we are to believe the critics, they are unputdownable, too.
fields.body:
WG "Max" Sebald is sometimes compared with Kafka. His fictions - if they are fictions - are unpindownable - but, if we are to believe the critics, they are unputdownable, too.

He is perhaps the most often praised contemporary author (the laudatory quotes in the paperback of his second book, The Rings of Saturn, run to four pages), yet he is the antithesis of the much-hyped modern author. He has lived in the UK for 30 years, but still writes in his native German. (His books are translated by Michael Hulse with what all agree is extraordinary delicacy.) He teaches German literature at the University of East Anglia and rarely gives interviews, and is about as far removed from the London literary scene as it is possible for an author to be.

Sebald is elusive and enigmatic, and so are his books. Typically, his latest, Vertigo (Harvill, £12), is actually his earliest, written before The Emigrants and The Rings of Saturn, and published now in the wake of the critical (and, encouragingly, commercial) success of those two books. While weaker than the other parts of what is in effect a trilogy, the critical consensus is that it is still rather wonderful. But what is it about?

That's where criticism proves a somewhat blunt instrument in describing Sebald's curious mix of travelogue, literary essay, philosophical reflection and fictive exploration. William Sutcliffe blathered splendidly in the Independent on Sunday: "The very mysteriousness of the status of his text is central to his point ... Without ever explicitly saying so, Sebald is writing about the nature of truth, about the fictionality of biography, and the biographical nature of fiction ... Sebald is a writer of ideas and yet he never says what his ideas are. It is in what is missing, what is unsaid, that the meat of Sebald's writing lies."

Got that? Sutcliffe, at the end of a longish piece, was left simultaneously gasping for breath and clutching at straws: "In my experience, one's reflections sometimes run aground before discerning any particular meaning. Nonetheless, it is always worth the attempt."

Claire Harman, in the Evening Standard, was more coherent but equally nonplussed: "Vertigo is a cerebral novel which tests the limits of the form even further than its two successors and hangs together by the frailest threads. Observations, anecdotes and memories free-float in the narrator's nervous imagination; signs and symbols, like the doppelganger and the huntsman, dates and gestures, recur with secret significance - or not - from which the reader is deliberately excluded ... This technique is disarming, not least because it encourages your own mind to wander; you have to keep backtracking to re-establish yourself in the flow. However, it is peculiarly appropriate to the process of disintegration and breakdown which the narrator is trying to replicate as well as recall."

"The psychoanalyst Adam Phillips once praised writers who 'allow themselves to be a bit weird'," wrote Alain de Botton in the Sunday Telegraph, "and Sebald is certainly one of these. There seem to be no logical connections between the various parts of Vertigo, and yet the disunity and digressions add up to a faintly pleasing whole. One is afforded a sense of the unusual connections that can occur in the mind. Also, Sebald manages never to be boring. He infuses his prose with the tension of a stylish thriller; the narrator is constantly racing from one location to another in an escape from his demons, and this atmosphere of paranoia keeps us turning the pages."

The most illuminating review was A S Byatt's in the Sunday Times. "Sebald's subject is memory, its tenacity and fallibility," she explained. "The conscious identity of an individual is his personal memories, and the integrity of his body inside his skin. History and literature are the memories of peoples and cultures, held together by languages and records. Thomas Hobbes in the 17th century remarked that imagination was nothing else but decayed memory. Sebald's great contribution to the fictive study of memory is to study it at the point of decay, of feverish imagining, of inventive wildness. His dogged, apparently random wanderings, from country to country and encounter to encounter, have a manic precision. He records tiny conversations, describes carefully the strangers he briefly travels with. He gives maps and timetables. He appears to be holding himself together with his writing."

Erica Wagner, in the Times, also stressed the ever-present danger of disintegration: "The book's title is perfect; it is a work that teeters at the edge of uncertainty ... Sebald's journey into himself and his past is compelling, puzzling, unique. Perhaps Harvill should abandon their current attempt at classifying Sebald and settle simply for 'metaphysics'."

Vertigo, then, is strange, baffling, and almost uncategorisable - but it is a must-read, or perhaps a must-try-to.

webTitle: Russian cabinet launches new Mir mission

fields.headline: Russian cabinet launches new Mir mission
fields.trailText: Russia's Mir space station got a new lease of life on Thursday when the government decided to keep it in orbit through August, using hardware previously allocated for the International Space Station.
fields.body:
Russia's Mir space station got a new lease of life on Thursday when the government decided to keep it in orbit through August, using hardware previously allocated for the International Space Station.

Mir has been flying unmanned since its last crew left in August, and the cash-poor government had decided to stop financing it and abandon the nearly 14-year old station around March unless private investors came up with funds.

But the Cabinet ruled Thursday that space officials can use booster rockets and cargo ships that had been intended for the 16-nation International Space Station in the new Mir mission. Russian space agency chief Yuri Koptev said the move would help cover government debts to the RKK Energia company, which runs the Mir.

The cost of the two Progress cargo ships, a Soyuz spaceship for the crew and three booster rockets to be used in the mission is estimated at 500-550 million rubles ($18 to 19 million), Koptev said.

The government will provide the same amount of money to build new spaceships and rockets for the International Space Station, which is far behind schedule due to the Russian failure to finance its construction. A cargo ship with supplies will be launched to Mir on February 1, and a crew is set to blast off on March 30 for a mission of 45-72 days, Koptev said.

If private funds arrive, space officials will discuss plans for another mission. If no money comes, they will take steps to discard the Mir after August.

Koptev insisted that the government's ruling did not contradict its previous decision to stop financing the station and keep it aloft only on condition of finding private investors. He said that foreign investments were expected to cover a further 750 million rubles ($26 million) necessary for the mission.

But neither he nor Energia chief Yuri Semyonov would reveal any details about a foreign company that had reportedly agreed to finance the Mir's operation. Energia officials had previously said that the company had pledged to provide $20 million for the Mir's operation and had already transferred $7 million of that sum to Energia.

"The company has already provided some funds, and has taken on obligations to continue financing the project under certain conditions," Semyonov told reporters.

The US space agency NASA has long urged Russian space officials to abandon the Mir, which has suffered a series of accidents and technical problems in recent years, and commit their scarce resources to the International Space Station. The entire project has been behind schedule for more than a year, due to the Russian failure to build a crucial component on time.

When the module was almost ready last summer, two crashes of Russian Proton booster rockets pushed the launch date back again. Koptev said the segment would not be launched until late July or August because flaws in the booster rocket needed fixing.

He also said that Russia was planning to launch one spaceship with a crew and two unmanned cargo ships to the international station this year.

The government has earmarked 1.2 billion rubles ($42 million) for the Russian contribution to the international station, Koptev said.

Anticipating a negative U.S. reaction to reviving the Mir program, Koptev insisted that the decision to use ships earlier allocated for the international space station would not bring yet another delay in the project.

"We will explain to them that there will be no damage to the new station," he said.

webTitle: Sundance: a victim of its own success?

fields.headline: Sundance: a victim of its own success?
fields.standfirst: Also today, Beatty in line for lifetime-achievement Oscar | Bullock bitten by 'canine-style' Corman film | Ecstasy star Lamarr dead at 86, and Sam Mendes on his American Beauty. And, on the casting couch, Johnny Depp and Winona Ryder to be reunited on screen , and Rhys Ifans to star opposite Keanu Reeves.
fields.trailText: The Sundance International Film Festival kicks off today amid whispers that the world's premiere low-budget showcase is losing touch with its independent roots. This year's event boasts a line-up more suited to a mainstream festival - films showing include: The Big Kahuna starring Kevin Spacey, Ethan Hawke's Hamlet, Ben Affleck in The Boiler Room (pictured), the provocative American Psycho and the Robert Altman-produced Trixie, starring Nick Nolte and Emily Watson. All of these have already been snapped up for domestic distribution.
fields.body:
The Sundance International Film Festival kicks off today amid whispers that the world's premiere low-budget showcase is losing touch with its independent roots. This year's event boasts a line-up more suited to a mainstream festival - films showing include: The Big Kahuna starring Kevin Spacey, Ethan Hawke's Hamlet, Ben Affleck in The Boiler Room (pictured), the provocative American Psycho and the Robert Altman-produced Trixie, starring Nick Nolte and Emily Watson. All of these have already been snapped up for domestic distribution.

Sundance - which plays out near Robert Redford's ranch in Park City, Utah - was initially conceived as a showcase where small-scale, independently-produced pictures could find a buyer. Last year, the event scored a major coup with The Blair Witch Project, which was bought by Artisan Entertainment for $1m and went on to earn more than $140m at the American box-office.

Writing in the LA Times, Kenneth Turan criticised the current state of Redford's festival. "It's difficult to think of Sundance as a place where films are shown. It's become, partly by happenstance, partly by design, a kind of multicultural circus, a self-fulfilling prophecy more than a festival."

On a more encouraging note, 26% of the 112 films or so on offer are from women directors - a higher percentage than ever before.

 Sundance opens today with the premiere of the Thanksgiving comedy What's Cooking? and finishes on January 29 with an awards presentation for the Best Feature and Best Documentary.

Beatty in line for lifetime-achievement Oscar

It has been confirmed that Warren Beatty is to receive a lifetime achievement award at this year's Oscar ceremony.

The President of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Science, Robert Rehme, explained that: "in discussing this award for Warren, our governors stressed his passion for film, for getting it just right, and his courage in producing pictures that many other producers might have considered too dangerous to try."

Previous recipients have included Walt Disney, Alfred Hitchcock, Ingmar Bergman and Clint Eastwood. Beatty, who missed out on a Best Screenplay award for his political satire Bulworth last year, is expected to attend the ceremony.

 The prestigious Irving Thalberg Memorial Award will be presented to the 62-year-old actor and film-maker at the 72nd annual Academy Awards on March 26.

Bullock bitten by 'canine-style' Corman film

From Jack Nicholson to Francis Coppola, Martin Scorsese to John Sayles, many of Hollywood's biggest hitters owe their first break to fabled B-movie producer Roger Corman. For Sandra Bullock, however, the experience is not likely to be one she would wish to be reminded of.

The schlock auteur is currently negotiating with American censors to pass his 1992 picture Fire on the Amazon for cinema release. Bullock stars alongside Craig Sheffer, and one scene finds the actors indulging in what the production-notes decorously describe as "passionate, canine-style love-making in the jungle".

Fire on the Amazon was originally rated R back in 1994. But Corman has since added a further five seconds to the infamous "canine-style" extravaganza, and the MPAA has now decided that the new version merits a prohibitive NC17 rating. "The board says the movie is obscene, which is ridiculous," Corman told Variety. He is planning to screen the movie at this month's American Film Market convention, and worries that the new rating will scare off potential buyers. Corman is considering appealing the decision but refuses to tone down the offending scene. Bullock has yet to be drawn on the matter.

Ecstasy star Lamarr dead at 86

Once billed as the most beautiful woman in the world, the actress Hedy Lamarr was found dead at her home in Orlando, Florida. She was 86 years old.

Lamarr was born Hedwig Eva Maria Kieslar in Vienna, and rose to fame in a clutch of Austro-German films before making her Hollywood debut with Algiers. Her combination of raven hair, porcelain skin and almond eyes entranced 1930s film-goers, while her upfront sexuality stirred up controversy within middle America. She went down in film folklore for her famous nude bathing scene in the 1932 erotic classic Ecstasy - filmed just before the Hays Code imposed a rigid set of guidelines on screen sex.

Lamarr lost out to Ingrid Bergman in the race to star in Casablanca, and in the 40s and 50s her acting career faltered. "The problem is that I'm a hell of a nice dame," Lamarr mused to an interviewer in 1970. "The most horrible whores are famous. I did what I did for love. The others did it for money."

Mendes goes on the record

Acclaimed first-time film director, Sam Mendes' American Beauty opens in the UK next week. The former theatre director's movie arrives with a very impressive collection of award nominations, and is hotly tipped for Oscar success.

In keeping with the mythical status that is starting to attach itself to the British wunderkind, Mendes says Alan Ball's script was pushed across a restaurant table by Steven Spielberg himself. But in an interview in today's Independent, Mendes admits that on first impressions he wasn't particularly enamoured of the script, and it wasn't until he read on and saw the layering of textures that he came round.

Making the film was a learning process which was largely a case of discovering what he get rid of - cutting away superfluous scenes, freeing the sets from unnecessary clutter and moving the film towards a greater sense of ambiguity. Mendes relates how he was wary of indulging his new-found liberties too far, especially the lure of the close-up, and the (particularly non-theatrical) ability to control exactly what the audience should look at. "One of the things I did was to cut out a silhouette of the front row in a cinema audience and stick it on the monitor screenÄ just to remind me that this is a 40-foot screen."

Casting couch

fields.bodyText: The Sundance International Film Festival kicks off today amid whispers that the world's premiere low-budget showcase is losing touch with its independent roots. This year's event boasts a line-up more suited to a mainstream festival - films showing include: The Big Kahuna starring Kevin Spacey, Ethan Hawke's Hamlet, Ben Affleck in The Boiler Room (pictured), the provocative American Psycho and the Robert Altman-produced Trixie, starring Nick Nolte and Emily Watson. All of these have already been snapped up for domestic distribution. Sundance - which plays out near Robert Redford's ranch in Park City, Utah - was initially conceived as a showcase where small-scale, independently-produced pictures could find a buyer. Last year, the event scored a major coup with The Blair Witch Project, which was bought by Artisan Entertainment for $1m and went on to earn more than $140m at the American box-office. Writing in the LA Times, Kenneth Turan criticised the current state of Redford's festival. "It's difficult to think of Sundance as a place where films are shown. It's become, partly by happenstance, partly by design, a kind of multicultural circus, a self-fulfilling prophecy more than a festival." On a more encouraging note, 26% of the 112 films or so on offer are from women directors - a higher percentage than ever before.  Sundance opens today with the premiere of the Thanksgiving comedy What's Cooking? and finishes on January 29 with an awards presentation for the Best Feature and Best Documentary. Beatty in line for lifetime-achievement Oscar It has been confirmed that Warren Beatty is to receive a lifetime achievement award at this year's Oscar ceremony. The President of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Science, Robert Rehme, explained that: "in discussing this award for Warren, our governors stressed his passion for film, for getting it just right, and his courage in producing pictures that many other producers might have considered too dangerous to try." Previous recipients have included Walt Disney, Alfred Hitchcock, Ingmar Bergman and Clint Eastwood. Beatty, who missed out on a Best Screenplay award for his political satire Bulworth last year, is expected to attend the ceremony.  The prestigious Irving Thalberg Memorial Award will be presented to the 62-year-old actor and film-maker at the 72nd annual Academy Awards on March 26. Bullock bitten by 'canine-style' Corman film From Jack Nicholson to Francis Coppola, Martin Scorsese to John Sayles, many of Hollywood's biggest hitters owe their first break to fabled B-movie producer Roger Corman. For Sandra Bullock, however, the experience is not likely to be one she would wish to be reminded of. The schlock auteur is currently negotiating with American censors to pass his 1992 picture Fire on the Amazon for cinema release. Bullock stars alongside Craig Sheffer, and one scene finds the actors indulging in what the production-notes decorously describe as "passionate, canine-style love-making in the jungle". Fire on the Amazon was originally rated R back in 1994. But Corman has since added a further five seconds to the infamous "canine-style" extravaganza, and the MPAA has now decided that the new version merits a prohibitive NC17 rating. "The board says the movie is obscene, which is ridiculous," Corman told Variety. He is planning to screen the movie at this month's American Film Market convention, and worries that the new rating will scare off potential buyers. Corman is considering appealing the decision but refuses to tone down the offending scene. Bullock has yet to be drawn on the matter. Ecstasy star Lamarr dead at 86 Once billed as the most beautiful woman in the world, the actress Hedy Lamarr was found dead at her home in Orlando, Florida. She was 86 years old. Lamarr was born Hedwig Eva Maria Kieslar in Vienna, and rose to fame in a clutch of Austro-German films before making her Hollywood debut with Algiers. Her combination of raven hair, porcelain skin and almond eyes entranced 1930s film-goers, while her upfront sexuality stirred up controversy within middle America. She went down in film folklore for her famous nude bathing scene in the 1932 erotic classic Ecstasy - filmed just before the Hays Code imposed a rigid set of guidelines on screen sex. Lamarr lost out to Ingrid Bergman in the race to star in Casablanca, and in the 40s and 50s her acting career faltered. "The problem is that I'm a hell of a nice dame," Lamarr mused to an interviewer in 1970. "The most horrible whores are famous. I did what I did for love. The others did it for money." Mendes goes on the record Acclaimed first-time film director, Sam Mendes' American Beauty opens in the UK next week. The former theatre director's movie arrives with a very impressive collection of award nominations, and is hotly tipped for Oscar success. fields.headline: I feel, therefore I am
fields.standfirst: Who am I? Where do I come from? And what shall I have for supper? The great questions of human self-awareness may never be answered. But a leading neurologist believes our emotions are the key to the last great scientific enigma - consciousness.  Tim Radford  meets Antonio Damasio
fields.trailText: Antonio Damasio makes himself up as he goes along. Every waking moment, he is engaged in the study of his identity. Beyond the core self - the man who absent-mindedly picks up the orange juice or steps around the furniture - is an autobiographical fiction; he is an actor in a drama he writes for himself.
fields.body:
Antonio Damasio makes himself up as he goes along. Every waking moment, he is engaged in the study of his identity. Beyond the core self - the man who absent-mindedly picks up the orange juice or steps around the furniture - is an autobiographical fiction; he is an actor in a drama he writes for himself.

At least, that's how the Van Allen distinguished professor at the University of Iowa college of medicine sees it. Damasio is one of a worldwide brainstorm of neurologists exploring the great question of consciousness, the inexplicable mystery of why humans know who they are, where they came from and what they would really like for supper. And the key, for him, is that all human identity is a kind of fiction. We are all engaged in a process of self-creation.

"I make a distinction: there is the very simple self, the core self, something for which you do not need memory, for which you do not need language - you just have a feeling of being," he says. "Then there is the other self, which is the autobiographical, which gives us the sense that we have an identity, we have a personhood. We even have names for that collection, that history, and that is something very elaborate that I regard as a fiction, a literary fiction - something that we have built on the basis of events that have happened to us, and events that have not yet happened but that we presume will happen."

The centrepiece of Damasio's exploration is the brain; it is a spongy bundle of nerve cells not much heavier than a bag of sugar, just a virtual-reality headset internally fitted before birth, but each human brain becomes capable of containing and traversing the entire human universe.

It is part of the machinery of life management - it keeps the heart beating and the fight-or-flight machinery prepared for danger, and tells you when you are hungry - but it can also stun you with questions such as, "What was there before time began?" or "Why didn't they christen him Beckenham Beckham? Or maybe Penge?" Damasio, like his colleagues, is probing science's last great mystery, unravelling the enigma of the human mind, the thing inside that interprets the firings of the neurons and conjures up an "I" to watch the movie in the brain.

He is, however, at odds with many of his colleagues. Some of them think consciousness is an evolutionary adaptation conferring advantage in survival; some of them argue that the higher consciousness grew out of a capacity for language. He agrees with neither. He has a gut response, a visceral feeling that something else was at work first. He believes that human identity is a sensational response - a way of coping not just with feelings but with an awareness of those feelings. The human mind is a way of coping with fear, anger, disgust, laughter and other things as well: awe, social embarrassment, guilt and so on. These are all feelings, sensations, chemical events, changes in heart rate, skin responses. Knowledge of them is part of the bargain humans make with creation. Sea anemones and snails have feelings, but humans write novels about them. "The cost of a better existence is the loss of innocence about that very existence," Damasio writes. "The feeling of what happens is the answer to a question we never asked."

That is why he called his new book The Feeling of What Happens. He wanted to get the idea of feeling in before the idea of consciousness. "A lot of our constructions, such as morality and empathy and sympathy, really come from the fact that we feel, we know that we feel, and all of that comes from deep within, and is inseparable from being alive. Art is already an expression of a concern. I like the word concern."

Damasio was born in Portugal in 1944, and grew up in the shadow of the dictator Salazar. From his earliest years, he was fascinated by how things worked, by engines made from Meccano. He went from there to the mechanisms of the mind, dithered about being a writer or philosopher, and then read about brain research and said: "'This is exactly what I want to do!' I went into medical school and straight into the thing that interested me most."

Well into his career as a neurologist - he has a chair at the Salk Institute in La Jolla, California, as well as a department in Iowa - he began to get interested in cases of frontal-lobe damage. The most famous was that of a railway worker called Phineas Gage, who in 1848 was in the wrong place when an explosive charge was ignited. The blast drove an iron spike right through his skull and out the other side. Before the accident Gage was well-liked and was considered honest, trustworthy and dependable. With a hole in his frontal neocortex, he became vulgar, irresponsible, capricious and prone to offensive profanity.

The case was a classic piece of evidence that personality and identity were creations of the brain, and that the brain was a machine into which spanners could be thrown. Damasio, however, was more interested in the lesson to be drawn from the way patients with frontal-lobe damage will take decisions.

"What they have is an inability to decide correctly; they do it in a setting where the emotions are gone. If you suffer damage to your frontal lobe, especially in a particular territory, you will maintain your overt intelligence. You speak normally, you are very smart, you have lots of memory - and you make the most foolish decisions in relation to you, to your family, your work. In essence you go from being a productive member of society to a rather sociopathic kind of person."

"The big distinction is that you no longer have an ability to emote and feel normally, especially in relation to the social emotions. You don't feel embarrassment, you don't feel guilt - you don't feel pride for that matter - and so your ability to reason properly has been lost, together with your ability to feel properly. And that is what put me on to the idea that emotion is really the only explanation for this kind of problem. All my work starts from there."

In short, humans feel, therefore they are. The mind could not exist without a body to inhabit - even if, paradoxically, everything to be known is known through the mind. Humans don't just experience risk, danger and pain, they know they experience risk, danger and pain. That is the first step on the journey to consciousness and, ultimately, to the higher consciousness that - helped by prodigious memory and fed by a fantastic capacity for language - leads to art and philosophy and the creation of conscience. Damasio thinks conscience is one of humankind's great creations.

"You cannot create conscience, you cannot create a sense of moral good and moral evil, if you do not have a sense of self. You need to have a sense of self first. Although I think religion of itself is another of our great creations, conscience, religion, morals, arts and science are different, very important human creations. But I think you can have a moral sense without practising a religion."

People ask him, "Aren't you afraid of solving the problem of consciousness? Aren't you afraid of taking away the mystery?" Not at all. Consciousness is not the problem of mind, consciousness is the problem of knowing we own a mind. There is a difference between having a movie in the brain and knowing that this movie is different from someone else's. That is a problem neuroscientists might be able to solve.

"But how we begin to generate, from matter, the pictures in our brain?" he says. "That is a little bit more complicated."

fields.headline: House of cards
fields.standfirst:
As Lord Wakeham unveils his plans to reform the House of Lords, Martin Wainwright ponders the question of what we can expect for Britain's new upper house
Plus: Signs of the times
fields.trailText: The pained voices on the radio today spoke their own epitaph. Yes, it was true as they said that they had worked unselfishly for years, and it was easy to sympathise when they complained that it had all ended so suddenly and with little thanks.
fields.body:
The pained voices on the radio today spoke their own epitaph. Yes, it was true as they said that they had worked unselfishly for years, and it was easy to sympathise when they complained that it had all ended so suddenly and with little thanks.

But the accents were so uniformly cut glass; not just posh, but redolent of Pathé News reels of 80 years ago or those quaint, early Ealing comedies where chirpy errand boys speak in the thinly disguised tones of Eton. It is the year 2000 after all, and a very long time since most of us echoed Gilbert and Sullivan's claim that "We love our House of Peers".

Even in 1882, when G&S's Iolanthe first wowed audiences at the Savoy theatre in London, sarcasm about the odd make-up of the second chamber was common currency. The operetta may have turned the lord chancellor and all his ermined colleagues into contented fairies, but they don't so much float off stage at the end as get the boot.

"Well, now that the peers are to be recruited entirely from persons of intelligence, I really don't see what use we are down here, do you?" the fictional Earl of Mountararat asks his counterpart Lord Tolloller. "None whatever," comes the reply. The audiences roared, but were content (scarcely half of them had a vote) to do nothing about it.

Now that we have, suddenly and with the absence of fuss which marks one of our occasional, deep, national changes of mood, there is no need to fret if we fail to get the new second chamber immediately right. The complaint that Blair has acted against the hereditaries "without knowing what to put in their place" is an old chestnut. Nothing would ever be altered if its perfect replacement had to be ready to hand.

Government in this country is firmly in the hands of the Commons - indeed absolutely so, whatever the polite fictions about the Lords having to agree and the sovereign needing to sign bills. This is not the United States, with its delicate balance between Congress, Senate and presidency, all of which have the sacred endorsement of the People's vote. We elect only the Commons and accept that they can tell us to do anything they want.

An elected element in the Lords may be the beginning of a fundamental change in that social contract, but all the more reason why the process should take place in stages - testing various ratios of appointment to election, or selection from a sub-group such as the English regions or even the random citizens' element obtainable by "jury choice", picking names from the electoral roll.

The trick to turn is the difficult one of combining expertise with a genuine cross-section of 21st-century Britain, in a way which those pained, aristocratic voices have failed to do. The fact that the present Lord Nelson is a Bradford police sergeant is not enough; for all its uncertainties, the Wakeham commission is the start of a journey to something consistent, reliable and multi-voiced - in the broad northern vowels, west-country burrs and Geordie singsong which Wakeham's elected regional peers would bring.

Related documentary
Lords reform: special report

Signs of the times

There is something wonderfully rich about the department of the environment, transport and the regions' (DETR) refusal to let Liverpool add "birthplace of the Beatles" to its road signs, on the grounds that motorists would be confused by so much text as they hurtle by. It is true that too many hoardings can clutter the landscape (even the much criticised Americans recognise this by making their multitude of road signs much smaller than ours). But the DETR are absolute specialists in baffling travellers.

I can speak in detail only of west Yorkshire, but I'm sure that people out there also have local treasures of their own. Certainly round Leeds, Bradford and Halifax, a failure to keep up with the effects of time and weather have long reduced major signs into an incomprehensible (though strangely attractive) cuneiform.

At Odsal Top for instance, the huge green sign points mysteriously to "road...arro...at...ei...hley...kipt". By the time you - or more probably your children - have worked out that this once read "Ring road Harrogate Keighley Skipton", you are miles away. Go on, DETR - why don't you let the Scousers have an "erp...Bir...plac...he...eatl" sign to intrigue a few more passers-by?

fields.headline: All about deals and fixes
fields.standfirst: Guardian columnist David Mckie gives his immediate reaction to the Wakeham report
fields.trailText: Guardian columnist David Mckie (left) gives his immediate reaction to the Wakeham report.
fields.body:
To give them their due, Lord Wakeham and his commission, who reported today on reform of the House of Lords, were wrestling with problems which have eluded every attempt to solve them in 90 years. Back in 1911, parliament agreed to an interim solution for the second chamber, to last only until a way was found of replacing hereditary peers. Every effort to find a new pattern thereafter foundered. Although there was broad support for ending the right of people (nearly all of them men) to speak and vote in Parliament merely through the accident of birth, no formula could be found for a new, democratic chamber, able to monitor and challenge governments without constituting a rival power base to the Commons.

Lord Wakeham's team has failed too. It was given a year to deliberate, but even two years, or ten, would not have resolved its differences. The fact that a former chief whip was chairman guaranteed what kind of committee this was going to be. It was all about deals and fixes. It was not going to waste its effort on finding the "best" solution, in terms of ensuring good government or serving the interests of the voters, since however sublime a solution may be, it has little practical value if politicians are not going to buy it. So the Wakeham commission set out to devise a formula acceptable first to the prime minister and then to the parliament which would be called on time to push these changes through. That virtually excluded any recommendation for a second chamber elected by popular vote, as recommended by the Liberal Democrats and to some extent by the Conservative party. The government was not having that: too difficult to control. An elected second chamber would be able to call itself as democratically legitimate as the Commons, creating a check on untrammelled government power as formidable as the Commons - and probably very much more so than a Commons as docile as this one.

And so they arrived at a botch. Some elected members should sit in the new second chamber, yes - though they could not agree how many - but only as a minority in an otherwise hand-picked assembly. Nor could the commission agree on a new name for the chamber, or on what its members should call themselves - senators, members of the Lords, or whatever. Despite their attempts to please it, the government's first response has been unenthusiastic, and it's hard to see anyone else being keener. It seems entirely possible that the "interim" solution, instituted last year after the despatch of most hereditary peers, could be with us for quite some time - which will mean that some ninety hereditaries, given a "temporary" reprieve at that time, will be sitting there for another decade or more. Which is what, one suspects, that wily Tory bird Lord Cranborne, member of one of the House's oldest families and architect of the plan which saved the 92 hereditary peers from extinction, was banking on all along.

fields.headline: Lords reform: who said what
fields.trailText: Lord Wakeham, Tory peer and chairman of the royal commission
fields.body:
Lord Wakeham, Tory peer and chairman of the royal commission

"The royal commission was not set a simple question and our report does not provide a simple answer.

"We very much hope that it will prove possible to move rapidly to the next stage.

"But, if interested parties choose to hold out for what they would ideally like, the opportunity may pass for another generation, maybe another century. If they are prepared like us to go back to first principles and ask the same questions, we believe they will recognise the force of our argument and that these will provide a firm foundation on which to build a house for the future - authoritative, confident and broadly representative of the United Kingdom."

"Above all, we wanted to produce a chamber with the authority and confidence to carry out a vital role at the heart of the United Kingdom's system of parliamentary democracy. It must have the authority to force the government and the House of Commons to think again and the confidence to use its powers wisely and effectively.

"However, the second chamber should not just be another home for professional politicians - there would be no point in having a second chamber identical to the House of Commons."

"[The commission members] are totally agreed that there should be a minority of regional members, we are totally agreed on the length of the term that they should serve, we are all agreed they should not be able to stand again and we are also agreed on the restriction of their ability to go back to the House of Commons. The only bit we are disagreeing about is exactly the numbers and the way we do it."

Margaret Jay, leader of the House of Lords

"The royal commission was set a complex and difficult task to be completed within a demanding timetable. I am grateful to Lord Wakeham and to all the commissioners for their hard work and commitment in producing this carefully considered and thoughtful report and for meeting the government's tight deadlines.

"The government will need time to consider the recommendations made by the royal commission. However, it is very welcome that the commissioners have produced a unanimous report as this provides a sound platform for moving forward on a genuine cross party basis."

Liberal Democrat spokesman Robert Maclennan:

"This report is shot through with dismal, old-fashioned, self-serving clubby attitudes. If its recommendations were to be given effect, the Lords would continue to be illegitimate and the public would properly disregard it.

"This is probably the least persuasive royal commission report to have been issued in my political lifetime. It is neither informed by democratic principle nor a practical concern to strengthen parliament's capability to oversee the work of central government."

"This report cannot form the sole basis of the discussions which will now start about the future of the second chamber. Liberal Democrats have proposed a wholly elected house with greater powers than the present one. The all-party committee of the two houses of parliament must give due consideration to these proposals which, unlike those of the Wakeham commission, would further the cause of democracy in Britain."
