fields.headline: A religious experience
fields.standfirst: It's done big business in the US and opens here tomorrow. Rupert Wainwright tells Film Unlimited about Stigmata
fields.trailText: It's not a horror movie, it's more of a love story. Its creator is an atheist who's made a movie about the Catholic church. Stigmata, the American blockbuster by British director Rupert Wainwright is a film that defies easy categorisation. Starring Patricia Arquette as a Pittsburgh hairdresser who finds herself afflicted by stigmata wounds, and Gabriel Bryne as the priest the Vatican (headed by a malignant Jonathan Pryce) sends to investigate, the film is tightly paced, entertaining and stylish - bearing more than a little resemblance to the MTV pop videos that Wainwright cut his teeth on.
fields.body:
It's not a horror movie, it's more of a love story. Its creator is an atheist who's made a movie about the Catholic church. Stigmata, the American blockbuster by British director Rupert Wainwright is a film that defies easy categorisation. Starring Patricia Arquette as a Pittsburgh hairdresser who finds herself afflicted by stigmata wounds, and Gabriel Bryne as the priest the Vatican (headed by a malignant Jonathan Pryce) sends to investigate, the film is tightly paced, entertaining and stylish - bearing more than a little resemblance to the MTV pop videos that Wainwright cut his teeth on.

Wainwright denies that his movie is jumping on the current anti-Vatican bandwagon. "A good movie has to be pro something," he argues, but "those guys have had such an easy time of it for the last 2,000 years it's about time someone took them on." However, he adds mischievously, "I had my son christened before the movie came out - in case no-one would do it afterwards."

The story of the missing fifth gospel (which New Testament experts put as the most accurate and contemporaneous of all accounts of Christ's life, but whose veracity the Catholic Church denies) forms the basis of the tale, but was actually added to the original script at the director's instigation. "I was obsessed by it" says Wainwright, who found himself involved in the writing to a large extent. Similarly the developing relationship between the two central characters, which now forms the crux of the story, was introduced at a later stage.

Wainwright's original ending was modified following test screenings. The one cinema audiences will see makes concessions to the studio's wish for a happy ending, and is not the director's choice. If you're curious, wait for the DVD release which will feature two versions of the ending, and is perhaps the first truly interactive DVD: viewers can choose at the beginning which version they'd rather watch.

The film itself owes much to Ken Russell's Altered States and Jacob's Ladder. Wainwright went to the trouble of hiring Jacob's Ladder cameraman Jeffrey Kimball because he wanted to convey a similar look. The influence of seminal British psycho-drama Don't Look Now is also evident - Stigmata uses the same palette of muted colours offset against a garish red.

Wainwright's past career has included a part in 1984's Another Country (he played Devenish), ballet dancing, and ad and pop video directing. He was discreet over what it was like to work with Michael Jackson on the promo for 1994's History' but did concede that he is "really obsessive a Howard Hughes character," and confirmed that Jackon's entourage then included the world's smallest dwarf. Employed as a security guard, no less.

As for his next projects, the California resident says he'd love to make a film in his native UK, but there are fewer opportunities here, and the whole process strikes him as too labyrinthine. Wainwright is currently involved in a Jim Carrey-produced female action thriller set in Shanghai, and is developing a movie about the National Rifle Association. Not surprisingly, this is proving hard to get off the ground in a nation where the right to bear arms remains a political hot potato. Still, having managed to make a film which lambasts the Vatican and seriously suggests that a non-believing modern woman receives all five Stigmata wounds, a movie on the NRA should be no problem.

fields.headline: Trouble in Tinseltown
fields.standfirst: Once again, Hollywood is gearing up for the award ceremonies that help celebrate - and sell - its movies. But behind the spectacle and tear-stained speeches, the industry is in difficulty.  Duncan Campbell  tells a story of job losses, high-profile defections and fierce criticism of the way the studios work
fields.trailText: Once again, Hollywood is gearing up for the award ceremonies that help celebrate - and sell - its movies. But behind the spectacle and tear-stained speeches, the industry is in difficulty. Duncan Campbell tells a story of job losses, high-profile defections and fierce criticism of the way the studios work
fields.body:
It's prize-giving time in Hollywood. On Sunday, the Golden Globes will be handed out at a ceremony in Beverly Hills. Next month, the nominations for the Oscars will be announced and three weeks later many of the same people who will be gratefully thanking their agents and their grandmothers for helping them to carry off a Globe statuette will be doing the same to a slightly larger audience as they receive their Oscars.

Unless anyone actually dedicates their award to, say, "Fidel, Saddam and Yasser for all their help and inspiration over the years", the ceremonies themselves are likely to run smoothly. It has been a while since a winner took a deep breath and brought a political note to the proceedings. To do so is a bit like proposing a toast at a family gathering and talking about your father's incestuous tendencies (see Thomas Winterberg's Festen for the effect this causes). But this year's ceremonies will have an edge to them for a very different reason.

They will cap a tempestuous year in Hollywood which has seen more than 20,000 jobs lost as productions take cheaper roads to Canada, Mexico and Australia, a host of high profile defections and, most recently, a bruising critique unleashed by two senior industry figures.

The announcement of the Globe nominations came as Tinseltown was digesting the departure from the studio world of Joe Roth, the highly respected chairman of Walt Disney Studios, who announced that he was quitting to join the independent sector because he felt he would be happier free from the corporate constraints of a major publicly-held media company.

His reservations about the studio system are echoed by two new books which question what has happened to the industry and how the structural changes affect the kind of films being produced. So what is going on?

In Who Killed Hollywood and Put the Tarnish on Tinseltown? the editor-in-chief of Variety, the industry newspaper, Peter Bart, argues that "the studios have lost their identities . . . they've been relegated to a new role as mere appendages of vast multinational corporations grinding out 'content' for their global distribution mills. Hollywood's assembly line has been scaled down and re-tooled not only to feed the world's movie theatres and television screens but also to channel new product and ideas into theme-park rides, music, toys, video game emporiums and all the other ancillary goodies that enhance the revenue streams of their corporate parents."

Another book, Where Did I Go Right? You're No-one in Hollywood Unless Someone Wants You Dead - death seems to be a must in these book titles, this is Hollywood - features Bernie Brillstein, the veteran producer, manager and former studio chief, lamenting the arrival of a new breed of executive who once would have chosen to work on Wall Street but has come west to the film industry: "My contemporaries were streetwise people. Sure, you could make money - and we wanted to - but nowhere near the kind of money you can make in the business today . . . Too many of today's showbusiness players just want to make the money their clients make. If power and notoriety are part of the bargain, all the better."

The result of the change, suggests Peter Bart, who was once a studio executive at Paramount and MGM/United Artists, is not only that fewer films are being made but that productions are chosen for being as "risk averse" as possible; they are chosen because they will appeal to financing and marketing partners rather than an audience.

"Today the decision on whether to green-light a movie may involve scores of executives, with the debate hingeing on questions like: will the movie play well in Europe and Asia? Will the subject matter attract a marketing partner like a McDonald's? Will there be tie-ins for toys? Will the star be willing to travel to openings around the world?" concludes Bart.

This part of his argument can be backed up by figures released last week for the international box office receipts of American films. It is only since 1996 that the money taken from the international market has exceeded the revenues from the US market.

Last year, 16 American films took more than $100m abroad. The message in the studios has to be: make the films that will make money abroad. This means make them to existing formulas, heavily promoted, expertly packaged and overwhelmingly predictable.

It is a gratifying rebuke to this formulaic approach that many of the films in the running for awards this season address themselves to the dark as opposed to the redemptive side of the American psyche. The leading contenders for Globes - and, most likely, Oscars, whose shortlist is announced on February 15 - include films which expose corporate corruption (The Insider); satirise suburban emptiness (American Beauty); portray a young woman who tried to be a man (Boys Don't Cry); satirise suburban emptiness (The Election); portray a psychopath sympathetically (The Talented Mr Ripley) and expose the fatally - literally - flawed system of American justice (The Hurricane.)

The merger between Time-Warner and America Online has merely fuelled the argument that multi-media ownership will lead to bland product and that every arm of a conglomerate will be required to operate on behalf of the studio's product. A conglomerate's magazines will get access to stars to plug that conglomerate's films which will be sympathetically handled on that conglomerate's television channel while tie-in marketing items are sold in that conglomerate's stores. Bart and Brillstein are hardly outsiders railing against the evils of capitalism and their disenchantment is an indication of the wider malaise and disillusionment in the business.

Writer-director Ron Shelton (Bull Durham, White Men Can't Jump) has this week been promoting his new film, Play It to the Bone starring Woody Harrelson and Antonio Banderas. He has used the occasion to attack the studios for their narrow views and obsession with marketing and demographics at the expense of film-making.

Not everyone, of course, buys the pessimistic take on what has been happening in the film industry over the past decade. Lynda Obst, a producer at Paramount, is the author of Hello, He Lied and Other Truths from the Hollywood Trenches. (Can't anyone write a two-word book title any more?) Obst is less impressed about the great old days. In a tongue in cheek review of Brillstein's book in the Los Angeles Times last week, Obst thanks him for clarifying a number of things about studio executives: that they are mostly in the business for the sex. "Showbusiness has always been a great trade-off, a way to get laid because most men in that line of work are, let's face it, not that attractive," says Brillstein.

Obst notes: "He said it . . . Chicks in flicks hate the game part. We wish we could just make the movie and go home to dinner."

Another woman producer who has written about her experience of the movie business is Christine Vachon who was responsible for Safe, I Shot Andy Warhol and Velvet Godmine and has described the process in her book, Shooting to Kill (death, again.) In her list of dos and don'ts for would-be independent film-makers she includes the advice: "Never compare your film to Mean Streets . . . I hope that the film-makers I work with are not simply trying to rehash elements from financially successful films. Do that song and dance when you pitch to Paramount."

And so to the Globes, the awards made by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association (HFPA ) which currently consists of 84 foreign journalists who cover Hollywood for their own countries. The awards started in 1944 and the event was low-key and pretty much unremarked outside Los Angeles. When it was first screened on television in 1995 it attracted an audience of 7m. Now the event is networked and last year attracted 50m, a figure which will certainly be exceeded this year.

What is interesting is the way in which the film industry has helped to give the event a credibility it might never have had, for the HPFA has had a lingering reputation for containing more that its fair share of star-struck oddballs who knew little about film - some were not even journalists - but a lot about receiving hospitality. One American Hollywood critic described them as the only people he knew who lived entirely off hors d'oeuvres. However, the current executive is anxious to say that those days have gone, and to clean up the organisation's image.

Certainly their choices, as evidenced in the shortlists, correspond largely with those of their more thoughtful US counterparts. It is the independent films - whether genuinely independent or made by one of the big studios' "independent" arms - that are being lauded.

The Golden Globes ceremony has been wholly embraced by the studios which have a chance before the Oscars for their films to be brought to the attention of 50m-plus television viewers, a wonderfully cost- effective marketing opportunity. Variety has devoted a special issue to the event, even listing details of the best ways to enter post-award parties at the Beverly Hills Hilton. (To get to the rooftop bash, take the elevator to the fourth floor and walk down the long corridor to the exit that opens on to the garage roof.)

One of the regular features at the Oscars which always produces a discreet flutter of handkerchiefs in the audience is the review of all the actors who have died in the previous year, with clips from their old films shown. One of those who will feature at this year's ceremony will be George C Scott, who died last year aged 71. He was nominated four times for an Oscar and won in 1970 for his portrayal of General Patton in the eponymous film, but didn't accept the statuette. He described the ceremony thus: "A meaningless, self-serving meat parade. It is barbarous and innately corrupt."

The studios will be watching the results of both the Globes and the Oscars closely because they see them as far from barbarous and certainly not meaningless. The Globes now quite closely foreshadow the Oscars and many critics and film industry people feel that nothing would be better for the business than a healthy round of victories to go to films that do not seem to have been made according to formulas and with marketing tie-ins in mind.

For all the departure of business across the nearest foreign borders, Hollywood is still healthy and highly profitable and is not suddenly going to abandon making films that will generate a predictable profit.

However, if the dark and the quirky and the unpredictable in film-making can be shown to succeed at the highest level, winning prizes and making bucks as they do, there will be a hope that America's burgeoning independent sector can make more of the kind of fresh, original, dangerous films that people would, well, kill to see.

It is only since 1996 that the money taken from the international market has exceeded the revenues from the US market. Last year, 16 American films took more than $100m abroad. The message in the studios has to be: make the films that will make money abroad. This means make them to existing formulas, heavily promoted, expertly packaged and overwhelmingly predictable. It is a gratifying rebuke to this formulaic approach that many of the films in the running for awards this season address themselves to the dark as opposed to the redemptive side of the American psyche. The leading contenders for Globes - and, most likely, Oscars, whose shortlist is announced on February 15 - include films which expose corporate corruption (The Insider); satirise suburban emptiness (American Beauty); portray a young woman who tried to be a man (Boys Don't Cry); satirise suburban emptiness (The Election); portray a psychopath sympathetically (The Talented Mr Ripley) and expose the fatally - literally - flawed system of American justice (The Hurricane.) The merger between Time-Warner and America Online has merely fuelled the argument that multi-media ownership will lead to bland product and that every arm of a conglomerate will be required to operate on behalf of the studio's product. A conglomerate's magazines will get access to stars to plug that conglomerate's films which will be sympathetically handled on that conglomerate's television channel while tie-in marketing items are sold in that conglomerate's stores. Bart and Brillstein are hardly outsiders railing against the evils of capitalism and their disenchantment is an indication of the wider malaise and disillusionment in the business. Writer-director Ron Shelton (Bull Durham, White Men Can't Jump) has this week been promoting his new film, Play It to the Bone starring Woody Harrelson and Antonio Banderas. He has used the occasion to attack the studios for their narrow views and obsession with marketing and demographics at the expense of film-making. Not everyone, of course, buys the pessimistic take on what has been happening in the film industry over the past decade. Lynda Obst, a producer at Paramount, is the author of Hello, He Lied and Other Truths from the Hollywood Trenches. (Can't anyone write a two-word book title any more?) Obst is less impressed about the great old days. In a tongue in cheek review of Brillstein's book in the Los Angeles Times last week, Obst thanks him for clarifying a number of things about studio executives: that they are mostly in the business for the sex. "Showbusiness has always been a great trade-off, a way to get laid because most men in that line of work are, let's face it, not that attractive," says Brillstein. Obst notes: "He said it . . . Chicks in flicks hate the game part. We wish we could just make the movie and go home to dinner." Another woman producer who has written about her experience of the movie business is Christine Vachon who was responsible for Safe, I Shot Andy Warhol and Velvet Godmine and has described the process in her book, Shooting to Kill (death, again.) In her list of dos and don'ts for would-be independent film-makers she includes the advice: "Never compare your film to Mean Streets . . . I hope that the film-makers I work with are not simply trying to rehash elements from financially successful films. Do that song and dance when you pitch to Paramount." And so to the Globes, the awards made by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association (HFPA ) which currently consists of 84 foreign journalists who cover Hollywood for their own countries. The awards started in 1944 and the event was low-key and pretty much unremarked outside Los Angeles. When it was first screened on television in 1995 it attracted an audience of 7m. Now the event is networked and last year attracted 50m, a figure which will certainly be exceeded this year. What is interesting is the way in which the film industry has helped to give the event a credibility it might never have had, for the HPFA has had a lingering reputation for containing more that its fair share of star-struck oddballs who knew little about film - some were not even journalists - but a lot about receiving hospitality. One American Hollywood critic described them as the only people he knew who lived entirely off hors d'oeuvres. However, the current executive is anxious to say that those days have gone, and to clean up the organisation's image. Certainly their choices, as evidenced in the shortlists, correspond largely with those of their more thoughtful US counterparts. It is the independent films - whether genuinely independent or made by one of the big studios' "independent" arms - that are being lauded. The Golden Globes ceremony has been wholly embraced by the studios which have a chance before the Oscars for their films to be brought to the attention of 50m-plus television viewers, a wonderfully cost- effective marketing opportunity. Variety has devoted a special issue to the event, even listing details of the best ways to enter post-award parties at the Beverly Hills Hilton. (To get to the rooftop bash, take the elevator to the fourth floor and walk down the long corridor to the exit that opens on to the garage roof.) One of the regular features at the Oscars which always produces a discreet flutter of handkerchiefs in the audience is the review of all the actors who have died in the previous year, with clips from their old films shown. One of those who will feature at this year's ceremony will be George C Scott, who died last year aged 71. He was nominated four times for an Oscar and won in 1970 for his portrayal of General Patton in the eponymous film, but didn't accept the statuette. He described the ceremony thus: "A meaningless, self-serving meat parade. It is barbarous and innately corrupt." The studios will be watching the results of both the Globes and the Oscars closely because they see them as far from barbarous and certainly not meaningless. The Globes now quite closely foreshadow the Oscars and many critics and film industry people feel that nothing would be better for the business than a healthy round of victories to go to films that do not seem to have been made according to formulas and with marketing tie-ins in mind. For all the departure of business across the nearest foreign borders, Hollywood is still healthy and highly profitable and is not suddenly going to abandon making films that will generate a predictable profit. However, if the dark and the quirky and the unpredictable in film-making can be shown to succeed at the highest level, winning prizes and making bucks as they do, there will be a hope that America's burgeoning independent sector can make more of the kind of fresh, original, dangerous films that people would, well, kill to see.

webTitle: My life on the net: Glenys Kinnock MEP, Wales

fields.headline: My life on the net: Glenys Kinnock MEP, Wales
fields.trailText: www.oneworld.org/euforic
fields.body:
www.oneworld.org/euforic

My favourite website is called euforic - Europe's Forum on International Co-Operation - which gives an overview of development issues on debt, trade and a lot of emphasis on EU programmes. It provides, for instance, information on trade aid for African Caribbean and Pacific countries, and on the globalisation of trade. It's a very good site: user-friendly, speedy, topical, and written in a very accessible way. No matter what issue you're interested in, it crops up here.

There are a number of complex issues with which it deals very well:, for example, the World Trade Organisation in Seattle. It didn't just concentrate on the streets but on the nature of negotiations, the positions of the main negotiations, the role of developing countries.It's not written simply from a northern perspective. You never feel they're giving any kind of spin.

www.ft.com, www.theguardian.com

Newspapers online are equally indispensable in terms of research. There was a story yesterday we were looking at - the South Africa trade agreement with the EU - and we were able to access three pieces the FT had done in the last week. We generally look at the Guardian and the FT. The FT has a global archive, which comes in useful for us - the way we work in this parliament we specialise in areas. I'm responsible for Wales and the FT's global archive helps me access news from Wales at the touch of a key. The newspaper itself does a lot of work on trade issues. Of course, that's an important element in the EU.

In the work I do, the financial pages of Larry Elliott, Dan Atkinson, and a number of people at the Guardian who write on the issues with which I work would be natural to look at. On the other hand, it may be a feature piece - Polly Toynbee, for example - which I might refer to if I'm writing a speech. Newspapers online are useful because I can't read every paper from Caernarvon to Cardiff, but this way, I can quickly get the best of several.

webTitle: Web addresses: is yours a Mayfair or an Old Kent Road?

fields.headline: Web addresses: is yours a Mayfair or an Old Kent Road?
fields.standfirst:
Forget buying a personalised number plate - that's so 20th century. The must-have accessory, says Martin Clark, is a flashy web address
Get the most out of the net with Guardian Unlimited's guide to Life online
fields.trailText: Forget buying a personalised number plate - that's so 20th century - the must-have accessory, says Martin Clark, is a flashy web address
fields.body:
What's in a name? On the world wide web, perhaps millions of pounds. As e-commerce burst into the public consciousness last year, the scramble to establish a web presence began to reach gold rush proportions. And like shovel sellers who made a fortune from the prospectors, vendors of domain names have flourished now that the latest must-have accessory is a snappy web address.

Domain names are the unique part of the web address of a site, and as internet hype has snowballed, so has the rush to stake a claim in cyberspace. In the middle, in charge of this important part of the net's plumbing, is one US-based company: Network Solutions.

This fact has upset many people online. Six years ago, when your life was complete without the words "e-commerce" and "MP3", the US government handed to NSI some obscure rights to domain name suffixes, including those to the all important ".com" ending. The problems for NSI came when its obscure rights got the company placed right in the middle of one of the greatest revolutions of the 20th century.

When other companies saw NSI sitting unchallenged on top the domains goldmine, they began to cry foul. The disagreements were resolved only recently, when the US Department of Commerce chaired an agreement between NSI and a non profit organisation called the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (Icann).

Headed by Esther Dyson, "queen of the internet" and Online columnist, Icann won the right for approved companies to access the Whois database, where all .com, .org and .net info is listed. "We've all kissed and made up," she explained. "It is now clear... that the Whois database is available to anybody."

Agreement or not, NSI still hit the headlines several times recently.

First it had to withdraw almost a thousand domains it issued by mistake. Then a hacker tapped into NSI's database and began redirecting addresses to a single site. Netizens everywhere remain disgruntled.

To get yourself that snappy website name requires either skill or cash. The skill comes not in thinking up a neat name, but finding one that's available. Take a random choice such as, say, the unlikely "monkeyjuice", and you will quickly find that the name Monkeyjuice.com is taken, as are so many of the precious .com domains. Head to the handy search tool at NSI's site and you'll find all the three letter domains are long gone, even com.com's been snapped up.

But once you locate an available domain, follow the instructions (the "wizard" after the domain search), add your details then your credit card info and proceed to make your mark in cyberspace. One small step for man, one tiny but important drop in the virtual ocean for you.

The British domains are controlled by Nominet, a non-profit organisation given powers by NSI. Having recently lowered the cost of registering the co.uk domain, Nominet has seen an explosion of companies offering free, or practically free domains.

Additional interactive features like email may cost more. To register a co.uk name yourself, you have to contact one of the many internet service providers (ISPs) listed at Nominet. The database, however, suffered a serious crash on January 12. The website adds: "The full domain name index has been restored, but recovery of full registrant details continues."

To register a co.uk domain go to, for example, www.usp.net and insert your domain of choice into the "check availability" box. Follow the instructions, filling in your details and then credit card numbers.

If you don't have that skill or very good timing, then obtaining the perfect domain name will now cost you dearly. As the interest in the web has boomed, so has a lucrative cottage industry: playing the domain name game. For any company wanting to make an online impression, a memorable domain name is essential. And www.please/remember/this.sorrywhatdidyousay?simply won't cut it.

Many websites are discovered by word of mouth, and in this world ".com" is king. There are hundreds of domain names other than the .org, .com and .net suffixes.

These include the well known .co.uk, but vary to suit the colourful spectrum of nations whoch is now online [see http://uninett.no/navn/domreg.htm], such as .is or .fm. And this week the Italian domain name ".it" became available throughout Europe, making humour along the lines of www.shut.it and www.slap.it possible. Any remaining domain names - they were being snapped up quickly as we went to press -are available from Virtual Internet.

But beware gold rush style claim-jumpers. The internet has spawned its own, known as cybersquatters. While others were just starting to explore the internet, they jumped in and registered the best domain names. Then offered to sell them at a vast profit.

If you're in the spotlight, they're after your name. No one is safe, not even the world's richest man. Bill Gates might have built Microsoft, but he never thought to register the name billgates.co.uk. That domain was registered by a British businessman, who attempted to auction it for more than £2m. He now faces possible legal action from the software giant.

"We would object to anyone taking unfair advantage of the goodwill and recognition of Mr Gates' name and reputation," a Microsoft spokeswoman explained. The name has currently been withdrawn from sale.

Corporations and superstars alike have been caught unawares by quick witted cybersquatters. Brad Pitt was offered bradpitt.com for £16,000 and a 17-year-old boy registered the name of the global financial services firm Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, before they announced any online plans . Legal proceedings commenced when the teenager reject a $10,000 offer and demanded $75,000.

Registering trademarks as domain names can infringe copyright and invite legal action. But personal names like Faldo.com - currently up for auction at a price of £2m - escape due to a grey area of the law.

Other squatted domains seem aimed at specific companies, with www.ipcmags.com, freeserveonline.com and MTVBase.com perhaps more valuable to some than others.

Action has been promised. NSI recently reclaimed domains from many suspected squatters and entrepreneurs, claiming unpaid bills as the reason.

However, with the growing need for names, it will take much more than that to halt a healthy trade. Auction sites have sprung up for names such as greatdomains.com and names123.com. At greatdomains.com you could buy America.com - but bidding starts at $10m.

On a more positive note, sites like www.netnames.com, offer services to companies wishing to secure their trademarks beyond the obvious .com and .co.uk realms.

Taking an original approach is www.funmail.co.uk. Like greatdomains.com, this company buys up domain names, but then offers a free email service with the most original of names. If you've ever fancied being zoeball@horrendous.co.uk or hounddog@elvislives.co.uk, then now is your chance.

"We have a database of 14,000 domains," explains funmail co-founder Graham Goodkind. "Despite over 50 requests a week, we never sell the names. "

Goodkind emphasises the creativity that goes into the process. "With up to 20 free email addresses per domain, you have more chance to express yourself online." Taking advantage of the UK's liberal domain laws, funmail has been able to build a healthy business, helping to add to the 300,000 names registered worldwide a week.

"You simply can't get good names anymore. The market has moved from a primary to a resale one," he concludes.

Domain facts and figures

1 300,000 domains are registered every week.
2 13 million domains are in use worldwide.
3 The BBC website tops the British sites with around 160 million page impressions a month.
4 The "big seven" banned swear words on US networks are withheld as domain names.
5 Originally, names were registered for two years, but Register.com is now offering 1, 2, 5 or 10 years - and discounts.
6 Buying a .com domain from NSI can cost between $70 and $169 US.
7 The record bid for a site is $10m for Year2000.com. Placed on the auction site eBay.com, it beat the last record of $7.5m for Business.com.
8 NSI looks set to expand domain names to up to 63 characters. Traditionally they could be only 26 characters.
9 There are more than 200 top level domains including .sh (St. Helena), .to (Tongo), .cd (Republic Of Congo).
10 Still confused about domain names and who runs the process? Check Studio24's clear guide: www.studio24.net/domainname.shtml

webTitle: Plans for new second chamber unveiled

fields.headline: Plans for new second chamber unveiled
fields.trailText:
A royal commission today struck a balance between tradition and
modernity as it unveiled recommendations for a more democratic House
of Lords that includes a significant elected minority from the
regions.
fields.body:
A royal commission today struck a balance between tradition and modernity as it unveiled recommendations for a more democratic House of Lords that includes a significant elected minority from the regions.

The new House of Lords should have around 550 members and a totally independent appointments system to prevent the upper chamber from being a source of patronage, the panel said. However, the commission stopped short of advocating that a majority of peers be elected and it recommends the retention of a large proportion of appointed peers.

The document comes after last year's controversial axing of more than 600 hereditary dukes, marquesses, viscounts, earls and barons. The changes unveiled by the royal commission chaired by Lord Wakeham, a Conservative former cabinet minister, reflect the Labour government's determination to give Britain a more modern cast. Devolution is seen as the other motor for modernisation.

Lord Wakeham was reported to have struck a compromise after bitter disagreements among the 12 members of the commission. He acknowledged that his team's recommendations would not be palatable to everyone, but he predicted that most people would consider it a "practical" way forward.

He said it was time for the issue of reform to be addressed: "I think if the nation doesn't seize this at the present time, we will still be having these discussions in many, many years' time and still have a House of Lords which is not really best equipped to do the job in the 21st century."

The royal commission recommends:
 a significant minority of "regional members" chosen on a basis which reflects the views of the regional electorates;
 a totally independent appointments system with a remit to bring in representatives from all sectors of society;
 a statutory minimum proportion (30 per cent) of women, and of men;
 fair representation for members of ethnic minority groups; and
 a broader range of religious representation.

On the proposals for a statutory appointments commission, Lord Wakeham said: "We want to ensure that the reformed second chamber will no longer be a source of political patronage. The prime minister will no longer be able to control the size, political balance or individual membership of the second chamber."

The panel said it was determined to make recommendations that were not only "persuasive and intellectually coherent but also workable, durable and politically realistic". The House of Lords is one of the last two parliamentary chambers in western democracies appointed rather than elected, the other being the Canadian Senate.

Lord Wakeham said he did not believe that the government would stall on second stage reform of the Lords.

"It's not the message I'm getting. Certainly if you look at the Queen's speech, if you look at other statements by ministers, there is no sign that they don't want to complete the job that they started," he said.

The long-awaited document said the proposals "represent a significant change from what has gone before. No new member of the second chamber will arrive there on the same basis as any existing member of the House of Lords."

No new member of the second chamber will arrive there on the same basis as any existing member of the House of Lords."

webTitle: Women of the world, click here!

fields.headline: Women of the world, click here!
fields.standfirst:
It's official: women are going online like never before. But is what's on offer really worth having? Sally Weale goes surfing
Get the most out of the net with Guardian Unlimited's guide to Life online
fields.trailText: It's official: women are going online like never before. But is what's on offer really worth having?  Sally Weale goes surfing
fields.body:
A gleeful little press release winged its way to most media organisations this week. A survey had shown that handbag.com - the website launched four months ago with much hullabaloo and the slogan: "A woman is lost without her handbag.com" - was the most widely recognised and visited women's website among UK female internet users. Of the 404 women surveyed, 30% said they were aware of the site, launched by Boots and Hollinger Telegraph New Media, compared with 10% awareness for its chief competitor, the Daily Mail's CharlotteStreet.com, and 58% for the well-established amazon.co.uk.

Awareness is one thing, enthusiasm quite another. What the survey tells us is that the 300,000 users who have visited the site are staying online for about 10 minutes, with health, beauty, shopping and fashion the most popular channels. What it doesn't tell us is what those women thought of the service they were offered.

So let's take a look ourselves. The main offerings yesterday were Wok Around The Clock, about buying and using a wok; an item on millennium celebrations in the Antipodes; an opportunity to discuss sex problems with sex expert Tricia Kreitman; and a health and beauty quiz, with questions like: "What is the average weight of a UK female?"

CharlotteStreet.com, meanwhile, was concentrating on getting fit after flu, millennium marriages, grandmothers getting IVF and parental leave rights. Oh, and there's shopping. There's always shopping.

The internet may have set the world on fire, but these sites, sadly, barely ignite a spark. A quick survey of women working in the net industry confirmed my own impressions: "banal", "patronising", "disappointing" were common reactions.

"Everybody's in a bit of a rush to capture market share," says Carol Dukes, founder of thinknatural.com, a website promoting natural health. "They are going for what they think is a big target market, ie women, but which may prove not to exist. They are trying to be all things to all women. I don't think you can meaningfully target 'women'. Targeting women just as women is about as meaningful as targeting men just as men.

"What the internet does superbly is offer special interest information. Because it's a go-seek medium, you have to have a good reason to go somewhere. The more generalist the site, the harder it is for people to know why they are going there. With TV, people let it wash over them. The internet is different. It serves niche markets."

Dukes' own site has avoided being gender-specific, but the overall user base is skewed towards women because it is largely women who look after health in the family. "Everyone's running to do things very, very fast, but the subtlety and the craft of developing a brand personality will take time. It's a skill acquired by print journalism over years. It's still early days on the internet."

So why the sudden hurry? Recent research has shown a massive growth in women using the net. Five years ago, women made up just 10% of the UK internet community; that figure is now 40% and looks set to keep rising. More women under 24 than men are already on the net. Add to that the fact that women make two-thirds of all purchasing decisions in a household and watch the gold rush.

This is one of the key differences in the way women are targeted. They are seen first and foremost as shoppers; everything is dictated by the commercial imperative. Wow, you're surfing the world wide web, you're in cyberspace ... Want to buy some chocolate, a Liberty scarf, some lactating breast pads?

Maybe it will all be different when magazine group IPC, which includes titles such as Marie Claire and Woman's Own, launches Beme.com early next month. Its media director, Hilary Burden, promises it will be the "best site for women in the world".

As Burden is well aware, there is considerable competition from the States where there are already sites for women that are challenging and interesting in a way the UK portals for women are not. There's I-Village.com, where earlier this week you could chat with Hillary Clinton; salon.com, with its Mothers Who Think channel full of high-quality women's writing; and chickclick.com with 30-plus home-grown sites called everything from Disgruntled Housewife to Riotgrrl and Hipmama. Of course the commercial element exists, but the women targeted by these sites are treated as intelligent net users rather than unadulterated shopaholics.

Burden admires such sites but says they can't reflect British women's experience. "We are completely different: CharlotteStreet.com comes out of the Daily Mail and is primarily repeating Mail stories, handbag.com is from the Telegraph, but we come out of an organisation that really knows the female audience. We are not saying Beme is a women's channel - it's for women and by women, but it includes men, too. Of course there's a commercial reality: we don't have a cover price so you need to be able to sell advertising. But we are very, very keen to make it something people can trust. It is an editorial-led site rather than a shopping-led site."

Ultimately the net is out there for all of us, irrespective of our gender. As more and more women get on-line, as more women get involved in the creation and management of sites (and make their e-fortunes alongside their male counterparts), so the nature of the beast is constantly changing. We're all going to need the internet, whether it's to get the latest global news as it breaks or to email friends across the room. What women don't need is just another excuse to target our credit cards.

fields.headline: The best angelic scene
fields.standfirst: Dogma
fields.trailText: Dogma
fields.body:
Night. As Bethany (Linda Fiorentino) sleeps, a spectral presence (Alan Rickman) appears in her bedroom, enveloped in fire. Waking in terror, Bethany attempts to put the flames out with an extinguisher. Reaching for her baseball bat, she screams:

"Who the fuck are you, and what the fuck are you doing in my room?"

"I'm the one who's soaked and she's the one who's surly. That's rich."

"Get the fuck out of here. Now!"

"Or you'll do what exactly? Hit me with that... fish?"

As she looks down, the base ball bat has transformed into a fish.

"Just sit down," the presence continues, "and shut up."

"Look, take whatever you want but don't kill or rape me."

"Give over will you? I couldn't rape you if I wanted to. Angels are ill-equipped."

He pulls down his trousers: his groin is indeed as flat as a pancake.

"See? I'm as anatomically impaired as a Ken doll. You bottom-feeders, so arrogant, you think everyone's just trying to get in your knickers."

"What are you?"

"Pissed off is what I am. Do you go around drenching everyone that comes into your room with flame-retardent chemicals? No wonder you're single."

The intruder steps back and unfolds a giant pair of wings.

"As I was saying, prior to your little fire-fighting episode..."

His voice becomes strangely unearthly.

"...I am the Metatron."

See also: A Matter of Life and Death, Wings of Desire

Don't see also: City Of Angels

Pointless trivia: Kevin Smith's daughter Harlequin is named after Harley Quinn from the Batman comic-book series.

webTitle: Smart shopping:  how to make the web as safe as the high street

fields.headline: Smart shopping:  how to make the web as safe as the high street
fields.trailText: When we pay for a meal out, we happily allow a waiter to make off to a back room with our credit card; and when we order theatre tickets, we think nothing of blaring our account details to a complete stranger over the phone. And yet many of us are still jittery about consigning our vitals to the vagaries of the web. There is possibly good reason.
fields.body:
When we pay for a meal out, we happily allow a waiter to make off to a back room with our credit card; and when we order theatre tickets, we think nothing of blaring our account details to a complete stranger over the phone. And yet many of us are still jittery about consigning our vitals to the vagaries of the web. There is possibly good reason.

A year ago, research by consumer organisations worldwide found that one in 10 items ordered over the net never arrived, while the Credit Card Research Group says that, although cybershopping accounts for only 2% of credit card transactions, it generates 50% of complaints. As far as Consumer readers are concerned, Dear Anna has only received a handful of complaints about online catastrophes. Indeed, virtual purchasing can be as safe as cruising down your high street - provided you know your rights and do your homework.

Precautions

 Check out who you are dealing with and where they are based. If in doubt, try phoning them.

 Beware of PO Box addresses. If possible, use a UK-based company so that you are protected by UK consumer laws.

 Credit card companies like to argue that they are not liable under the consumer credit act if a foreign trader breaches the contract.

 Stick to the familiar names or recommended firms.

 Ask for the company's refund and return policies before ordering, and check on delivery times.

 Save all the information relating to your purchase, from the initial advert to your completed order form, so you have proof if things go wrong.

 For extra protection use a credit card - under the 1974 consumer credit act, the credit card company may be liable if the seller is in breach of contract, provided you paid £100 or more for each item.

 Good retailers allow you to send your credit card details via a secure page which scrambles them while in transit. Your browser should tell you if you are entering a secure page - you will probably see a closed padlock in the status bar on your screen. In a secure area, the address should start https:// rather than http://.

 Use a firm that abides by a code of practice. Which? web trader scheme has one, as does the Direct Marketing Association and the Interactive Media in Retail Group (IMRG), which has members in 20 countries. Consumer Assistance Bureau has a smaller database of approved sites and will help you check up on suppliers before you buy. Participating retailers will display the relevant logo. (See below for web sites)

Your rights

 No one has yet worked out conclusively which country's law's apply if you buy from a company outside the EU. If you choose a UK-based company, the same rights apply as when you shop in the high street. UK law may apply in EU countries and the forthcoming European distance selling directive will oblige suppliers to provide key information before purchase to make follow-ups easier.

 You are entitled to exchange or refund the goods if they are not as described in the blurb, of satisfactory quality, or fit for their purpose.

 Don't be fobbed off with excuses that it's the manufacturer's fault. The retailer has a legal duty to handle complaints.

 Your rights are unaffected if you lose your receipt, but the onus is on you to prove where and when you bought the goods.

If things go wrong

 Make sure you have copies of the transaction documents and write to the seller. Keep copies of all correspondence. If that fails, contact the above associations if the retailer is a member.

 The Direct Marketing Web page is at www.the-dma.org

 Which? Web Trader Scheme is at www.which.net/webtrader/index.html

 IMRG is at www.imrg.org/ If that fails try your local Trading Standards authority. Details of your local branch are at www.tradingstandards.gov.uk/

 The Advertising Standards Authority can help if you feel you were deceived by the blurb. Visit it at www.asa.org.uk/

 If you are seeking redress from a foreign trader, the internet Consumer Assistance Bureau should provide support. Its home page is at www.isitsafe.com/

webTitle: The death camp guard who saw no killings

fields.headline: The death camp guard who saw no killings
fields.standfirst:
Alexander Schweidler says he is not a war criminal, but Jewish groups want a new look at his role at Mauthausen, where 86,000 died Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
Special report: the David Irving libel trial
fields.trailText: Alexander Schweidler says he is not a war criminal, but Jewish groups want a new look at his role at Mauthausen, where 86,000 died
fields.body:
The SS did not class Mauthausen as a death camp, but of 191,938 prisoners who passed through its gates at least 86,185 would die there. People died through medical experiments in which they were injected with typhus and tested with quack cures. Others were starved as the Nazis tested how much malnourishment the human body could endure.

Those who did not perish in Mauthausen's gas chambers died working in the nearby stone quarries where prisoners were used as slave labour. Some were crushed as they were made to carry boulders. Five thousand people who could not work or who were mentally handicapped were exterminated under a programme which bore the anodyne file name of 14F 13.

Alexander Schweidler says the scale of this human misery passed him by in his three years as a guard, as did the shootings, the hangings and the beatings. Of those who died one third are estimated to have been Jews. Mauthausen also held Poles, Russians, French, Spanish Republicans and Soviet prisoners of war.

Mr Schweidler denies any direct knowledge of the mass murder or ill treatment that caused so many to perish.

In the bungalow into which he and his wife moved in November last year, Alexander Schweidler looks like the archetypal grandfather in his red woollen hat, cardigan and purple slippers. He is still angry at the United States's decision to throw him out. His wife Anna says: "Have we done something wrong again?"

In the corner of his front room is an electric organ, on which Mr Schweidler plays German favourites such as the 'beer barrel polka'.

The most damning evidence against him concerning alleged war crimes is the document bearing his signature in which he details shooting dead two Russians who were trying to escape.

He told US investigators that senior officers had told him to sign the document. But he gave the Guardian a different account, saying the document was "falsified". He did not know by whom.

He said: "I never shot anyone, not to my knowledge."

Later he said: "I believe the Geneva convention says that if an armed soldier stands guard at a prison camp where soldiers are, and there are some soldiers trying to escape, and the armed guard shoots some of them, that isn't even a war crime... I'm saying still I never did it. They're holding that against me when it might not actually be a war crime."

He said he did hear talk that there were gas chambers, but never set foot inside the camp, merely patrolled the perimeter.

Mr Schweidler maintains he saw no killings. "In those days I was courting my first wife, I didn't care about anything much except when I could get out and meet her.

"I just forget, one of my bad things is I'm forgetting very easily, I always have."

Mr Schweidler says that even if he had known, there was nothing he could have done. To have intervened could have cost him his life.

He was born in Pressburg, Slovakia, on January 18 1922. He was part of the ethnic German minority, and admits in his youth being a fan of Adolf Hitler: "What do you know as a 16-year-old boy, everything was nice and rosy."

Mr Schweidler says he was proud when he was chosen to serve in the SS. He fought in campaigns against Holland and France, and was awarded the Iron Cross.

In February 1941 he became a German citizen and was wounded in September of that year. Aged 20 he was posted to Mauthausen, serving from January 1942 until the camp's liberation in May 1945 by American troops.

If Mr Schweidler was just a guard he was a lucky one, because by the war's end he had been promoted to sergeant. If his account is correct, all he did was stand on the outer edge of the camp. He said he fled the camp days before the Americans arrived because he feared capture.

He moved to Britain in 1948 and became a naturalised citizen in 1964. The next year he went to the US where he worked his way up from a cleaner to become a computer programmer.

His retirement to a house with a pool in Florida came to a crashing halt when a routine immigration check flagged him as a suspected war criminal. He chose to return to Britain in 1994 after deportation proceedings began and he is barred from re-entering the US.

Looking back at his time at Mauthausen is clearly difficult for Mr Schweidler, but he can remember enough to have regrets: "It shouldn't have happened. I wish I hadn't been there myself. That's fate."

It was also John Sowa's fate to end up in Mauthausen. Now settled in Britain, his memories of Mauthausen are clearer than Mr Schweidler's. He survived two years in its notorious stone quarry where prisoners were forced to work with their bare hands. For many the only escape was death.

Mr Sowa, 74, who lives in London, is still on plagued by nightmares: "Anybody who is in a camp, it is with them for life."

When he left after liberation, he was just skin and bones and spent six months in hospital recovering.

Fed on starvation rations, Mr Sowa was forced to pick up rocks in the quarry and carry them to a crushing machine. He had no shoes, just wooden clogs, no socks and no tools.

"A hell of a lot of people died. Everytime we returned to the camp, there were four or five dead. Mauthausen was an extermination camp, just as Auschwitz was. In Auschwitz they sent people to the gas chambers, in Mauthausen they sent you to do work which you simply could not manage.

"I carried the heaviest load, a hundredweight. I don't know how I did it, and loaded it with my bare hands. The sharp ends of the stone cut my hands and they were bleeding."

Mr Sowa was sent to Mauthausen from Warsaw, and can still recall its sadism. One prisoner who tried and failed to escape had a boulder put on his shoulder. Dogs were then let loose as he tried to run for his life. The dogs killed him.

Mr Sowa is in no doubt that all the guards at Mauthausen and its satellite camps were war criminals: "I will call them murderers, plain murderers. They murdered children, women and men. It gave them pleasure."

A leading authority on the Holocaust is also in no doubt about the culpability of the guards. Peter Black, senior historian at the US Holocaust museum, said: "The guards were taught quite explicitly that the prisoners were diehard enemies and that it was quite proper if they encountered resistance to shoot first and ask questions later. The camp system could not have been run in the way it was, with the brutality it was, without the camp guards' assistance."

The view that all at Mauthausen were criminally responsible for the atrocities was stated by a US military tribunal in 1946: "The circumstances, conditions and the very nature of the concentration camp Mauthausen was of such a criminal nature as to cause every official - governmental, military and civil - and every employee thereof, whether he be a member of the Waffen SS, Allgemeine SS, a guard or civilian, to be culpably and criminally responsible."

Whether the past will catch up with Mr Schweidler will be up to the British authorities. He is keen to show two letters from Scotland Yard saying that there would be no prosecution of him following an investigation.

For Jewish groups, there is no doubt that Mr Schweidler should be reinvestigated.

Mr Schweidler's former neighbours believe that he should be left alone. For five years he lived in Milton Keynes two miles away from his current address. Both his neighbours said he and his wife were a lovely couple, and said that talk of Mr Schweidler being a war criminal was a witchhunt.

He was part of the ethnic German minority, and admits in his youth being a fan of Adolf Hitler: "What do you know as a 16-year-old boy, everything was nice and rosy." Mr Schweidler says he was proud when he was chosen to serve in the SS. He fought in campaigns against Holland and France, and was awarded the Iron Cross. In February 1941 he became a German citizen and was wounded in September of that year. Aged 20 he was posted to Mauthausen, serving from January 1942 until the camp's liberation in May 1945 by American troops. If Mr Schweidler was just a guard he was a lucky one, because by the war's end he had been promoted to sergeant. If his account is correct, all he did was stand on the outer edge of the camp. He said he fled the camp days before the Americans arrived because he feared capture. He moved to Britain in 1948 and became a naturalised citizen in 1964. The next year he went to the US where he worked his way up from a cleaner to become a computer programmer. His retirement to a house with a pool in Florida came to a crashing halt when a routine immigration check flagged him as a suspected war criminal. He chose to return to Britain in 1994 after deportation proceedings began and he is barred from re-entering the US. Mr Sowa, 74, who lives in London, is still on plagued by nightmares: "Anybody who is in a camp, it is with them for life." When he left after liberation, he was just skin and bones and spent six months in hospital recovering. Fed on starvation rations, Mr Sowa was forced to pick up rocks in the quarry and carry them to a crushing machine. He had no shoes, just wooden clogs, no socks and no tools. Mr Sowa is in no doubt that all the guards at Mauthausen and its satellite camps were war criminals: "I will call them murderers, plain murderers. They murdered children, women and men. webTitle: Nazi war criminal, expelled from US, is living in UK

fields.headline: Nazi war criminal, expelled from US, is living in UK
fields.standfirst: Nazi war criminal living in BritainSpecial report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: An SS guard at a concentration camp where more than 80,000 people were gassed, worked to death or died after being subjected to experiments is living in Britain and receiving a state pension, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
An SS guard at a concentration camp where more than 80,000 people were gassed, worked to death or died after being subjected to experiments is living in Britain and receiving a state pension, the Guardian has learned.

Alexander Schweidler, 78, who lives in a council house in Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire, became a naturalised British citizen after the war. He was deported from the United States in 1994 because of his alleged crimes against humanity.

In the US he admitted helping the persecution of civilians on the basis of their race, religion, nationality or political views.

For three years he was a member of the SS "death's head" unit at the Mauthausen concentration camp in Austria.

It is rare to get documentary evidence of alleged war crimes. But in a document seen by the Guardian, which Mr Schweidler signed during the war, he details how he gunned down two prisoners. He wrote that they were trying to escape in broad daylight in the report he submitted to the SS.

But testimony from another guard, seen by the Guardian, reveals that SS troops would chase prisoners so that guards could use them as target practice.

Yesterday he denied murdering prisoners. Last night Jewish groups demanded action against Mr Schweidler, and that the home secretary revoke his citizenship.

The case will reignite the debate about whether Britain has the political will to investigate and try war criminals. Earlier this month Jack Straw came under fire after Britain allowed another suspected war criminal, Konrad Kalejs, to leave the country after police said there was insufficient evidence to hold him.

Mr Schweidler naturalised as a British citizen in 1964, having come from Germany in 1948. After being deported from the US he returned to Britain with his second wife.

Scotland Yard decided not to proceed with a criminal case under the war crimes act in 1997, despite US investigators believing his role in crimes against humanity was proven.

In a report signed by Mr Schweidler, a corporal, he explains the shootings committed on April 28 1942 of inmates Nikolay Titov, 23, and Wasili Dundukowo, 25. Both were Soviet prisoners of war and according to the document shot within five minutes of each other.

But another guard at Mauthausen Stefan Leili told US investigators that SS guards would use prisoners as "target practice". Leili, who was deported from the US, confirms that the man he shot had been made to run towards the camp's outer perimeter by SS men who hit the prisoner.

To get Mr Schweidler deported, the American authorities had to build a case against him that met the criminal standard of proof. Eli Rosenbaum, director of the US justice department's office of special investigations, which gathered the evidence, told the Guardian: "Schweidler admitted it was his signature on the document but denied that the incident occurred. His explanation was that when an officer puts something in front of you to sign, you sign it. In my view that's nonsense. His denial is obviously false.

"As a guard he shares responsibility for the mistreatment, including murder, to which thousands of prisoners were subjected. His job was to keep them in there so they could be abused and murdered."

John Sowa, 74, survived two years in Mauthausen. From his London home he expressed outrage that one of his former tormentors was living in the same country as him: "It's disgusting, it's unbelievable. He should be prosecuted. Some of the guards are living better off than we are."

Nazi hunter Efraim Zuroff of the Simon Wiesenthal centre said: "Jack Straw has to get his act together and go for denaturalisation and deportation to get this war criminal out of England."

Amid growing concern over Britain's record in prosecuting war criminals, the all-party war crimes group will reform today. Its secretary, Lord Janner, called for police to reinvestigate the case: "It's yet another case of a person against whom there is evidence of war crimes who has has found refuge in this country. How can a former guard at Mauthausen get a state pension?"

Mr Schweidler, who was born in Slovakia, told the Guardian that his support for Hitler was a youthful indiscretion. He said he had no recollection of any shootings, and that though he heard talk of there being gas chambers at the camp, to have intervened may have led to him being killed.

Mr Schweidler said that the document bearing his signature detailing his shooting dead of two prisoners was "falsified".

Scotland Yard confirmed that Mr Schweidler had been interviewed under caution in 1996. A home office spokeswoman said the home secretary had the power to revoke citizenship.

webTitle: Trash your rivals and get away with it

fields.headline: Trash your rivals and get away with it
fields.standfirst:
Amazon has revolutionised bookselling. But it has also changed book reviewing. Now anyone, from the book's publisher to the author's competitors, can post anonymous comments about a work. Emma Brockes uncovers evidence of score-settling and self-promotion

Guardian Unlimited's guide to Life online
fields.trailText: Amazon has revolutionised bookselling. But it has also changed book reviewing. Now anyone, from the book's publisher to the author's competitors, can post anonymous comments about a work. Emma Brockes uncovers evidence of score-settling and self-promotion
fields.body:
In the pantheon of unkind book reviews, there have been worse slanders. Jessica Duchen's biography of Erich Wolfgang Korngold, the Austrian composer, stood accused of a "lack of empathy", a "failure to enthuse" and an over-simplicity that reduced it to a work of "great disapointment [sic]". The forum was Amazon.co.uk, the online bookshop; the reviewer, an anonymous contributor to the customer comments section signing himself "a reader from London".

It wasn't the criticism that annoyed Duchen, but the suspicion of foul play behind it. Perhaps the bad spelling tipped her off, or the tautologous prose style ("further investigate the artist's work further"), but when Duchen read the review she had an uneasy feeling about its authorship. It was not, she suspected, the response of a disinterested member of the public, but the work of an adversary out to get her. Amazon's bluff entreaty to "Share your thoughts with other readers!" had been exploited, she believed, as a licence to "Trash your rivals and get away with it!"

If this is the case, it represents a stunning inversion of publishers' hopes for Amazon. Authors' much savoured grumble - that, like theatre reviewers, book critics allow professional jealousy to colour their reviews since they are all failed novelists - holds no sway at Amazon, where members of the public provide the bulk of review copy. Those dear, guileless readers have, over the past year, posted 1,921 reviews of Thomas Harris's Hannibal, 370 of Michael Crichton's Timeline, 91 of Alex Garland's The Beach and enjoyed snippy exchanges about the value of the opinions. The concept of a "reading community", once defunct almost to the point of oxymoron, suddenly leapt to life and threatened to wrest critical opinion away from the professionals and hand it to the readers.

As with most internet forums, Amazon's comment section attracted a fair share of cranks and morons, its "horrible book - I could have written better" rants that sensible authors ignored. But the site's combination of anonymity and vast exposure also enabled what Duchen believes to be a more damaging line of spite.

Philip Pullman agrees. Pullman's forthcoming book, The Amber Spyglass, has been promoted on Amazon for the past couple of months. In December, the Oxford author received an unexpected call from his US publicists, who had logged on to the book's promotional page and noted with alarm that the section dedicated to author's comments had been filled in by an impostor. "It was completely illiterate stuff," says Pullman. "Any old twit can log on and review a book, or click on the 'I am the Author' button and post up a load of old rubbish. They hadn't even spelled my name right." Amazon swiftly removed the posting, but not before Pullman had converted his initial amusement into anger. "God knows how many people saw it," he says with a shudder.

"The review was posted last February," says Duchen of her own misfortune. "I didn't check it until September and thought, 'My God, what is this?'" The Korngold biography was Duchen's first book. It was reviewed in the major music magazines and received largely favourable notices, although she insists she wasn't over-sensitive about the bad ones. "I thought the criticisms were fair and well-expressed. But this was different. It referred to talks I had done on Korngold, outlining my intentions to stir up enthusiasm for the music. The reviewer said this was exactly what I hadn't done. There was a sense that here was a person being nasty for the sake of it."

Duchen is a critic herself and suspects the phantom reviewer is someone she has crossed in a former article. It is not altogether paranoid. "Duchen had a point," says Kate Pool, editor of the Author magazine. Duchen referred her concerns to the magazine's parent organisation, the Society of Authors, which sustained a "very lively" debate about it, but concluded nothing could be done. "We have always been aware of the potential for trouble," says Pool. "But the whole essence of the internet is freedom of expression, and how could you regulate it anyway?"

Publicly, publishers sympathise with their authors' vulnerability to Amazon's maverick reviewers. Privately, however, there is a sense that they have more to lose in reforming the system. "We have regular discussions about this area of online reviewing," says Joanna Prior, head of publicity at Penguin Books. "It is open to people using it in a malicious way. I don't know how you would prevent it."

Don't hold your breath for suggestions. Publishers aren't as innocent in all this as might be expected and, while it is unlikely that they'd stoop to trashing rival books on Amazon, there is little doubt that they use it as an extension of their sales pitch. "As a publisher, one is tempted to add in favourable reviews about our books," admits Katie James, head of Macmillan publicity. "We have done it once or twice, pretending to be members of the public." She giggles. "I mean, we are members of the public, but we have a professional vested interest."

The admissions are just as frank at Penguin. "The more editorial information there is on a book, the more likely people are to buy it," says Prior. "I encourage staff, not necessarily associated with the book, to review it on Amazon. It is a free advert."

Evidence for this is manifest in the reviews one finds that are dated before the official publication of the book, a discreet indication that they emanate from within the author's publishing house.

"Allowing anonymity opens the service to too much misuse," says Duchen. "If you are honest, you don't need the protection of anonymity. It is an invitation for people to start inventing things." But as far as Amazon customers are concerned, the possibility of invention is half the fun of browsing the reviews. Like most features on the internet, you are never quite sure of what is real and what is hoax. The customer comments are valuable, not as measured criticisms, but as gut reactions, spicy dialogues and despatches from bonkersville; as pieces of fiction in their own right, authored by the usual mix of evangelists and the Very Angry.

"I have great fun reading through the readers' comments," says Pool at the Society of Authors. "There was one gem on Aldous Huxley's Brave New World that went, 'I have only read one chapter, but I can already say that, apart from the Bible, this is my favourite book.' You can pretty quickly guess the nature of the reviewer."

And even if you can't, there is nothing Amazon can do without releasing the contributors' email addresses and they won't do that. Editors at the site take a cursory glance at incoming messages to scout for obscenity but, whilst agreeing that Duchen and Pullman's cases are "unfortunate", fail to see what they can do about it. "We prefer people with vested interests to identify themselves," says Judith Catton at the British arm of the company. "But we can't control it if they don't. We want both good and bad reviews, because it creates debate."

She is unlikely to face much opposition. Given the choice, after all, most authors would opt for bogus reviews over no reviews at all.

fields.headline: 10 top sites for women
fields.standfirst: Get the most out of the net with Guardian Unlimited's guide to Life online
fields.trailText: The best on the UK net
fields.body:
www.handbag.com

Launched in May 1999, its funky graphics, mix of news and features, trivia quizzes and free email make it appealing to younger women. Want to know how many calories are in half an avocado? This site is for you.

www.CharlotteStreet.com

Feels like a slightly older version of handbag.com. Updated daily, it has over 20 channels, from health and horoscopes to love and leisure. Strong on news.

www.icircle.co.uk

Launched by Freeserve for its half a million women users, this multi-channel site offers lots of information and practical advice from the likes of agony aunt Anna Raeburn. From ISAs to Greek Islands, a no-nonsense site for working women.

www.planetgrrl.com

Set up in 1998 in response to what founder Jules calls the "dire lack" of UK sites for or by women and girls. Content ranges from a beginner's guide to the internet to animal welfare, clubbing and employment.

www.cabinet-office.gov.uk/womens-unit

Includes downloadable factsheets on subjects like family friendly employment, plus info on women's ministers.

http://www.gn.apc.org/wen/

The Women's Environmental Network campaigns on issues that concern women. This site looks at activities ranging from calling for waste prevention to lobbying for pesticide-free food.

www.newwomanonline.co.uk

Online version of Emap-owned mag New Woman, it features around 20 channels covering everything from careers to childcare. Editorial content and offers supplied by other Emap titles like Heat and Red.

www.patient.co.uk

UK-based site with a dedicated section on women's health, from anorexia to menopause. Set up to provide accessible medical information.

www.womensaid.org.uk

Women's Aid is a national charity for women and children being physically, sexually or emotionally abused in their homes. An excellent site giving advice and info including National Domestic Violence campaign details.

www.womenconnect.org.uk

Set up in 1998, this site aims to create an electronic network of women's organisations. Offers training, support and information to groups and individuals.

Guy de Beaujeu and Patrick Stockhausen persuaded Bristol Rovers officials they could enhance the club's results by such devices as installing a fish tank containing plastic fish behind the goal and ordering staff to make sure all toilet seats were down at all times.

Their other requirements included erecting an ornamental ceramic frog above the stadium entrance, placing potted house plants in all four corners of the players' dressing room, and hanging wind chimes around the stadium.

Gullible staff carried out all the recommendations made by the "experts in the ancient Chinese art" in an effort to beat second division rivals Gillingham. But the mumbo jumbo failed to create the right aura - and Rovers lost 1-0.

Yesterday Mr De Beaujeu, 32, said: "They fell for it, hook, line and sinker. They did everything we asked without question."

Mr De Beaujeu and Mr Stockhausen, who are based in Bristol, staged the stunt for a comedy series, The Gatecrashers, which they filmed last year for ITV2.

One of their producers telephoned Bristol Rovers and told the club they were making a documentary about the power of feng shui.

The ancient art is believed to balance one's surroundings and induce general well-being.

Rovers agreed to let the pair into their Memorial Ground stadium in the hope that this might boost the team's performance.

The duo duly arrived with a cameraman two hours before the kick-off of Rovers' tie against Gillingham, armed with bags of supposed feng shui paraphernalia.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Sun
fields.body:
The Sun

Stan Collymore is set to join West Ham on a free transfer. Harry Redknapp wants to sign outcast Collymore so he can get rid of Paolo Wanchope, who has scored only three goals this season. The Collymore deal could go through within 48 hours.

The Mirror

Arsenal hope to sign Uruguayan striker Daniel Fonseca from Juventus. The 30-year-old would be available on a short-term loan.

Daily Mail

Ruud van Nistelrooy has announced his intention to leave PSV Eindhoven this summer, but only for a big club. "I want to make it clear to the small clubs that there is no point screaming about how much they want me," he said. "You can count on the fingers of one hand the clubs in Europe I would be willing to join." Manchester United, Arsenal and Chelsea are all rumoured to be interested in the Dutch international striker.

Marseille have turned down the opportunity to sign Stan Collymore. "The player's personality does not suit Marseille," said the club's general manager Bernard Casoni.

Daily Star

Spurs are on the trail of Romanian international Constantin Galca. The cultured holding midfielder plays for Spanish side Espanyol and will be available on a Bosman in the summer.

Swindon are hoping to re-sign former star Jan Aage Fjortoft, who currently plays for Eintracht Frankfurt.

Ipswich have confirmed their interest in Crystal Palace striker Mattias Svensson.

Teamtalk

Newcastle United are being linked with a move for 20 year old non-league striker Graham Goulding. Goulding plays for Workington in the Unibond League.
