fields.headline: Weblife: search engines
fields.standfirst:
If you're struggling to find what you need on the net, Danny Sullivan offers a few tips and tricks
Get the most out of the net with Guardian Unlimited's guide to Life online
fields.trailText: If you're struggling to find what you need on the net, Danny Sullivan offers a few tips and tricks
fields.body:
Have you made the typical New Year's Resolutions: lose weight, quit smoking, drink less? How about one more for the hi-tech millennium? Learn to search the web better. Here's a search exercise plan to get you into shape.

First, it helps to understand the basics of how search engines get their listings. There are two main ways: human beings or automated "crawlers".

Yahoo is a great example of a search engine that uses human beings. Its editors classify websites into different categories. So a search for "travel" reveals categories such as Travel Booksellers, Travel Companies and Hawaiian Travel. Click on a topic, and you'll be shown a list of sites that an editor has selected for that particular category.

In contrast, a search engine like AltaVista sends robot crawlers out across the web to read automatically a large number of pages. The text is stored in what you can think of as a big book. So when you search for "travel", AltaVista flips through its book to displays links to all the individual web pages it has found with those words.

In general, use a human-powered search engine when looking for answers to something general. But for something specific, such as "places to stay in Fort William", a crawler-based search engine may be more helpful.

It is also helpful to understand basic search engine "maths". This means that by using symbols such as + or -, you can get better search results.

For instance, say you were looking for "football" and kept getting answers about the NFL, the National Football League in the United States. Try searching again like this: football-nfl

The minus symbol tells the search engine to look for pages that say football then to subtract any pages which contain the word NFL. That makes it more likely you'll get pages about Manchester United, rather than the Miami Dolphins!

In fact, you can use the + symbol to get even closer to Man U. Try a search like this: football +manchester +united

That tells the search engine to find all the pages with football on them, then to show you only pages that also say "manchester" and "united".

If you were seeking Manchester United information, then the best way would be to search like this: "manchester united".

Using the quote marks around a series of words tells the search engine to return only pages with that exact phrase on them, in that exact order which greatly increases the odds that they'll be about Manchester United.

By searching in lower-case, you'll find both lower and upper-case versions of your words at all major search engines. So save your fingers and stay off the shift key!

Another search tip is to always be specific. For instance, if you want to buy tickets for Manchester United matches online, then search that way, such as: Where can I buy tickets for Manchester United matches online?

It's fine to use natural language queries like this on any search engine - you don't need to use only Boolean commands or even the maths commands described above. Just start with a specific query, and you may find what you are looking for without having to resort to other attempts.

Another way to get better results can be to use multiple search engines. No two search engines are exactly the same, and if you use only one, you might miss good results that another might have. Since they are all free, don't be afraid to try a couple when searching the web.

You can even send your query to multiple search engines at the same time, using metasearch engines. Also called metacrawlers, these sites save you time by forwarding your query to several major search engines then bringing back the results to one place. There is even metasearch software that brings back answers from multiple places to sort through.

Finally, have you every looked for something to do with Britain and come back with a load of results that made you feel like the entire web is American? Next time, try a British search engine. These services make an extra attempt to ensure the sites they list are either British or about Britain. Just be sure to use the UK option usually located near the search box.

The best places to start looking

Yahoo

Yahoo.co.uk

The oldest major human-powered search engine on the web, and a great starting place for any search. Has UK or webwide search abilities.

AltaVista
www.altavista.co.uk

Crawler-based service that's an excellent choice for finding unusual or very specific information. Offers the ability to search within the UK or across the entire web.

Google
www.google.com
Crawler-based service with a unique ranking system that finds great answers, even when seeking general information.

Excite
www.excite.co.uk

Crawler-based service with UK or webwide abilities.

AskJeeves
www.askjeeves.com Many like its unusual style of asking you questions to get you to the right website. Also a meta search engine.

Northern Light
www.northernlight.com Crawler-based service popular with researchers. Good place to look for hard-to-find information.

UKMax www.ukmax.com
Crawler-based search engine for both UK and worldwide.

SearchUK
www.searchuk.com
Crawler-based search engine specifically for the UK.

UK Plus

www.ukplus.co.uk
The only major human- powered service produced for the UK, in the UK.

LookSmart
www.looksmart.co.uk

Human-powered service that classifies sites into categories, helpful for finding general information. Search within the UK or across the world.

Lycos
www.lycos.co.uk
A crawler-based search engine with UK or webwide search abilities.

Virgin Net

www.virgin.net

Search the web with a special edition of the Google engine, with extra listings for the UK.

FAST www.alltheweb.com

Crawler-based service with a large number of listings. Good for unusual information.

Go2Net www.go2net.com

Meta search site that lets you query many popular search engines at once.

SavvySearch

www.savvysearch.com
Another popular meta search site.

webTitle: Lords report fails to back single blueprint

fields.headline: Lords report fails to back single blueprint
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will today be given an opportunity to stall future reform of the House of Lords with the publication of a royal commission report which fails to endorse a single blueprint for the upper house.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will today be given an opportunity to stall future reform of the House of Lords with the publication of a royal commission report which fails to endorse a single blueprint for the upper house.

Lord Wakeham, the former Tory cabinet minister who chaired the commission, will put forward three options for the Lords which would include some elected members, but which would be dominated by appointed peers. The veteran fixer, who prides himself on his ability to win a consensus among sworn opponents, was forced to strike a compromise after bitter disagreements among the 12 members of the commission.

Lord Hurd of Westwell, the former foreign secretary, led a faction which argued for the Lords to have up to 200 elected members. The one-time cabinet colleague of Lord Wakeham reflected Tory anxieties that Mr Blair wants to turn the Lords into a new Labour-dominated quango by appointing his supporters. Lord Hurd was opposed by the former Labour frontbencher, Gerald Kaufman, who called for an elected element of fewer than 80.

The compromise by Lord Wakeham, who was drafted in by Mr Blair to chair the commission, will fuel speculation that the prime minister was never serious about the second stage of Lords reform.

Labour won plaudits for removing all but 92 hereditary peers last year, but set up the commission after failing to work out plans for the next stage which could win broad political support. Labour sources have indicated that Wakeham is likely to join the long list of commissions and reviews which have been "kicked into the long grass".

Senior ministers, who saw a great political opportunity in abolishing hereditary peers, are sceptical of taking Lords reform much further. The prime minister has made no secret of his belief that the Lords cannot be dominated by elected members because the supremacy of the Commons must not be challenged. By failing to implement major re form beyond the abolition of the hereditaries ministers will open themselves to the charge that the Lords will be dominated by "Tony's cronies". Ministers believe they have gone some way to answering this charge by ensuring that the strength of parties broadly reflects general election results, but with no party commanding an overall majority.

The commission's report is published after a year's work, involving 2,000 submissions and 10 public hearings.

fields.headline: A boy's own story
fields.standfirst: Lennie James grew up in a children's home, then tried to help kids in the same position. Now he's turned his shocking experiences into a film.  Dominic Bradbury reports
fields.trailText: Lennie James grew up in a children's home, then tried to help kids in the same position. Now he's turned his shocking experiences into a film. Dominic Bradbury reports
fields.body:
Lennie James has been travelling a long, hard road, and is glad to have reached the end. As an actor, he has made his name with TV series such as Undercover Heart and Cold Feet and the movie Among Giants. As a writer he is still little known, but now the BBC is about to air his first self-penned film, Storm Damage. What's more, this searing children's home drama is the most personal piece of work he is ever likely to produce. "If I'd written 20 scripts," says James, "this would be the important one, because almost everything the film's about actually happened."

Storm Damage came out of James's experiences of foster care: good times mostly with his foster mother Pam, who adopted him at 16 after six years in a council-run home, where he was sent following the death of his mother, and then some difficult times, when he helped out at the children's home Pam set up while he was at drama school. The spur to write Storm Damage was the funeral of a teenager from the home, one of two dead children to whom the film is dedicated.

"My foster mother wanted to create a family home. For me, she had made a place that I felt I could always go back to, and that was what she was trying to do for these kids. I was about 21 and went back to help - you think that you are going to go in there and change a life. But it was just relentless and you felt like you were riding this wild bull and had to hang on for dear life."

James took classes at the Guildhall School of Music and Drama in the day and spent nights at the home. Like the main character, Danny, in the film (played by Primary Colors star Adrian Lester), he thought he could make a difference, but found himself simply trying to cope. One girl died after sniffing aerosols, and a boy ended up bleeding to death on the street.

"When that boy got stabbed a whole group of kids went round to stone the house of the guy who did it and he had to run to the police station and say, 'I did it.' But everybody knew this kid who died, and that if you fought him, you had to hope the police would come soon, or that you killed him before he killed you. Yet outside that he really was a sweetheart, a charming boy.

"When I wrote Storm Damage it was with the sense that these kids had gone, 'I'm going to do what I've got to do to make sure I'm all right.' If no one takes responsibility for them, of course they are going to screw up. These aren't lovable kids, but we tend to forget they are children and we relinquish our responsibility to teach them anything."

At 33 James is now a father of three. But it was as a son that he felt most nervous about the film, given that he'd never expressed to Pam a lot of the feelings that come out in Storm Damage. The film is "a testament" to her.

James also stars in the film, as the villain Bonaface. He was slated to play Adrian Lester's foster brother, but director Cellan Jones thought that playing against type would add more weight to James's character. Certainly, it's different from his most memorable turn to date, playing the sensitive cop Matt Lomas in the BBC drama Undercover Heart. For James that was a turning point, the first time he felt he had been judged for a part against his contemporaries purely on talent, not because of the colour of his skin.

"The part of Matt Lomas was just a man, but also the most rounded character I have ever been given, a gift of a part. But when people stop you in the street they're saying it's really good to see a black person up there doing that kind of stuff, so it's still like you are some kind of pioneer."

Last year James took some time off from acting to concentrate on writing: two film scripts, a commission for a new four-part Channel 4 drama called Angeltown, set in Brixton, and a co-writing job on another forthcoming Channel 4 series, Our Friends in Notting Hill. All a world away from his first experiences of writing for television when a stint on The Bill collapsed in acrimony. As the first black writer to script an episode for the show, he was persuaded to do some publicity. Interviews were done and a picture taken with one of the stars. The picture was mistakenly sent out to a handful of nationals with the caption, "Burnside makes another arrest."

"I rang up the publicity girl and she said someone had come in and assumed it was a still from the programme. I said what does that say about the programme? She said, 'All I can say is sorry' and I said, 'All I can say is fuck off'. I didn't write for them again."

fields.headline: The sound of silence
fields.standfirst: Garbo, Valentino, Fairbanks - Carl Davis has worked with all of them.  Michael Billington meets the composer who brought life to more than 30 classics of the silver screen
fields.trailText: Garbo, Valentino, Fairbanks - Carl Davis has worked with all of them. Michael Billington meets the composer who brought life to more than 30 classics of the silver screen
fields.body:
Carl Davis is a man with a mission. Or, rather, several missions. One is to renew the audience for classic silent films - which is why he has composed scores for more than 30 features. Another is to win over a lost generation to good music - which is why he stages summer concerts in big tops and football stadiums and is even prepared, on occasion, to don bizarre costumes. But although there's a touch of the showman in the jovial Davis, he seriously believes that music is everyone's birthright and that no one should be barred from enjoying it by lack of either income or education. "The arts should no more be governed by profit than the underground or the health service," he proclaims.

At the moment, though, sex is very much on his mind - more precisely, the allure of Greta Garbo, who stars in the 1926 classic Flesh and the Devil, which on Saturday gets a rare screening at the Royal Festival Hall with Davis conducting his own score with the London Philharmonic Orchestra. Garbo plays a femme fatale who wrecks the friendship between two Prussian soldiers, and the film is famous for several reasons: for Garbo's torrid on- and off-screen affair with co-star John Gilbert, for Clarence Brown's pioneering use of horizontal love scenes and for technical devices like the minute light bulb Brown put in the tip of Gilbert's cigarette to give the lovers an extra glow.

For Davis, who premiered his score in 1982, the challenge lies in matching the movie's eroticism. "The thing that influenced the musical style is that it's Garbo for the first time being the Garbo we know and recognise. It was her third Hollywood film and up to that point she wasn't a great success. But here the lighting, her performance and the fact that she was having an affair with Gilbert - the love scenes went on long after the director shouted 'Cut!' - all come into play. What I try to do is be part of the make-up and lighting department and make sure that musically she also glows. Before her arrival I've used Strauss-style marches for the scenes in the military barracks and quasi-Wagnerian music for the big blood-oath sworn between the two men. But suddenly Garbo appears and the whole film takes on another dimension along with the sound. I haven't overdone the score when she's around but I've used Mahlerian, even Bergian echoes because the music has to shimmer like the star."

Davis, 63, has been composing scores for silent classics ever since the landmark restoration of Abel Gance's Napoléon in 1980, and is now expert at writing music that complements the screen image. But how exactly does he set about creating scores which, in the case of Napoléon, required a mammoth five hours of continuous music?

"In a modern film you work with a shot list that tells you where music is needed second by second. With a silent film, it's different. In order to learn the film, I actually write a book. I study the film in great detail, using the timings shown on the screen. Not only do I write down in longhand what's happening in each scene, but I also work out the story's structure - where the paragraphs and chapter divisions are. It's a long process but then I sit down to write the score without referring to the pictures at all because I've taken away an impression.

"One also has to find a style appropriate to the work: romantic melodrama with Flesh and the Devil, historical pageant with Napoléon, swashbuckling epic with [the Douglas Fairbanks movie] The Iron Mask, which I recently did for the London Film Festival. In a sense, it's more like writing an opera or ballet than conventional movie music - you provide the complete sound picture."

What changed Davis's life was the premiere showing of Napoléon in 1980. Until then, as an American living in London and married to actress Jean Boht, he'd been a prolific composer for film, theatre and TV, for which he worked on The World at War with Jeremy Isaacs. But Kevin Brownlow's restoration of Gance's movie, backed by Thames TV and the BFI, turned out to be a big public success.

"Around that time Jeremy was creating Channel 4 and he commissioned a whole series of silent film restorations," Davis recalls. "That was the historical moment. Because Jeremy had the vision to go on with it, Kevin and I began an elaborate programme of restorations, which we took to festivals around the world. It turned into a way of life - and another career bounced out of it for me. Up to then I'd been a backroom boy, but when people saw me doing these live shows they got the idea I could conduct, which I've been doing steadily for the past 20 years."

Davis, however, doesn't just conduct live film shows and orthodox concerts; he also believes strongly in taking music to the people. "As soon as I started conducting I realised there was a generation of schoolchildren who, because of cuts in education funding, simply never went to a concert, opera, ballet or theatre. What I did was fasten on a style of presentation very popular in America called the Boston Pops. In the early 90s I started doing a summer season with the Liverpool Philharmonic.

"We perform in a big top in the King's Dock in Liverpool and we start from scratch by saying that being in the same space as a symphony orchestra is very exciting. I talk a lot, I clown around a bit, I wear funny clothes_ That all started when I was conducting a Strauss railway polka and came on, at someone's suggestion, in a British Rail cap. The place went up in smoke and so each season I wear a jacket or waistcoat related to the music. I don't do this if I have a soloist and I certainly wouldn't do it for a Beethoven symphony. But I try to dispel the idea that going to a concert is like going to church or school assembly."

Davis is an unashamed populist. He's followed the Liverpool experiment with summer concerts in a soccer stadium in Woking and at Leeds Castle. He's also presented three seasons of classic music on Radio 2 and last year conducted the first ever concert of film music at the Proms. He only becomes cautious when asked if there is hard evidence that an audience's delight in the Beatles or Bernstein leads them on to Beethoven or Bruckner. "Whether there's a continuum_ I don't really know. The evidence is contradictory. In Liverpool they say that the young audience that comes to the Pops is not being seen in the main hall. On the other hand, in Manchester the Hallé reckon that if one does a silent classic or a Broadway night in the Bridge-water Hall, it has a knock-on effect.

"I'm not claiming to change the world. All I'm trying to do is break down social barriers about places of entertainment and encourage more people to enjoy music. You have to start from rock bottom because there is a whole generation that, because of Thatcherite cuts in education, was lost to classical music."

Davis is a man who wears many hats, and not just funny BR ones: composer, conductor, DJ, creator of original scores for film, TV and ballet_ In a whirlwind life, he's recently done the Sullivanesque score for Mike Leigh's forthcoming film Topsy Turvy, and has composed the music for Scottish Ballet's Aladdin. What unifies his activities is his missionary belief that music should be available to all. Ironically, it takes an ebullient American expatriate like Davis to point out basic British socialist truths.

Carl Davis conducts his score for Flesh and the Devil at the Royal Festival Hall, London SE1 (0171-960 4242), on Saturday.

fields.headline: Hedy Lamarr
fields.standfirst: Hollywood star who was billed as the most beautiful girl in the world
fields.trailText: In the 1940s, Hedy Lamarr, who has died aged 86, was thought to be the most beautiful woman in films and was the byword for glamour. "Her beauty made up for whatever she lacked in acting ability," remarked King Vidor, who directed Lamarr in one of her best pictures (HM Pulham Esquire) and one of her worst (Comrade X) . "Acting probably didn't come naturally to her but the note of unsureness in what she did seemed to give her a certain childish attractiveness."
fields.body:
In the 1940s, Hedy Lamarr, who has died aged 86, was thought to be the most beautiful woman in films and was the byword for glamour. "Her beauty made up for whatever she lacked in acting ability," remarked King Vidor, who directed Lamarr in one of her best pictures (HM Pulham Esquire) and one of her worst (Comrade X) . "Acting probably didn't come naturally to her but the note of unsureness in what she did seemed to give her a certain childish attractiveness."

She herself thought, "Any girl can be glamorous: all you have to do is stand still and look stupid." Although Hedy never looked stupid - she had a certain self-mocking twinkle in the eyes - she was often called upon to be no more than a marble mannequin, as in Ziegfeld Girl (1941), stiffly parading around in a star-spangled costume as Tony Martin sang You Stepped Out Of A Dream to her.

Born Hedwig Eva Maria Kiesler in Austria, she had a privileged upbringing as her father was director of the Bank of Vienna. She started acting with Max Reinhardt's theatre company in Berlin, where she appeared in The Weaker Sex and Private Lives, as well as Elizabeth of Austria in Sissi in Vienna. Her name was changed by Louis B Mayer to Lamarr after the silent screen beauty Barbara LaMarr, and also because he thought Kiesler sounded too much like a Yiddish slang word for buttocks.

It certainly wasn't her acting that obtained her an MGM contract. As Hedy Kiesler, the 18-year-old had gained international notoriety by appearing fleetingly naked in a couple of scenes in Ecstasy (1932), a Czech film directed by Gustav Machaty. Pope Pius XII denounced it, Hitler banned it, and the offending scenes were excised from most European and American versions. It was much ado about nothing on. The film itself, shot partly on location, is full of lyrical beauty and stylish eroticism, and Hedy's "kiesler" is hardly seen. Her husband, German munitions magnate Fritz Mandl, a man in his 50s, spent millions trying to buy up all the prints of the film. As his decorative wife, she entertained dinner guests such as Gustav Mahler, Frantz Werfel, as well as Hitler and Mussolini.

Finally, disguising herself as one of her servants, she fled to Paris by train with enough jewels to pay for her passage to New York on board the Normande, on which she met Louis B Mayer. Before the liner had docked, she had secured a new name and a seven-year contract starting at $500 a week. Mayer personally supervised every detail of her star grooming though he was uncertain of what to do with her.

In fact, Mayer loaned her out to Walter Wanger for her Hollywood debut in Algiers (1938), in which Charles Boyer did not say, "Come with me to the Casbah," though the phrase stuck to him for most of his life. Lamarr was ravishing enough to tempt the fugitive Boyer out of the Casbah, into her arms and those of the police. More exoticism came in Lady of the Tropics (1939), her first MGM movie after two years under contract. The film, co-starring Robert Taylor, flopped, despite the publicity line of "The Most Beautiful Girl in the World".

I Take This Woman (1940), starring Spencer Tracy and Lamarr, took two years to reach the screen, by which time it had been dubbed I Retake This Woman; it had been in and out of production for 18 months with three changes of director and miles of rejected footage. The marital melodrama failed to ignite the public, and Mayer cooled towards Hedy. She only got fourth billing in Boom Town (1940), below Clark Gable, Claudette Colbert and Spencer Tracy, playing "the other woman", a role she also took in HM Pulham Esquire (1941), this time enlivening staid Robert Young's existence.

As Dolores "Sweets" Ramirez in Tortilla Flat (1942), she gave what she herself considered her best performance, and if the film had been a success, MGM might have found better roles for her. Certainly better than the sultry hip-swinging half-caste whispering "I am Tondelayo" in White Cargo (1942). At first, MGM considered her for Gaslight (1944), but the studio had lost faith in her, giving the role to Ingrid Bergman instead, who won an Oscar. This led to Lamarr leaving MGM in 1945 to form her own production company, for which she played a number of femme fatales in rather dreary soap operas.

She was virtually a has-been when Cecil B DeMille chose her to play the most famous femme fatale of all in Samson And Delilah (1949). In it, she looked gorgeous in a number of Old Testament off-the-shoulder creations by Edith Head, and managed satisfactorily to deliver lines like, "I shall find the swiftest camels in Gaza, my silver will open the gates that bar your way. All Gaza will be there." Samson And Delilah was by far the biggest box-office hit of her career, which seemed about to be relaunched. But when Cecil B.DeMille offered her a role in The Greatest Show on Earth she declined, because she found the director too autocratic, and disliked his obsession with her feet.

She made only a few more films, including a Western, Copper Canyon (1950), opposite Ray Milland, took the title role in My Favourite Spy (1951) in which she got an unreluctant Bob Hope in her clutches, and was Joan of Arc screaming "Attack!" to her minions in the ludicrous The Story of Mankind (1957). Her final film was The Female Animal (1958), in which she virtually played herself as an ageing movie star.

But retirement did not keep her out of the headlines. She was arrested for shoplifting in 1966 and again in 1991, when she allegedly took $25 worth of toiletries from a Florida chemist. She was cleared of the charge both times. She also became litigious, suing the ghost writers of her titillating autobiography Ecstasy and Me, as well as Mel Brooks for using her name without permission in Blazing Saddles, in which a character called Hedley Lamarr is infuriated by being continually called Hedy Lamarr. She gained nothing on both occasions, and was forced to sell many of her valuable possessions.

She was married six times: her second husband was screenwriter Gene Markey, her third the actor John Loder (with whom she had two children), her fourth was Texas oil millionaire W Howard Lee, the fifth restaurateur-bandleader Ernest Stauffer, and lastly, her own divorce lawyer, Lewis W Boles Jr.

Another aspect of her life was revealed only recently. During the war, she and the composer George Antheil invented a system of preventing the jamming and scrambling of signals via radio frequencies. A patent was granted to them, but the army considered the system too complicated to put into practice. However it was taken up by the military in 1957 and its first application was during the Cuban missile crisis in 1962. It was classified as a top secret defence mechanism until the mid-1980s, when the system was used commercially, especially in the prevention of interception of cell phones by telecommunications.

Her son Anthony Loder explained: "My mother was an extremely intelligent woman, always seething with new ideas. She was known as being just a beautiful face, but is now recognised as having invented a brilliant scientific concept, although she never made a cent out of it."

To the scientists who rather tardily paid homage to her, she sent a message. "I am happy that my invention was not conceived in vain". Occasionally, as an old woman living alone in Florida, she would meet people and say, "Would you believe I was once a famous star? It's the truth."

 Hedy Lamarr (Hedwig Kiesler), actress, born November 9 1913; died January 19 2000

webTitle: The fastest hundred that never was

fields.headline: The fastest hundred that never was
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: I recently met Farokh Engineer, the former Indian Test wicketkeeper, and he told me he holds the record for a century in the fewest number of balls, against West Indies. He acknowledged that this record is not to be found in any cricketing publication, although he's adamant the record is his. Can you throw any light on this? asks N Ashworth
fields.body:
I recently met Farokh Engineer, the former Indian Test wicketkeeper, and he told me he holds the record for a century in the fewest number of balls, against West Indies. He acknowledged that this record is not to be found in any cricketing publication, although he's adamant the record is his. Can you throw any light on this? asks N Ashworth

This was at Madras in 1966-67. Engineer had swashbuckled to 94 by lunch on the first day, and reached his hundred (he was out for 109) shortly afterwards. Unfortunately no record of the number of balls he faced seems to have survived (perhaps an avid Indian statistician has details somewhere?). The fastest-known Test hundred in terms of balls faced is 56, by Viv Richards for West Indies v England at St John's, Antigua, in 1985-86. It's hard to believe that Engineer's was quicker than that. However, it was a magnificent attacking innings - he was facing a top-class bowling attack, in Wes Hall, Charlie Griffith, Garry Sobers and Lance Gibbs. Richards's hundred took 81 minutes, but the fastest-known in minutes is 70 (67 balls), by Australian allrounder Jack Gregory against South Africa at Johannesburg in 1921-22.

During the third Australia-Pakistan Test at Perth, Shane Warne was given out caught behind sweeping, although the ball appeared to come off his forearm. My son thinks off the forearm is out; I say it must be off glove or bat. What is the rule? asks David Stern

Law 32 says the striker is out caught if the ball touches his bat or if it touches below the wrist his hand or glove, holding the bat (and the ball is subsequently held by a fieldsman before it touches the ground). So if Warne was hit on the forearm at Perth he shouldn't have been given out.

Which England cricket captain also won an Olympic gold medal for boxing? asks David Slater

This was John Douglas, who captained England in 18 of his 23 Tests between 1911-12 and 1928-29. He was rather a defensive batsman, and his initials (JWHT) were said to stand for "Johnny Won't Hit Today". At the 1908 Olympic Games, in London, Douglas won the middleweight boxing gold medal. He also played soccer for England at amateur level.

I'm 13, and I'm creating a website about The Art of Slow Left-Arm Bowling. I want to do a page about Daniel Vettori of New Zealand. What would be the best way of getting in touch with him to ask for some tips? asks Daniel Baber

If you log on to the official New Zealand Cricket site on Cricinfo (www.cricket.org) you will be able to send an e-mail to Daniel Vettori. Just click the link "E-mail the Clear Black Caps" at the bottom of the page.

Could you please give me some info on the playing career of Clive Radley? asks Ed Svenson

Clive Thornton Radley, who was born in 1944, played 520 first-class matches for Middlesex between 1964 and 1987. He was a dependable middle-order batsman, with a workmanlike rather than classical technique, who reached 1000 runs in a season 16 times. He was particularly effective in one-day cricket, where his trademark was scampering between the wickets and sliding into the crease like a baseball player. He received a late England call-up at 33, and made a monumental 158 in 648 minutes at Auckland in 1977-78 in only his second Test. He toured Australia in 1978-79, but was hit in the face early on and didn't play another Test, finishing with 481 runs (48.10) from eight matches. He is now MCC's head coach at Lord's.

Who in cricket is known as "The Gnome"? asks Sheena Gaston

It's Keith Fletcher, the former Essex and England batsman, presumably because he looked a bit like one out on the field. For all his diffident exterior, he had a very successful career, particularly when he took over as Essex captain. webTitle: Telegram exposes quest for personal riches in civil war

fields.headline: Telegram exposes quest for personal riches in civil war
fields.trailText: Sordid details of the extent to which the Zimbabwean military is exploiting the Congolese civil war for personal gain are provided in a foreign office telegram leaked to the Guardian.
fields.body:
Sordid details of the extent to which the Zimbabwean military is exploiting the Congolese civil war for personal gain are provided in a foreign office telegram leaked to the Guardian.

The telegram, intended purely for internal Whitehall consumption, also evaluated the risks of a coup by the armed forces in Zimbabwe.

The assessment of the military, titled A Coup for Zimbabwe?, was made by Peter Longworth, the British high commissioner to Harare. The four-page document was dated this month and marked restricted.

Although Mr Longworth concluded that a coup was unlikely, his assessment turned an unflattering spotlight on both the Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, and his armed forces over their conduct in the Congolese civil war.

Mr Longworth, 57, an experienced diplomat who has been in Harare since 1998, said the loyalty of the armed forces was not to the Zimbabwean government but to Mr Mugabe and his inner circle.

Mr Longworth said: "Even Mugabe needs to massage this loyalty and he has added substance to the status and privilege of senior officers with material rewards for services rendered.

"We believe all military commanders of one star and above have received or have the expectation of land cascading from the land acquisition programme.

"Retired generals have acquired business interests directly resulting from their former positions."

Black marketing

He added that Zimbabwe's involvement in the Congolese civil war had contributed to this. "A byproduct of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) operation has been its associated money-spinning opportunities, whether through semi-overt mining ventures or outright black marketing. We hear of some envy among more junior officers who are not getting their share of patronage at home or sufficient of the [financial] action in the DRC but resentment seems to be directed not so much towards the government, as against more senior officers - not an immediate recipe for a coup."

Power struggle

He said: "Even so, all ranks are getting something out of the DRC. The basic benefit has been hard currency allowances. We know that many private soldiers have opened bank accounts in Zimbabwe and are building up respectable deposits.

"They will return to a signficantly higher standard of living than they left, inflation notwithstanding."

He concluded that the armed forces would not stage a coup against Mr Mugabe but the military would have an interest in the succession and "could well become involved if the party power struggle went badly against their favoured presidential candidate. This would take the form of behind-the-scenes kingmaking, rather than putting troops on the street."

Where does the UK fit in? Mr Longworth reports on the Zimbabwean military's unhappiness with the British government for its arms embargo, which is hitting the Zimbabwean air force.

"The military have not understood HMG's position on the DRC and bear a burning resentment as a result of the decision not to continue with supplies of Hawk spares. This will not help us influence events at a senior level in the Zimbabwe defence force," he said.

He said British military involvement with the Zimbabwean defence force helped promote UK values that made it less likely it would mount a coup.

He cautioned against any decisions that might jeopardise that.

fields.headline: Parental leave law challenged
fields.trailText: Cherie Booth yesterday accused her husband's government of breaking European law by excluding millions of parents from new rights to take leave.
fields.body:
Cherie Booth yesterday accused her husband's government of breaking European law by excluding millions of parents from new rights to take leave.

In legal advice prepared for the TUC, Ms Booth, a QC in employment law, says Tony Blair's administration is in breach of the EU parental leave directive - which guarantees all parents up to 13 weeks unpaid leave - because parents of children now under five will not benefit. On the basis of her advice the TUC executive yesterday decided on a legal challenge to the British regulations, brought in by the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers.

Ms Booth, who is expecting her fourth child, insisted her opinion was given to the TUC to protect the government rather than find fault with it. The exclusion of 3.3 million parents, she wrote, "cannot be justified" by the need for flexibility and the European directive "does seem to have been misimplemented".

Under Mr Byers's regulations all mothers, fathers and adoptive parents have the right to take up to 13 weeks' unpaid leave during the first five years of a child's life - but only for children born on or after December 15 last year, the deadline for implementing the EU directive.

The argument is over parents with children under five born before the December cutoff date. The European commission is due to rule next month on a less stringent restriction by Ireland, which applied the right to parents of children born after the date when the directive was passed in 1996, and is expected to find it unlawful.

John Monks, the TUC's general secretary, said last night he hoped the government would now recognise the force of the legal arguments and extend unpaid parental leave to the parents of all under-fives.

The trade and industry department said the government remained convinced there was no requirement under European law to extend the rights.

webTitle: 'Bullying' Yale forces new name on Welsh college

fields.headline: 'Bullying' Yale forces new name on Welsh college
fields.trailText: One of America's oldest and grandest universities has used all its might to force a new college in Wales to change its name or face a huge legal bill.
fields.body:
One of America's oldest and grandest universities has used all its might to force a new college in Wales to change its name or face a huge legal bill.

Yale university insisted that Yale college, in Wrexham, would cause confusion with its name and website, and after the threat of legal action - an intimidatory letter, claimed college principal Emlyn Jones - the Welsh institution caved in.

Yale college, founded in 1993, took the name from Elihu Yale, a 17th century millionaire whose elegant tomb is in the local churchyard. But Yale university, which had altered its own name - from the collegiate school at Saybrook - when the same Mr Yale donated gifts and a portrait of George I in 1718, decided it could not tolerate the effrontery.

Mr Jones could have pointed out that Mr Yale had family links with Wrexham and, though born in Massachusetts, had left the colony aged three, never returned and certainly never seen the Yale campus at New Haven, Connecticut. Yale, too, is an anglicisation of the Welsh ll, which refers to a limestone outcrop near Wrex-ham. "That name predates Columbus by 500 years, so we seem to have history on our side," mused Mr Jones.

But Yale, whose alumni include Bill Clinton, Gerald Ford and George Bush, plus Samuel Morse of code fame, and actor Paul Newman, stood firm, and the deal now is that the college will keep its Welsh name (coleg ll) but in English becomes Yale college of Wrexham.

Mr Yale, who died in 1721, is buried beneath his own epitaph - which sets his name in a worldly context: "Born in America, in Europe bred, In Africa travell'd and in Asia wed, Where long he liv'd and thriv'd; in London dead; Much good, some ill, he did; so hope's all even. And that his soul thro' mercy's gone to Heaven."

webTitle: Tough rules on excluding pupils eased

fields.headline: Tough rules on excluding pupils eased
fields.trailText: The government has agreed to relax rules restricting schools' powers to exclude violent and disruptive children after teachers' leaders claimed they put discipline at risk.
fields.body:
The government has agreed to relax rules restricting schools' powers to exclude violent and disruptive children after teachers' leaders claimed they put discipline at risk.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, will write to every school and education authority in England in the next few days "clarifying" the regulations set out in a circular last summer and making some measures less bureaucratic.

The letter will explain the circumstances in which schools can make an immediate exclusion, such as extreme violence, while amending other rules, including reducing the number of meetings that governing bodies' discipline committees must hold to consider exclusions. Teachers complained that a decision to exclude a pupil could be reversed on a technicality.

Ministers have set a target for the number of pupils permanently excluded to be reduced by a third in two years. Last June the department for education and employment announced a fall of 3% from the high of 12,700 in 1996-97. Confirming the change of approach yesterday, a spokesman said there was no question of relaxing the target.

The National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers and the Secondary Heads Association wrote to Mr Blunkett late last year complaining that the regulations made it impossible to maintain discipline in schools.

The NASUWT said ballots on industrial action were under way in seven schools where members were refusing to teach children they could not exclude.

Its deputy general secretary, Eamonn O'Kane, said the regulations were "bureaucratic, time-consuming and impractical... While we recognise that the government is putting money into learning support units, where disruptive kids can be given extra help, we welcome this change which takes account of practicalities."

The Conservatives said they would abolish targets for exclusions and leave such matters to the discretion of heads. The party leader, William Hague, said: "We will not allow a single child to disrupt the education of children who want to learn."

The shadow education secretary, Theresa May, added: "This is a staggering climbdown, especially when schools can be fined anywhere from £3,000 to £6,000 for every exclusion above the target level."

webTitle: Celebrities join alliance for ban on child smacking

fields.headline: Celebrities join alliance for ban on child smacking
fields.trailText: Writers, comedians and actors have joined Labour peers, child psychologists, police chiefs and lawyers to lobby for legislation to end parents' rights to smack their children.
fields.body:
Writers, comedians and actors have joined Labour peers, child psychologists, police chiefs and lawyers to lobby for legislation to end parents' rights to smack their children.

Comedians Harry Enfield and Ruby Wax, the authors Martin Amis and Helen Fielding, model Jerry Hall, the scriptwriter Richard Curtis, and actors Patsy Kensit and Pete Postlethwaite are among 250 celebrities backing the anti-smacking alliance, Children Are Unbeatable.

Lady Kennedy and Lords Bragg, Puttnam and Hollick have added their support alongside the broadcasters Michael Parkinson, Anna Ford, Jon Snow and Joan Bakewell, lawyers Michael Mansfield and Sir Louis Blom-Cooper, and entrepreneurs Anita Roddick and Richard Branson.

The alliance, formed 18 months ago and backed by more than 200 organisations, will lobby the government in earnest after the launch on Tuesday of Labour's consultation document on beating by parents. The document, Protecting Children; Supporting Parents, proposes prison sentences for parents who use implements on their children or who smack them on the head or ears, but does not consider making smacking illegal.

Commenting on why he was supporting the campaign, the author Ian McEwan, who says he has never hit his two sons, said: "Nobody should hit anyone. I don't see why we should make an exception for children. I think generations to come will look back at our permitting it with amazement."

The alliance, spearheaded by Barnado's, the National Children's Bureau, the NSPCC, Save the Children, and End Physical Punishment of Children has the support of royal colleges, churches and groups concerned with parenting, domestic violence and crime.

Wax said: "The only thing you ensure when you strike a child is that a tiny grenade of violence is carried on to the next generation." Enfield com mented: "If someone twice your size hit you, you'd call them a bully." For Branson there has not been a single time when hitting his child would have been "the right thing to do".

Others backing the campaign include musician John Dankworth, broadcasters Jonathan Dimbleby and Bel Mooney, television presenters Noel Edmonds and Mariella Frostrup, and directors Sir Richard Eyre, Trevor Nunn and Stephen Frears.

Groups include the Methodist church, the United Reform church, Society of Friends, the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, British Agen-cies for Adoption and Fostering, Kids' Clubs network, Child Poverty Action Group, the Mental Health Foundation, the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders, Crime Concern, Victim Support, and the Howard League for Penal Reform.

The full list of campaign backers is available on the website: www.newsunlimited.co.uk/comment

webTitle: Student died of infection from breast surgery

fields.headline: Student died of infection from breast surgery
fields.trailText: A student aged 20 died from blood poisoning less than two weeks after an operation to reduce her breast size, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A student aged 20 died from blood poisoning less than two weeks after an operation to reduce her breast size, an inquest heard yesterday.

Natalie Baylis, of Carlton Colville, Suffolk, is believed to have picked up an infection from the plastic surgeon who carried out the routine operation at West Norwich hospital last August.

After the inquest in Norwich, Miss Baylis's parents Tom and Christine, said they were planning to launch a legal investigation into her treatment. The coroner, William Armstrong, recorded a verdict of misadventure.

Hospital officials said after the hearing that Jonathon Clibbon, the registrar who operated on Miss Baylis, had been an unwitting carrier of the streptococcus septicaemia infection and could not be blamed for the tragedy. A spokesman said the hospital was satisfied that she had received the best possible care.

The inquest heard that Miss Baylis, a business and marketing student at Sunderland university, had complained of pain in her breasts, loin and back in the days after the operation.

Her condition worsened, and she was moved to intensive care at Norfolk and Norwich hospital. But despite a consultant plastic surgeon's attempts to control the infection she died.

The inquest heard that five other patients had picked up infections at around the same time as Miss Baylis but all made full recoveries.

Mr Clibbon had stopped work as soon as it was confirmed that he was a carrier of the infection. The hospital spokesman said he had since resumed work.

The inquest heard that wide-ranging tests were carried out on staff and patients, and all but emergency operations were stopped until the cause of the infection was established.

fields.headline: An enemy of justice
fields.standfirst:
Jack Straw's illiberal bill to restrict the right to trial by jury must be defeated

Are your rights at risk? Find out here
fields.trailText: When Michael Dukakis ran for the presidency, Reaganites attacked him as a card-carrying member of the American Civil Liberties Union. I am a card-carrying member of Liberty, the British equivalent, and I too am under attack for opposing restrictions on jury trial. We in the Lords will vote on it today.
fields.body:
When Michael Dukakis ran for the presidency, Reaganites attacked him as a card-carrying member of the American Civil Liberties Union. I am a card-carrying member of Liberty, the British equivalent, and I too am under attack for opposing restrictions on jury trial. We in the Lords will vote on it today.

It seems that there is now a formula for getting illiberal legal change through parliament and past the public: divert attention by attacking the people with the most experience and insist that they are "fat cat" lawyers whose real interest is in lining their own pockets; maintain that the reform is another bold step in the difficult modernising project, impeded by the forces of conservatism; and, above all, insist that change is being introduced in the interests of victims. Victims have become a magical category, hijacked to justify any erosion of rights because most people can imagine themselves being victims and can't imagine needing legal aid or or a jury.

This is a well-honed, public relations mantra. But I have spent my professional life acting for the least privileged in our courts - an alleycat by comparison with the very sleek and glossy commercial lawyers who seem to have the government's ear. I do not stand to earn an extra sou from this. I argued for the rights of victims and the "modernising" of bar, bench and the criminal justice system long before it became fashionable. So people like me cannot be so readily marginalised as "fat cats". We must then be "woolly liberals", I suppose. God bless us. People like me are appalled by this change to the jury system, but not through ritual adherence to tradition. It is concern about taking a fundamental right away from the citizen, giving the choice about jury trial to magistrates who are largely white and middle-class and not legally qualified. Magistrates do a great job, indeed they handle 97% of all criminal cases, most of which are pleas of guilty. And they come cheap. However, anyone who sits on cases too regularly tends to become case hardened, and cynical about the people who appear in the dock. If I were facing a theft charge or a charge of assault, I would most certainly want the fresh eyes and breadth of human experience that comes with the jury. Why should it be within the magistrates' gift whether I get it? And if I am refused my jury, are the magistrates who try me going to sit and speculate as to why I am not off in the crown court getting jury trial? Are they assuming I must have a load of convictions or be a jobless layabout?

The black community is entitled to be alarmed at this change because they foresee how invidious the choosing by the magistrates might be. The bill indicates that the magistrates should consider whether the accused has a reputation deserving of protection or is someone with previous convictions. What happens if you are unemployed, or homeless, or you are a young black man with a couple of convictions for cannabis, now charged with assault or burglary? And there will be the usual variables as to your chances between the Croydon bench, say, or the beak in Ipswich.

Jack Straw argues that similar changes have been wrought by previous Labour home secretaries. However, they affected every citizen in the same way. Jury trial was removed for criminal damage under a certain value and assault on the police became a summary offence, but these changes affected rich and poor, black and white alike. The potential for discrimination with this new legislation is considerable. It is socially and racially divisive. It is as though the debates around Stephen Lawrence's death exist inside a box marked "police" and have no relevance to other parts of the justice system where there is also institutional racism.

Jack Straw insists that the black community is deluded, citing research which shows black people faring slightly better than whites in the magistrates courts. This is probably because black people are consistently overcharged or wrongly charged in the first place. It has also been suggested to me that those statistics are distorted because the discrimination experienced by black people is shared by the Irish and other minority groups. Placed in the white group, they make the picture for black people look more favourable than it actually is.

The other argument spun by the home office is that the Scots do not get to choose the mode of trial, so why should the English? It seems a madness to me that this is being argued when there should be growing recognition that law is cultural and not a set of transferable rules. That is why Britain is resisting those in Europe who want all-consuming legal harmonisation. Jack Straw expresses concern at the rise of rightwing English nationalism in the wake of devolution, but instead of pointing up the good and decent things which are distinctly English he argues for cherrypicking of the Scottish system, which is different on so many counts. These cases would be tried by a judge in Scotland, either with or without a jury, and when he or she does sit without a jury the maximum power of sentencing is three months imprisonment with no power to commit to a higher court for sentence. A very different and more severe set of powers rest with magistrates south of the border.

The cost and time-saving arguments are also now exposed as a nonsense. Obliged by the new human rights act to include a right of appeal from the magistrates' decision, there will have to be legal aid for that and cases will ping-pong between the courts. If this is to stop people electing trial and then pleading guilty at the crown court, all you have to do is create sticks and carrots: last-minute pleas can carry additional penalties. But the bill's changes will be costly and time-consuming. Hell mend them, as my granny would say of those who advocate this mess. She would also have added that the policy fellow who thought this one up should be sacked immediately.

The folly in all this is that juries are a good thing . They really are democracy in action. While all the talk in Whitehall is about social cohesion and citizenship and the creation of social capital, and think tanks are thinking and wonks are wonking, here we have one of the most awe-inspiring examples of citizen engagement being eroded by the same people who agonise at the loss of civic responsibility.

Jack Straw's bill to remove the right to jury trial is a thoroughly illiberal measure that should be voted down today by the Lords: not only by Liberal Democrats, Conservatives and cross-benchers but by every self-respecting Labour peer who cares about liberty and justice. It is not with relish that we should part company with the government on this. It is because we have to speak out when we know something is profoundly wrong.

fields.headline: Jury rebels expect Straw defeat
fields.standfirst: Are your rights at risk? Find out here
fields.trailText: Campaigners against moves to limit the right to trial by jury were last night convinced that Jack Straw's plan will be defeated in the House of Lords today.
fields.body:
Campaigners against moves to limit the right to trial by jury were last night convinced that Jack Straw's plan will be defeated in the House of Lords today.

Although the arithmetic is expected to be tight, a significant number of abstentions amongst Labour peers is set to seal the fate of Mr Straw's controversial bill in the first clash between the government and peers since the Lords' in-built Tory majority was removed through the departure of the hereditary peers. The chief Labour opponent of reform, the Blairite Labour peer Helena Kennedy QC, today delivers a fierce broadside against government critics of her questioning of the changes.

Writing in the Guardian, the normally loyal Lady Kennedy accuses the government of using attacks on "fat cat" lawyers and a professed concern for the rights of victims in order to divert attention from "getting illiberal legal change through parliament and past the public". Lady Kennedy's attack follows Mr Straw's dismissal of his opponents as "woolly-minded" and Downing Street claims that the government was about to take on "the forces of conservatism in the legal profession".

Lady Kennedy argues: "I have spent my professional life acting for the least privileged in our courts. I am certainly an alley cat by comparison with the very sleek and glossy commercial lawyers who seem to have the government's ear."

The cross-party challenge to the criminal justice (mode of trial) bill is not expected to lead to full-scale rebellion in Labour's ranks, but the new composition of the upper house - 180 Labour peers, 230 Conservatives, 50 Liberal Democrats and 160 cross-benchers - means the government may face defeat anyway. The rebels hope to restore the right of the accused to choose jury trial for middle-ranking offences such as burglary and theft while leaving the legislation itself intact. This has provoked the home secretary to threaten to drop the bill completely if it is amended.

webTitle: Eidos celebrates Tomb Raider Dreamcast deal

fields.headline: Eidos celebrates Tomb Raider Dreamcast deal
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Eidos, the computer games maker which issued a profits warning on Tuesday after weak sales in the run up to Christmas, has been thrown a potential lifeline by a deal to distribute its Tomb Raider game on Sega's new Dreamcast console.
fields.body:
Eidos, the computer games maker which issued a profits warning on Tuesday after weak sales in the run up to Christmas, has been thrown a potential lifeline by a deal to distribute its Tomb Raider game on Sega's new Dreamcast console.

The agreement follows the end of a contract with Sony to format the series exclusively for the Playstation and PCs and could provide a fillip for the Eidos share price. Yesterday, shares in the company slipped another 2.5% to £25.48 after losing a third of their value on the back of the warning.

"This will bail them out after the last couple of weeks which have been a disaster," said one media analyst. "Tomb Raider is a pretty decent franchise and they could get away another half a million on the back of Dreamcast which would add perhaps £5m to profits this year."

Sega hopes that Dreamcast, which has a built-in modem for internet access and online playing, will enable it to get back into contention in a market which has been dominated in recent years by Sony. Sega claims to have sold 250,000 Dreamcast consoles in Britain alone since launch at the end of last year.

Eidos made pre-tax profits of £37.9m last year on sales of £226.3m.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: On edge Wall Street was skittish yesterday as it waited for some of America's largest companies to report their results late last night.
fields.body:
 On edge Wall Street was skittish yesterday as it waited for some of America's largest companies to report their results late last night.

The technology sector was particularly nervous ahead of announcements from bellwether companies such as IBM, the world's biggest computer hardware group, and Apple, the software company.

The Nasdaq composite index was trading up just 16 points at midday after a weak morning. America Online , the internet service provider which announced the ground- breaking takeover of Time Warner last week, was also due to report earnings after markets closed in New York.

IBM was expected to report a 14% drop in quarterly earnings largely because customers stopped buying large computers in the run-up to the end of the year.

The company horrified Wall Street several months ago when it warned that fears over Y2K would hit sales.

Some analysts now believe that sales of mainframe computers could be as much as 60% lower than the same time last year.

webTitle: Blair plans to keep PR vote hopes alive

fields.headline: Blair plans to keep PR vote hopes alive
fields.standfirst: Proportional representation: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will face down opponents of his links with the Liberal Democrats by placing a commitment in Labour's next election manifesto that will keep alive the prospects of electoral reform.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will face down opponents of his links with the Liberal Democrats by placing a commitment in Labour's next election manifesto that will keep alive the prospects of electoral reform.

Alarmed by reports that the prime minister is going cool on his "project" to realign the centre-left, senior Labour sources have made made clear that Mr Blair remains deeply committed to Lib-Lab links. "There is no way the prime minister is saying goodbye to this," one well-placed Labour source said.

Labour sources went out of their way to talk up Downing Street's commitment to the "project" after Liberal Democrats reacted angrily over the weekend when the prime minister appeared to distance himself from electoral reform.

Within hours of Mr Blair's remarks on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost, the Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy warned that "all bets" would be off if Labour's next election manifesto failed to contain a commitment to a referendum on electoral reform.

The prime minister, who refused to give a commitment on Frost that he would hold a referendum, has made clear in private this week that electoral reform will be included in the manifesto."The idea of electoral reform has not been removed," the Labour source said. "There will be some reference to it in the manifesto."

In a sign of the fierce internal debate over the issue in the Labour party, however, the source said that Mr Blair has still not made up his mind whether to give a specific commitment to hold a referendum.

The prime minister has sounded more cool in public about electoral reform in recent months after an internal Labour consultation showed that the party grassroots are overwhelmingly opposed to abolishing Westminster's first-past-the-post system. Labour will vote on the issue at this year's conference and supporters of change fear that a vote for the status quo could set back their cause by years.

Lib Dems have reluctantly accepted that no referendum will be held this side of the general election - despite Labour's commitment in its 1997 manifesto - and are demanding a clear commitment in the party's next manifesto.

Labour supporters of electoral reform last night welcomed the positive signal from Downing Street. Stephen Twigg, MP for Enfield Southgate, said: "I have been encouraged by Tony Blair's remarks in recent weeks because he said that people should have a choice on electoral reform at some stage. We have already accepted that a referendum will not be in this parliament - we now have to work to make sure it takes place in the next parliament."

Supporters of the status quo were adamant that they were winning round the prime minister who is still officially "unpersuaded" of the need for reform. Fraser Kemp, Labour MP for Houghton and Washington East, said: "The indications are that PR is dead in the water. The chances of it being introduced are about as much as William Hague winning the next election."

Blairite sources qualified their enthusiasm for Lib-Lab links by admitting that the relationship between the two parties has worsened since Paddy Ashdown retired as party leader in August. One Labour source said: "The links are not as strong as they were. It was Tony and Paddy's project and had a head of steam. This is not Charles Kennedy's project, but that does not mean it is over."

fields.headline: BT's £130m settles Esat legal dispute
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: British Telecommunications has been forced to pay out £130m to dampen a legal row triggered by its acquisition of Ireland's second largest telecoms business, Esat, last week.
fields.body:
British Telecommunications has been forced to pay out £130m to dampen a legal row triggered by its acquisition of Ireland's second largest telecoms business, Esat, last week.

BT is using the cash to buy the Irish Electricity Supply Board out of Ocean, their fledgling, fixed-wire joint venture in the republic. The ESB was angered by BT's £1.5bn acquisition of Esat, which it said broke agreements not to compete with Ocean.

The deal hammered out over several days of talks will leave BT as the sole owner of Ocean and removes the final obstacles from its acquisition of Esat. A BT spokesman said the company is "happy to have brought a period of uncertainty to an end."

Analysts, though, rounded on BT which has had to weave its way through a complex set of negotiations since emerging as a white knight to rescue Esat from the unwanted attentions of Norway's Telenor.

"They found themselves with their backs against the wall and so have paid a pretty full price for the stake in Ocean," said one analyst. Shares in BT which had dropped 3% on the original deal fell another 32p to £12.49.

After last week's agreement BT had to offer Telenor around £750m for its existing share in Esat's mobile phone network or else a third stake in the wider Esat group.

ESB, which invested around IR£22.5m (£17.7m) in the business which was set up in 1998, said it was happy with the turn on its investment. "Our main objective was to ensure the value of our assets was protected and their value fully recognised" a spokesman said.

 Tim Samples, managing director of One2One, has quit the mobile phone network five months after it was acquired by Germany's Deutsche Telekom. Mr Samples is joining an unnamed London telecoms start-up business and said he had been lured partly by the promise of equity.

"One2One has become a massive business and I was anxious to go back to something much smaller and build from the ground up," he said.

webTitle: Business is booming on Britain's B2B site

fields.headline: Business is booming on Britain's B2B site
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A British website has become the busiest business-to-business (B2B) trade site in Europe, just 90 days after its launch.
fields.body:
A British website has become the busiest business-to-business (B2B) trade site in Europe, just 90 days after its launch.

The site, eceurope.com, which allows companies to post digital classified ads for goods and services, is receiving nearly 1,000 "for sale" and "wanted" ads every week for everything from timber to medical supplies.

The site has also generated 4,472 subscribers since its launch in October last year, making it the fastest-growing site of its kind in Europe.

Share price of the site's main backer, City of London PR which owns 49.9% of the company, almost tripled on the news, from last week's price of around 120p to close yesterday at 325p.

The site's managing director, Jonathan Cutting, began in 1997 to compile a directory of over 1,300 international trade sites and decided to set up his own to meet what he saw as an urgent need for a high-quality B2B site for Europe.

Although most trade sites allow companies to post offers to buy or sell from anywhere in the world, sites specific to countries, industries or geographical regions have become more prevalent in recent years owing to the sheer number of companies using them to look for sales leads.

Mr Cutting's directory, URL2Trade, which includes details of a variety of B2B resources available on the web, will shortly be appearing on-line as part of eceurope.com.

webTitle: Hamilton faces court summons after naming only one libel suit backer

fields.headline: Hamilton faces court summons after naming only one libel suit backer
fields.standfirst: Special reports on the Hamilton- Al Fayed libel case on the Guardian network at www.newsunlimited.co.uk/hamilton
fields.trailText: Neil Hamilton is to be summoned back to the high court after disclosing the name of only one backer who funded his failed libel action against the Harrods owner, Mohamed Al Fayed.
fields.body:
Neil Hamilton is to be summoned back to the high court after disclosing the name of only one backer who funded his failed libel action against the Harrods owner, Mohamed Al Fayed.

A court order gave the disgraced former Conservative minister until Tuesday night to provide the names of anyone who had put up more than £5,000.

A letter received by Mr Fayed's solicitors at 5.25pm on that day listed a sole Hamilton supporter, thought to be the Earl of Portsmouth.

The letter also said that neither Mr Hamilton nor his legal team knew the identity of any other wealthy backers, and invited Mr Fayed to contact Lord Harris of High Cross, who co-ordinated the fighting fund.

Laurie Mayer, Mr Fayed's spokesman, described the response as delaying tactics, and said the Harrods owner would be seeking a court hearing to force Mr Hamilton to comply with the court order.

"I promised them strict confidentiality and that's how it stands," he said.

fields.headline: Archer faces sack from Tories
fields.standfirst:
Tories in opposition: special report
The fall of Archer: special report
fields.trailText: Jeffrey Archer faces expulsion from the Conservative party after he was summoned to a secret meeting of the party's new ethics and integrity committee last week.
fields.body:
Jeffrey Archer faces expulsion from the Conservative party after he was summoned to a secret meeting of the party's new ethics and integrity committee last week.

The millionaire novelist, who is determined to remain in the party, was represented at the hearing in London by the veteran South African civil rights lawyer Sydney Kentridge.

The Tory leadership refused last night to comment on the meeting, which was chaired by Elizabeth Appleby QC.

However, sources made clear that they could not wait to see the back of Lord Archer, who had to stand down as the Tory candidate for London mayor last year after admitting asking a friend to lie in a libel trial. "Jeffrey has behaved very badly," one source said.

The ethics committee, set up by William Hague to clear up the party's image, will disclose nothing about its deliberations. Ms Appleby criticised central office last year for briefing against Lord Archer before her committee began its work.

However, his future in the party looks bleak. He revived memories of the Tory sleaze of the mid 1990s when he admitted that he was prepared to allow a friend to perjure himself in his 1987 libel trial against the Daily Star.

Mr Hague, who was informed that the committee met last Thursday, said at the weekend he was looking forward to its pressing on with its investigation of the novelist. "I've called the ethics and integrity committee in, and they arrange their own meetings," he told BBC1's On the Record.

"Their report has to be independent of me, and they will be proceeding with that over the next few weeks."

The committee includes Sir Archibald Hamilton, chairman of the 1922 committee of backbench MPs, and Robin Hodgson, chairman of the national convention which oversees the voluntary wing of the party.

webTitle: Blair sticks to his guns in face of Tory taunts

fields.headline: Blair sticks to his guns in face of Tory taunts
fields.standfirst:
Special report: The future of the NHS

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday insisted he is "entirely confident" that the government will be able to increase spending on the NHS for the five years it will need to reach the average EU spending on health and attacked Conservative calls for more private insurance as a "ludicrous notion".
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday insisted he is "entirely confident" that the government will be able to increase spending on the NHS for the five years it will need to reach the average EU spending on health and attacked Conservative calls for more private insurance as a "ludicrous notion".

But the prime minister faced ferocious Tory taunts at question time in the Commons as William Hague accused him of backtracking from what had been widely seen as a firm pledge - not the mere "aspiration" which Downing Street and the treasury now say it was.

"So far we've had Frost on Sunday, panic on Monday, u-turn on Tuesday and waffle on Wednesday," said Mr Hague. Mr Blair insisted: "I stand entirely by what I said on the Frost programme," and quoted extracts where he had stressed that the extra cash would only be available "if we run the economy properly over the next few years. I am entirely confident we will get those 5% real term rises," he told MPs. He accused Mr Hague of "zero judgment" on yet another policy initiative, one which would force people over 60 to pay up to £80 a week for insurance for non-urgent operations

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, who has made higher spending on public services a central campaign theme, complained that Labour's 1p income tax cut in April will be worth £2.4bn - and should be spent "on solving the problems of the health service". Mr Blair said the cut was "in part compensation for other tax changes that have been made."
