webTitle: Paying for the PM's health cash pledge

fields.headline: Paying for the PM's health cash pledge
fields.standfirst: Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Shock waves from Tony Blair's pledge to increase NHS spending to European levels have been reverberating across Whitehall from the moment the microphones were turned off on the Frost programme on Sunday morning. While the prime minister's intervention was just what the doctor ordered for Alan Milburn, other ministers were doing a simple calculation: does more money for the NHS mean there's nothing left for me?
fields.body:
Shock waves from Tony Blair's pledge to increase NHS spending to European levels have been reverberating across Whitehall from the moment the microphones were turned off on the Frost programme on Sunday morning. While the prime minister's intervention was just what the doctor ordered for Alan Milburn, other ministers were doing a simple calculation: does more money for the NHS mean there's nothing left for me?

David Blunkett, for one, has asked whether the NHS commitment is compatible with the government's promise to raise the proportion of national output spent on schools and colleges and the rallying cry of "education, education, education".

As a result, since Sunday both Downing Street and the treasury have been stressing the caveats carefully mentioned by Mr Blair on Sunday. Raising health spending is now "an aspiration" rather than a cast-iron pledge.

So how do the numbers stack up? Britain currently spends 6.7% of GDP on health, compared to an EU average of 8%. Given that Britain's GDP is currently just short of £900bn, that would mean spending on the NHS would have to be around £12bn higher at the end of a five-year-period to close the gap. That means above-inflation increases of around 5% for the next five years.

In reality, the increase needed may be slightly higher than that, since the size of the UK economy will grow over the next five years, and the rest of Europe could spend more on health as their economies recover from the spending squeeze imposed as they tried to qualify for monetary union.

On the face of it, bringing the NHS into line with other European health systems would empty Gordon Brown's war chest in one fell swoop. The latest treasury forecasts show that by 2003-04 the government will be running a current surplus of £12bn. Mr Blunkett and others have been doing their sums: a £12bn increase in NHS spending wipes out the surplus and leaves nothing for schools, transport, the police, Scotland, Wales and so on. It may also mean playing fast and loose with the chancellor's golden rule - which forbids him from borrowing money over the economic cycle for anything other than infrastructure projects - and Mr Brown is highly unlikely to agree to that.

However, the true picture may be more favourable than the treasury is admitting. It is entirely plausible that the government will have enough money to spend an extra £12bn on the NHS and find more money for other priorities. But this will depend on the economy continuing to do well and above-inflation increases in "sin taxes" on cigarettes and petrol.

Underlying the government's arithmetic is the cautious assumption that the economy grows by 2.25% a year - its long-term trend for the past century. It uses this figure to work out tax revenues and projected spending. But the treasury believes the economy's trend rate of growth is now 2.5%, largely as a result of there being more people of working age.

The difference between the two figures - an extra 0.25 percentage points of growth a year - sounds miniscule, but its impact on the government's finances would be considerable over time. On the basis that the economy's output is worth £1trn, slightly higher growth means GDP is £2.5 bn higher in the first year, but £14bn higher in the fifth year. The cumulative increase in GDP would be around £40bn, of which around two-fifths would be higher government spending.

The second piece of good news for spending ministers is that the chancellor's fiscal numbers make two key assumptions, both of which make the public finances look worse than they actually are. One is that there will be no above-inflation increases in tobacco and fuel duties in future budgets following the decision to scrap the automatic real annual increases of 5% on smokers and 6% on drivers. Treasury projections are based on no real increases at all in the coming years, which would cost the government £1.25 bn in 2000-01, building up to £6bn by 2003-04.

It seems probable that there will be above-inflation increases in sin taxes, particularly since any extra money raised from cigarettes has been earmarked for the NHS.

The second treasury assumption is that unemployment is about to take a sharp turn for the worse. Mr Brown stashed away a total of £5.25bn for the three-year period up to 2001-02 on the basis that unemployment would be 1.55m in the final quarter of 1999, 1.7m by the end of this year and 1.73m by the end of 2001. Figures yesterday showed the number of people out of work and claiming benefit in December stood at 1.16m and falling. The chancellor has also increased his contingency reserve - money set aside for a rainy day - by a total of £8bn over the next three years.

So there should be plenty of money available when the government unveils its second comprehensive spending review in the summer, and no need to raise taxes (other than sin taxes). Assuming that Mr Brown is prepared to halve his projected surplus and increase sin taxes by around 3% in real terms, the government might have around £18bn extra to play with in five years time. If spending on health rises by £12bn, that would leave up to £6bn for everything else.

There are risks to all this, most obviously that the economy fails to perform as well as expected. As the Conservatives found to their cost at the start of the 1990s, recession slashes tax revenues and pushes up spending on social security. In those circumstances, there would be no dividend from economic growth, leaving the government with the choice of increasing health spending either through extra borrowing or higher taxation.

The consequence of spending more on the NHS -let alone education - will be to increase the share of GDP accounted for by public spending. Bringing the public sector up to European levels will mean accepting European-style levels of public spending and taxes.

Even if everything goes according to plan, there will be precious little room to cut taxes for middle England in the run-up to the election, and interest rates may rise if the Bank of England starts to worry about higher spending pushing up inflation. As all governments know, there is no such thing as a free lunch.

Brown's war chest

The chancellor's spending options by 2004-5

 Reducing his surplus from £12bn to £6bn: raises extra £6bn.

 Dividend from growth at 2.5%: Raises extra £6bn.

 Increasing sin taxes: Raises £3bn.

 Lower unemployment: Raises £3bn.

Total : £18bn.

 Less higher spending on NHS: £12bn.

 Net figure for other spending or tax cuts: £6bn.

webTitle: Accountant sorry for new year antics

fields.headline: Accountant sorry for new year antics
fields.standfirst: The Millennium: special report
fields.trailText: An accountant has taken out a newspaper advertisement so that he can publicly apologise for his behaviour on New Year's Eve.
fields.body:
An accountant has taken out a newspaper advertisement so that he can publicly apologise for his behaviour on New Year's Eve.

Howard Potter said he wanted to say sorry to everyone he had "castigated, vilified, insulted, embarrassed or, worst, bored" during his celebratory night out.

The 52-year-old, who lives in Dinas Powys, near Cardiff, said he had taken out the advert after finding out what he had done from those who were still prepared to "speak civilly" to him.

Mr Potter, who runs an accountancy firm in his home village, was out drinking champagne in Cardiff on the eve of the new millennium. In the advert, taken out in the Western Mail, he addressed his apology "to whom it may concern".

He went on to say sorry to "the entire staff of the Cardiff Hilton hotel, several city centre landlords, the beadle at Cardiff Castle, the residents of Prospect Drive in Llandaff, a man called Toni at a fish bar in Caroline Street, two passing police constables he met and, finally, the cleansing department of Cardiff city council".

Mr Potter ended the note by denying he was sponsored by Veuve Cliquot, the makers of the £25-a-bottle champagne he was drinking.

His wife said that Mr Potter was a "larger than life" character who was quite well known in Cardiff.

They "broke the mould" when they made him, she commented.

Mrs Potter added that family and friends had been amused by the advert.

webTitle: Sharif indicted for murder plot three months after coup

fields.headline: Sharif indicted for murder plot three months after coup
fields.standfirst: Pakistan coup: special report
fields.trailText: The former prime minister of Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif, was formally charged yesterday with a series of offences that carry the death sentence.
fields.body:
The former prime minister of Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif, was formally charged yesterday with a series of offences that carry the death sentence.

During a brief appearance in a special anti-terrorism court in the southern port city of Karachi, Mr Sharif, who was ousted by the military in a coup just over three months ago, was indicted for terrorism, hijacking and conspiracy to murder.

Mr Sharif pleaded not guilty to all charges.

The judge appeared to have rejected the prosecution's request to charge the former prime minister with treason.

Mr Sharif's co-defendants - his brother Shabhaz, a former senior minister and four senior officials - also pleaded not guilty to charges relating to events on October 12, the day of the military coup.

Prosecution lawyers say that Mr Sharif and his aides attempted to force a plane carrying the leader of the armed forces, General Pervez Musharraf, and 198 passengers to crash by denying it permission to land in Pakistan even though they knew it was running low on fuel.

Mr Sharif told the court: "Actually, Gen Musharraf hijacked the plane himself [and] he hijacked the democratically elected government of Pakistan."

Referring to the night of the coup he said: "Two dozen gunmen came to arrest me then [for five weeks] I was unaware of the charges against me."

Although Mr Sharif, 51, has been incarcerated since October 12, legal arguments have delayed the start of proceedings. The most recent row was over the right of Mr Sharif's lawyers to tapes of conversations between the Pakistan International Airlines plane and air traffic controllers.

The outcome of the trial is crucial to Gen Musharraf's government. Its claims of legitimacy have been based on the alleged criminal nature of the previous administration. If Mr Sharif is acquitted, then Gen Musharraf has a serious problem in justifying the takeover.

He also faces a growing domestic disappointment in his government. Although he has tried to maintain the momentum of a national anti-corruption campaign, less than a tenth of the 211bn rupees (£2.5bn ) owed to banks by businessmen and cronies of the last government have been recouped.

The respected Friday Times newspaper last week wrote: "We understand that radical reforms can't be wrought overnight, but evidence of political immaturity and lack of strategic thinking is beginning to litter the bleak landscape of our beloved country."

Mr Sharif's full trial will start next Wednesday and few believe the death sentence will be passed if he is found guilty. "The political fallout internationally would be too damaging and Musharraf is not the kind of man to take things that far," said one political analyst.

Following a spate of bombings in Pakistan, police yesterday defused a bomb in the car park of a Karachi civil court building. It was found stuffed in a bag beneath a vehicle, witnesses said. On Monday, a bomb in Karachi killed eight and injured three. Police blamed the explosion on India's secret services.

The respected Friday Times newspaper last week wrote: "We understand that radical reforms can't be wrought overnight, but evidence of political immaturity and lack of strategic thinking is beginning to litter the bleak landscape of our beloved country." Mr Sharif's full trial will start next Wednesday and few believe the death sentence will be passed if he is found guilty. "The political fallout internationally would be too damaging and Musharraf is not the kind of man to take things that far," said one political analyst. Following a spate of bombings in Pakistan, police yesterday defused a bomb in the car park of a Karachi civil court building. It was found stuffed in a bag beneath a vehicle, witnesses said. On Monday, a bomb in Karachi killed eight and injured three. Police blamed the explosion on India's secret services.

fields.headline: Troops clash in central Grozny
fields.standfirst:
Rebel commanders vow to wage guerrilla war across breakaway republic if Russians drive them out of Chechen capital

Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Bitter hand-to-hand fighting was raging between Russian troops and Chechen guerrillas in the centre of Grozny yesterday in what appeared to be the climactic battle for control of the Chechen capital.
fields.body:
Bitter hand-to-hand fighting was raging between Russian troops and Chechen guerrillas in the centre of Grozny yesterday in what appeared to be the climactic battle for control of the Chechen capital.

Backed by salvoes of artillery shells and air cover, Russian troops advanced from several points on Minutka Square, just south of the centre and the scene of a massacre of Russian troops last month.

The Russians said they had taken control of a key city centre bridge over the Sunzha river, a claim contested by the Chechens.

"The fighting in Grozny is getting increasingly intensive and fierce with every hour that passes," said Aslanbek Islamilov, chief of the Chechen forces in Grozny.

"Everything is destroyed in Grozny. My house was completely demolished," said Hazan Dukayev, a Grozny resident who has just fled east to the town of Gudermes which was visited yesterday by a Council of Europe delegation led by Lord Russell-Johnston.

But despite the Russian advance to the city centre and predictions by the Kremlin that the city would fall this week, Malik Saidullayev, a prominent Chechen businessman loyal to Moscow, said the Russian military still had a long way to go to capture Grozny.

"The situation there is far from the one painted by the military reports. Vladimir Putin should double-check the reports because they are 70% untrue," he added.

And a Chechen commander in the city told the Interfax news agency that the rebels were deliberately luring Russians into the city in order to ambush them.

"The real fighting in Grozny will begin only after Russian troops are drawn fully into the streets and advance to the city centre," said Mumadi Saidayev. "We want armoured vehicles to appear on the streets since the mobile groups that know how to destroy armour are ready for that."

He conceded the Chechen capital would fall to the Russians but warned that Moscow would pay a "huge price". He predicted that the Grozny fighters would spread guerrilla war across Chechnya after receiving orders to abandon the city.

Despite the presence of foreign visitors in the region, the Russians pressed home their offensive and one of the Russian commanders, General Gennady Troshev, bluntly told the Europeans: "The western public must understand that if the terrorists are not eliminated in Chechnya, they may turn up in Europe."

He predicted that the war would be over by February 26, exactly one month before Vladimir Putin, prime minister and acting president, expects to be elected to succeed Boris Yeltsin. The Russian deputy prime minister in charge of Chechnya, Nikolai Koshman, said the conflict would be under control by March.

The Russian attempts to control the visit by the delegation from the Council of Europe - which is to consider suspending Russia's membership next week - backfired in Gudermes when local residents complained bitterly about the occupying forces.

The Russians took Gudermes with barely a shot being fired in November and have repeatedly asserted that the locals are content to be living in a town garrisoned by the Russians. Mr Koshman is in the process of moving his administration there and has said it will be the new capital of the republic.

But yesterday in Gudermes Lord Russell-Johnston was confronted by local women shouting: "We want them out."

"Russia is pretending to own this land, but they treat us all like terrorists," one man told reporters travelling with the delegation. "The Russians have created instability so they could destroy us completely."

At a refugee camp in Ingushetia, west of Chechnya, the Council of Europe team was encircled by two rings of Russian troops and police in order to minimise the visitors' contact with the homeless Chechens who were shouting for help and support.

"The visit was totally controlled by the [Russian] interior ministry," said Peter Boukaert of Human Rights Watch in Ingushetia.

Mr Saidullayev said he was negotiating with unnamed Chechen commanders who had not taken part in the war and that he was also in touch with aides to president Aslan Maskhadov of Chechnya.

fields.headline: Versailles suspends finance chief
fields.trailText: Troubled trading group Versailles yesterday suspended long-serving finance director Fred Clough, 24 hours after the serious fraud office launched a full-scale criminal investigation into the company.
fields.body:
Troubled trading group Versailles yesterday suspended long-serving finance director Fred Clough, 24 hours after the serious fraud office launched a full-scale criminal investigation into the company.

It is thought that new evidence of accounting irregularities, uncovered this week, triggered both the SFO move and Mr Clough's suspension.

Versailles says its action against Mr Clough - who has been with the company since it was founded in 1989 - had been prompted by information supplied to it on Tuesday night.

The group would not elaborate but it is believed one of the two teams of accountants currently combing the group's books has found new problems in terms of accounting irregularities.

Baker Tilly are looking at the accounts on behalf of Versailles - which will be required to hand over their findings to the stock exchange - while PricewaterhouseCoopers are conducting an accounting investigation on behalf of Versailles's three bankers - Royal Bank of Scotland, Barclays and NatWest - who are together owed about £65m.

Mr Clough is 62 years old and had been due to retire. Before the events of this week, his replacement by a new high powered finance director had been part of Versailles's plan to bounce back from the suspension of its shares, announced on December 8. Other parts of the recovery package included the appointment of a non-executive chairman and the engagement of top-drawer financial advisers.

The SFO's decision to inves tigate throws doubt on all of this and on the group's target of having its shares relisted by the end of this month.

Shares in Versailles, which provides finance to small companies for buying goods or raw materials against temporary ownership of their products, were suspended over possible violations of British accounting rules.

No SFO officers are currently on the premises at Versailles's London HQ; the office will be writing to the group's solicitors Ashurst Morris Crisp to arrange interviews with key Versailles personnel.

webTitle: A tight little insiders' circle is about to put in the fix

fields.headline: A tight little insiders' circle is about to put in the fix
fields.standfirst: Lords reform is done by professional politicians to suit themselvesLords reform: special report
fields.trailText: Everything that has surrounded the Wakeham commission on the House of Lords, whose report will be published today, conspires to place it in the realm of conventional politics. It has no aura of grandeur. It is not seen as the prelude to a great constitutional decision. From start to finish the exercise has been loaded with grubbery.
fields.body:
Everything that has surrounded the Wakeham commission on the House of Lords, whose report will be published today, conspires to place it in the realm of conventional politics. It has no aura of grandeur. It is not seen as the prelude to a great constitutional decision. From start to finish the exercise has been loaded with grubbery. Whatever Wakeham recommends, these elements of the process will remain.

It started, itself, as a fix. The only political event in which the Labour government was interested was getting rid of hereditary peers. In this it did not fully succeed, but the change was still substantial. Several hundred descendants of arbitrary patronage have been returned to the place whence their forefathers came, beyond political power. The mark of modernity is made. But Labour leaders had given no thought to what should happen next. They were agents of gesture, not reform.

So a committee was established, to fill this absence. It comprised a spread of party stalwarts, a cohort of tokens, a handful of active brains, and a chairman whose eligibility for the task was as a fixer. Without discernible convictions, awkward prejudices, known form, or Labour taint, Lord Wakeham would have a silky understanding of what was required. By several accounts, he has been a good chairman. His report, while apparently containing a few sharp surprises on the edge, will at its heart be a muddled compromise, minimising in ternal dissents and courting no outright rejection.

This kind of mundane politics will also, in all likelihood, dominate the outcome. The end will be as murky as the beginning. Much the most probable end is that nothing will happen. Yet another ponderous debate will commence, for the chattering class is interested in the subject, however little they can agree about it. There will be letters, papers, pamphlets, and every kind of objection to every kind of second chamber. But the political will to act will go missing.

For who has any interest in acting to change the transitional arrangements and achieve reform? The Tories are happy, because they extracted life after death for the hereditary peerage, and a large majority in the rump of 92. Labour are happy, because most of the birthright toffs were slaughtered, without conferring legitimacy on the remainder - as we will hear at full volume tonight, if the second chamber performs the public service of protecting trial by jury.

The Lib Dems may be unhappy, because they're being cheated of their quota in the coming handout of slots. But all life peers will be very happy indeed, ensconced safely away from any threat to their lifelong term - which now replaces heredity as the uniquely eccentric feature Britain contributes to the rule-book of second chambers round the world (see Meg Russell's excellent new survey, Reforming the House of Lords: Lessons from Overseas, OUP £18.99).

What is the chief characteristic of this process so far, however? Its seclusion within the political world. Its rating as a banal political issue. Its distancing from the solemnity of what might be called constitutional. So that, if any change were really to be contemplated, all concerned take it for granted that the matter should be decided within the same system that has produced a transitional arrangement, whose only logic is that it keeps professional politicians happy. Who could possibly doubt that the reform of parliament should be done, or not done, by parliament itself?

There was a time when this surely could not be challenged. Isn't parliament sovereign, especially over itself? But that has become a pretty old-fashioned idea. Parliament has been relentlessly obliged to accept regulators, inspectors, standards-enforcers, and encroaching judicial oversight of the legality of the laws it passes. Parliament, we increasingly recognise, is not enough, and least of all when it comes to the constitution.

The one proposal I hope Wakeham makes is that any reform which might grow out of its proposals has to be approved by a referendum. For this is not a banal political matter. It could not be more constitutional. It affects the very life of government and democracy. Indeed, even before the specifics of a new second chamber were settled - and there are multiple choices to be made, which will never get universal agreement - the people should be consulted about what sort of government they want. Before and beyond the modalities - elected, half-elected, unelected, territorial, functional, lifelong, fixed-term, symmetric, asymmetric, empowered, disem- powered - the choice of principle exists.

Option A: A chamber that complements the Commons; keeps the show on the road; submits to the executive; does some revising donkey-work on legislation; assists the complex state machine; requires little coalitionist negotiation; has no special rights; sustains the British way of government, facilitating quick decisions, in line with a broad mandate secured by those elected to the Commons. This kind of chamber is an article of faith for the Blair government, as it has been for all post-war predecessors.

Option B: A chamber whose legitimacy is somewhat separate from the Commons; somewhat moderates the executive; sometimes slows down decision-making; on selected classes of legislation has greater powers; obliges the government on occasion to negotiate with it; is not in thrall to another chamber's mandate; makes ministers' lives more complicated. This kind of chamber would produce a British polity more akin to those elsewhere in the western world.

It is impossible to answer the Wakeham agenda without deciding between these two broad options, and unimaginable that any process controlled by the political establishment would give preference to Option B. Yet Option B would be one with much appeal. It certainly deserves to be considered. It addresses modern cynicism about accountability. It is at the root of the fundamental constitutional choice - the ends question, from which the means question then follows - that all involved in the Wakeham process have so far ducked: indeed, have not so far even contemplated removing from the tight little insiders' circle which will now decide what does or doesn't happen.

In the unlikely event that a choice is made, and a detailed blueprint for a new second chamber written by government in the next few years, it too should be put to the people. This is especially so if the second chamber is not to be elected. Though the case for an appointed house is not absurd, it would doubly need direct democratic approval. But so does anything that happens of such constitutional significance. Scotland and Wales had referenda on their parliamentary rearrangements. This one is every bit as basic as those. Reform without direct popular approval will be an inside job, not worthy of the name.

webTitle: Parachuting crabs fail to bite on an easy target

fields.headline: Parachuting crabs fail to bite on an easy target
fields.trailText: It's been a rough 10 days for the government. The NHS is in crisis, the crime rate is up, likewise unemployment. Their poll figures are plunging, they may have to drop legislation on jury trials, General Pinochet is still here, as is Mike Tyson. Ken Livingstone emerges from the Tube like a grinning Godzilla, and the weather is set to get worse in time for the weekend. It was   an Opposition's most blissful scenario.
fields.body:
It's been a rough 10 days for the government. The NHS is in crisis, the crime rate is up, likewise unemployment. Their poll figures are plunging, they may have to drop legislation on jury trials, General Pinochet is still here, as is Mike Tyson. Ken Livingstone emerges from the Tube like a grinning Godzilla, and the weather is set to get worse in time for the weekend. It was an Opposition's most blissful scenario.

So of course the Tories flubbed their attack. William Hague wasn't a disaster at prime minister's questions; he just wasn't quite good enough. The jokes were all right without being very funny, the criticisms sharp but not barbed.

In the end, their front bench was reduced to mimicking Mr Blair's hand movements, in the vain hope of putting him off. He has one particular gesture, which I think of as the parachuting crabs. The right hand is spread out, with the index finger held outwards, and it descends on the dispatch box repeatedly, as if a troop of airborne crustaceans were making an opposed landing.

So Michael Ancram and Ann Widdecombe both spent many happy minutes doing the same on their notes, but Mr Blair didn't notice, or at least pretended not to, and the pair of them merely looked as if they were suffering from rheumatism.

Mr Hague started off on crime, and called the government's pre-election pledge "empty, worthless and fraudulent". But he soon got tired of that and moved back to the health service.

The prime minister had made promises about funding on the Frost programme. "So far we've had Frost on Sunday, panic on Monday, U-turn on Tuesday and waffle on Wednesday."

This didn't get much of a reaction, so Mr Hague did what Tories always do when they can't tackle Tony; they attack Alastair Campbell instead.

(It would be tempting to say that Mr Campbell, like members of the royal family, cannot answer back. In fact, he spends his life doing little else. He prefers to get in his answer back before anyone has attacked him in the first place. However, since he isn't an MP - he's far too important to waste time in the Commons - he can't reply on the spot.)

The Tory leader pointed out that a junior health minister had promised a 5% rise in NHS funding, whereas Mr Campbell had apparently back-tracked on this promise. "You must be responsible for your own spokesman."

The real question is whether Mr Campbell is responsible for Mr Blair, but let that pass. He sat in the gallery, chewing gum and looking pleased.

Back came Mr Hague, yet again. There had been a 29% increase in fraud, he said, "but in your answers it has gone up by 129%."

At this fairly feeble riposte, the prime minister pulled out his most devastating weapon, the Maxim gun in his armoury: boredom.

Gosh, he went on. There are quite large insects that have a shorter lifespan than Mr Blair's answer yesterday.

He started with a general tour d'horizon of the French health system, and the various costs it inflicts upon patients and employers.

We moved east to Germany for a similar investigation. As bats began to wake for their nocturnal quests, he moved on to the topic of the private finance initiative and its beneficent effect on patients.

All over Britain workers were coming to their end of night shifts. Weary clubbers were trying to phone minicabs, but Mr Blair was still on about how private health would not help the NHS.

"Firstly," he said. Firstly? Were we no nearer lastly? "Secondly!" he exclaimed. "If you want the true figures ... he proves he has no judgment ..." Still it was not over.

Next time I think I shall try reading the whole of Proust instead.

fields.headline: Email from a zillionaire
fields.trailText: Peter Preston (The net boys have no interest in real news, January 17) wrote to a dozen "thirtysomething (internet) zillionaires" asking them for money for his pet cause. None wrote back. From this, he extrapolates that "they don't see news as part of their business" and that "content is something you buy in like a kilo of sausage meat".
fields.body:
Peter Preston (The net boys have no interest in real news, January 17) wrote to a dozen "thirtysomething (internet) zillionaires" asking them for money for his pet cause. None wrote back. From this, he extrapolates that "they don't see news as part of their business" and that "content is something you buy in like a kilo of sausage meat".

As one of the dozen recipients of his letter, maybe I can help. Firstly, the letter still sits on my desk waiting for a response. Secondly, I probably only write a half-dozen letters on paper in a year, so not getting written responses from internet entrepreneurs should not be a surprise. If he emailed me, he would get a response. Guaranteed. If he emailed me with a web address at which I could make an online credit card donation, he would probably have some of my money by now. And lots of other people's. I can't speak for the other "zillionaires", but I do believe that content is more than a kilo of sausage meat. I also believe that you should understand your audience before you ask them for money and then insult them.
Ivan Pope
London
ivan@netnames.com

 Peter Preston's treatment of the Time-Warner-Aol merger was a bleak diatribe against new media. Aol, like all media owners, gears its content provision towards projected audience demand. If it is less concerned with "serious" news content, does that not reflect a failure of the existing media to have inculcated a desire for such content? Preston's fears are expressed in terms of the old paradigms of print and broadcast. Unlike these media, the internet by nature favours pluralism and decentralisation. We are not in the sway of media monopolies as we once were: unlike Preston, it is possible to resist the conniving allure of Aol's "shiny new discs" which "trussed" the unwitting hack to an email address. And how many tabloid hacks treat news as "a kilo of sausage meat"?

Preston concludes that corporate culture will dominate news values. A more balanced prognosis would acknowledge that the internet, by virtue of allowing almost all to publish, offers a modicum of resistance to corporate control. This offers a better prospect for democracy in the next century by promoting a diverse and pluralistic exchange of ideas and information.
Matthew Davies
Manchester
mattd@dircon.co.uk

 Re your coverage of Bill Gates (Gates to cast wider net, January 15): does Microsoft own the Guardian?
Catherine Wattebot
Coventry
cathy@maths.warwick.ac.uk

fields.headline: Spirited replies on Ken
fields.trailText: I was surprised that you devoted two whole pages to a personal attack on Ken Livingstone (Labour's mayoral turmoil, January 19). It would seem that the Guardian is doing Tony Blair's dirty work for him. None of the Labour leadership has explained why, if Ken Livingstone is an example of all that made 80s Labour so unpopular and unelectable, he is so popular today.
fields.body:
I was surprised that you devoted two whole pages to a personal attack on Ken Livingstone (Labour's mayoral turmoil, January 19). It would seem that the Guardian is doing Tony Blair's dirty work for him. None of the Labour leadership has explained why, if Ken Livingstone is an example of all that made 80s Labour so unpopular and unelectable, he is so popular today.

The reason is that to a majority of Londoners Livingstone's GLC worked for Londoners and gave London a community spirit which has been lost since its demise. All the opinion polls show Ken Livingstone as the most popular choice for mayor. I hope Labour allows Londoners the chance to vote for the candidate of their choice.
Mark Dawes
London

 As one of Labour's prospective Greater London Assembley candidates, I believe that Ken Livingstone's comments about selecting his own poodles to serve him as mayor (Labour's troubles pile up, January 19) emphasises why not one of my colleagues supports him. His comments prove that he intends to ignore the party and its manifesto, which has been drawn up by the party membership in London. The GLA must be a partnership, working with all sections of London. It was not set up to feed egos.
Maggie Cosin
London

 The policies of New Labour have decimated the membership in our London constituency party. We are now down to 631 members from a peak of over a thousand in 1997. This is due to continuing Tory policies such as cutting corporation tax and reducing benefits. Your piece on Ken Livingstone attacks his personality, rather than his policies, which are designed to make the strong contribute more and the vulnerable suffer less.
Andy Walker
Ilford, Essex

 What sort of a London mayor are poor Londoners going to end up with? While the shenanigans in the Labour party may be amusing (It's criminal, January 18) they are a disgraceful abuse of democracy by Tony Blair. When Mr Norris was turned down by the Tory selection panel, he was reported as saying that "it was a great shame since business people were ready to donate £2m to my campaign fund". Are we now to believe that he will fight for the interests of ordinary Londoners or be expected to repay his debt to those anonymous business people who are paying for his campaign?
Cllr Paul Lorber
LibDem leader, Brent council
paul.lorber@brent.gov.uk

 Ten reasons why Ken would make a bad mayor: (1) Tony Blair doesn't like him; (2) Tony Blair's friends don't like him; (3) Ken's former friends who are now Tony's friends don't like him; (4) The GLC was going to be abolished anyway (5) Okay, the Livingstone administration delivered on its promises, decreased traffic and generally made London a nicer place to live in, but it wasn't that great. Really; (6) Ken isn't very nice. He might seem nice, but he's a bit of a sad case, really; (7) He consorts with known lefties; (8) He's not really a socialist, you know; (9) errr ... (10) That's it. Is that the best you can come up with?
Sarah Smith
London

 I always imagined a fair trial involved not only a case for the prosecution but also one for the defence.
Gill Lusk
London

 Presumably we can now expect a double page spread devoted to the case against Dobson/Blair/New Labour?
Richard Williams
London

fields.headline: Smack on target
fields.trailText:
If people like shadow minister Dr Liam Fox really believe that "smacking children to teach them the difference between right and wrong is often a necessary, if painful, task" (New laws to limit parents' right to smack, January 18), we suggest they reflect on who suffers the pain (not to mention the fear and humiliation) this "task" engenders. The concepts of "right and wrong" are often nebulous and uncertain, but rarely less so than when they concern violence towards children.
Harriet Davies & Bill Hawkes
London

fields.headline: Things past
fields.trailText:
So Doris Lessing found Proust (Finding the time, January 14) neither dense nor difficult. Come off it. He is both - and exasperating too. It took me three years to read A la Recherche du Temps Perdu in the original, during which time, irritated by Proust's longueurs or my own inadequacies, I occasionally flung it in a corner to gather dust. But one gets hooked, so I always came back.
P Wood
Peopleton, Worcs

webTitle: The end of a royal road

fields.headline: The end of a royal road
fields.standfirst:
RUC changes are hurtful but necessary

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The government's response to the Patten report on the future of the Royal Ulster Constabulary was always going to be a queasy moment for unionists of all persuasions, but especially for those who want the peace process to succeed. Short of a straight repudiation of Patten, whatever Peter Mandelson announced was bound to dismay them and set their various spokesmen fuming. Yesterday they were duly dismayed and duly fumed; but not to a point which suggested that the damage was potentially fatal.
fields.body:
The government's response to the Patten report on the future of the Royal Ulster Constabulary was always going to be a queasy moment for unionists of all persuasions, but especially for those who want the peace process to succeed. Short of a straight repudiation of Patten, whatever Peter Mandelson announced was bound to dismay them and set their various spokesmen fuming. Yesterday they were duly dismayed and duly fumed; but not to a point which suggested that the damage was potentially fatal.

The essential logic of Patten is scarcely disputable. The province needs a police force which is seen to work for and represent the whole Northern Ireland community. That may never be entirely achievable, but it was certainly not at all achievable by perpetuating the RUC in its existing form. To nationalists, it has always looked like an instrument of the old unionist hegemony which so grievously misgoverned the province, so much so that Sinn Fein wanted to have it swept entirely away. That Protestants in the force outnumber Catholics by eleven to one has alone been enough to guarantee a sense of being policed by the other side. What has to be aimed for is policing based on consent. That means, first, a force which as far as is possible commands broad trust and support from both sides of the divide and, arising from that, a gathering conviction among potential recruits that they can enlist without a sense of betrayal. The intimidation of potential recruits will no doubt continue, but at least the aim of creating a greater even-handedness through a policy of positive discrimination in recruitment should make a start. Changing the name, however hurtful to the RUC past and present, was always essential to that.

The most worrying ingredient of Patten was the proposal for forms of community policing which seemed likely in effect to bring the paramilitaries back to the streets, but this time as policemen. Mr Mandelson has sensibly shelved that and by doing so may have denied ammunition to the campaign on both sides of the water for public action to save the RUC. The Tory leadership at Westminster has resisted pressure to endorse that campaign, leaving disgruntled advocates muttering that William Hague is no Bonar Law - which others must feel is just as well. The party's spokesman yesterday disputed specific details, but did not pretend that the status quo was a sensible option in the new Northern Ireland context.

What happens next will be interwoven with the looming deadlines for decommissioning arms. By making his statement earlier than originally planned, Mr Mandelson has given the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, a bit of much-needed breathing space. His situation is still unenviable. In just over three weeks his party's governing council will reconvene to consider the progress made towards decommissioning since it agreed that the party should enter government with Sinn Fein. Mr Trimble won a narrow decision then, with votes possibly swayed towards him by the announcement of the award of the George Cross to the RUC. Without some firm immediate prospect of decommissioning, his chances of holding the line on February 12 will be slim. Sinn Fein is already warning that by going ahead with the threat to pull out, the Unionists would capsize the peace process and possibly plunge the province back into bloodshed. The sense of developing trust, even amity, between Mr Trimble and the Sinn Fein leadership at the end of last year is less evident now, but they have rarely needed each other more than they do today.

fields.headline: View from a prison cell
fields.trailText: You report that Britain is sending its defence chief of staff, Sir Charles Guthrie, to Pakistan to tell General Mushrraf that if he moves towards democracy, Britain will help him to reform its police and judiciary (Britain set to restore links with Pakistan, January 8).
fields.body:
You report that Britain is sending its defence chief of staff, Sir Charles Guthrie, to Pakistan to tell General Mushrraf that if he moves towards democracy, Britain will help him to reform its police and judiciary (Britain set to restore links with Pakistan, January 8).

Britain should reform its own judiciary first. Its home secretary can overrule any judicial decision at will, particularly the mandatory life sentence. A fellow Kashmiri, Mohammed Riaz, and I were sentenced to life in 1984 on circumstantial evidence for the alleged involvement in the killing of an Indian diplomat. Our trial judge secretly recommended that we serve 10 and 15 years respectively. This was secretly increased by another 10 years by Dou glas Hurd in 1988. It took us a 10-year legal battle to get our sentences disclosed. The high court quashed our increased terms on December 16, 1994, but Michael Howard reinstated them two years later. Jack Straw promised a fresh review as a result of recommendations by 33 MPs, who accused successive British home secretaries of appeasing India to secure economic interests.

In undemocratic Pakistan, the executive cannot overrule the judiciary and is more compassionate than Britain in certain respects. My sister came from Pakistan last month to visit me for the first time, but I was transferred into a punishment wing and locked up 23 hours a day.
Quayyum Raja
HM Prison Long Lartin

webTitle: Tyson is an insult to black people too

fields.headline: Tyson is an insult to black people too
fields.trailText: When Mike Tyson raped Desiree Washington, the doctor who examined her could scarcely believe the extent of her internal injuries; so bad were they that he thought she had been the victim of some bizarre mishap.
fields.body:
When Mike Tyson raped Desiree Washington, the doctor who examined her could scarcely believe the extent of her internal injuries; so bad were they that he thought she had been the victim of some bizarre mishap.

GZ Opadia-Kadime was wrong to suggest (Letters, January 18) that no black jury would have found Mike Tyson guilty and that most black people will never consider him as a rapist.

As a black woman I consider him guilty as charged. I am offended that anyone could suggest that black people will overlook crimes committed by other black people just because we share the same skin colour. This is not true. The only people who would have found Tyson innocent are the "no means yes" lobby.

Mike Tyson was guilty. All the evidence was there to substantiate his guilt. Colour, race and gender aside, the facts speak for themselves. Mike Tyson is no role model and no hero and should not have been allowed into this country and heralded like a returning avenger. All those involved in his being here should be ashamed.
Susan Kara
London

 As a black woman, I am convinced of Tyson's guilt and if I were on the jury I would have found him guilty. The colour of his skin is irrelevant. It is wrong to say that a black man convicted by an all-white jury must be innocent.

GZ Opadia-Kadime's black pride is misplaced. It is wrong to support a man and ignore his crimes simply because of the colour of his skin. One point he seems to ignore is that Tyson's victim is black. Maybe this is because it does not fit into his theory of a racist conspiracy.
Ingrid O'Gunleye
Brighton

 I view both the Guardian and Mr Opadia-Kadime as outrageous and irresponsible: him for the suggestion that all black people everywhere condone the behaviour of Mike Tyson and the Guardian for publishing the views of a ludicrous extremist.

As black people, we constantly argue against the inaccurate and insulting assumptions of the majority, but why should they listen when a black person such as Mr Opadia-Kadime is given a platform?
Stephen Sandiford
London

fields.headline: Have they no gratitude?
fields.standfirst: Apparently not. But why be surprised?
fields.trailText: Ungrateful lot, the Belgians. Not only did the Brits save them from French intrigue and possible takeover in 1815 and 1830, but we also gave them sovereignty and a dynasty which has endured. We rescued them again, we like to tell ourselves, in 1914 and 1944-45, this time from the Germans. Yet now they are entertaining a court case to stop the tribute they were required to pay to the hero of Waterloo, in the shape of the permanent award to the duke's descendants of the proceeds of a rich slice of land near the battlefield.

webTitle: Kinnock unveils plans for radical reform of Brussels

fields.headline: Kinnock unveils plans for radical reform of Brussels
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Pledging to build the "best multinational administration in the world," Neil Kinnock yesterday unveiled proposals for the most drastic reforms the European commission has seen in 40 years.
fields.body:
Pledging to build the "best multinational administration in the world," Neil Kinnock yesterday unveiled proposals for the most drastic reforms the European commission has seen in 40 years.

Mr Kinnock, the vice-president for administrative reform, told the European parliament in Strasbourg that he wanted to create a "modern public service" in which "the best in the commission would be typical of the commission".

In a move welcomed by the prime minister, Tony Blair, the former Labour party leader promised speedy changes which would ensure efficiency, accountability, transparency and responsibility in the 22,000-strong Brussels bureaucracy, which implements key areas of European union policy.

"It's root, branch, trunk and trees reform," Mr Kinnock quipped.

Member states across the EU are anxious to see public faith restored in the commission. Nowhere is this more true than in Britain, where the debate over the single currency has yet to be resolved and where yesterday's Guardian/ICM poll showed opposition to the euro at a record high of 63%.

Reform is a key commitment - if not the raison d' être - of the new commission under Romano Prodi, which was created after Jacques Santer and his team resigned last year following damaging allegations of corruption, mismanagement, incompetence and cronyism.

But critics of the heavily-trailed reform package complained yesterday that it did not address questions such as immunity from prosecution and the bewitching tax-free perks and allowances which have given Eurocrats a reputation for feather-bedding and leisurely lunches.

"They'll be shaking in their Gucci shoes," one former official remarked sarcastically.

Mr Kinnock, facing difficult talks with six nervous staff unions, repeatedly insisted that he did not want to cut commission jobs or benefits. "If we want a high-quality administration, we have to attract and retain high-quality people, and they don't come free," he said.

But Franco Ianiello, head of the Renouveau et Démocratie union, said last night: "We are extremely concerned that the sort of reforms Mr Kinnock is proposing would create a big mess if they are all implemented at once."

The British commissioner is likely to face calls for more radical changes, which some officials admit are long overdue, pointing to successful internal overhauls at the UN and the World Bank. Mr Kinnock praised the ability of the vast majority of staff, but pointed to problems of poor morale, slow promotion and mismanagement.

"Changing that is going to take time. But what we are doing is providing the equipment and the follow-through according to a very strict timetable, in order to achieve the change," he added.

Mr Prodi pledged to make sweeping changes and vowed to react to the recommendations last year of three elder statesmen, or "wise men", who roundly condemned the Santer commission's management of public money.

Mr Kinnock said the commission would revamp its recruitment and disciplinary procedures and set up a new audit service by May this year.

A new deputy secretary-general is to be appointed to cut red tape and simplify procedures, while a body to oversee standards in public life - modelled on Britain's Nolan committee - will be created.

The commission has already vowed to review the rotation of senior civil servants around departments and to ensure that each of the EU's 15 member states is fairly represented.

Recent appointments have been made on merit rather than according to informal national quotas, though the French are annoyed that several key jobs have been given to British officials. With signs of a charm offensive to woo the Eurosceptic British press, Mr Blair's official spokesman said: "The prime minister believes commission reform has to be the top strategic objective fundamental to rebuilding public confidence."

He added: "Neil has proven reform credentials, having reformed the Labour party."

But the Tories' reaction was predictably negative. The shadow foreign secretary, John Maples, dismissed Mr Kinnock's proposals as "too little, too late".

The Liberal Democrats' foreign affairs spokesman, Menzies Campbell, said the proposals deserved "a fair wind".

But he added: "The test will be whether there is sufficient political will to match the rhetoric with real and lasting reform. The inadequacies of the commission have been a crucial factor in fuelling public discontent with the European union. The commission has a moral responsibility to put its house in order."

Clean-up for commission
Strategic planning function to assist commissioners

Deputy secretary-general to cut through red tape

Internal audit service to be set up by May 1 to look at control and management

Comprehensive human resources policy

Audit progress board to ensure follow-up on recommendations

Committee on standards in public life to supervise general code of conduct

fields.headline: Serbian spies 'killed Arkan'
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Militiamen who served under the notorious warlord Zeljko "Arkan" Raznatovic yesterday accused the Serbian secret service of murdering their boss.
fields.body:
Militiamen who served under the notorious warlord Zeljko "Arkan" Raznatovic yesterday accused the Serbian secret service of murdering their boss.

But the government denies the killing - and since Arkan was a kingpin of the Belgrade underworld with no shortage of enemies, alternate theories of who was responsible abound.

"There is no doubt that the [state security] service killed him," said a member of Arkan's "Tigers" paramilitary unit yesterday during a gangland-style memorial service yesterday.

Arkan and two of his associates were gunned down on Saturday in the lobby of a plush Belgrade hotel.

He had been indicted by the Hague tribunal in 1997 for war crimes in Bosnia and Croatia and made a fortune operating in the Belgrade underworld, controlling gambling and oil smuggling.

There were widespread rumours that the government had a hand in the attack on Arkan because he was reportedly prepared to give evidence to war crimes investigators that would implicate President Slobodan Milosevic and other Yugoslav leaders.

Admirers, militiamen and family members, including Arkan's wife, Ceca, a singer, packed a converted cinema for the service. A white wreath lay at the base of a stage decorated with a large photo of Arkan dressed in a first world war uniform and flanked by two Serbian flags.

In the crowd that included Yugoslav celebrities, state officials were notably absent, even though he was known to have links with the government.

Arkan's funeral was scheduled to take place today.

fields.headline: The shadow boxers
fields.standfirst: For years, Britain's immigration laws have been used to keep black people out. Now they are being bent to let a convicted sex offender in.  Raekha Prasad examines the blind spot where rape and race meet
fields.trailText: For years, Britain's immigration laws have been used to keep black people out. Now they are being bent to let a convicted sex offender in.  Raekha Prasad examines the blind spot where rape and race meet
fields.body:
In 1991, when Mike Tyson was on trial for raping 18-year-old beauty queen Desiree Washington, a black minister in Indianapolis, where the crime took place, gave a sermon. He asked the court to consider that the boxer was one of very few modern-day African-American heroes. "It is difficult, no matter what the reason, to see a fallen hero and not be affected," he said.

In the same state, a 15-year-old girl telephoned a black radio station to have her say on Washington's decision to return to the champion's room late at night: "Even I know that the only thing open at two in the morning is legs." Centuries of racial apartheid were showing their wounds. Many African-Americans were torn about who exactly was the biggest victim.

On his release, his home town of Harlem was divided, too, on whether to welcome Tyson. Over 200 African-American women held a vigil supporting victims of violence, while others, including the poet Maya Angelou, voiced support for the sporting hero.

But no British women's voices have this week been raised in defence of Tyson. How could any woman defend a convicted rapist, who left Desiree Washington with severe internal injuries, and a wife-beater who once bragged that the best punch he had ever thrown was at his former wife?

Instead women in the UK - both black and white - share a sense of betrayal. Betrayed by the home office decision to admit Tyson, a decision taken by the very government department responsible for implementing a national strategy on violence against women. It tells us it's listening, taking notes even, then when financial push comes to shove, packs its very own punch. Bruises like these do not fade easily.

But here end the similarities between black and white women's reactions to Jack Straw's decision. Straw and his department have many roles. His several hats affect black and white women in different ways. When dealing with the national stategy against violence against women, it is, after his decisions this week, fair to deduce that the home secretary wears a cloche. However, as the great gatekeeper of Britain in his responsibility for immigration and asylum, it would not be unfair to pressume he favours a helmet.

By allowing Tyson in, the home secretary exercised his discretionary powers outwith the standard immigration rules. It was this legal decision that the campaigning group Justice for Women challenged in court, arguing that he did not have the power to intervene in a decision that should have been made by the immigration authorities.

For black and Asian women, these rules symbolise institutionalised racism in Britain par excellence. They have been used, if not against women personally, then against a member of their family, a friend or friends of friends. Hands up all those women who have been made to feel like an illegal alien by British customs officials after visiting family abroad. Why would they support a campaign that opposes the use of discretionary powers?

Consider the case of Kiranjit Ahluwalia, who was released from prison in 1992 after her conviction for murdering her violent husband was reduced to manslaughter. The home office has since denied her British citizenship on the basis of her criminal conviction. Consider, too, those women whose immigration status is dependent on their British husbands and who risk deportation if they flee a violent marriage during the probationary period. It is these women who depend on the home secretary'sdiscretionary powers.

Pragna Patel of campaigning group Southall Black Sisters says the group makes no argument in defence of Tyson but cannot condone the campaign that argues he should not have been allowed in. "We can never support the deployment of racist immigration laws to solve or even highlight violence against women," Patel says. "If we can't contemplate deporting violent black men to protect women, we cannot support the denying of entry to black men, violent or otherwise, on the basis of such laws."

The question then is not why was Mike Tyson let in but why are so many other black men, women and children kept out? It is answered at least partially by a look at the portrayal of Tyson this week in many newspapers as the devil personified; a "brutal rapist" - as if other rapists or rapes are otherwise.

The images of Tyson as a half-crazed animal show just how active in white Britain's imagination remain fears about the nature of black male sexuality. These feed the notions that keep the gates of Britain closed to many black people. These are the notions that have been used by police officers as a defence when asked why a black person had to be so forceably restrained in custody.

Over 50% of women seeking asylum have been raped, according to Cristel Amiss of the Black Women's Rape Action Project. "The vast majority have been raped by agents of military regimes. Feminists have been very vocal against Tyson, yet have said little about Pinochet, a white general responsible for the rape and torture of thousands of women."

Taking a position over a case like Tyson's so often involves black women dividing loyalites: weighing up how a decision might help women against how it will end up oppressing a greater number of black people and vice versa. The struggle for racial equality in Britain has largely been fought over who is allowed in and, once they are in, to what extent they're left out. Black and white women's disparate views over Tyson's entry to Britain are testimony to the continuing struggle for racial equality. But there is one truth that is undoubtedly shared by all women. Jack Straw will have a hard job winning back respect from British women, whatever their race.

webTitle: Whistleblower sets up fund for informers

fields.headline: Whistleblower sets up fund for informers
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Paul van Buitenen, the auditor whose allegations of fraud and mismanagement triggered the collapse of Jacques Santer's European commission, said yesterday that he was setting up a fund to help international whistleblowers,  writes Ian Black .
fields.body:
Paul van Buitenen, the auditor whose allegations of fraud and mismanagement triggered the collapse of Jacques Santer's European commission, said yesterday that he was setting up a fund to help international whistleblowers, writes Ian Black .

Mr Van Buitenen, 42, who was named European of the year by Reader's Digest magazine as the latest reforms were unveiled, said he would donate his £6,200 prize money to a fund in Holland that would help with legal advice. He said he was in touch with informers throughout the EU, including Britain.

The Dutchman was suspended from his job in audit control after revealing financial irregularities to an MEP in 1998. He has since been given a new job helping to manage the commission's budget, but he has made it clear that he would prefer his old position.

Mr Kinnock, when asked whether Mr Van Buitenen should receive a medal, suggested his actions could have compromised legal cases against people accused of misconduct.

Mr Van Buitenen retorted: "I don't want a medal. I only want a suitable job back in the European commission."

webTitle: Bush leads charge of death brigade

fields.headline: Bush leads charge of death brigade
fields.standfirst:
US presidential candidates, with the governor of Texas at the fore, have put capital punishment at the top of the agenda

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Today will be just another execution day in Texas. David Hicks will be strapped on to a bed and lethal chemicals will be injected into his arm. His only chance is last-minute clemency, but in a state run by George W Bush, that is a very slim chance indeed.
fields.body:
Today will be just another execution day in Texas. David Hicks will be strapped on to a bed and lethal chemicals will be injected into his arm. His only chance is last-minute clemency, but in a state run by George W Bush, that is a very slim chance indeed.

In his five years as governor, Mr Bush has approved 116 executions, more than any other US governor in modern times. Lethal injections on death row in Huntsville have become so commonplace that they are barely noted in the press.

Michael King, the editor of the Texas Observer, said: "The politicians, both Democrat and Republican, always compete to say 'I killed more than you did'."

Thus Mr Bush lost no popularity points for supporting a 1995 law aimed at shortening the delay between conviction and execution, known locally as the "speed up the juice" law. Nor was he taking a political risk when he opposed a bill to ban executions of the mentally handicapped or ill.

That bill, if passed, would probably have spared the life of Larry Robison, who is due to be executed tomorrow. Robison is a diagnosed paranoid schizophrenic who was not covered for treatment by his family's health insurance.

Despite their appeals for him to be cared for, he was continually released on the grounds he showed no signs of violence. In 1982, responding to voices he said were coming out of clocks, he murdered five people.

The Texas board of pardons and paroles also has no history of making allowances for age. No clemency is expected for Glen McGinnis, who was 17 when he shot a laundry attendant in a bungled raid. He is due to die on January 25.

Their deaths will almost certainly go unnoticed in a presidential campaign in which all the candidates support the death penalty, as do three out of four Americans. But defence lawyers and human rights activists in Texas say that the state's record on capital punishment should be a national issue.

"A person may be condemned to die in Texas in a process that has the integrity of a professional wrestling match," said Stephen Bright, the director of the Southern Centre for Human Rights.

There is no state public defender system in Texas and the courts assign poor defendants lawyers who are often on low pay and have few qualifications. One court assigned 14 death penalty appeals to two former law clerks with no experience in capital cases.

Court-appointed defence lawyers have even been known to fall asleep during a trial. When asked why he had nodded off, a 72-year-old named John Benn told journalists: "It's boring." In another capital case, the defence lawyer dispensed with a closing summary and proceeded to sing Home on the Range instead.

But even if the defence lawyer is awake and competent, he is likely to be enmeshed in a web of political and financial obligations. Maurie Levin, who leads a fairly lonely campaign in Austin against the death penalty, said: "Judges are elected, and attorneys are dependent on the court for their next job.

"And if a trial judge approves too much money for, God forbid, defence of a murderer, they would not be well-viewed in the next election. Everything is intertwined. There is no independence."

A convicted murderer's last hope is the pardons board, an 18-member panel appointed by the governor, which decides on issues of clemency. Over 99% of cases fail. The board's proceedings are secret and the members fax in their decisions from separate regional offices.

This practice, known in Texan legal circles as "death by fax", has been roundly criticised by a string of judges and legal scholars.

But "death by fax" continues, with Mr Bush's support. Last year he opposed two bills requiring the board to consider clemency appeals in public. This, the governor said, might create "a chance for people to rant and rail, a chance for people to emotionalise the process beyond the questions that need to be asked".

Mr Bush and his supporters insist that the system works and that under his watch, no innocent person has been wrongly convicted.

Friends of James Beathard, executed on December 9, argue differently. He was convicted on the testimony of another suspect, Gene Hathorn, who believed he would be spared as a result. When prosecutors reneged on the deal, Hathorn recanted his testimony, but it was too late to beat a 30-day deadline following Beathard's conviction.

At the time of his death, Beathard wrote: "There is a part of me that feels that as bad as it is to die in here, it's just a little worse to die without anyone saying 'This is wrong'."

Four for death row

'The Clinton-Gore administration has supported efforts to expand the death penalty. As president, I would continue to support the death penalty and expansion of it where appropriate'
Al Gore

'As a senator, I supported expanding the death penalty to punish the most heinous crimes ... I want to ensure however that the death penalty is not implemented in a racially unequal way'
Bill Bradley

'I support the death penalty for violent criminals who commit heinous crimes because we must send a strong message that the consequences of violent criminal behaviour are swift and sure'
George W Bush

'I support the imposition of the death penalty for heinous crimes in which the circumstances warrant capital punishment. I've supported legislation in the senate that sought to significantly expand the number of federal crimes punishable by death, including terrorism and narcotics trafficking by drug kingpins'
John McCain
fields.bodyText: Today will be just another execution day in Texas. David Hicks will be strapped on to a bed and lethal chemicals will be injected into his arm. His only chance is last-minute clemency, but in a state run by George W Bush, that is a very slim chance indeed. In his five years as governor, Mr Bush has approved 116 executions, more than any other US governor in modern times. Lethal injections on death row in Huntsville have become so commonplace that they are barely noted in the press. Michael King, the editor of the Texas Observer, said: "The politicians, both Democrat and Republican, always compete to say 'I killed more than you did'." Thus Mr Bush lost no popularity points for supporting a 1995 law aimed at shortening the delay between conviction and execution, known locally as the "speed up the juice" law. Nor was he taking a political risk when he opposed a bill to ban executions of the mentally handicapped or ill. That bill, if passed, would probably have spared the life of Larry Robison, who is due to be executed tomorrow. Robison is a diagnosed paranoid schizophrenic who was not covered for treatment by his family's health insurance. Despite their appeals for him to be cared for, he was continually released on the grounds he showed no signs of violence. In 1982, responding to voices he said were coming out of clocks, he murdered five people. The Texas board of pardons and paroles also has no history of making allowances for age. No clemency is expected for Glen McGinnis, who was 17 when he shot a laundry attendant in a bungled raid. He is due to die on January 25. Their deaths will almost certainly go unnoticed in a presidential campaign in which all the candidates support the death penalty, as do three out of four Americans. But defence lawyers and human rights activists in Texas say that the state's record on capital punishment should be a national issue. "A person may be condemned to die in Texas in a process that has the integrity of a professional wrestling match," said Stephen Bright, the director of the Southern Centre for Human Rights. There is no state public defender system in Texas and the courts assign poor defendants lawyers who are often on low pay and have few qualifications. One court assigned 14 death penalty appeals to two former law clerks with no experience in capital cases. Court-appointed defence lawyers have even been known to fall asleep during a trial. When asked why he had nodded off, a 72-year-old named John Benn told journalists: "It's boring." In another capital case, the defence lawyer dispensed with a closing summary and proceeded to sing Home on the Range instead. But even if the defence lawyer is awake and competent, he is likely to be enmeshed in a web of political and financial obligations. Maurie Levin, who leads a fairly lonely campaign in Austin against the death penalty, said: "Judges are elected, and attorneys are dependent on the court for their next job. "And if a trial judge approves too much money for, God forbid, defence of a murderer, they would not be well-viewed in the next election. Everything is intertwined. There is no independence." A convicted murderer's last hope is the pardons board, an 18-member panel appointed by the governor, which decides on issues of clemency. Over 99% of cases fail. The board's proceedings are secret and the members fax in their decisions from separate regional offices. This practice, known in Texan legal circles as "death by fax", has been roundly criticised by a string of judges and legal scholars. But "death by fax" continues, with Mr Bush's support. Last year he opposed two bills requiring the board to consider clemency appeals in public. When prosecutors reneged on the deal, Hathorn recanted his testimony, but it was too late to beat a 30-day deadline following Beathard's conviction. webTitle: Body found aboard sunken fishing boat

fields.headline: Body found aboard sunken fishing boat
fields.trailText: Investigators examining the wreck of the Solway Harvester, the fishing boat which sank in the Irish sea last week, have discovered the body of one of its seven crewmen.
fields.body:
Investigators examining the wreck of the Solway Harvester, the fishing boat which sank in the Irish sea last week, have discovered the body of one of its seven crewmen.

The body was discovered by underwater video cameras, probing the wrecked vessel on the seabed 11 miles off the Isle of Man. The scallop dredger is lying in 100ft of water and police said yesterday they were now considering raising the wreck.

It has not yet been possible to identify the body, but investigators from the marine accident investigation branch now believe that all seven crewmen are on board the vessel.

A survey vessel, the Mansal 18, which had been chartered by the board, returned to harbour yesterday and video evidence from the surveillance cameras was being examined in detail by investigators.

The families of the fisherman are all anxious to have the bodies of the men returned home for burial.

Mike Culverhouse, chief constable of the Isle of Man, said this would be the investigators' priority. Mr Culver house said the possibility of raising the vessel was being discussed. However, other courses of action to recover the bodies, including diving, were still under consideration.

"All parties will decide on the best course of action, but we want to make sure that whatever we do is within the bounds of safety," he added.

The body was found on the gutting deck of the wreck, in the centre of the ship below the wheelhouse, by a camera lowered through a porthole.

An MAIB spokesman said inspectors on the survey vessel had been able to leave the scene ahead of schedule because enough evidence had been gathered for them to conduct their inquiry.

Families of the seven victims, all from the three villages of the tiny community of the Machars of Whithorn in south west Scotland, will travel to Douglas, the Isle of Man capital, if the bodies of the crewmen are raised.

The seven were skipper Andrew Craig Mills, 29; his brother Robin Mills, 33; their cousin David Mills, 18; John Murphy, 22; Martin Milligan, 26; David Lyons, 17; and Wesley Jolly, 17.

webTitle: Jehovah's Witness died after refusing transfusion

fields.headline: Jehovah's Witness died after refusing transfusion
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A Jehovah's Witness died after she refused to have a blood transfusion which would have saved her life, because it was against her religious beliefs.
fields.body:
A Jehovah's Witness died after she refused to have a blood transfusion which would have saved her life, because it was against her religious beliefs.

Beverley Matthews, 33, of Stockport, Greater Manchester, was suffering from toxic shock syndrome when she was taken to Stepping Hill hospital with chronic sickness and diarrhoea last November.

She failed to respond to antibiotics and her condition deteriorated rapidly. Hospital consultants told her that she would have a 30% chance of survival if she had a blood transfusion, but she and her family refused. Mrs Matthews died several hours later.

At the inquest last week the coroner, John Pollard, recorded an open verdict. He said it was not clear whether the illness had been caused by a natural localised infection or by tampon use.

He said the consultant had been blunt enough to say death was inevitable, but Mrs Matthews and her family had refused treatment. He added that her condition was so serious that a transfusion may not have saved her.

Mrs Matthews was the mother of a four-year-old son, Jake, and lived with her husband, Ian, in Bredbury, Stockport. Her family had been Jehovah's Witnesses for 25 years, although her husband is not thought to share her beliefs.

Philip Lewis, a consultant at Stepping Hill hospital, told the inquest: "She had an infection which was causing the blood to start destroying itself. The idea of the blood transfusion is to give you time for the antibiotics to work and for the poisons to clear.

"It buys you that time. It was a last ditch attempt. But it was the only advised course and her only hope at the time."

Mr Lewis said he had spoken to Mrs Matthews's father, brother and one of the church elders who had visited the hospital.

Mrs Matthews's mother, Marie Vernon, said yesterday: "I was looking for the truth and this religion gave me that. She made the right decision - she had to stick to her beliefs. Beverley was a lovely girl."

Jehovah's Witnesses base their beliefs on three passages in the Bible which order them to abstain from blood.

Derek Casey, a spokesman for the Jehovah's Witnesses, said: "Jehovah's Witnesses' love of life moves them to seek the best medical treatment for themselves and their families. However, they respect and obey the plain scriptural command to abstain from blood.

"She loved life and in harmony with her religious beliefs, chose non-blood medical management of her condition.

"We deeply sympathise with Beverley Matthews's family as they come to terms with their sudden and tragic loss."

Jehovah's Witnesses prefer to use their own blood in operations or they choose bloodless surgery - blood spilt during surgery is cleaned and returned to the body.

Last year, Ewan Opperman, a 19-year-old Jehovah's Witness from South Africa, survived a liver transplant operation at St James's hospital, Leeds, after the surgeon used plasma products and blood recycled from his own body.

Bloodless surgery is reported to increase the risk of death by between 35% and 40%. But for Mrs Matthews there was no alternative to a blood transfusion.
