webTitle: Forgive me, Father, for I am on your website

fields.headline: Forgive me, Father, for I am on your website
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: There are plenty of opportunities for sin on the internet, but precious few sources of absolution. So today, Britain's only Christian radio station launches an online "confession box" for sinful surfers who feel the need to repent.
fields.body:
There are plenty of opportunities for sin on the internet, but precious few sources of absolution. So today, Britain's only Christian radio station launches an online "confession box" for sinful surfers who feel the need to repent.

The website, www.theconfessor.co.uk allows users to file their wrongdoings - in return for a comforting Bible text. The automated response will not reflect the gravity of the offence: coveting thy neighbour's wife and throttling thy neighbour's tearaway teenage son elicit similarly sympathetic passages.

Peter Kerridge, managing director of Premier Christian Radio, said: "When people allocate a little time in their life to review what they are doing and how it will impact upon others, it's undoubtedly of considerable spiritual benefit."

Visitors to the site receive the message: "You are invited to spend a few moments in reflection. Here is an opportunity for confession and repentance. By the grace of God there is the real possibility that the time spent here will have real healing consequences."

They see a series of contemplative texts and then a page offering the chance to type out a confession. They are reassured with the message: "All you type remains on your computer and will not be transmitted in any way to anyone else. This is between you and God and your privacy is respected."

Premier, which broadcasts to London and south-east England, said that it did not intend to get involved in an interactive service with "hail Marys" dispensed by online priests. The verses were like the liturgical "words of comfort" given by any parish priest.

One, from psalm 51, says: "Wash me with hyssop until I am clean and whiter than snow. Turn your eyes from my sin and cover my guilt. Create pure thoughts in me and make me faithful again."

Mr Kerridge said: "When we repent, God cancels these three- dimensional consequences of our sin. The confessor provides a way of concentrating the mind in the act of repentance."

fields.headline: Tory link with strikebreakers
fields.standfirst: How Thatcher minister met wives of working minersTories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The Thatcher government held secret meetings with the wives of strikebreaking miners as part of a hidden strategy behind the greatest domestic crisis of the 1980s, it is revealed today.
fields.body:
The Thatcher government held secret meetings with the wives of strikebreaking miners as part of a hidden strategy behind the greatest domestic crisis of the 1980s, it is revealed today.

Participants have talked for the first time about four sessions held privately at the House of Commons and attended by the then energy minister, David Hunt, who reported the results directly back to the prime minister.

Lady Thatcher was closely interested in the psychology of the split villages because of her own background, according to Elizabeth Peacock, the former Conservative MP for Batley and Spen in West Yorkshire, who helped to organise the meetings.

She said yesterday: "As a wife and mother Mrs T, as she was then, was very concerned about intimidation, all the more so when it took the form of banning strikebreakers' families from corner shops, which struck a chord with her own upbringing."

The secret gatherings, described tonight on a BBC Close-up North investigation, Divided We Stand, also gave ministers useful insights on the pressures which drove some of the women to persuade their husbands to keep working in spite of the intimidation.

The meetings were attended, but never publicly described, by the late Woodrow Wyatt, a key member of an informal group of advisers on breaking the 1984-85 strike.

Angry references to intimidation of strikebreakers and their families peppered his News of the World column subsequently, but he gave no hint of the meetings and left them out of his memoirs.

The MPs at the meetings were initially concerned about his presence because of his past Labour links, but said that "he sat in a corner making copious notes and was clearly very discreet".

"It was all behind the scenes and - remarkably for Westminster - never discovered by anyone else or reported," said Mrs Peacock, whose constituency's mining equipment firms made her part of an inner circle of concerned backbenchers regularly briefed by the then energy secretary, Peter Walker.

"Peter was marvellous at keeping people informed - never anything in writing, just calling you into his office to pass on the news. I think that is how these visits came about."

The "scab wives", as they were known in tightly knit communities which detested strikebreakers, gave frightening accounts of smashed windows, slogans carved on the bricks of their houses and being treated like pariahs. Mr Hunt, whose brief as "coal minister" made him a principal player in a battle always portrayed by the government as entirely between the national coal board and the National Union of Mineworkers, passed the information straight on.

Now Lord Hunt, he said: "I found it very useful indeed to hear exactly what was happening and of course I took steps immediately afterwards to make the prime minister and other ministers aware of the extent of the intimidation."

He also passed on accounts to the home secretary whose department coordinated police and covert operations during the bitter, 11-month dispute.

No wives involved in the meetings have been prepared to talk openly about them, with divisions still strong in the pit villages and former coalfield areas after 16 years. But strikers' leaders expressed surprise yesterday at the scale of the operation.

Peter Heathfield, general secretary of the NUM during the strike, said: "We knew nothing about this. It's news to me."

And Ken Capstick, prominent in the Yorkshire NUM during the 1980s, said: "Mrs Thatcher always said that the government was nothing to do with it, that it was the business of the coal board and the NUM. In fact they were involved in it up to their necks."

webTitle: Apple a day keeps lungs working

fields.headline: Apple a day keeps lungs working
fields.trailText: An apple a day keeps the lung specialist away, according to medical research. A report published yesterday says a study of 2,512 men in Wales has found that eating five or more apples a week was associated with a marked improvement in lung function.
fields.body:
An apple a day keeps the lung specialist away, according to medical research. A report published yesterday says a study of 2,512 men in Wales has found that eating five or more apples a week was associated with a marked improvement in lung function.

The researchers, led by Barbara Butland of the department of public health sciences at St George's hospital medical school, in south London, reported their find ings in the journal Thorax. The study centred on men aged 45 to 59 living in Caerphilly, testing their lung capacity over a period of five years. The study showed that the apple eaters had lung capacity which was 138ml higher than those who did not.

Initially, good lung function was associated with eating plenty of vitamins C, A and E, citrus fruits and apples, and with frequent consumption of fruit juices and squashes.

But after adjustment for factors such as age, smoking history, social class, exercise and energy intake, there remained only the link with apples - and a smaller association with vitamin E.

The researchers concluded: "A strong positive association is seen between lung function and the number of apples eaten per week." They suggested this might be due to an antioxidant called quercitin, found in hard fruits. Quercitin, abundant in apples, as well as onions, tea and red wine, is thought to protect the lungs against effects of pollutants.

Adrian Barlow, director of the trade association English Apples and Pears, said members would be delighted with the news about Britain's second favourite fruit - after bananas.

fields.headline: Research into causes of obesity
fields.trailText: A group of researchers from Aberdeen has been given grants of nearly £600,000 to study obesity.
fields.body:
A group of researchers from Aberdeen has been given grants of nearly £600,000 to study obesity.

The disease is officially deemed to be a world epidemic by the World Health Organisation. Now 50 scientists from Aberdeen university, the Rowett research institute and Grampian university hospitals NHS trust are joining forces to work on obesity and related phenomena.

Some fear that with more than 40% of the population overweight, it is only a matter of time before the UK is in the same situation as the US, where more than half of adults are obese.

Problems linked to disease are estimated to cost the US health service $99bn a year. Obesity is closely tied to diabetes, hypertension, high blood pressure and heart disease.

John Speakman, professor of zoology at Aberdeen university, said: "It is clear that the failure of some people to regulate their body weight is not just a matter of people overeating or being lazy. It is also a problem with their physiology which might have many causes."

His colleague, Paul Trayhurn, said: "Obesity is a problem of energy imbalance which appears to have a combination of cultural, environmental and genetic causes."

Part of the research will involve examining the changes in body weight of animals affected by seasonal changes to see if the causes can be translated into humans.

fields.headline: RAF officer survives 1,300ft fall
fields.trailText: Mountain rescue teams yesterday said they were amazed that an RAF flight lieutenant, Jeanine Godfrey, 35, had survived a 1,300ft fall down a Scottish gully.
fields.body:
Mountain rescue teams yesterday said they were amazed that an RAF flight lieutenant, Jeanine Godfrey, 35, had survived a 1,300ft fall down a Scottish gully.

Flt Lt Godfrey is based at RAF Uxbridge in west London and was on a five-day winter mountain training course. She slipped and fell from a peak in Glencoe, suffering serious spinal and head injuries.

An RAF spokesman said: "She is in a stable condition and the prognosis looks good for her to make a full recovery."

The accident happened on Stob Coire nam Beath's Summit Gully, part of the Bidean Nam Bian mountain range. John Grieve, leader of Glencoe mountain rescue team, said the fall had probably been softened by snow. But he added that he had never known anyone to fall so far and live.

webTitle: Drive to cut pollution speeded up

fields.headline: Drive to cut pollution speeded up
fields.trailText: Towns and cities will be under increased pressure to introduce road tolls and other traffic control measures following a government decision to shorten the time-scales for reductions in air pollution.
fields.body:
Towns and cities will be under increased pressure to introduce road tolls and other traffic control measures following a government decision to shorten the time-scales for reductions in air pollution.

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, yesterday promised "dramatic improvements" in air quality over the next five years with cuts ranging from 10% in particles from diesel fumes to 60% in benzene, a component of petrol. Overall, traffic exhaust fumes should be cut by half over the next decade.

Maximum limits for benzene and carbon monoxide, due to be achieved in 2005, must now be achieved by 2003.

Mr Meacher said Britain was on course to reach some of the objectives, but others would take "greater effort".

The government is giving local councils powers to conduct kerbside exhaust emission checks. The transport bill will allow councils to introduce congestion charging on busy roads.

Businesses will be expected to cut industrial emissions and look at the environmental impact of fleet cars.

Damian Green, Conservative environment spokesman, said the government should do "three big things" to cut pollution: end the moratorium on new gas-fired power stations, cut taxes on cleaner fuels and vehicles which use them, and increase its targets for renewable energy, such as solar power.

fields.headline: Butterflies can hear, say scientists
fields.trailText: A group of tropical butterflies has evolved ears to warn them of danger from squeaking bats, according to Canadian researchers.
fields.body:
A group of tropical butterflies has evolved ears to warn them of danger from squeaking bats, according to Canadian researchers.

Moths, which come out at night, can "hear". But until now, entomologists had presumed that butterflies, which come out in daylight, were deaf.

But James Fullard of Toronto university and Jayne Yack of Carleton university report in Nature that they had identified "ears" on the wings of a night-flying butterfly.

Hedylids are nocturnal insects found in south and central America, and until recently were classed as moths. They are now grouped as ancestors of modern butterflies.

But these butterflies could survive at night, alongside insectivorous bats. Bats hunt by emitting ultrasonic squeaks and homing in on the signals that bounce back. So the two predicted that just because it could survive on an island in Panama, at least one hedylid, a creature called macrosoma heliconiara, would prove to have ears which could detect ultrasound and would exhibit what scientists call "bat-avoidance behaviour". They were right. In the wing of the butterfly was a tympanal ear, with a membrane and eardrum stretched over an airfilled chamber with three vibration-sensitive organs stuck to the inner surface. When it heard the squeak of a bat swooping in, the butterfly reacted by making steep climbs and dives.

The duo said they believed all 40 species of hedylid had evolved moth-like hearing and that the insects that did not develop hearing aids decided instead to show up only when the bats had gone to bed.

fields.headline: Pole position
fields.standfirst: Minister blocks export of explorers' flags
fields.trailText: The export of two flags flown on the ill-fated polar expeditions of Captain Robert Scott and Sir Ernest Shackleton has been delayed in an attempt to keep them in Britain.
fields.body:
The export of two flags flown on the ill-fated polar expeditions of Captain Robert Scott and Sir Ernest Shackleton has been delayed in an attempt to keep them in Britain.

A sledging flag from Scott's fatal attempt on the south pole and a royal standard from Shackleton's trans-Antarctic expedition of 1914-17 were bought at auction last September by an anonymous overseas buyer. Yesterday Alan Howarth, the arts minister, said a decision on whether to grant an export licence had been deferred for three months to allow time for a British purchaser to emerge.

Speaking at Christie's in central London, Mr Howarth said the flags were emblems of Britain's "great heroic age", and urged museums and private donors to come forward with the estimated £100,000 required to buy them. Scott's flag was sold for £35,287 and Shackleton's standard for £64,342. Mr Howarth recommended an initial offer of 50p more than those sale prices should be made. but Christie's was unable to confirm whether the new owner had any interest in selling the flags so soon.

The deferral is the latest example of a resurgence of interest in the exploits of two explorers who earned their fame through failure. Scott died on the return journey from the pole, which he reached 35 days after Norwegian Roald Amundsen. The silk flag, bearing the words "Stretched wings to the south", was among belongings returned to his wife in 1913.

Shackleton's royal standard was presented to him by Queen Alexandra in July 1914 before he set sail for the south pole on his ship the Endurance. Unlike Scott, he returned alive in 1917, having failed to cross the polar ice cap.

The Endurance became trapped in pack ice and sank, but the crew of 22 survived after Shackleton sailed 800 miles from Elephant Island to South Georgia in a 22ft dinghy in one of the greatest feats of navigation in maritime history.

David Spence, exhibitions director of the National Maritime Museum at Greenwich, south-east London, which had lobbied the department of culture, media and sport to halt the export, said: "These are not just unique items but are really inextricably bound with our country's notion of heroism.

"It was that heroic age which was to be gone forever in the first world war. It was one of those episodes that marked the diminishing of the British empire."

He said his museum hoped to be able to display the flags alongside other polar artefacts to go on show at an exhibition this year to be called the Race to the Pole.

Last September the remains of a biscuit found at Scott's last camp was bought by Sir Ranulph Fiennes for £4,000.

fields.headline: Mandelson gambles on RUC revamp
fields.standfirst: Acceptance of Patten commission's plans for reform raises tensions in Belfast Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson yesterday embarked on his most dangerous gamble since assuming command as Northern Ireland secretary 101 days ago, provoking deep political crisis as he announced the most sweeping reform of the Royal Ulster Constabulary in its 78-year history.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson yesterday embarked on his most dangerous gamble since assuming command as Northern Ireland secretary 101 days ago, provoking deep political crisis as he announced the most sweeping reform of the Royal Ulster Constabulary in its 78-year history.

Mr Mandelson's strategy in adopting almost all of Chris Patten's 175 recommendations on policing reform intensified the pressures on the fledgling government. It enraged unionists, who saw the proposals as the latest in a long line of concessions towards the nationalists.

The force is to be renamed the Police Service of Northern Ireland next autumn, when a scheme to draw recruits equally from the Protestant and Catholic communities will come into operation. A new, more powerful police board will oversee the force, and Sinn Fein will have at least two of its 19 places.

Mr Mandelson's approach, designed to boost Catholic representation in the force from its level of 8%, depends on Sinn Fein buying into the package. It said it would wait to see the legislation, but it sounded unenthusiastic yesterday.

First minister David Trimble, whose career is already on the line over IRA decommissioning, was left looking vulnerable. Democractic Unionists were last night blaming him for backing the Good Friday agreement, which paved the way for the Patten commission.

Mr Trimble's ruling Ulster Unionist council meets on February 12 to decide on continuing to participate in the power-sharing executive. Yesterday's developments cut any scope he has for manoeuvre if the IRA has failed to make a start to arms decommissioning by then.

Speculation is already suggesting that Mr Mandelson will take the initiative and collapse the new institutions next month rather than leave Mr Trimble to walk away.

Mr Trimble was incandescent yesterday. Just before Mr Mandelson's announcement, he berated Tony Blair, telling him: "Nothing that this government says or does can dishonour the RUC or the men that serve in it. But the government can and is dishonouring itself."

Ken Maginnis, Ulster Unionist security spokesman, said Mr Mandelson's package "degraded, demeaned and denigrated the RUC". He believed the low rate of representation among Catholics, who make up more than 40% of the population in Northern Ireland, was more to do with intimidation from republicans than with its name.

Jeffrey Donaldson, an Ulster Unionist MP opposed to the Good Friday agreement, underlined a common theme among unionists. He felt unionists were being asked to take all the pain, and were gaining nothing from republicans.

Mr Donaldson said: "The proposals will weigh heavily in the minds of Ulster Unionist delegates when they come together on February 12. Many will conclude this process isn't worth a candle."

Sir Ronnie Flanagan, RUC chief constable, said his force stood ready to endure the pain of losing its name and badge if it were to prove that those moves would boost Catholic representation. But he remained to be convinced that would be the outcome.

Sir Ronnie said: "We will pursue transition with dignity. We will be hurt but we will do our best to continue to provide the highest quality policing service to all members of the public in Northern Ireland."

The RUC has seen 302 of its officers murdered during the troubles, and almost 9,000 have been injured in terrorist attacks.

Christine Ead, whose husband, David, 38, an inspector, was murdered by the IRA on Easter Monday 1987, said: "I feel our sacrifices have been in vain. Mr Mandelson says we would not be here today without the RUC, and he is not allowing them to police the peace."

The Police Federation, which last week delivered a petition with 400,000 signatures in support of the RUC to Downing Street, labelled Mr Mandelson's move "vengeful and destructive".

Les Rodgers, chairman, said he had fallen for the slick publicity machine of a minority who had poisoned minds worldwide.

Civil rights groups and the SDLP backed Mr Mandelson. Alex Atwood, the SDLP's policing spokesman, said that he would be recommending young Catholics to join the revamped police service.

But Sinn Fein's position which will be the most important. Old Bailey bomber Gerry Kelly, its policing spokesman, who denounced the RUC's human rights record, introduced a new bargaining chip last night when he called on Mr Mandelson quickly to publish proposals for demilitarisation.

Mr Mandelson said the RUC's crown and harp badge would go, but left it open to the new police body to decide what its replacement should be. He suggested that the George Cross, awarded to the force two months ago, could be incorporated.

There was one crucial concession to unionists. Mr Mandelson postponed deciding whether the proposed district policing partnership boards would have fund-raising powers as the Patten commission suggested. There were fears they could be usurped by paramilitaries.

The key changes

RUC to be renamed Police Service of Northern Ireland

New recruits to be drawn from a 50/50 pool of Protestants and Catholics

Force to be reduced from 13,500 to about 7,500

RUC's crown and harp cap badge to be scrapped

All RUC officers will receive human rights training and accept a new police oath

New policing board will replace the current police authority


Royal Ulster Constabulary
Police Authority for Northern Ireland
The Patten Commission

fields.headline: IRA man mourned, 58 years on
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: They buried IRA volunteer Tom Williams yesterday - again. None of his friends was able to attend his first funeral 58 years ago, but his comrades turned up in their thousands yesterday, gridlocking his native republican west Belfast.
fields.body:
They buried IRA volunteer Tom Williams yesterday - again. None of his friends was able to attend his first funeral 58 years ago, but his comrades turned up in their thousands yesterday, gridlocking his native republican west Belfast.

Most prominent among the mourners was Joe Cahill, now 80 but almost Williams's age when in September 1942 the 19-year-old volunteer became the only IRA man to be executed in Northern Ireland.

Cahill, like Williams, had been given a death sentence over the murder of Patrick Murphy, an RUC constable shot during an attempt to divert attention from an illegal parade commemorating the 1916 Easter Rising. Cahill, with the four other IRA gang members, was reprieved but Williams was hanged at Belfast prison. He was buried in an unmarked grave at the Crumlin Road jail until last year when the former Northern Ireland secretary, Mo Mowlam, allowed the exhumation of his body and he was re-buried in a family grave.

Yesterday Cahill, who became IRA chief of staff, said: "I have mixed feelings. I would have loved him to be laid to rest in the grave we reserved for him [in an IRA area] but I am happy Tom's remains are in Milltown."

Speaking about the first burial of Williams, Cahill added: "There was a deafening silence at that mass, broken only by the sobbing of men. Tom was one of the bravest men I ever met. The priest said there wasn't a quiver in his body when he went to the gallows. The only people trembling were the English hanging him."

The funeral mass at St Paul's church on the Falls Road was very different yesterday with 1,000 or more in the church and twice as many outside.

webTitle: London the most expensive city in EU

fields.headline: London the most expensive city in EU
fields.trailText: Londoners are in the unenviable position of living in the most expensive city in the European Union and the seventh most costly in the world, according to an international survey published today.
fields.body:
Londoners are in the unenviable position of living in the most expensive city in the European Union and the seventh most costly in the world, according to an international survey published today.

Manchester enters the top part of the league for the first time, holding the joint number 20 position with Chicago and Schenzen, according to the Economist Intelligence Unit's biannual cost of living rankings. Continuing its steady march up the global price index, London has leapfrogged Paris and Geneva for the first time, and now lags behind only Tokyo and Osaka in Japan, Libreville in Gabon, and the non-EU cities of Oslo and Zurich.

The survey, which compares the cost of more than 120 goods and services, from a loaf of bread to a full-time maid, confirms Londoners' complaints that they face increasingly prohibitive prices, especially for food, transport and entertainment. For accommodation costs, only Tokyo and Hong Kong are more expensive.

London first entered the world's top 10 most expensive places in December 1997. The rise from ninth to seventh position in the rankings over the past year is blamed mainly on the strong pound and the relative weakness of the euro.

But Bill Ridgers, the report's editor, said the results would be taken as further evidence of the poor deal enjoyed by British consumers compared to their European counterparts.

"The latest change is almost entirely due to currency fluctuations but the fact that London has been consistently in such a high position brings up the whole rip-off Britain issue again."

Business leaders also voiced concern that rising living costs are undermining the city's long-term economic prospects, making it too expensive for lower-paid workers, pushing up wage demands for employers, and discouraging companies from locating there.

The EIU rankings, covering 126 countries, are regarded by multinational companies as a key guide when setting salary levels and considering relocation plans.

"We are concerned that London is becoming the most expensive city in the EU," said Simon Sperryn, chief executive of London chamber of commerce. "The high cost of living and doing business in London could have serious implications for the capital's future competitiveness."

Manchester's economic renaissance has taken it to 20th place in the rankings, making it as pricey as Chicago and dearer than every city in Germany, as well as Amsterdam and Helsinki. Dublin, by contrast, has become cheaper to live in over the past year, dropping from 34th to 48th place.

European cities have the dubious distinction of holding six of the 10 most expensive places. Paris, consistently the EU's most expensive place, has fallen from fifth to eighth position. The Romanian capital, Bucharest, in 120th spot, is now the cheapest city in Europe.

But even Londoners will feel a pang of sympathy for residents of Tokyo, who for the ninth year running find themselves topping the rankings. The city's cost of living has risen by 26% in the past year thanks to the economy's revival - making it almost 30% dearer than Hong Kong in third place - and consumers now face exorbitant prices for basic foodstuffs. A 500g pack of supermarket cheese, for example, costs more than £12 on average.

At the opposite end of the scale, the Indian cities of New Delhi and Mumbai - formerly Bombay - have usurped Tripoli to become the least expensive places in the world. For less than the monthly rent of a one-bedroom flat in a moderate area of London, residents of New Delhi could live in a fully-furnished three-bedroom house.

Tokyo: 25 tea-bags will set you back £1.50 Whereas sightseers in most cities in the world gasp at architectural marvels or great works of art, visitors to Tokyo are just as often bowled over by the astonishing prices they encounter because of the strong yen and land values.

Many supermarkets provide only hand baskets, perhaps because it is so expensive to fill up trolleys. Among the most shocking average costs are a box of 25 regular tea bags at £1.56, a kilogram of oranges at £2.46 and a litre of milk at £1.16. Land prices have plunged since 1980, when Tokyo's real estate was valued higher than the whole of the US, but are still insane. Houses in Japan cost 13 times an average worker's annual salary and much more in the capital. Little wonder Japan has one of the highest number of smokers in the world. At about £1.26 a pack, it is one of the few cheap pleasures available.

Delhi: cheap for the UK tourist, steep for the Indian

Delhi might be the cheapest city for the international traveller, but it does not feel that way for people earning in Indian rupees.

With the pound worth about 70 rupees, a night out, including dinner at a moderately priced restaurant in posh south Delhi followed by the cinema and a taxi home, will cost well under a tenner a head.

But consider the cost for a middle class Indian. A university lecturer generally takes home £200 a month. Rents in south Delhi start at about £145 a month for a two-bedroom flat. Electric ity costs £12 a month, not including an air conditioner for summer temperatures that touch 45C.

Little is left over for entertainment. A litre bottle of beer costs £1.40 in bars, and while you can eat your fill at a roadside stall for 40p, a meal in a more comfortable setting without alcohol costs about £3 a head. 1 Tokyo (last year 1)

Dublin, by contrast, has become cheaper to live in over the past year, dropping from 34th to 48th place. European cities have the dubious distinction of holding six of the 10 most expensive places. Paris, consistently the EU's most expensive place, has fallen from fifth to eighth position. The Romanian capital, Bucharest, in 120th spot, is now the cheapest city in Europe. But even Londoners will feel a pang of sympathy for residents of Tokyo, who for the ninth year running find themselves topping the rankings. The city's cost of living has risen by 26% in the past year thanks to the economy's revival - making it almost 30% dearer than Hong Kong in third place - and consumers now face exorbitant prices for basic foodstuffs. A 500g pack of supermarket cheese, for example, costs more than £12 on average. At the opposite end of the scale, the Indian cities of New Delhi and Mumbai - formerly Bombay - have usurped Tripoli to become the least expensive places in the world. For less than the monthly rent of a one-bedroom flat in a moderate area of London, residents of New Delhi could live in a fully-furnished three-bedroom house. Tokyo: 25 tea-bags will set you back £1.50 Whereas sightseers in most cities in the world gasp at architectural marvels or great works of art, visitors to Tokyo are just as often bowled over by the astonishing prices they encounter because of the strong yen and land values. Many supermarkets provide only hand baskets, perhaps because it is so expensive to fill up trolleys. Among the most shocking average costs are a box of 25 regular tea bags at £1.56, a kilogram of oranges at £2.46 and a litre of milk at £1.16. Land prices have plunged since 1980, when Tokyo's real estate was valued higher than the whole of the US, but are still insane. Houses in Japan cost 13 times an average worker's annual salary and much more in the capital. Little wonder Japan has one of the highest number of smokers in the world. At about £1.26 a pack, it is one of the few cheap pleasures available. Delhi: cheap for the UK tourist, steep for the Indian Delhi might be the cheapest city for the international traveller, but it does not feel that way for people earning in Indian rupees. With the pound worth about 70 rupees, a night out, including dinner at a moderately priced restaurant in posh south Delhi followed by the cinema and a taxi home, will cost well under a tenner a head. But consider the cost for a middle class Indian. A university lecturer generally takes home £200 a month. Rents in south Delhi start at about £145 a month for a two-bedroom flat. Electric ity costs £12 a month, not including an air conditioner for summer temperatures that touch 45C. Little is left over for entertainment. A litre bottle of beer costs £1.40 in bars, and while you can eat your fill at a roadside stall for 40p, a meal in a more comfortable setting without alcohol costs about £3 a head. 1 Tokyo (last year 1) 2 Osaka (2) 3 Hong Kong (3) 4 Libreville (7) 5 Oslo (5) , Zurich (4) 7 London (9) 8 Paris (5) 9 Geneva (8) 10 Copenhagen (10) 11 Vienna (10) 12 New York (14) , Taipei (33) 14 Stockholm (12) , Tripoli (123) 16 Beijing (13) 17 Shanghai (16), Singapore (30) 19 Guangzhou (27) 20 Manchester (25), Chicago (31), Schenzhen (na)

webTitle: Arts council a bottomless pit, say MPs

fields.headline: Arts council a bottomless pit, say MPs
fields.standfirst: Commons committee denounces 'catalogue of cost increases and delays' and says 13 of 15 key projects were over budget
fields.trailText: MPs have criticised the arts council as a bottomless pit and soft touch for failing to control £325m of lottery grants for projects ranging from the Royal Opera House to Sadler's Wells Theatre.
fields.body:
MPs have criticised the arts council as a bottomless pit and soft touch for failing to control £325m of lottery grants for projects ranging from the Royal Opera House to Sadler's Wells Theatre.

The Commons public accounts committee concluded that if the arts council had put its house in order sooner, "there might not have been such a catalogue of cost increases and delays".

The timing of the report could not have been more embarrassing for the government, as the culture secretary, Chris Smith, is today announcing the "biggest programme of museum and gallery openings in Britain's history".

But architects, designers and construction companies who have lost millions on lottery projects claim arts council schemes "should carry a health warning".

The MPs said that out of 15 large projects they examined, 13 were over budget and eight behind schedule. As a result " the paying public may yet end up with substandard facilities because of the need to cut costs and defer work".

The report followed an earlier investigation by the national audit office, which was equally scathing of the lack of checks on spending.

Worst examples included a £16m overrun on the £38m rebuilding of Sadler's Wells theatre in London and a £9m overspend on the £57m Royal Albert Hall refurbishment.

With 11 significant lottery buildings costing more than £400m due to open in the next few months, including the new Tate Bankside gallery and the Lowry complex in Salford, construction industry insiders have warned that further overruns were inevitable.

Some firms are being forced to settle for as little as 10p in the pound from failing lottery projects, and they have claimed they were paying for the arts council's "naivete in backing ideas which were put together on the back of an envelope".

The German architect Stefan Behnisch, who lost £400,000 when the plug was pulled on the £89m Harbourside concert hall in Bristol, said the arts council "wanted all the privileges of being a client without the obligations".

Max Fordham, whose design company worked on the same project, as well as on the troubled £17m Centre For Popular Music in Sheffield - where senior management resigned over the summer - said the council passed on the responsibility for its own mistakes to the contractors.

Ron Bennion, of Wates Construction, which had its fingers burned on the lottery redevelopment of the Cambridge Arts Theatre, said: "These schemes should carry a health warning."

In their report, the MPs said that £20m of extra lottery grants needed to bail out projects meant that there was less cash available for other deserving causes. Not paying out the cash would put projects at risk, but the committee concluded that the payments led to the council being considered "a soft touch ".

The MPs were particularly scathing about the lax attitude taken by the council towards partnership deals with the private sector. They pointed out that one reason supplementary cash was paid out was to overcome cashflow problems because private sponsorship money never materialised in time. "We note the arts council's confidence that required partnership funding will eventually be achieved, but there is a considerable way to go. On five projects we examined, a total of some £67m of partnership funding has still to come in (including £44m for the Royal Opera House). "We conclude that there is still significant risk to the arts council."

The MPs said that as a result " the financial stability of some organisations remain open to question."

They cited the Royal Opera House as one example, saying that despite the arts council claiming it would have an endowment fund of £30m by 2001, "it remains to be seen whether these aspirations will be met."

The MPs were also highly critical of the way the arts council failed to put its house in order until most of the money had been lost. It now has a three-stage assignment process to minimise cost over runs and delays - but did not introduce this until three years after the first grants had been handed out.

The arts council now has a finance and business services unit, but the MPs found it unacceptable that the proper financial and project management expertise had not been available in the first place.

They warned the arts council that it must enforce any future conditions to lottery grants. They cited the decision to give the Royal Opera House some £68m out of a £78.5m grant, without meeting its condition that it should have a business plan, as the worst example of this practice.

David Davis, chairman of the public accounts committee, said yesterday: "Too many of these projects are late and over budget, And too often recipients of grants go back to the arts council, cap in hand, and are given more funds. The arts council must tighten up its act. Lottery funded projects should be subject from rigorous control from day one. The arts council must take tough action to break the perception that it is a bottomless pit. "

But the arts council - which has since undergone a shake-up under the chairmanship of Gerry Robinson - claimed the committee's findings were out of date. The chief executive, Peter Hewitt, said the problems were confined to the early days of the lottery five years ago.

"We found the national audit office report helpful, but by the time we gave evidence to the committee last June, we already had implemented, or were in the process of implementing, all the recommendations."

fields.headline: Doctor denies making 'secret profits'
fields.trailText: One of Britain's leading infertility doctors reaped substantial "secret profits" from treating private patients abroad using the staff and facilities of his university employers, the high court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
One of Britain's leading infertility doctors reaped substantial "secret profits" from treating private patients abroad using the staff and facilities of his university employers, the high court heard yesterday.

Nottingham university is sueing Simon Fishel for about £400,000, covering undisclosed earnings, interest and damages, in a case with important implications for academics who top up their pay with private work.

The university claims that Dr Fishel, 47, breached his employment contract and induced staff to break theirs.

An embryologist with an international reputation, Dr Fishel worked with the team responsible for the birth, in 1978, of the first test-tube baby, Louise Brown. He left the university in 1997 to set up a clinic at Nottingham's BMI Park hospital, and ran infertility clinics abroad which raised fees of up to £10,000 over two- or three-day periods, said Timothy Dutton QC for the university.

None of the money went to the university, said Mr Dutton on the first day of the trial scheduled for three weeks.

In 1996 Dr Fishel was earning £138,000, the court heard. He charged patients abroad and kept the money for himself and to pay the university embryologists and staff. "He was bound to declare the profits... from his activities abroad to obtain informed consent from the university. But he did not do that," said Mr Dutton.

Dr Fishel contests the claim and says the university encouraged him and the staff to keep fees earned abroad. His work had led to valuable data and experience, applied for the benefit of the university, and was not "outside work". His gross earnings abroad were about £160,000, from which he paid £50,000 to staff and 40% income tax, he says.

But Mr Dutton said evidence suggested that, at least once, Dr Fishel was concerned to keep financial information away from the university.

The hearing continues today.

fields.headline: Dinosaur find could be biggest
fields.trailText: The longer scientists spend studying dinosaurs the longer dinosaurs seem to get, and the latest find in Argentina's southern Patagonia region has unearthed what local paleontologists are saying is the world's biggest dinosaur ever.
fields.body:
The longer scientists spend studying dinosaurs the longer dinosaurs seem to get, and the latest find in Argentina's southern Patagonia region has unearthed what local paleontologists are saying is the world's biggest dinosaur ever.

The bones were found by a villager in canyons in Patagonia known as La Buitrera (The Vulture Cage), and are believed to be 26ft longer than the previous longest dinosaur, Argentinosaurus.

The behemoth was a herbivore that roamed the earth during the Cretaceous period up to 105m years ago, and was between 157ft and 167ft long.

Paleontologist Carlos Munoz, director of the Florentino Ameghino museum in southern Rio Negro province, said: "We're ecstatic with this spectacular find. In Patagonia, walking among the rocks is enough to discover fossils.

"Two cervical vertebrae 3.94ft high were found, in addition to a femur 6.56ft in height and some other indicative bones." Colin Blackstock

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Tigers - perhaps. Environment minister Michael Meacher announced that the UK would be the first country where the animals do not live in the wild to join the Global Tiger Forum. The organisation is working to eliminate trade in tiger parts, increase the protected area network of tiger habitats, and promote training and research.

Bad day

Shaun Woodward. The Tory turned Labour MP made his first Commons contribution for his new party in the debate on RUC reform. Not only was he greeted with nasty hisses from the Conservative benches, there were shouts of "backstabber". He was given a warm welcome by Peter Mandelson, though.

Shortage of day

Top guns. The head of RAF personnel, Air Marshal Sir Anthony Bagnall, told MPs that the service had 95 vacancies for Tom Cruise level fighter pilots - making it 20 per cent short of its full complement. One of the main problems is poaching of top fighter pilots by civilian airlines.

Today

Lord Wakeham publishes his 180 page report into Lords reform. Jack Straw faces defeat in the Lords over his right to jury trial reforms.

fields.headline: Can you 'ack it?
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: My luxury on a desert island would be a butler. If someone struggled through mountainous seas to rescue me, he would open the door and say "Modom is not at home." I would, naturally, need a door as well.
fields.body:
My luxury on a desert island would be a butler. If someone struggled through mountainous seas to rescue me, he would open the door and say "Modom is not at home." I would, naturally, need a door as well.

A desert island should be deserted. Castaway 2000 (BBC 1), however, put 36 comparative strangers on a Hebridean island, lit the blue touch paper and retired. It claims to be a social experiment.

The castaways were allowed one traditional luxury. Impromptu suggestions were a teapot, Tampax, eye liner, cricket paraphenalia, a really good Chardonnay, a beer-making kit and a trapeze. I think she said trapeze. I like the notion so much I won't probe further in case it all falls down.

Scrutinising a batch of possibles for fibre was a man for whom the word gnarled was invented. Lofty (motto "Can you 'ack it?") looks like Compo's big brother. He has spent a lifetime in the army and is full of bluff barrackroom humour about how to kill a chicken or spot a gay, but under that gnarled bark throbs an unsuspected soul. He looked at Taransay and said "Beautiful! People'd search all their lives for a place like that." Indeedy doody, Lofty. The island is exquisite. It looks like God's golf course. Taransay has that silvery Hebridean way of not distinguishing between air or water. What seems another island is a cloud. Westwards there is only America. Angus McKay, the owner, is less lyrical. Asked how you keep warm, he replies briefly "You work."

According to Lofty the veneer of civilization soon peels off. Oh, good. The pre scient Nigel Kneale once wrote a play called The Year Of The Sex Olympics in which a young couple were left alone on a desert island. Alone with a murderer. They had an appreciative TV audience.

Absolutely invaluable tips for any castaway are that sheep always run uphill and a condom holds two litres of water. Or was it the sheep that holds two litres of water?

Anyway, 28 adults and eight children, chosen from 4,000 applications, began their year on Taransay at the millenium. Several instantly got flu.

Alternatively you could be Shipwrecked (Channel 4) on a small South Pacific island for 10 weeks. This jaunt was only for the young, nubile and agile. Just watching them running about was quite jolly. They did a lot of that, as the only visible meal was a small spotted pig called Gaynor. She was caught by the boys and surreptitiously released by a girl.

It Shouldn't Happen To... A Newsreader (ITV), a curiously uncatchy title in an occasional series, was a ragbag of fairly familiar clips. "Colin Baker for Thames News. Westminster. Soaked. With cold feet. An aching heart. Married. Several children. Pissed off. Really dreadfully pissed off." I wonder if he has cheered up at all. And Jeremy Paxman who, after asking Michael Howard the same question nine times, had the sauce to say "I'm sorry I'm going to be frightfully rude." And ask it again. Paxman has recently been ploughing a lone furrow by pronouncing Pinochet correctly with a final t. Foreign names are a quagmire. There must have been furtive celebrations among newsreaders when Lee Bum-Suk was assassinated.

If it's any comfort, worse things seem to happen in America. Armed with an eight-inch knife, a viewer once entered a CBS studio, and crying "I hate all television. There ought to be a law against it!" stabbed the cameraman and hit the producer on the head with a water carafe.

Like a game old oyster, Brookside (Channel 4) has been trying to digest the grit of several foreign bodies. The Hon Nathan Cuddington and three posh pals have settled in a semi in Brookside Close. Nathan is the son of an earl, who owns a stately home. In a moment of abstraction, he has got engaged to Jacqui, daughter of Ron, who owns a strange wig. Yesterday Ron gatecrashed Cuddington Hall, surprising the countess, who was changing her tiara ("Charmed!") and partook of tea ("I could eat a scabby horse") with the heir ("Later, Mater!")

This is madness. I wonder if one of Brookside's celebrated explosions could be arranged. I would pay for the gas.

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Which actor will return, in 2002, to the TV role that first made them famous?
fields.trailText: Which actor will return, in 2002, to the TV role that first made them famous?
fields.body:
Joe Absolom as Matthew Rose (EastEnders) 7/4

David Duchovny as Fox Mulder (X Files) 3/1

George Clooney as Dr Doug Ross (ER) 3/1

This week Daniella Westbrook announced a fourth departure from the part of stroppy Sam in EastEnders, complete with an open door for her return. A good deal done, but what are the chances of other actors returning to the staid soap roles that made them stars, asks Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler, Ed Nicholson.

Once again the word is out that George Clooney may go back to ER as heartthrob rogue Dr Doug Ross. Though the rumours are well timed, as a new series has just begun on Sky One, Ed doesn't think the story has much substance.

"I can't see him making a one-off appearance", says Ed, referring to Juliana Maguilie's (Nurse Hathaway) remarks that Clooney might pop back and show Ross isn't a "deadbeat dad". "I don't think he'll go backwards, and it's really only likely to happen if there was a film of ER", Ed concludes.

In October Joe Absolom announced he was quitting EastEnders, just after his charactor Matthew Rose was framed for manslaughter. Joe told bosses he wanted to concentrate on a musical career with his band Hung Up.

Martine McCutcheon left for similar reasons, "but where Martine's character is dead, there is a history of EastEnders management leaving the door ajar for young stars to come back", says Ed.

David Duchovny, on the other hand, has bitter relations on the other side of the camera - he has made unpleasant comments about Gillian Anderson, and has a bitter lawsuit with the programme makers.

"There has also been plenty written about him wanting to go back into cinema," says Ed. "And the entire X Files programme is in the balance, after the announcement a couple of months ago that Gillian Anderson is quitting. Obviously their relationship is pivotal. Fans can only hope that if Mulder disappears it's under the guise of taking time off."

Though the rumours are well timed, as a new series has just begun on Sky One, Ed doesn't think the story has much substance. "I can't see him making a one-off appearance", says Ed, referring to Juliana Maguilie's (Nurse Hathaway) remarks that Clooney might pop back and show Ross isn't a "deadbeat dad". "I don't think he'll go backwards, and it's really only likely to happen if there was a film of ER", Ed concludes. In October Joe Absolom announced he was quitting EastEnders, just after his charactor Matthew Rose was framed for manslaughter. Joe told bosses he wanted to concentrate on a musical career with his band Hung Up. Martine McCutcheon left for similar reasons, "but where Martine's character is dead, there is a history of EastEnders management leaving the door ajar for young stars to come back", says Ed. David Duchovny, on the other hand, has bitter relations on the other side of the camera - he has made unpleasant comments about Gillian Anderson, and has a bitter lawsuit with the programme makers. "There has also been plenty written about him wanting to go back into cinema," says Ed. "And the entire X Files programme is in the balance, after the announcement a couple of months ago that Gillian Anderson is quitting. Obviously their relationship is pivotal. Fans can only hope that if Mulder disappears it's under the guise of taking time off."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Miracle
fields.body:
The Miracle

(Neil Jordan, 1990)

10pm, FilmFour

In between the big budget We're No Angels, and his hit The Crying Game, Neil Jordan directed this romantic drama. Set in Ireland, it focuses on two 15-year-olds who spend their time making up stories about people they see in the street. One such woman, a glamorous American actress (Beverly D'Angelo) in town for a local theatre production, becomes something of an obsession for Jimmy (Niall Byrne), which develops into something more. The performances are thoroughly engaging.
Richard Vine

Batman And Robin

(Joel Schumacher, 1997)

10am, 5.55pm, Sky Premier

Schumacher must have had to work hard to make a hash of this fourth instalment of Gotham's caped crusader. For goodies he has George Clooney (pictured) donning heavy-fetish rubber batgear for the first time, Alicia Silverstone as Batgirl, plus Chris O'Donnell back as Robin; for baddies, Arnold Schwarzenegger's cool Mr Freeze, and stealing the show, Uma Thurman's Poison Ivy. How did Schumacher manage to make it so dull?

Sword in the Stone

(Wolfgang Reitherman, 1963)

7pm, Disney

Walt on Wart - a bewitching Disney animated version of TH White's novel about the young King Arthur, The Once and Future King. Produced by Disney himself, it's an exuberant tale, with the young Wart serving an apprenticeship to Merlin the Magician.

Blood Simple

(Joel Coen, 1984)

11.40pm, FilmFour

The Coen brothers' debut is a savage but worthy descendant of classic 40's film noir. The plot is a foul brew of lust, vengeance, greed and treachery, winding through a series of vicious twists with malignant humour, Barry (Men in Black) Sonnenfeld's rich photography belying the paltry budget. The cast has a ball too: Dan Hedaya the Texas bar owner reaping the whirlwind when he hires sleazy private eye M Emmett Walsh to murder his wife, Frances McDormand, and her lover, John Getz.

Paul Howlett

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: A couple of quick turns round the body zone today, no queuing required. The first opportunity comes courtesy of Material World (4.30pm, Radio 4), where Dr Kevin Fong argues for British participation in space-travel research, particularly into its long-term effects on the human frame. A 1,000-day mission to Mars is due in 2004. However, unless the European Space Agency and its partners understand what could happen to a crew journeying through areas of high radiation, the project may be scuppered.

A couple of quick turns round the body zone today, no queuing required. The first opportunity comes courtesy of Material World (4.30pm, Radio 4), where Dr Kevin Fong argues for British participation in space-travel research, particularly into its long-term effects on the human frame. A 1,000-day mission to Mars is due in 2004. However, unless the European Space Agency and its partners understand what could happen to a crew journeying through areas of high radiation, the project may be scuppered.

If that seems esoteric, try Night Waves (9.30pm, Radio 3) where Patrick Wright delves into the development of human consciousness with Antonio Damasio. Their discussion stems from the Iowa neurosurgeon's latest book - notable for such observations as "The non-conscious neural signalling of an individual organism begets the proto-self". Just the thing for any Mars mission whose members want to offer the bemused locals an insight into these uninvited weirdos.

fields.headline: How did they do that?
fields.standfirst: Programmes about ancient civilisations have never been more popular. And no wonder. Lost empires are perfect subjects for documentary makers who want results for the minimum of effort.  Richard Vine  explains how it's done
fields.trailText: Blood And Fire, Secrets Of The Ancients, The Search For The Lost Civilization - is there anybody left in the country who isn't an expert on the world of the Aztecs?
fields.body:
Blood And Fire, Secrets Of The Ancients, The Search For The Lost Civilization - is there anybody left in the country who isn't an expert on the world of the Aztecs?

With an alarming frequency, documentary makers are heading for the wilds of South America in search of ancient civilisations. Tonight's visit to The Lost City Of Nasca (Horizon, BBC2, 9.30pm) is already the second this century, and Channel 4 are promising to unveil more Secrets Of The Incas next month.

Like the virus of DIY makeover shows, one thing about this strand of docutainment seems clear: it's a winning formula, and when you've got a winning formula you churn out more.

For an ideal Ancient Hidden Secrets Of The Lost World show you first need to find a great monument. Pyramids are best, as they open up all the tricky engineering questions, as well as offering some great sunset shots. But they have been done a lot. Mayan pyramids are useful, as you don't often see ads for cruises to visit them, and lots of them are (or used to be) lost in the jungles, so you can also get the word "Lost" in your title.

Choosing a civilisation is another crucial factor. Incas, Aztecs and Mayans work best, as no one's really sure when they lived or what they did, apart from playing the odd game of severed-head football. The Egyptians don't offer so much of a blank slate for you to work with, but they did come up with the pyramids.

Then of course, you need some stunning locations. Thoughtfully, most ancient civilisations who built great monuments seem to have chosen photogenic sites for their architectural feats. Atlantis is good in this respect; no one knows where it is, so you can go wherever you like.

Next you need to find a historian, engineer, astronomer or archaeologist who's willing to come up with a startling enough new revelation about the site's origin, meaning or construction.

The astronomical phenomenon of precession is always a good one to throw in at some point to add some irrefutable scientific weight - you can't deny that the earth shifts its position in the universe, so at least part of your theory is already true.

Another good trick is to try and get people to find out how the ancients actually built your chosen great monument by staging a recreation, using, of course, authentic materials. This allows for your Changing Tombs team to hop on the first flight to Mexico, where, let's face it, it's a lot more fun trying to move huge boulders with only a few bits of hand-woven rope, some logs and a bunch of beefy local farmers to help you, than it is back home in the Blue Peter garden.

As long as you tie most of the strands together, in a convincing fashion, it's impossible for an audience to dispute what your expert is saying. Most people are not archaeologists, no matter how many episodes of Time Team they've got on tape.

Tonight, it's the turn of the Nasca lines, the carvings of birds, monkeys, and geometric shapes etched in a South American desert floor. In an attempt to show how far we've come in our understanding of them, the BBC plunders its own museum of antiquities during the Lost City Of The Nasca to show us a few examples of the "fantastic explanations" they have previously inspired.

Erich Von Daniken, the Graham Hancock of the 70s, thought the lines were alien landing strips. But, a 1977 Horizon episode, The Case Of The Ancient Astronauts, proves they weren't by driving a VW van onto one of the supposed runways.

"In fact, if anything heavy leaves one of the modern paths crossing the plain, and drives onto a Nasca line," the narrator informs us, "it simply gets stuck."

After this history of the "outlandish" theories that have gone before, we are then presented with today's Nasca expert, Italian archaeologist, Giuseppe Orefici.

To establish his credentials, Horizon gets him to show how the the Nasca made the lines. It's disappointingly simple. You just move the darker stones from on top of the lighter pampas floor, mark off the shapes with bits of rope nicked from crop circle hooligans and there you go - Instant Nasca!

With this mystery of the ancients revealed, Giuseppe then unleashes his own theory.

He's found some impressively preserved weavings buried among the mummies dug up in Cahuachi, the eponymous lost city. As it's pretty ornate work, he thinks it would have been reserved for top members of the Nasca culture, like priests, and this leads him to the theory that the lines had some kind of religious purpose.

Giuseppe then enlists the help of the Nasca's living descendants to demonstrate the next part of his masterplan. The weavings were made with a single thread, which matches the single line that make up the huge birds and monkey patterns. He drafts in some modern Nasca school kids and gets them to march around the lines, crocodile fashion, to show us what it would have looked like when their ancestors walked around them. And there we have it. Ancient monument, great location, talkative expert, recreation, new theory: tonight, Matthew, the Nasca will be an ancient tribe of ramblers who liked to walk in an orderly fashion.

webTitle: Gay clause campaigners backtrack on backers

fields.headline: Gay clause campaigners backtrack on backers
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: The campaign to stop the Scottish parliament from repealing section 28 descended into farce yesterday when PR officials were forced to withdraw claims of support from a number of Scottish celebrities.
fields.body:
The campaign to stop the Scottish parliament from repealing section 28 descended into farce yesterday when PR officials were forced to withdraw claims of support from a number of Scottish celebrities.

PR firm Media House told a press conference in Edinburgh that rock star Jim Kerr of Simple Minds, TV chef Nick Nairn, and hairdresser Taylor Ferguson had all joined the campaign to retain the clause, which bans teachers from promoting the acceptability of homosexuality. But within minutes they were forced into an embarrassing retreat as it emerged that Nick Nairn has expressed support for the Scottish executive position; Taylor Ferguson said he had not been approached by anyone to use his name; and Jim Kerr was quoted in a newspaper as supporting equal rights in Scottish education. Later Media House said they had been duped by a hoax fax.

Wendy Alexander, the minister behind the reform, meanwhile insisted the Scottish executive would not waver on their commitment to see the clause erased.

webTitle: Labour targets 'weak' voters in 2001 poll drive

fields.headline: Labour targets 'weak' voters in 2001 poll drive
fields.trailText: Labour is gearing up for a general election campaign before June next year by targeting the one group of supporters which threaten Tony Blair's hopes of a second landslide - "weak Labour voters" who may stay at home.
fields.body:
Labour is gearing up for a general election campaign before June next year by targeting the one group of supporters which threaten Tony Blair's hopes of a second landslide - "weak Labour voters" who may stay at home.

An analysis of the challenge which the government faces to hold on to the 146 seats won in 1997, leaked to the Guardian last night, brutally reminds MPs and party activists that Labour voters were better motivated then than they will be next time.

"They hated the Tories and they liked Labour. It is worth remembering that voters are more motivated to vote against something that they do not like," says the analysis which is called Operation Turnout.

The most striking claim in the 10-page report is the calm assertion in the opening sentence, drafted this week, that "we are less than 18 months away from the next general election".

That confirms most MPs' assumption that party HQ in Millbank is planning for an election in April, May or June 2001.

MPs who were shown the document at a private meeting yesterday predicted that the sentence will be deleted in future drafts. But the main message will remain. "At the next election the challenge is different" from the drive to hang on the "Tory switchers" in 1997.

"The government is popular and the Tories are weak and divided. People's motivation to vote will be less and the danger is that turnout will be lower than last time. A low turnout is dangerous for Labour - you only need to look at the European election (the 25% poll in June 1999) to see that," the Millbank analysis warns.

The key passage continues: "The core Tory voters are more motivated to vote than any other group as their motivation is a negative one - they dislike Labour. Our own voters perceive that Labour is so far ahead that the result is a forgone conclusion, they do not see the Tories as a threat."

Cynicism about politics, a legacy of the Tory years, and pressure on voters' time, add to the problem. The stark conclusion which the Labour general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, and her election team have drawn is that "what we need to do to win the next election is to find and then target supporters who are less likely to vote".

fields.headline: Blair warns voters off Livingstone
fields.standfirst:
PM and chancellor claim former GLC leader would raise taxes and reopen old wounds if elected mayor
Special report on the London mayoral race on the Guardian network at www.newsunlimited.co.uk/mayor
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night warned Labour activists in London that it is "time to get serious" about the race to be Labour's candidate for mayor, telling them Ken Livingstone is not up to the job.
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night warned Labour activists in London that it is "time to get serious" about the race to be Labour's candidate for mayor, telling them Ken Livingstone is not up to the job.

Accusing the former GLC leader of "gesture politics" and of making a joke of controversial remarks, Mr Blair said: "I tell you this job is no laughing matter. Crime in London is no joke. Poverty in London is no joke, these are serious issues. This is a serious job, we are a serious party."

Addressing Labour members with the chancellor, Gordon Brown, in London, Mr Blair promised to back whoever emerges as Labour's candidate when the votes are counted in four weeks.

But he made it clear that his former health secretary, Frank Dobson, "would be the best man for the job".

"He is experienced, serious, his own man, but a team player too," said Mr Blair.

Mr Brown described Mr Dobson as "a loyal member of the party" who would argue in private but unite in public.

Mr Blair said there was "precious little evidence" that Mr Livingstone has changed since the turbulent 1980s.

Mr Brown yesterday used an article in the London Evening Standard to attack Mr Livingstone's policies. Six new taxes would hit the growth of new businesses in the capital of which there were 40,000 last year - and start "an 80s-style economic policy and a re-run of the old fights over economic policy," the chancellor claimed.

Mr Livingstone has attacked the chancellor's "high interest rate and high sterling" policies, saying they cost jobs. Mr Blair last night told party activists that the chancellor had done "brilliantly".

Writing in today's Guardian, Mr Livingstone claims to be the victim of "huge forces mobilised to stop me" but insists London loves him. "It is simply not possible to change Londoners' memories of what the GLC did," he said.

He admits that he canvassed non-Labour academic experts such as Tony Travers and Peter Hall to join his cabinet - not itself a breach of Labour rules.

"Tony Blair has brought Liberals into a cabinet committee and appointed all sorts of Tory ex-cabinet ministers to all sorts of important posts. I'm just continuing with this inclusive tradition," he explained.

But he denied a report in yesterday's Guardian that he was organising a slate for the elected Greater London Authority (GLA) that would help him run as an independent if Mr Dobson were to win the party nomination. Jim Fitzpatrick MP, the chairman of the Greater London Labour Party, said last night that Mr Livingstone would suffer an automatic, five-year expulsion from the party only if he filed independent nomination papers.

Others, including Clive Soley, the chairman of the parliamentary Labour Party, argue that canvassing for would-be GLA candidates would render Mr Livingstone liable to disciplinary action for "bringing the party into disrepute" or "attacking colleagues".

In his article, Mr Brown defended John Prescott's private partnership plan for restoring the London Underground and attacked the bond issue alternative backed by Liberal Democrats and Mr Livingstone.

"For Ken Livingstone the Tube has become an issue of economic dogma, ignoring the realities of getting the investment needed to improve everyday life for Londoners," said Mr Brown.

He warned party voters: "What would threaten jobs and put the economy at risk is to attack the very policies that are creating stability and steady growth - and then to advocate huge business and personal tax rises, an 80s-style economic policy and a re-run of the old fights over economic policy at the heart of the Labour Party."

Tony Blair cites three examples to back his claim that Ken Livingstone has not changed:

Blair's example
'The calls for Gordon Brown, rightly acknowledged throughout the party for his brilliant handling of the economy, to be sacked'

Livingstone's reply
'I think Gordon should avoid this policy of high interest rates and an over-valued pound because we have lost 100,000 manufacturing jobs in 1999'

Blair's example
'The revelation that Ken does not want to work with our party candidates, and instead is casting around for his own kitchen cabinet.'

Livingstone's reply
'The mayor is allowed to appoint a cabinet and I have always made clear that it will not just be Labour party people. It will be anyone with a commitment to London'

Blair's example
'Silly and offensive remarks about the riots in Seattle and his views on policing generally'

Livingstone's reply
'There were no offensive remarks about [the disrupted World Trade Organisation conference in] Seattle. There was a series of jokes [in The Face magazine], the whole column was a series of jokes. It was only because the No 10 press office and Frank's campaign went berserk that anyone noticed'

Tony Blair cites three examples to back his claim that Ken Livingstone has not changed: Blair's example 'The calls for Gordon Brown, rightly acknowledged throughout the party for his brilliant handling of the economy, to be sacked' Livingstone's reply 'I think Gordon should avoid this policy of high interest rates and an over-valued pound because we have lost 100,000 manufacturing jobs in 1999' Blair's example 'The revelation that Ken does not want to work with our party candidates, and instead is casting around for his own kitchen cabinet.' Livingstone's reply 'The mayor is allowed to appoint a cabinet and I have always made clear that it will not just be Labour party people. It will be anyone with a commitment to London' Blair's example 'Silly and offensive remarks about the riots in Seattle and his views on policing generally' Livingstone's reply 'There were no offensive remarks about [the disrupted World Trade Organisation conference in] Seattle. There was a series of jokes [in The Face magazine], the whole column was a series of jokes. It was only because the No 10 press office and Frank's campaign went berserk that anyone noticed'

fields.headline: Internet vote
fields.standfirst: Derek Wyatt is Labour MP for Sittingbourne and Sheppey. He helped to found the Associate Parliamentary Internet Group
fields.trailText: Derek Wyatt is Labour MP for Sittingbourne and Sheppey. He helped to found the Associate Parliamentary Internet Group
fields.body:
What system do you run? I'm Apple mad, despite the rest of the world being wrong! I have a G3 laptop and each of my kids has an Apple. I've also had to get a PC (a Dell laptop) because you can't use an Apple in the House of Commons. We try to be a virtual office and I have things like video conferencing - I'm the first MP to do video conferencing surgeries.

Why do so few MPs seem to embracing IT? If you didn't come in in '97 you would never have got the internet. If you came in in '92 or '87 or '83 you'd still be on logarithms. To be honest I think that, even though Netscape was a '95 flotation, we're only really getting it now. Six of the eight major advertisers in the Rugby World Cup were .com companies - something's happening. Then you think we're only just having an e-commerce Bill and it feels like we're a bit slow to the dance floor as a nation.

What's the idea behind the Associate Parliamentary Internet Group? I'd done the .tv computer channel at Sky. When I came to the house there was only PITCom (Parliamentary Information Technology Committee). It seemed sensible to form something more geared toward the internet so we did and now there are more than 100 members - although about six to 12 regulars.

Is IT going to swamp all other communications mediums? I'm on the select committee for the digital stuff and I just think that the internet wins. On Open (Sky's interactive channel - hardly anyone's gone to the Walled Garden but 300,000 people have sent email using the zapper pad. You see that they've just been using number 1 on the pad... how slow, but indicative that people just want to send email.

Where do you see the net going? I founded the World Internet Forum and what I'm trying to do is create a portal for public services. What we have to do is to make sure that the public services are not left behind by the private use of the net. I'd like to see unmetered calls and BT broken up into a carrier and a dot com.

Any gadgets you'd like? Virtual voting! Why should I be in the House of Commons at one o'clock in the morning when they could see me and I could say I'm voting? We're trying to modernise Britain but we're not prepared to modernise the systems of voting at the House of Commons - that doesn't add up to me.

How does Labour plan to progress as regards IT? I think we've finally done well on the National Grid for Learning but we need to get computers linked into libraries. If I had one big wish it would be to digitise the British Library so it could become the hub for all schools and universities in the world.

 Derek Wyatt's homepage can be found at: www.derekwyattmp.co.uk
