webTitle: Unita leader personally ordered Angola plane attacks, UN told

fields.headline: Unita leader personally ordered Angola plane attacks, UN told
fields.trailText: The United Nations security council last night saw videotape evidence from former senior military leaders of the Unita rebel movement in Angola that the Unita leader Jonas Savimbi personally ordered the shooting down of two UN planes just over a year ago, killing a total of 23 people.
fields.body:
The United Nations security council last night saw videotape evidence from former senior military leaders of the Unita rebel movement in Angola that the Unita leader Jonas Savimbi personally ordered the shooting down of two UN planes just over a year ago, killing a total of 23 people.

Mr Savimbi also ordered the burial of the planes' fuselage to prevent any effective inquiry by the UN.

"We had instructions to bring down any type of aircraft that was flying within range of our anti-aircraft guns. Savimbi said the UN aircraft were in the service of the government," one defector said.

The evidence, along with a report from the Canadian ambassador Robert Fowler, the chairman of the UN sanctions committee on Angola, also detailed Unita's trade of diamonds for arms. The trade, which breaks sanctions, has kept the war going since Unita rejected the results of the 1992 UN-supervised elections.

Mr Fowler promised a fuller report in March which would name people, countries and companies involved in breaking the UN sanctions.

His report finally nails any chance of a political future in Angola for Mr Savimbi, once the protege of successive US presidents, the CIA and their allies in Africa, and various west European governments, including Britain.

Many UN officials failed for years to reveal publicly what was known privately about Unita's responsibility for the war. However Mr Fowler's work has dramatically changed the UN tone on Unita, and Mr Savimbi has been declared a war criminal by the southern Africa group of countries, SADCC, and the Organisation of African Unity.

"If the outside world ceases and desists from providing military assistance to Savimbi, he will not be able to maintain this war," Mr Fowler told the security council. "Responsibility for this war has been squarely and unequivocally laid at the feet of Jonas Savimbi."

The ambassador said Unita put out tenders to the international arms market, with brokers flying into Mr Savimbi's headquarters at Andulo in the central highlands.

"The supplier would offer the whole package, delivered to Andulo," Mr Fowler said. "They would settle the price in diamonds."

Mr Fowler added: "There is a huge volume of information out there indicating - crystal clear - that Unita's arsenal is essentially east European."

The video shows six interviews between Mr Fowler and Unita defectors, including General Jacinto Bandua who was in charge of Unita's logistics. One witness said that the airport at Andulo was receiving 15-20 flights a day, including Illushin 76s and Antonov 72s carrying T74 tanks.

Andulo and much of the central highlands is now in government hands but military officials in Luanda have warned that the war is not over. Tens of thousands of refugees have poured into eastern Zambia in the last few days, while northern Namibia has also seen incursions by Unita troops.

webTitle: Istanbul shootout leads police to house of horrors

fields.headline: Istanbul shootout leads police to house of horrors
fields.trailText: Police in Istanbul yesterday found the decomposing bodies of nine local businessmen who are believed to have been kidnapped and killed by a radical Islamic group which wants to overthrow Turkey's secular system.
fields.body:
Police in Istanbul yesterday found the decomposing bodies of nine local businessmen who are believed to have been kidnapped and killed by a radical Islamic group which wants to overthrow Turkey's secular system.

The recovery of the bodies of the men, who were naked and had their hands and feet tied, came after a dramatic shootout in the city on Monday, in which the leader of the hard line Turkish Hizbullah faction, Huseyin Velioglu, was killed by police.

After interrogating two senior members of the group who were captured during the exchange of fire, the police cordoned off streets in the early hours of yesterday morning around a run-down house in Uskudar, on the Asian side of Istanbul.

Forensic experts picked their way through the house and garden to make a series of grim discoveries.

The businessmen, who were all thought to have had Islamist sympathies, had disappeared over the course of the past few weeks. Local media reports say their bank accounts had been emptied before they were killed. It was the fraudulent use of a credit card which led to a breakthrough in the case.

The death of Velioglu, who exchanged fire with police marksmen for several hours, is being seen as a big setback to Turkish Hizbullah.

"The organisation has suffered a great blow," said Suleyman Ikizer, the head of the police anti-terror department in Istanbul. He alleged that Velioglu had been trained in Iran, and had only recently returned to Turkey to try to set up new radical Islamic cells in the city.

Turkish Hizbullah first emerged in the 1980s with the aim of setting up an Islamic republic ruled by strict Sharia religious law. It quickly won supporters among rural religious Kurds in the south-east of the country and there have been persistent suggestions that it was initially sponsored by elements within the state in the battle against Abdullah Ocalan's secular Kurdish rebel group, the PKK.

But as the military threat from the PKK has decreased, so the level of concern about Hizbullah's activities has risen. There have been hundreds of arrests of alleged Hizbullah sympathisers in the south-east in the past couple of years.

The Turkish prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, yesterday hailed the success of the security forces and pledged to continue the campaign against Islamic extremism.

"I believe we will be able to eradicate the Hizbullah in a short time," he told a meeting of his parliamentary group, "just as we have started to eradicate the PKK in Turkey and the world."

The Turkish military has described Islamic radical groups such as Hizbullah as the biggest security challenge facing the country. Some critics say the threat has been exaggerated to allow the armed forces to maintain a tight grip on the south-east, but the military high command says it will protect the country's secular republic at any cost.

In a separate police raid in Ankara yesterday, security forces arrested five suspected members of Hizbullah, two of them women. A large amount of bomb-making material was allegedly recovered from their house.

The semi-official Anatolia news agency said the five detainees could be linked to the murder of Ahmet Taner Kislali, a leading intellectual and former culture minister, who was killed in a bomb attack in October last year.

Huge resources are now being mobilised to stop me. Indeed, the scale of it is such that only last month, the Guardian ran an editorial criticising the use of question-and-answer meetings with the prime minister for Labour party members to oppose me. "The degree of energy being sunk into winning this contest for Mr Dobson is becoming embarrassing," said the Guardian.

Many of the criticisms levelled at me yesterday were old chestnuts. Indeed, at least one dates from the front the page of the Sun in 1981. This is not a new aspect of the campaign - Frank Dobson's "Cost of Ken" document last week was revealed by the Guardian to have been written by Douglas McWilliams of the Centre for Economics and Business Research, who is an adviser to Conservative shadow chancellor Francis Maude.

The onslaught over my candidacy is certainly overwhelming. Labour party members were promised a one member one vote ballot to choose their candidate. They now have an electoral college where 75 MPs, MEPs and GLA candidates have votes 1,000 times larger than that of an ordinary party member.

Unlike the election of Tony Blair as Labour leader, there is no requirement for trade unions to ballot. Rules in the trade union section were imposed so that several thousand trade unionists were denied a vote. MPs will not have a secret ballot.

The party presided over a situation in which one candidate - Frank Dobson - was able to campaign with the full use of party membership lists for three months, while Glenda Jackson and I could not. Panorama revealed that this was only possible following the intervention of a senior party official. This situation led to Glenda and I submitting a 14-page dossier of concerns about the conduct of the selection to the independent scrutineer.

The choice of Labour's candidate for mayor should be on the policies needed to get London moving and the candidate most likely to ensure the largest possible Labour victory. I believe that my record and my commitment to London speak for themselves. That is why yesterday's stories that I am about to stand as an independent are ludicrous. I will not stand against the party I have spent my whole adult life serving.

Once Labour has selected a candidate we must work together to defeat our opponents in the London election. A united Labour administration will be a huge asset in meeting the challenges of the new authority. Both Glenda Jackson and Frank Dobson would make fine Labour mayors. Indeed, if elected, my first act as mayor will be to offer both Glenda and Frank major roles in my administration.

As mayor I will draw on the skills and knowledge of people who want to make London a better place to live, which is why I would very much like to invite academics and commentators such as Tony Travers and Simon Jenkins to be members of my cabinet. These are people with a wealth of knowledge about London and local government and the fact that these people do not support me politically is important.

What I need is their critical analysis of the various reports that the mayor will have to consider on issues ranging from transport and planning to arts and the environment. I intend that these cabinet meetings should be open to the media and broadcast live on the internet, so that all Londoners can get involved in the development of the mayor's policies.

Contrary to the litany of criticisms of my record at GLC which were regurgitated yesterday by leading supporters of Frank Dobson, Londoners recall that the period of the 1981-86 Labour GLC was the only period in living memory that public transport in London improved. This was possible because I was able to run a dynamic administration of people whose political opinions varied enormously, but all of whom had a genuine commitment to London.

Bill Bush, now a senior Downing Street aide and formerly the head of the Labour Group office at the GLC, told my biographer John Carvel that I "read papers fast and got the point. On the big issues I don't remember him ever being bounced by officials into an ill-considered decision. He got through a lot because he was good at delegating. He was mayoral in the way he worked at the GLC".

It is simply not possible to change Londoners' memories of what the GLC did. Asked by Mori last year whether the GLC did a good job or a bad job for London, 51% of Londoners - 12 years after the GLC was abolished - responded that it had done a good job. That is an impressive political legacy and one of which London Labour party members are rightly proud. Thousands of London Labour party members - and millions of London Labour voters - want to be represented by the open and devolved form of Labour's politics that I stand for.

Ken Livingstone is Labour MP for Brent East and was leader of the GLC from 1981-86

fields.headline: European consortium wins £1bn RAF contract
fields.trailText: The government will deliver a boost to Europe's defence industry by awarding an almost £1bn contract to arm the RAF's fleet of 232 Eurofighters to a pan-European group building a new "smart" missile.
fields.body:
The government will deliver a boost to Europe's defence industry by awarding an almost £1bn contract to arm the RAF's fleet of 232 Eurofighters to a pan-European group building a new "smart" missile.

The ministry of defence (MoD), according to industry sources and defence analysts, will choose the ramjet-powered Meteor missile being developed by a consortium headed by Franco-British group Matra BAe Dynamics, and including German, Italian and Swedish partners.

The outcome, creating up to 3,000 British jobs which ever side wins, will be a blow to American rival Raytheon, the world's biggest missile maker, which issued another profits warning on Tuesday.

It has offered to supply the missiles at half the price of Meteor - £450m - when the government is keen to contain the defence budget and is committed to spending much of its war chest on improving the national health service.

But, the sources say, the decision to opt for Meteor will be part of a wider series of industrial and political trade-offs costing £4bn. It will enable Tony Blair to prove his commitment to developing a pan-European defence capability, while remaining loyally transatlantic in outlook.

Raytheon, the world's biggest defence electronics group, last month sealed a £750m MoD contract to supply a new airborne stand-off radar and is almost certain to win a separate bid, worth £500m to £1bn, to supply a new smart black box to the RAF, enabling its fighters to "identify friend or foe".

The final decision to buy the Meteor missiles, taken under intensive lobbying from other European leaders, is expected to be announced late next month or in early March.

It should coincide with the award of another lucrative contract to provide the armed forces with a new strategic airlift capability for transporting heavy armour both in the short and long term.

The short-term winner is almost certain to be American group Boeing, which is offering to provide, possibly on a leasing arrangement, around four C17s capable of carrying 80 tonnes of equipment. Boeing, which faces competition from Europe over the longer term in the shape of Airbus's A400M and is pitted against Lockheed's C130J, is offering the same terms as for the US air force.

The USAF is considering a Boeing proposal to supply 15 planes a year at a 15% discount to the $150m (£91m) cost of each plane, which would be fitted with an extra tank to provide 15% more fuel.

fields.headline: Jobless figures tumble
fields.standfirst: Rising wages and bounce-back in economy point to early interest rate rise
fields.trailText: The bounce-back in the economy sent unemployment tumbling by 20,000 last month to a near twenty-year low, official figures showed yesterday.
fields.body:
The bounce-back in the economy sent unemployment tumbling by 20,000 last month to a near twenty-year low, official figures showed yesterday.

The number of people out of work and claiming benefit in December fell to 1.164m, the lowest level since March 1980, according to the Office for National Statistics. Despite fears that the dwindling numbers of job seekers might push up pay claims, average earnings increases remained steady at 4.9%.

But City analysts warned that wage inflation was too high for the Bank of England's comfort. The Bank's monetary policy committee (MPC) expressed concern about developing pressures in the labour market when it raised interest rates earlier this month.

"With the main annual bonus round about to commence, earnings growth is poised to move above the 5% mark in the next few months," said Dharhini David, UK economist at HSBC markets. "With the strength of the consumer sector and the tight labour market uppermost in the MPC's mind, these figures only make a further rate hike in February look more likely."

And optimism about household finances has risen to its highest level for more than a year, according to figures released yesterday by the Consumers' Association. "Even after the Christmas spending spree, more consumers are willing to increase their debts than three months ago and more people are planning home improvements," the association said.

The falling jobless total is one of the factors propelling household confidence figures. The ONS figure showed that the proportion of the workforce out of work and claiming benefit fell 0.2 percentage points to 4% - its lowest level since January 1980. "However you define full employment, we are nearly there," said Michael Saunders of Salomon Smith Barney Citibank.

But the government's preferred measure of unemployment showed an increase, according to the ONS. The number of people out of work and looking for a job rose by 11,000 in the September to November period.

Analysts said it was not unusual for the two measures to diverge when the labour market was buoyant, because people who had previously been put off seeking work were encouraged to start looking.

webTitle: Rank poised to sell Odeon chain

fields.headline: Rank poised to sell Odeon chain
fields.trailText: The troubled Rank Group is understood to be close to selling its Odeon cinema chain to venture capitalists for £300m, writes Julia Finch.
fields.body:
The troubled Rank Group is understood to be close to selling its Odeon cinema chain to venture capitalists for £300m, writes Julia Finch.

The Odeon business is Britain's largest cinema chain with 469 screens in 79 venues nationwide, including its flagship Odeon Leicester Square venue, which has recently been renovated.

The cinemas are a profitable operation, expected to rake in £18m this year, but were put on the market last year after Rank hired a new chief executive, Mike Smith, from Ladbrokes.

Mr Smith conducted a review of the ailing Rank businesses - which range from video duplication to Hard Rock Cafes and Butlins - to identify divisions that could be sold off in an attempt to reduce Rank's £1.3bn debt mountain.

Venture capital group Cinven, which already owns ABC cinemas, is understood to be the front runner to take over the chain.

webTitle: Sterling reaches new highs as euro languishes

fields.headline: Sterling reaches new highs as euro languishes
fields.trailText: Sterling yesterday powered to its highest level against the German mark since Nigel Lawson was chancellor, and moved to a new high against the euro, as expectations rose that the Bank of England would raise interest rates again.
fields.body:
Sterling yesterday powered to its highest level against the German mark since Nigel Lawson was chancellor, and moved to a new high against the euro, as expectations rose that the Bank of England would raise interest rates again.

For the third day in a row, the pound set records against the beleaguered single currency, touching 61.5p at one point, equivalent to DM3.175 - the highest that sterling has traded against the German currency for more than a decade.

Traders are convinced that further interest rate rises are in the pipeline. "Sterling has been enjoying a bullish environment following today's labour report," Audrey Childe-Freeman at CIBC said.

Some analysts believe there is nothing to stop the pound rising further, to perhaps as high as DM3.20 or 3.25.

Sterling was also strong against other major currencies, ending the day at a fifteen-year high against a basket of the currencies of Britain's major trading partners.

The single currency was also in trouble against the dollar, hovering close to parity at $1.0115.

Hans Eichel, the German finance minister, attempted to put a brave face on the euro's woes, blaming US economic strength for the currency's decline.

"The foreign value simply reflects the differing economic developments in the euro and dollar areas," he said.

webTitle: Oil rig plan may help environment

fields.headline: Oil rig plan may help environment
fields.trailText: A plan to divert £1bn from the coffers of oil companies to an environment fund will be put to the UK Offshore Operators Association at a conference today.
fields.body:
A plan to divert £1bn from the coffers of oil companies to an environment fund will be put to the UK Offshore Operators Association at a conference today.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, has already expressed an interest in the scheme which is the brainchild of environmentalist David Bellamy and Pete Wilkinson, a former director of Greenpeace.

The oil industry is now committed to moving 250 old gas and oil rigs from the North Sea to land for disposal at a cost of around £20bn.

Mr Bellamy and Mr Wilkinson think leaving the bases where they are or towing them all to one area to act as a haven for fish is a better idea than lifting them to land.

This "elephants graveyard" for old rigs could be marked on charts to avoid it becoming a hazard to shipping.

The idea is to divert the money saved in not bringing the legs to land into a super-fund for the environment. This fund would be the largest sum of money ever devoted to environmental improvement.

The plan is controversial because the government's policy now is to dispose of all old rigs on land.

Following the row over plans to dump the Brent Spar oil storage platform at sea the North Sea Conference of 16 European nations decided two years ago that all oil platforms could not be dumped at sea, a decision Mr Wilkinson said was political rather than based on environmental concerns.

Tim Watson, chairman of the Recommissioning Partnership, a company which wants to refurbish and re-use old oil platforms, endorsed the idea. "As far as I can see everyone would gain," he said.

"The carrot for the oil companies would be that the super-fund would get slightly less cash than they would otherwise have had to spend on getting rid of the legs of the rig, but the environment would gain a huge sum to spend on projects that would otherwise not be funded."

fields.headline: Telecoms takeover: quick review planned
fields.trailText: Beginning its review of Vodaphone AirTouch's hostile takeover bid for Mannesman, the European Commission yesterday said the only clear overlap would be in Britain, where the Vodafone and Orange networks would end up in the same hands.
fields.body:
Beginning its review of Vodaphone AirTouch's hostile takeover bid for Mannesman, the European Commission yesterday said the only clear overlap would be in Britain, where the Vodafone and Orange networks would end up in the same hands.

The commission said that it hoped to rule on the bid by February 17, 10 days after the closing date for acceptances of the offer.

The statement appeared to deflate one of Mannesmann's key defence arguments, that a long regulatory inquiry would put the company in "the deep freeze", although if the commission feels the merger is raising serious concerns, it will launch a full investigation which would take another four months.

In an unusual step, the commission issued a statement to clarify its position, signifying that it has become as irritated by the contradictory statements from both companies as many in the investment community.

The commission, the EU's antitrust watchdog, said the clarifications were necessary because "statements made by Vodafone AirTouch and Mannesmann to the public appear to differ in a material respect".

Speculation that Mannesmann may try to hatch a deal with French media and telecoms group Vivendi to see Vodafone off continued, but a spokesman for Mannesman said nothing was imminent.

webTitle: BASF moves drugs HQ to London

fields.headline: BASF moves drugs HQ to London
fields.trailText: German chemical company BASF yesterday announced that it is restructuring its pharmaceuticals organisation, including moving the headquarters from its base in Ludwigshafen to London.
fields.body:
German chemical company BASF yesterday announced that it is restructuring its pharmaceuticals organisation, including moving the headquarters from its base in Ludwigshafen to London.

Though BASF insists that it is keeping all options for the future of the pharmaceuticals business open, the move will inevitably renew speculation that it might be prepared to exchange its drugs operations for acquisitions in other areas.

In the wake of the Astra-Zeneca merger, for example, there were suggestions BASF may have been prepared to swap the pharmaceuticals business for Novartis's crop protection interests.

Explaining the decision to switch the location of the headquarters of the drugs business a BASF spokesman said that about 90% of its pharmaceutical sales were now outside Germany from about 50% at the beginning of the 1990s.

"We chose London because we wanted to demonstrate the global nature of our business and the balance among the regions where we are active," he said.

"London has a tremendous talent pool for the pharmaceutical industry as well as being an important financial centre."

The spokesman acknowledged that BASF had been under pressure to make a move in the drugs sector but said that nothing should be read into the announcement of the reorganisation. "All our options are still open," he said.

Though BASF's drugs business - which had sales of €2.3bn (£1.42bn) in 1998 - is small compared with some of the drugs companies being created by recent mergers the spokesman insisted that it is focused, concentrating on producing products for the treatment of obesity, cardio-vascular problems and in pain therapy.

The drugs business employs about 13,000 worldwide - including 550 at its Nottingham research and marketing facility - and represents a little under 10% of total sales. In recent years BASF has not put as much emphasis on its pharmaceuticals business as its German peers. Hoechst has sold its chemical businesses and merged its life science operation with those of Rhone-Poulenc, while Bayer now regards itself as a chemicals and healthcare company. BASF by contrast remains keen to be seen as a chemicals business.

Yesterday's move is a response to the dramatic rationalisation of the pharma industry through deals like the Glaxo Wellcome-SmithKline Beecham merger and the takeover battle for Warner Lambert in the United States.

"Against the background of large and dynamic changes in the international pharmaceutical industry, BASF Pharma can now act faster and with more flexibility," the company said in a statement.

The new structure will be phased in over the next six months, with the new global management committee moving to London at the beginning of July.

webTitle: Late news: Reuters still looks pretty good

fields.headline: Late news: Reuters still looks pretty good
fields.standfirst: Shares reflect true picture
fields.trailText: On Tuesday at the editorial offices of Reuters in New York about 90 editorial staff threw an "organised sick-out," protesting at the snail's pace of contract negotiations between the company and their union, the New York Newspaper Guild.
fields.body:
On Tuesday at the editorial offices of Reuters in New York about 90 editorial staff threw an "organised sick-out," protesting at the snail's pace of contract negotiations between the company and their union, the New York Newspaper Guild.

The matter was swept aside as a little local difficulty and a team of non-unionised staff and editorial managers continued to pump out the news during the dispute. The product did not suffer.

Back in London, it is tempting to speculate that Peter Job, who has now notched up a decade in the chief executive's seat at Reuters, probably fancies throwing a quick sickie of his own.

Hardly a day goes by without a story appearing somewhere about how this information organisation is struggling to get a handle on how it should adapt to the internet age. Stories on spin-offs - whether the portfolio of start-up investments or the Instinet equity broking division - are re-cooked and re-syndicated, and all the while there is an unending stream of rumours about staff defections, low morale and the like.

All this has been fuelled by "real" events, such as this week's sudden and unexplained departure of information division chief John Parcell, who is leaving Reuters after 30 years with the firm. He was the internal favourite to take over when Mr Job retires, scheduled for summer next year. A news organisation should know that the suppression of facts simply cranks up a story, and the upshot now in the City is that when analysts are asked to put a price on Reuters stock, they routinely talk in terms of break-up values.

Yet this picture of corporate uncertainty fuelling internal crisis is not quite reflected in the performance of the share price. Mr Job himself stepped into the market back in October, spending £50,000 of his own money on shares then priced at 465p apiece. Three months on, he has doubled his money.

Some of this performance can be put down to takeover speculation, and we have already had the predictable snap on Reuters setting up a "bid defence committee" - which must be just about obligatory for all Footsie companies in the current climate.

There is a belief in certain high offices at 85 Fleet Street that some of the recent editorial coverage of its affairs is perhaps slightly tainted (paranoia is just another symptom of the smudging of lines of competition).

But it is fair to say that in recent coverage of this company's affairs there have been precious few attempts to explain just how powerful Reuters is when it comes to collecting and disseminating news and financial data. As a brand it carries an aura of "trust" which is unmatched by any of its competitors. In any newsroom, if Reuters spells a name one way and, say, Bloomberg another, the former will be printed. This is one piece of "old media" which is being substantially undervalued.

Twisted tips

It's a tricky business, tipping stocks. And in current market conditions, following the wrong tipster can prove very painful for investors - as quite a few readers of the Daily Mirror discovered yesterday.

On Tuesday, the newspaper's City Slickers column, aimed at Britain's growing hordes of amateur punters, brought us news that Alan Sugar's Viglen Technology was getting its internet act together and the shares subsequently doubled in price as the story proved correct.

So, yesterday's Mirror brought its readers another couple of business exclusives: Dixons boss Sir Stanley Kalms was reported to be lining up a bid for Electronics Boutiques, a little chain of computer games shops, while David Lloyd's MV Sport had apparently "won the contract to design, construct and have total control of" a new website for the current school playground cult game Pokemon. A Dixons spokesman had to be wheeled out to deny the Electronics Boutique story, while MV Sports chose to issue a formal statement. Never mind that there are thousands of Pokemon sites on the web, MV has not got a contract to design and build a new one. All that has happened is that it has applied for one of the licenses to make Pokemon branded products.

These might be shrugged off as a couple of loose shots - except that real people are getting hit. With so many inexperienced investors now following such wayward stock market tips, a huge transfer of wealth is under way - from the public to a small group of City professionals who have traditionally controlled trading in small and illiquid shares.

It is worth noting the Mirror first tipped Electronics Boutique when shares were close to 100p. Yesterday, the price spiked to 37p in the morning before falling back to 32p. MV Sports is a so-called "penny stock," quoted at 3p and of interest only to hardened market gamblers. As for Viglen, the £125m Mr Sugar (a Mirror columnist) made on Tuesday as the shares surged had shrunk by £10m by the close yesterday.

webTitle: Crusoe takes a bite out of Arm

fields.headline: Crusoe takes a bite out of Arm
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: One of the newest boys on the hi-tech block, microprocessor maker Arm, took a battering yesterday from a rival yet to produce a single chip. Arm fell more than 6% on the scantiest of details about the new Crusoe chip from Linus Torvalds, the man who dreamt up the Linux operating system while a student in Finland. Arm closed yesterday at £32.75.
fields.body:
One of the newest boys on the hi-tech block, microprocessor maker Arm, took a battering yesterday from a rival yet to produce a single chip. Arm fell more than 6% on the scantiest of details about the new Crusoe chip from Linus Torvalds, the man who dreamt up the Linux operating system while a student in Finland. Arm closed yesterday at £32.75.

The microprocessor, planned to be at the heart of the wireless world, is to be developed by Transmeta, a Silicon Valley start-up which has excited analysts despite its secretiveness. Before yesterday's launch, its website posted a tempting message about its new product. "Crusoe will be cool hardware and software for mobile applications. Crusoe will be unconventional."

After the London market closed Transmeta announced that Crusoe would be built by IBM and that a laptop computer would be available by mid-2000. The technology will enable "code morphing" - long seen as the holy grail of the computer world - so software written for the iMac could be used on a Crusoe-chipped machine. Transmeta claims its chip runs at 700 MHz - faster than any on the market.

The involvement of Torvalds alone was likely to attract significant interest in the fledgling company. Linux-based operations were huge successes on Wall Street last year as investors bet on a software rival to the mighty Microsoft. A feature of the code is that it is also freely developed and available on the internet. Transmeta has attracted other big name backers as well as Torvalds. These include Paul Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft and one of the world's richest men.

Crusoe could become one of the biggest challenges to Microsoft. Crusoe mobile devices will be able to run Windows or any other applications such as Java. Under a strategy designed to diversify away from personal computers, Microsoft is keen to expand in the market for mobile appliances.

The new company's most direct competition is likely to come from US semiconductor company Intel, whose shares fell almost $1 to $101 at midday in New York yesterday.

But Andrew Griffin, the Merrill Lynch analyst who is a strong buyer of ARM, downplayed the impact of the new competition. There was speculation that Transmeta would compete in the embedded chips sector. "My best guess is that this is not a threat."

webTitle: Sits vac: IMF seeks to fill leading role in world finance

fields.headline: Sits vac: IMF seeks to fill leading role in world finance
fields.standfirst: Infighting begins, though there is only one candidate
fields.trailText: Wanted: man or woman to fill the most powerful job in global finance - managing director of the International Monetary Fund. As finance ministers and central bankers from the G7 industrial nations gather in Tokyo tomorrow, they could be forgiven for expecting a bewildering array of top-flight talent to choose from.
fields.body:
Wanted: man or woman to fill the most powerful job in global finance - managing director of the International Monetary Fund. As finance ministers and central bankers from the G7 industrial nations gather in Tokyo tomorrow, they could be forgiven for expecting a bewildering array of top-flight talent to choose from.

Instead, there is just one declared candidate, a German official, Caio Koch-Weser, who is not even a household name in his own country, and whose qualifications for the job appear to be that he is a European and a Washington insider. He spent 26 years at the World Bank, the IMF's sister institution, latterly as its managing director, before becoming Germany's deputy finance minister last April.

Apart from the Germans, none of the other members of the G7 are especially keen on Mr Koch-Weser and behind the scenes any number of rival candidates are jockeying for position in the struggle to succeed Michel Camdessus, who steps down on February 16 after 13 years at the helm.

The political infighting and diplomatic intrigue surrounding the IMF post is threatening to become yet another embarrassing episode to rival the search for a new boss of the world trade organisation, which paralysed the organisation for several crucial months in the run-up to last month's fiasco in Seattle.

In theory such jobs ought to go to the best candidate, but theory counts for little when it comes to dividing up the spoils from international bureaucracy. Instead, it is all too often a case of Buggin's turn, with discussions soured by the worst form of petty nationalism.

In the case of the IMF, it has always been accepted that the managing-director's job is filled by a European, to counter-balance America's dominance of the World Bank. Mr Camdessus is a Frenchman, Britain has got Nato and the Bank for International Settlements, a Dutchman has the presidency of the European Central Bank, Italy has the presidency of the European Commission, but the Germans have nothing and feel that it is time their position as the world's third largest economy should be given due recognition.

The past few weeks have been marked by an unseemly round of leak and counter-leak, with the impression given that the final outcome will be a stitch-up between the G7 rather than a generally open contest that takes into account the views and interests of all IMF member governments rich and poor.

Sources said this week it was unlikely that a final decision would be made in Tokyo this weekend. Germany is still insisting that their man is the right man for the job, despite obvious American and French misgivings. Last Friday, the German chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, stepped up his lobbying efforts by sending letters to about 40 heads of state appealing for support.

But there have been rumours this week that the French will refuse to give him their support unless they get a copper-bottomed guarantee from the Germans that they will ensure Wim Duisenberg steps down after four years to make way for the Bank of France governor, Jean-Claude Trichet, as president of the ECB.

Paris has been quietly floating the names of Laurent Fabius, a former French prime minister, and Michel Sapin, a former French finance minister, as possible candidates. Both are better known than Mr Koch-Weser, and might garner support from the United States.

Mr Fabius was not impressed yesterday. "I've read various hypotheses here and there about potential roles for me at municipal, national, European or even world level and, flattering as they may be, that poses a problem," he said. "

I'm honoured but with all my thanks to the authors of these scenarios, I'm afraid they'll be disappointed."

Britain has maintained a diplomatic silence on the subject. Waiting in the wings is Andrew Crockett, currently running the BIS in Basle.

There are rumours that chancellor Gordon Brown might be interested - something that his advisers deny. One of the two Italians apparently vying for the job - the treasury minister Giuliano Amato or his department's top civil servant Mario Draghi - may emerge as the surprise victor, although neither has any publicly declared support.

The need for a candidate with real stature to run the IMF has never been greater. The organisation came under severe attack for its handling of the global financial crisis which began in Thailand in 1997, dispensing traditional remedies of fiscal and monetary tightening even when it was clear that the root cause of the problem lay in the inherent instability of the global capital markets.

It later backed down from its hard-line stance, but its credibility suffered and the job of the new managing director is to redefine the role of the 56-year-old institution for the new century. In particular, there is a need to design and manage a financial system to cope with vastly increased private-sector capital flows, which have the power to destabilise even well-run economies.

The US treasury secretary, Larry Summers, wants the IMF to be a lean and mean organisation, operating a sophisticated surveillance system for the global economy and stepping in to fire fight when crises erupt.

But while the top job remains vacant, the IMF's ambition, and Mr Summer's, will remain unfulfilled.

fields.headline: Zetters
fields.trailText: A battle may be looming over Zetters, the football pools group. Yesterday, the group announced that it had received an approach which could lead to an offer of 135p a share.
fields.body:
A battle may be looming over Zetters, the football pools group. Yesterday, the group announced that it had received an approach which could lead to an offer of 135p a share. But with the shares rattling up more than 17% in value to around 150p, it appears the City is pondering whether yesterday's mystery suitor has an clear field.

Zetters has been sturdily independent for most of its 65-year history but, like its fellow pools operators, has been under pressure since the advent of the national lottery. That prompted a return in 1996 to the bingo business, which it had quit in 1988 when it sold its existing chain to Bass.

Zetters, with the founding family still heavily represented on the share register, has effectively been in the shop window since January 1998, when it emerged it was involved in takeover talks. They came to nothing and that summer the group said it planned to split the pools and bingo businesses and sell the two parts separately.

Last year the bingo halls were sold to Riva for about £8m, clearing the way, belatedly, for the final chapter.

But that could yet prove the most exciting. Though Zetters' only comment yesterday was that it would make a further announcement "as and when appropriate", there were suggestions last night of a consortium being put together to launch a counter move.

The pools business might not look the most attractive bit of the leisure sector these days, but it is not the group's only asset. It also has its headquarters in Clerkenwell in London, as well as its stock market listing.

webTitle: Wise money is on the euro

fields.headline: Wise money is on the euro
fields.trailText: I have never doubted that Britain's inward investment will be at risk if we do not join the single currency. But every time I have said it, I have been accused of scaremongering.
fields.body:
I have never doubted that Britain's inward investment will be at risk if we do not join the single currency. But every time I have said it, I have been accused of scaremongering.

Now we cannot deny that it is true. Tuesday's Guardian revealed that Toyota's commitment to Britain might waver if we do not join. That involves more than 3,000 jobs, more than £1.5bn in investment funds, and new jobs for the future.

It comes as no great surprise. I have talked to leading investors, and their message is clear: unless we join, they cannot guarantee future investment. It is no empty threat. They are concerned; and so am I.

I know Toyota's Derby plant. Most workers there are AEEU members. And I know how hard they work, both shopfloor and management. They have built an efficient and productive plant that is a benchmark for success. I am proud to be part of that achievement.

Toyota and others want us to be at the centre of Europe, and that means joining the euro. They want to export their cars to the continent. But because our exchange rate goes up and down, their profits are slashed.

That is why they want us to join. After all, multinationals can move production almost by a flick of a switch. Business wants to ensure it gets the best return on its investment, and that means reducing margins and eliminating unnecessary risk. That is why we should worry if we remain out for too long.

The scale of inward investment is huge. Britain has done well, better than the rest of Europe. We get the lion's share. With our high skills, flexibility and international language, we are a magnet for new money. But most important of all, we are a bridge into Europe. The UK is a launchpad for new markets in Europe.

And that investment brings jobs. Companies like Toyota, Nissan, LG and others have created over 1,000,000 jobs. And they are good jobs too. Just the jobs we want to create - not put at risk.

But at risk they will be if we do not join. Investors are already making long-term decisions, and they want to know what the UK will do. They are looking ahead, not just one or two years, but five or ten. The indecision surrounding our future means we may lose out.

That is why I am in no doubt at all that we should join. Of course, the economics must be right, we do not want to repeat the mistakes of the past. We must join on the best terms for us, but that is no excuse for delaying a decision.

After all, what happens in Europe will affect us whether we like it or not. We are part of the single market, and the euro will affect how that market works, including investment and jobs.

I am sick and tired of the childish way in which we debate the issue. Some want to return to the days of tariffs and trade wars, ignoring the effects of globalisation. Has the global market passed them by? Do they not understand that technology and global pressures have allowed business to bypass national boundaries? It is as if the last 50 years never happened.

And they ignore the good reasons for joining. The boost to trade could be huge. A US study says this week that it could be even bigger than we first thought. The benefits of a single - and stable - common currency will help companies trade more than ever.

That is just the start. Lower interest rates will make investment much cheaper and will relieve the pressure on exporters. We all know they that they have suffered over the past few years. Joining the single currency will give them the stability to plan ahead. An end to exchange rates going up and down, transparent prices - all help industry grow and expand.

It is up to us. Do we want to play a full part in Europe, recognise that the world has moved on and accept that our economies are integrating whether we like it or not? Or will we ignore the threat to jobs, fall further behind our competitors and behave like some giant fortress off the mainland of Europe?

One thing is for sure. We will never decide while the debate about this nation's future is conducted as if we never left the playground. We should listen to investors like Toyota and understand the concerns they have. They are not making empty threats.

Sir Ken Jackson is general secretary the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union

They are looking ahead, not just one or two years, but five or ten. The indecision surrounding our future means we may lose out. That is why I am in no doubt at all that we should join. Of course, the economics must be right, we do not want to repeat the mistakes of the past. We must join on the best terms for us, but that is no excuse for delaying a decision. After all, what happens in Europe will affect us whether we like it or not. We are part of the single market, and the euro will affect how that market works, including investment and jobs. I am sick and tired of the childish way in which we debate the issue. Some want to return to the days of tariffs and trade wars, ignoring the effects of globalisation. Has the global market passed them by? Do they not understand that technology and global pressures have allowed business to bypass national boundaries? It is as if the last 50 years never happened. And they ignore the good reasons for joining. The boost to trade could be huge. A US study says this week that it could be even bigger than we first thought. The benefits of a single - and stable - common currency will help companies trade more than ever. That is just the start. Lower interest rates will make investment much cheaper and will relieve the pressure on exporters. We all know they that they have suffered over the past few years. Joining the single currency will give them the stability to plan ahead. An end to exchange rates going up and down, transparent prices - all help industry grow and expand. It is up to us. Do we want to play a full part in Europe, recognise that the world has moved on and accept that our economies are integrating whether we like it or not? Or will we ignore the threat to jobs, fall further behind our competitors and behave like some giant fortress off the mainland of Europe? One thing is for sure. We will never decide while the debate about this nation's future is conducted as if we never left the playground. We should listen to investors like Toyota and understand the concerns they have. They are not making empty threats. Sir Ken Jackson is general secretary the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Leading shares finished lower for a second consecutive session, weighed down by another lacklustre performance from the financial sector and amid further weakness on Wall Street.
fields.body:
Leading shares finished lower for a second consecutive session, weighed down by another lacklustre performance from the financial sector and amid further weakness on Wall Street.

With a strong UK employment report seen as virtually guaranteeing a rate rise at next week's meeting of the monetary policy committee, the FTSE 100 closed the session 59.2 points lower at 6,445.4, taking its losses for the last two sessions to well over 200 points. It was a similar story among the second liners, with the FTSE Mid 250 index off 71.9 points at 6,495.5.

The banking sector was notably weak, accounting for more than 30 points off the premier index. Dealers blamed the threat of higher bond yields as HSBC fell 21p to 724p, with the shares also unsettled by the 513-point drop on the Hang Seng index in Hong Kong overnight. Royal Bank of Scotland was close behind, sliding 62p to 960p, as the slanging match with NatWest (off 58p at £10.74) and Bank of Scotland (26p weaker at 594p). Elsewhere in the sector, Abbey National surrendered 7p to 763p, while Alliance & Leicester fell back 22p to 569p and Barclays dipped 38p to settle at £13.91.

Investment group Schroders was also among the prominent fallers, sliding 78p to £12.36 as a wave of profit taking hit the stock in the wake of Tuesdays news that Citigroup was taking over its investment banking arm.

Several brokers issued negative research recommendations on the stock, with Merrill Lynch leading the way, cutting its stance to "neutral" from "accumulate". It is worried about valuing the fund-management rump of the business.

The insurance sector was also under pressure on interest rate concerns. CGU gave up 41p 806p, Norwich Union fell 20p to 407p, while life assurer Legal & General lost 7p to 144. But Prudential managed to buck the weaker trend, gaining 83p to £11.03 in the wake of Tues day's spectacular new business figures.

But basic material stocks put in the best performance of the day. BP and Shell ended higher, up 6p at 562p and 5p at 490p, respectively, as the crude price flirted with a nine-year high.

Meanwhile, mining stocks Billiton , up 12p at 340p, and Rio Tinto , 5p better at £13.28, continued to push ahead in the wake of rising commodity prices.

Lower down the corporate scale, BTP was caught in a while of speculation suggesting bid talks are back on with Switzerland's Clariant. The shares sprinted 41p to 389p.

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Mani, musician
fields.trailText: Mani, musician
fields.body:
With the new Primal Scream album coming out, we're doing loads of press, which I suppose comes with the territory. It's much better to do it before the album's released, rather than when we're on tour - there's nothing worse than touring and having to sit gabbing to people all day. But obviously these magazines have to have something in them to shift copies. It's a necessary evil.

Everyone seems to really like the new LP. I only joined in time to play on two tracks on the last one, Vanishing Point, so really I'm popping my cherry here. There's a lot of collaborations on this one - Bernard from New Order and Kevin Shields from My Bloody Valentine both turn up - which keeps it fresh and interesting for the rest of us.

The only bad experiences we've had press-wise have been with Steve Sutherland at the NME, who accused us of being musical cowards; personally I think we should set out a new mandate to leather any journalist who has the audacity to tamper with our livelihood. We don't mind criticism, but he just wanted to focus on how off their tits Primal Scream were getting and whether we were goose-stepping Nazis because our single was called Swastika Eyes (which, unless you're a thick bastard who works for the NME, is pretty obviously an anti-Nazi song).

After the press is done, we'll be out touring. We only do it in short bursts so we don't end up faking it, plus it's a lot looser now - when you play live it's up to you what you want to do. The only rule is there are no rules. Which is a lot better than carrying a hod full of bricks up a ladder.

Primal Scream's new LP Exterminator is out on 31 January

webTitle: Letter from Joe Ashton MP to Dave Richards, chairman of Sheffield Wednesday

fields.headline: Letter from Joe Ashton MP to Dave Richards, chairman of Sheffield Wednesday
fields.trailText: Dear chairman,
fields.body:
Dear chairman,

I am writing this letter to give you and the other Wednesday shareholders a clearer picture of what the four Sheffield MPs discussed with Charterhouse Bank last Thursday, and the questions we raised.

The meeting lasted one hour. Our discussion about the performance of the team and whether the manager could keep it in the Premier League lasted one minute, which received enormous media coverage. Consequently the other major issues of this meeting have still to be aired.

We put it to the bank that there was serious concern as to where the debts of £16/18 million (which the club have never denied) had come from.

Less than three years ago the bank put £15million into Sheffield Wednesday. Since then the club has received another £50million or so in turnover. So how has this huge debt occurred?

You will remember that in 1995 the board decided to spend £8million on building 20 new hospitality boxes for sponsors' lunches etc, three large restaurants, together with new catering facilities for the Euro Championships.

Those of us on the board who had doubts were assured that the scheme would be totally self-financing with the income from the box sponsors producing the cash to repay a long-term mortgage loan, and that no money whatsoever would be taken from the team resources or from the other parts of the stadium.

Now it would appear that this business plan debt has been lumped together with the other debts for transfer fees and wages, and the interest is in fact being paid by fans on the Kop and from the cash available for the team.

Charterhouse admitted to us that if the club were to be sold then all the debts would be lumped together. These debts would of course be a serious deterrent to any prospective purchaser.

It might then be thought that if Sheffield Wednesday were to be downsized from a business with a £23million turnover with £18million debts in the Premier League to a First Division club of £9million with no debts it would be much easier to sell the club and regain some of the investment.

It therefore seems to the MPs that if this is the business plan of the board the shareholders and the fans are entitled to know. We would remind you personally and the other plc directors that you do not own the club.

The directors of Wednesday own less than 10% of it and as such are simply elected trustees. If this business plan is being adopted then it is in the public interest for MPs to ask questions.

The clear impression we gained from the bank was that it now anticipates relegation and naturally regard it as their duty to protect their assets.

Can I now raise the matter of your own personal position. Last May at Nottingham Forest when you told me you were going to run for the position of chairman of the Premier League and deputy chairman of the FA I reminded you of the old political advice that it is not possible to ride two horses with one arse in a three-ring circus.

Nevertheless, you are now chairman of the Premier League and sitting on the top committees of the FA which demands a great deal of time and a large part of the week in London, which in my opinion means that Sheffield Wednesday duties cannot have your undivided attention.

Can you now tell the shareholders whether it is your intention to apply for a top paid job as the full-time neutral chairman of the Premier League in April? And where would that leave Sheffield Wednesday? What is the point of you spending weeks this spring negotiating massive BSkyB deals for the Premier League when we may not be in it?

You will also remember that after the team's dismal display against Bristol City in the (FA) Cup on December 11, you specifically told me you wanted to stand down from the chairman's job.

You will also remember the heated discussion we had at Stamford Bridge on December 29, where you said the club debt was only £6.5million.

Quite frankly Mr Richards, this is not the way to run Sheffield Wednesday, and I am not surprised that our beloved team is stranded at the foot of the table.

Therefore I suggest to you that you should now answer these very relevant questions which the MPs put to the bank and seriously consider your position as chairman of the club.

Yours sincerely

Joe Ashton MP

webTitle: Ashton turns ire on the chairman

fields.headline: Ashton turns ire on the chairman
fields.standfirst: Joe Ashton's letter to Sheffield Wednesday's chairman
fields.trailText: Sheffield Wednesday's chairman Dave Richards came under renewed pressure yesterday when Joe Ashton claimed that some members of the club's hierarchy would welcome relegation from the Premiership in order to make the Wednesday more attractive to potential buyers.
fields.body:
Sheffield Wednesday's chairman Dave Richards came under renewed pressure yesterday when Joe Ashton claimed that some members of the club's hierarchy would welcome relegation from the Premiership in order to make the Wednesday more attractive to potential buyers.

Ashton's campaign to open up the club's finances to public scrutiny and rid the Premiership's last-placed team of chairman and manager took on a more vitriolic note yesterday morning with the publication of an open letter to Richards.

Ashton, one of four Sheffield MPs who last week demanded the immediate dismissal of the Wednesday manager Danny Wilson, then reacted with scorn to Richards's response.

In his letter Ashton demands answers to a number of questions concerning Wednesday's financial state and Richards's ability to combine the roles of chairman at Hillsborough and chairman of the Premier League.

League and FA business, Ashton wrote, demanded "a great deal of time and a large part of the week in London which, in my opinion, means that Sheffield Wednesday duties cannot have your undivided attention". It was not possible, he pointed out, "to ride two horses with one arse".

Ashton reiterated his claim of last week that Wednesday have debts of between £16m and £18m, which Richards yesterday vehemently denied.

"We put it to the [Charterhouse] bank that there was serious concern as to where the debts had come from," wrote Ashton. "Less than three years ago the bank put £15m into Sheffield Wednesday. Since then the club has received another £50 million or so in turnover - so how has this huge debt occurred?"

Richards countered by insisting that his club's debt was less than £12m and that Wednesday's bankers were "very comfortable with us".

"The bank trusts the board of this club," he said. "We have a facility for a £5.5m overdraft and we live within that facility.

"On top of that we built a new main stand three or four years ago and we have £6m outstanding on that. So the debt is less than £12m - and in Premier League terms that is nothing."

Ashton also claimed that it might suit some individuals if Wednesday were to be relegated this season. "These debts would, of course, be a serious deterrent to any prospective purchaser," wrote Ashton. "It might then be thought that, if Wednesday were to be downsized from a business with a £23m turnover and debts of £18m in the Premier League into a First Division club of £9m with no debts, it would be much easier to sell the club and regain some of the investment."

The allegation was described as "total nonsense" by the Wednesday director Howard Culley. "It beggars belief that anyone could even suggest we would be happy to be relegated," he said. "This is a public company with published accounts and there is nothing here that is not within the public knowledge."

Ashton was unhappy with Richards's response. "He hasn't answered any of my questions, with the exception of whether they are looking to be relegated. I've asked at least 10 questions in my letter and he's only responded to one. It's a disgrace and a joke."

The MP rejected Wednesday's offer of a private meeting. "The only way I will sit down and talk to him is if it is in front of the media," Ashton said. "It's about time he had a press conference because all he is doing is hiding behind public relations statements."

Richards announced that Wilson would remain as manager even if Wednesday were to be relegated. "He's not going and I'm not going," he said. "He has got more than two years left on his contract and he will see it out.

"The fans believe in Danny Wilson .What's happening at the moment is that they are shouting for me to go, not him."

Richards conceded that his club's plight was causing him sleepless nights. "I've had abuse hurled at me in the streets of Sheffield and that hurts," he said. "I have always said that, if there is someone out there who loves this club as much as I do, who cherishes it as I do, who will work [as hard] as I do, who will work 365 days a year - unpaid - as I do, then they can come here and do this job."

fields.headline: Arphexad spikes Gunners
fields.trailText: Leicester City continue to win their cup ties in the defiant spirit of a Rocky movie. Last week they reached the last four of the Worthington Cup on penalties after facing defeat by Fulham and last night they removed Arsenal from the FA Cup in similar fashion when at one point only the goalkeeping of Tim Flowers had stood between Arsène Wenger's side and victory.
fields.body:
Leicester City continue to win their cup ties in the defiant spirit of a Rocky movie. Last week they reached the last four of the Worthington Cup on penalties after facing defeat by Fulham and last night they removed Arsenal from the FA Cup in similar fashion when at one point only the goalkeeping of Tim Flowers had stood between Arsène Wenger's side and victory.

This time, to add even more melodrama to the occasion, the crucial saves in the shoot-out were made by Pegguy Arphexad, who had replaced Flowers, suffering from a recurrence of a knee injury, halfway through extra-time. The French Under-21 goalkeeper, born in Guadeloupe, blocked a penalty from Lee Dixon as four sure shots sent David Seaman the wrong way.

Then Seaman kept out one from Stefan Oakes as the shoot-out began to echo the protracted stalemate of the match itself. But with Leicester leading 6-5 Arphexad, signed from Lens on a free transfer, guessed right to thwart Gilles Grimandi and for the second time this season Arsenal had gone out of a cup on penalties, Middlesbrough having beaten them in the Worthington Cup in a shoot-out at the Riverside Stadium.

Leicester had never previously beaten Arsenal in the FA Cup and for much of last night's replay it did not seem that they were about to buck the trend. After a sluggish start Wenger's side gradually got their game together and dominated much of the second half.

But for Flowers Arsenal would now be savouring the prospect of a fifth-round tie at Chelsea. He was by far the busier of the two England goalkeepers, his performance reaching its zenith towards the end of normal time.

A beautifully struck volley from Martin Keown was turned round a post by an instinctive dive to the goalkeeper's right. Then a close-range shot from Davor Suker was tipped over the bar.

Flowers's most extraordinary saves came in the 83rd minute when he blocked a header from Patrick Vieira before keeping out the Frenchman's attempt to score from the rebound. Even then the ball fell to Suker whose shot beat Flowers but was headed off the line by Robbie Savage.

At that point one felt that, against considerable odds, Leicester would somehow get through again. Having had the defensive organisation and all-round commitment to force a scoreless draw at Highbury in the first game they were always going to make it difficult for Arsenal in the replay.

Last night Arsenal were again lacking Tony Adams in defence and Dennis Bergkamp, Marc Overmars and Nwankwo Kanu in attack. But the strength of their squad remained considerably deeper than that of Leicester, who were still missing Muzzy Izzet and Neil Lennon in midfield, Andrew Impey and Tony Cottee in attack and went into last night's match without Ian Marshall and Steve Walsh, their saviours against Fulham.

Martin O'Neill, the Leicester manager, is nothing if not an imaginative improviser. For the replay he employed Darren Eadie in space behind his strikers, Emile Heskey and Arnar Gunnlaugsson, and used Savage as a right wing-back.

Arsenal's football flowed only fitfully, yet Suker had ample opportunities both to win the replay for Arsenal and spare them the extra-time they did not need, with a renewal of hostilities against Manchester United only five days away. The Croatian might have put his side ahead soon after half-time when Ray Parlour's low centre reached him at the near post but he used his weaker right foot and shot wide.

In the 72nd minute a cross from Stephen Hughes, who had come on for Stefan Malz, reached Suker at the far post and he needed only to steady himself to score but he snatched at his shot and the ball flew over the bar.

Arsenal, like Manchester United, can now look forward to a run-in free of domestic cup ties. But they will have been annoyed to go out of the FA Cup in such a fashion.

Martin O'Neill, the Leicester manager, is nothing if not an imaginative improviser. For the replay he employed Darren Eadie in space behind his strikers, Emile Heskey and Arnar Gunnlaugsson, and used Savage as a right wing-back. Arsenal's football flowed only fitfully, yet Suker had ample opportunities both to win the replay for Arsenal and spare them the extra-time they did not need, with a renewal of hostilities against Manchester United only five days away. The Croatian might have put his side ahead soon after half-time when Ray Parlour's low centre reached him at the near post but he used his weaker right foot and shot wide. In the 72nd minute a cross from Stephen Hughes, who had come on for Stefan Malz, reached Suker at the far post and he needed only to steady himself to score but he snatched at his shot and the ball flew over the bar. Arsenal, like Manchester United, can now look forward to a run-in free of domestic cup ties. But they will have been annoyed to go out of the FA Cup in such a fashion.

webTitle: Dealers' cheap cars plan ends in junkyard

fields.headline: Dealers' cheap cars plan ends in junkyard
fields.standfirst: Trade body overrules members' EU imports scheme
fields.trailText: A revolt by franchised car dealers, disgusted at the prices charged by manufacturers, has been snuffed out by their trade body.
fields.body:
A revolt by franchised car dealers, disgusted at the prices charged by manufacturers, has been snuffed out by their trade body.

The National Franchised Dealers' Association has refused to back a scheme to import cheap cars from other European Union countries.

The scheme, put forward by 20 of the country's largest dealers, would have broken the manufacturers' grip on the way new cars are priced and sold.

That the dealers were, however, prepared to break ranks with the manufacturers changes the political landscape at a time when the gov ernment is keen to put an end to "rip-off Britain".

At the end of this month trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers is due to receive a report from the competition commission on the way cars are sold.

The car dealers' trade body is thought to have opposed the imports scheme because it feared retaliation by the manufacturers.

The car makers rejected such claims, saying that the scheme put forward by the dealers was perfectly legal. But they said it might have put small dealers out of business.

Under the franchise system, the dealers only have to pay the manufacturer for a vehicle after it has been sold. But if they were to buy from one of their counterparts on the continent, they would probably have to pay up front.

"Only cash rich dealers could afford to import cars in this way," said a spokesman for one of the large manufacturers. "They would be able to undercut the smaller firms."

The dealers believed their scheme got round restrictions in their franchise agreements because they would have been acting as agents for individual car buyers.

Under the proposed scheme, a car buyer would have asked for a particular model and specification, which the dealer would then obtain from an overseas dealer in return for a 5% commission.

By law, manufacturers have to provide any model to any franchised dealer in any community country. Failure to do so could lead to heavy fines.

Studies by the European commission have shown that British buyers could save thousands of pounds by sourcing their car from another EU country. Manufacturers, however, claim that the comparisons were done some months ago and that the gap has been closed considerably by exchange rate fluctuations.

Alan Pulham, franchised dealers director of the Retail Motor Industry Federation, said: "This illustrates the very serious situation that has developed in dealerships and the extremes to which some dealers will feel obliged to go to overcome their dwindling profits.

fields.headline: Bank of Scotland advisers accused
fields.standfirst: Takeover panel disputes CSFB poll findings at NatWest
fields.trailText: The takeover panel waded into the NatWest bid battle last night, reprimanding advisers to Bank of Scotland for dirty tactics.
fields.body:
The takeover panel waded into the NatWest bid battle last night, reprimanding advisers to Bank of Scotland for dirty tactics.

The takeover watchdog called on CSFB, BoS's financial advisers, to clarify its claims that just two out of some 60 big NatWest shareholders wanted the bank to remain independent.

Sir David Rowland, NatWest's chairman, insisted there was little to choose from between the bids by BoS and Royal Bank of Scotland: "Shareholders can roll the dice with either offer or benefit from the outstanding value and lower risk in a standalone NatWest."

BoS claims - which it later satisfied the takeover panel were legitimate and based on early soundings of investors - were made as the Edinburgh-based bank revealed it had sent 100 spies to 144 of its prey's branches, which it concluded need "major surgery".

BoS said it would open 125 new branches in areas where NatWest has gaps - the north east of England, the east coast and south Midlands - close 36 others, modernise 881 from the current "bandit screen" environment, modernise and relocate 523 and leave only 274 unchanged.

The alleged lack of support for NatWest independence coincided with mounting concerns that the job reduction programme initiated by NatWest in its defence against the bids were being conducted too hastily.

"NatWest may have damaged its revenue growth prospects by key staff cuts in recent weeks," said Martin Cross, banking analyst at Teather & Greenwood, one of the few brokers still to offer "independent" comment on the bid.

Ron Sandler, new chief operating officer at NatWest, admitted that 800 jobs had been cut from the bank's head office but disputed the anxiety.

Mr Sandler, engaged in a charm offensive of the bank's shareholders, who has a final chance to issue a defence on Monday, said he continued to argue the case for an independent NatWest.

He disputed the poll taken by CSFB for BoS. "How many of those 60 shareholders want BoS?" Mr Sandler said.

George Maddison at CSFB highlighted his informal poll to counter market concerns that NatWest might escape the two Scottish bids through a split vote of its investors.

"The mathematics of this and the reality are quite far apart," he said. After an informal poll, two shareholders had backed NatWest while the rest inferred they were still to make a choice between the two bids.

The BoS offer now values NatWest at £22.6bn, more than the £21bn offered by Royal Bank, which is widely expected to call on the fire power of its Spanish partner, BSCH, to raise its offer at the end of the month. Peter Burt, the BoS chief executive, said yesterday that his bank had made a "full and fair offer".

"If Royal Bank were to offer more than we thought it was worth, we wouldn't chase it," he said, without indicating whether the BoS offer was final.

BoS said its branch restructuring, cross-selling and changes to NatWest's business banking would allow it to generate £518m in revenue growth - worth more than £300m in pretax profit - in three years.

In response, Sir George Mathewson, chief executive of the Royal Bank, said: "We have been pointing out for some time that NatWest has an excellent franchise but is underperforming on income."

fields.headline: Power and sacrifice
fields.standfirst:
Don Carlos
The Pit, Barbican, London
****
fields.trailText: Perhaps we should start a campaign - on the lines of those for real ale and organic vegetables - for theatrical theatre. If we did, then Schiller's Don Carlos, with its blend of power, politics, romantic passion and heroic self-sacrifice, would be an exemplar; and Gale Edwards's superb RSC production, on its transfer from Stratford to the Pit, shows how you can create epic grandeur even in an intimate setting.
fields.body:
Perhaps we should start a campaign - on the lines of those for real ale and organic vegetables - for theatrical theatre. If we did, then Schiller's Don Carlos, with its blend of power, politics, romantic passion and heroic self-sacrifice, would be an exemplar; and Gale Edwards's superb RSC production, on its transfer from Stratford to the Pit, shows how you can create epic grandeur even in an intimate setting.

On second viewing I was more conscious of Schiller's shift of interest during the play's long period of composition in the 1780s. In the first, superior half the focus is on the distrait Hamletesque figure of Don Carlos, who suffers a fatal passion for his stepmother and a furious relationship with his brutal father, Philip II. But, in the intrigue-packed second half, Schiller clearly becomes more fascinated by Philip's isolation and by the complex idealism of the Marquis of Posa, who yearns to free the Netherlands from the Spanish yoke. Posa sacrifices himself to save Don Carlos and the Low Countries; but, theatrically, Schiller sacrifices his titular hero to an exploration of the dynamics of power.

If this makes the play somewhat unwieldy, it also throws up a disturbingly ambivalent figure in the character of Posa. What Ray Fearon, in rimless specs and well-cut suit, brings out very well is the fanaticism lurking under Posa's idealism. In his protestations about freedom to Philip II, he is a passionate libertarian. But his manipulation of Carlos, by having him arrested and showing his letters to the king, suggests that he enjoys playing God. The parallel that Fearon brings to mind is the Duke in Measure for Measure, another figure who, in the name of justice, treats people like puppets.

Even if the play becomes over-labyrinthine, it yields tremendous scenes and fine gestural acting from a first-rate cast. John Woodvine has done nothing better than his Philip - a testy despot, flinching at his son's touch, but also one racked by guilt, insomnia and fears of his wife's adultery. As the character disintegrates, so Woodvine's performance grows ever stronger. Seizing on the endless Shakespearean references in Robert David MacDonald's sparky translation, Rupert Penry-Jones turns Don Carlos into a capricious Spanish Hamlet clearly more concerned by the expression of his passion for Josette Simon's fiery Elizabeth of Valois than the oppression of Flanders and Brabant. And by a nice irony the grand inquisitor, who finally appears to show where the real power lies, is played by John Rogan not as a majestic prelate but as someone small, wiry and sightless.

Each to his taste; but if you have an appetite for romantic tragedy, where private passions intersect with public politics, then Gale Edwards's beautifully designed and lit production is the real, right thing. In short, theatre at its most theatrical.

fields.headline: Advertising themselves for once
fields.standfirst:
The Wannadies
Dingwalls, London
***
fields.trailText:
The Wannadies
Dingwalls, London
***
fields.body:
The old adage says that a pop song is only truly popular once postmen are heard whistling it, but the approbation of bar staff isn't to be sniffed at either. Such is the extent to which the Wannadies' You and Me Song has permeated the national consciousness. As its lilting verses tease inevitably towards that turbo-powered refrain, Dingwalls' entire complement of pint-pullers are mouthing along, word-perfect. No more maddeningly addictive than many other Wannadies tunes, it helps that You and Me Song is currently unavoidable due to its presence on a shampoo commercial, following a star turn on the Romeo and Juliet film soundtrack.

The Wannadies may be an advertising executive's dream, but this year could finally see the Swedish quintet reap the benefits of such doughty product placement and sell some records. They are the perfect postmodern pop band: an attractive male/female sparring duo lead their super-competent appropriation of punk's melodic ethos, though they downplay the visceral extremes that might offend people. It helps that most of the crowd tonight are either too young or square (or both) to have heard of the bands the Wannadies so adeptly rip-off - primarily the Pixies.

Providing you're not expecting the reinvention of the wheel, none of this is a problem. Like the Dandy Warhols, the Wannadies have resynthesised new-wave pop for a new generation, but do so with a good deal more charm than their American contemporaries. Indeed, there are few bands who could get away with a song as gauche as Shorty, in which Par Wiksten bemoans the lot of a small man fatally attracted to tall women, or as blatant as Hit, which brings the friendly mosh-pit to the point of collapse. Of course, that could have been because the audience remember it from a certain debit card commercial last year.

fields.headline: Pieces of hate
fields.standfirst:
Snuffhouse Dustlouse
ICA, London
****
fields.trailText: Faulty Optic is one of British theatre's best-kept secrets, a company that more than lives up to its name with its automated sets, loopy animated figures and out-of-focus snapshots of a world that is permanently on the blink.
fields.body:
Faulty Optic is one of British theatre's best-kept secrets, a company that more than lives up to its name with its automated sets, loopy animated figures and out-of-focus snapshots of a world that is permanently on the blink.

Dating from 1991, but until now performed mostly abroad, this piece, featuring a puppet figure called Mabel who is half human and half sack and who has sad eyes that glitter like faraway stars, is as weird and unsettling as anything the company has produced. It appears to owe quite a lot to Philip Larkin ("They fuck you up your mum and dad" etc etc) and just as much to Dennis Nilsen. There is a terrible tenderness here in the way love kills.

Yet although the wind howls continually as if Mabel has become stranded in some emotional polar wasteland, there is a wicked and irresistible humour at work here too, both in the Heath Robinson-ish contraption that is Mabel's lifeline and in the absurdities of her existence. Insanity is never far away, and yet the great trick of the performance is that it convinces you of the logic of everything that Mabel does, however ridiculous and however appalling.

Music, a set that takes on a life of its own and Mabel's desperate, eloquent body language pile on the tension as her isolated, pitiful existence is interrupted by the arrival of an intruder who both threatens and offers a last grasp at freedom. What does it all signify? The horror of human contact and the excruciating pain of having none? The joy of finding your feet at last? I can't tell you, but I loved its sad, demented vision to bits, and bits - or at least body parts - is what it's all about.

Until January 20. Box office: 0171-930 3647. At the Lawrence Batley, Huddersfield, on January 28. Box office: 01484 430528
